1001.a.Problem Statement:
A man of weight $w$ is in an elevator of weight $w$. The elevator accelerates vertically up at a rate $a$ and at a certain instant has a speed $V$.

What is the apparent weight of the man?
1001.a.Solution:
The apparent weight of the man is

$$
F=w+\frac{w}{g} a=w\left(1+\frac{a}{g}\right),
$$

$g$ being the acceleration of gravity.

1001.b.Problem Statement:
A man of weight $w$ is in an elevator of weight $w$. The elevator accelerates vertically up at a rate $a$ and at a certain instant has a speed $V$.

The man climbs a vertical ladder within the elevator at a speed $v$ relative to the elevator. What is the man's rate of expenditure of energy (power output)?
1001.b.Solution:
The apparent weight of the man is

$$
F=w+\frac{w}{g} a=w\left(1+\frac{a}{g}\right),
$$

$g$ being the acceleration of gravity.The man's rate of expenditure of energy is

$$
F v_{t}=w\left(1+\frac{a}{g}\right)(V+v) .
$$

1003.Problem Statement: In an amusement park there is a rotating horizontal disk. A child can sit on it at any radius (Fig. 1.1). As the disk begins to "speed up", the child may slide off if the frictional force is insufficient. The mass of the child is $50 \mathrm{~kg}$ and the coefficient of friction is $0.4$. The angular velocity is $2 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s}$. What is the maximum radius $R$ where he can sit and still remain on the disk?
1003.Solution:
Under the critical circumstance that the child just starts to slide,

$$
m R \omega^{2}=\mu m g .
$$

Hence

$$
R=\frac{\mu g}{\omega^{2}}=\frac{0.4 \times 9.8}{2^{2}}=0.98 \mathrm{~m} .
$$

As the centrifugal force is proportional to the radius, this is the maximum radius for no-sliding.

1004.Solution:
Neglecting the moment of inertia of the pulley, we obtain the equations of motion

$$
m_{1} \ddot{x}=m_{1} g-F
$$

and

$$
m_{2} \ddot{x}=F-m_{2} g .
$$

Hence the tension of the cord and the acceleration are respectively

and

$$
F=\frac{2 m_{1} m_{2} g}{m_{1}+m_{2}}=77.2 \mathrm{~N}
$$

\begin{aligned}
\ddot{x} &=\frac{\left(m_{1}-m_{2}\right) g}{m_{1}+m_{2}}=\frac{2 g}{16} \\
&=1.225 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2} .

$$

1006.Problem Statement: A person of mass $80 \mathrm{~kg}$ jumps from a height of 1 meter and foolishly forgets to buckle his knees as he lands. His body decelerates over a distance of only one $\mathrm{cm}$. Calculate the total force on his legs during deceleration.
1006.Solution:
The person has mechanical energy $E_{1}=m g(h+s)$ just before he lands. The work done by him during deceleration is $E_{2}=f s$, where $f$ is the total force on his legs. As $E_{1}=E_{2}$,

$$
f=\frac{m g h}{s}+m g=\left(\frac{80 \times 1}{0.01}+80\right) g=8080 g \mathrm{~N} \text {. }
$$

1007.Problem Statement:
A mass $M$ slides without friction on the roller coaster track shown in Fig. 1.4. The curved sections of the track have radius of curvature $R$. The mass begins its descent from the height $h$. At some value of $h$, the mass will begin to lose contact with the track. Indicate on the diagram where the mass loses contact with the track and calculate the minimum value of $h$ for which this happens.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-020.jpg?height=265&width=516&top_left_y=1035&top_left_x=512)

Fig. 1.4.
1007.Solution:
Before the inflection point $A$ of the track, the normal reaction of the track on the mass, $N$, is

$$
N=\frac{m v^{2}}{R}+m g \sin \theta,
$$

where $v$ is the velocity of the mass. After the inflection point,

$$
N+\frac{m v^{2}}{R}=m g \sin \theta,
$$

for which $\sin \theta=\frac{R}{2 R}$, or $\theta=30^{\circ}$. The mass loses contact with the track if $N \leq 0$. This can only happen for the second part of the track and only if

$$
\frac{m v^{2}}{R} \geq m g \sin \theta .
$$

The conservation of mechanical energy

$$
m g[h-(R-R \sin \theta)]=\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}
$$

then requires

$$
h-R+R \sin \theta \geq \frac{R \sin \theta}{2},
$$

or

$$
h \geq R-\frac{R \sin \theta}{2} .
$$

The earliest the mass can start to lose contact with the track is at $\mathrm{A}$ for which $\theta=30^{\circ}$. Hence the minimum $h$ required is $\frac{3 R}{4}$.

1008.Problem Statement: Consider a rotating spherical planet. The velocity of a point on its equator is $V$. The effect of rotation of the planet is to make $g$ at the equator $1 / 2$ of $g$ at the pole. What is the escape velocity for a polar particle on the planet expressed as a multiple of $V$ ?
1008.Solution:
Let $g$ and $g^{\prime}$ be the gravitational accelerations at the pole and at the equator respectively and consider a body of mass $m$ on the surface of the planet, which has a mass $M$. At the pole,

$$
m g=\frac{G M m}{R^{2}},
$$

giving

$$
G M=g R^{2} .
$$

At the equator, we have

$$
\frac{m V^{2}}{R}=\frac{G M m}{R^{2}}-m g^{\prime}=m g-\frac{m g}{2}=\frac{m g}{2} .
$$

Hence $g=2 V^{2} / R$.

If we define gravitational potential energy with respect to a point at infinity from the planet, the body will have potential energy

$$
-\int_{\infty}^{R}-\frac{G M m}{r^{2}} d r=-\frac{G M m}{R} .
$$

Note that the negative sign in front of the gravitational force takes account of its attractiveness. The body at the pole then has total energy

$$
E=\frac{1}{2} m V^{2}-\frac{G M m}{R} .
$$

For it to escape from the planet, its total energy must be at least equal to the minimum energy of a body at infinity, i.e. zero. Hence the escape velocity $v$ is given by

$$
\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}-\frac{G M m}{R}=0,
$$

or

$$
v^{2}=\frac{2 G M}{R}=2 g R=4 V^{2},
$$

i.e.

$$
v=2 V .
$$

1010.Problem Statement:
A marble bounces down stairs in a regular manner, hitting each step at the same place and bouncing the same height above each step (Fig. 1.5). The stair height equals its depth (tread=rise) and the coefficient of restitution $e$ is given. Find the necessary horizontal velocity and bounce height (the coefficient of restitution is defined as $e=-v_{f} / v_{i}$, where $v_{f}$ and $v_{i}$ are the vertical velocities just after and before the bounce respectively).

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-023.jpg?height=483&width=368&top_left_y=1099&top_left_x=539)

Fig. 1.5.
1010.Solution:
Use unit vectors $\mathbf{i}, \mathbf{j}$ as shown in Fig. $1.5$ and let the horizontal velocity of the marble be $v_{h}$. The velocities just before and after a bounce are respectively 

$$
\mathbf{v}_{1}=v_{h} \mathbf{i}+v_{i} \mathbf{j}
$$

and

$$
\mathbf{v}_{2}=v_{h} \mathbf{i}+v_{f} \mathbf{j} \text {. }
$$

As the conditions at each step remain exactly the same, $v_{i}, v_{f}$ and $v_{h}$ are all constant. The conservation of mechanical energy

$$
\frac{1}{2} m v_{1}^{2}=\frac{1}{2} m v_{2}^{2}+m g l
$$

gives

$$
v_{i}^{2}=v_{f}^{2}+2 g l .
$$

As by definition

$$
v_{f}=-e v_{i},
$$

the above gives

$$
v_{i}^{2}=\frac{2 g l}{1-e^{2}} .
$$

The time required for each bounce is

$$
t=\frac{v_{i}-v_{f}}{g}=\frac{l}{v_{h}},
$$

giving

$$
v_{h}=\frac{g l}{v_{i}-v_{f}}=\frac{g l}{(1+e) v_{i}}=\sqrt{\frac{g l}{2} \frac{1-e}{1+e}},
$$

which is the necessary horizontal velocity. The bouncing height $H$ is given by the conservation of mechanical energy

$$
\frac{m v_{f}^{2}}{2}=m g H .
$$

Therefore,

$$
H=\frac{v_{f}^{2}}{2 g}=\frac{e^{2}}{2 g} \frac{2 g l}{1-e^{2}}=\frac{e^{2} l}{1-e^{2}}
$$

1011.Problem Statement:
Assume all surfaces to be frictionless and the inertia of pulley and cord negligible (Fig. 1.6). Find the horizontal force necessary to prevent any relative motion of $m_{1}, m_{2}$ and $M$.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-025.jpg?height=213&width=400&top_left_y=229&top_left_x=529)

Fig. 1.6.
1011.Solution:
The forces $f_{1}, F$ and $m g$ are shown in Fig. 1.7. The accelerations of $m_{1}, m_{2}$ and $M$ are the same when there is no relative motion among them. The equations of motion along the $x$-axis are

$$
\begin{gathered}
\left(M+m_{1}+m_{2}\right) \ddot{x}=F, \\
m_{1} \ddot{x}=f_{1} .
\end{gathered}
$$

As there is no relative motion of $m_{2}$ along the $y$-axis,

$$
f_{1}=m_{2} g .
$$

Combining these equations, we obtain

$$
F=\frac{m_{2}\left(M+m_{1}+m_{2}\right) g}{m_{1}} .
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-025.jpg?height=286&width=503&top_left_y=1267&top_left_x=477)

Fig. 1.7.

1012.Problem Statement: The sun is about 25,000 light years from the center of the galaxy and travels approximately in a circle with a period of $170,000,000$ years. The earth is 8 light minutes from the sun. From these data alone, find the approximate gravitational mass of the galaxy in units of the sun's mass. You may assume that the gravitational force on the sun may be approximated by assuming that all the mass of the galaxy is at its center.
1012.Solution:
For the motion of the earth around the sun,

$$
\frac{m v^{2}}{r}=\frac{G m m_{s}}{r^{2}},
$$

where $r$ is the distance from the earth to the sun, $v$ is the velocity of the earth, $m$ and $m_{s}$ are the masses of the earth and the sun respectively.

For the motion of the sun around the center of the galaxy,

$$
\frac{m_{s} V^{2}}{R}=\frac{G m_{s} M}{R^{2}},
$$

where $R$ is the distance from the sun to the center of the galaxy, $V$ is the velocity of the sun and $M$ is the mass of the galaxy.

Hence

$$
M=\frac{R V^{2}}{G}=\frac{R}{r}\left(\frac{V}{v}\right)^{2} m_{s} .
$$

Using $V=2 \pi R / T, v=2 \pi r / t$, where $T$ and $t$ are the periods of revolution of the sun and the earth respectively, we have

$$
M=\left(\frac{R}{r}\right)^{3}\left(\frac{t}{T}\right)^{2} m_{s} .
$$

With the data given, we obtain

$$
M=1.53 \times 10^{11} \mathrm{~m}_{s} .
$$

1013.a.Problem Statement:
An Olympic diver of mass $m$ begins his descent from a 10 meter high diving board with zero initial velocity.

Calculate the velocity $V_{0}$ on impact with the water and the approximate elapsed time from dive until impact (use any method you choose).
1013.a.Solution:
$$
V_{0}=\sqrt{2 g h}=\sqrt{2 \times 9.8 \times 10}=14 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \text {. }
$$

The time elapsed from dive to impact is

$$
t=\frac{V_{0}}{g}=\frac{14}{9.8}=1.43 \mathrm{~s} .
$$

1014.Problem Statement: The combined frictional and air resistance on a bicyclist has the force $F=a V$, where $V$ is his velocity and $a=4$ newton-sec $/ \mathrm{m}$. At maximum effort, the cyclist can generate 600 watts propulsive power. What is his maximum speed on level ground with no wind?
1014.Solution:
When the maximum speed is achieved, the propulsive force is equal to the resistant force. Let $F$ be this propulsive force, then

$$
F=a V \quad \text { and } \quad F V=600 \mathrm{~W} .
$$

Eliminating $F$, we obtain

$$
V^{2}=\frac{600}{a}=150 \mathrm{~m}^{2} / \mathrm{s}^{2}
$$

and the maximum speed on level ground with no wind

$$
v=\sqrt{150}=12.2 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \text {. }
$$

1015.Problem Statement:
A pendulum of mass $m$ and length $l$ is released from rest in a horizontal position. A nail a distance $d$ below the pivot causes the mass to move along the path indicated by the dotted line. Find the minimum distance $d$ in terms of $l$ such that the mass will swing completely round in the circle shown in Fig. 1.8.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-028.jpg?height=223&width=285&top_left_y=1603&top_left_x=642)

Fig. 1.8.
1015.Solution:
Take the mass $m$ as a point mass. At the instant when the pendulum collides with the nail, $m$ has a velocity $v=\sqrt{2 g l}$. The angular momentum of the mass with respect to the point at which the nail locates is conserved during the collision. Then the velocity of the mass is still $v$ at the instant after the collision and the motion thereafter is such that the mass is constrained to rotate around the nail. Under the critical condition that the mass can just swing completely round in a circle, the gravitational force is equal to the centripetal force when the mass is at the top of the circle. Let the velocity of the mass at this instant be $v_{1}$, and we have

$$
\frac{m v_{1}^{2}}{l-d}=m g \text {, }
$$

or

$$
v_{1}^{2}=(l-d) g .
$$

The energy equation

$$
\frac{m v^{2}}{2}=\frac{m v_{1}^{2}}{2}+2 m g(l-d),
$$

or

$$
2 g l=(l-d) g+4(l-d) g
$$

then gives the minimum distance as

$$
d=\frac{3 l}{5} .
$$

1016.a.Problem Statement:
A mass $m$ moves in a circle on a smooth horizontal plane with velocity $v_{0}$ at a radius $R_{0}$. The mass is attached to a string which passes through a smooth hole in the plane as shown in Fig. 1.9.
("Smooth" means frictionless.)

What is the tension in the string?
1016.a.Solution: The tension in the string provides the centripetal force needed for the circular motion, hence $F=m v_{0}^{2} / R_{0}$.

1016.b.Problem Statement:
A mass $m$ moves in a circle on a smooth horizontal plane with velocity $v_{0}$ at a radius $R_{0}$. The mass is attached to a string which passes through a smooth hole in the plane as shown in Fig. 1.9.
("Smooth" means frictionless.)

What is the angular momentum of $m$ ?
1016.b.Solution: The tension in the string provides the centripetal force needed for the circular motion, hence $F=m v_{0}^{2} / R_{0}$.The angular momentum of the mass $m$ is $J=m v_{0} R_{0}$.

1016.c.Problem Statement:
A mass $m$ moves in a circle on a smooth horizontal plane with velocity $v_{0}$ at a radius $R_{0}$. The mass is attached to a string which passes through a smooth hole in the plane as shown in Fig. 1.9.
("Smooth" means frictionless.)

What is the kinetic energy of $m$ ?
1016.c.Solution: The tension in the string provides the centripetal force needed for the circular motion, hence $F=m v_{0}^{2} / R_{0}$.The angular momentum of the mass $m$ is $J=m v_{0} R_{0}$.The kinetic energy of the mass $m$ is $T=m v_{0}^{2} / 2$.

1016.d.Problem Statement:
A mass $m$ moves in a circle on a smooth horizontal plane with velocity $v_{0}$ at a radius $R_{0}$. The mass is attached to a string which passes through a smooth hole in the plane as shown in Fig. 1.9.
("Smooth" means frictionless.)

The tension in the string is increased gradually and finally $m$ moves in a circle of radius $R_{0} / 2$. What is the final value of the kinetic energy?
1016.d.Solution:
The tension in the string provides the centripetal force needed for the circular motion, hence $F=m v_{0}^{2} / R_{0}$.The angular momentum of the mass $m$ is $J=m v_{0} R_{0}$.The kinetic energy of the mass $m$ is $T=m v_{0}^{2} / 2$.The radius of the circular motion of the mass $m$ decreases when the tension in the string is increased gradually. The angular momentum of the mass $m$ is conserved since it moves under a central force. Thus

$$
m v_{0} R_{0}=m v_{1}\left(\frac{R_{0}}{2}\right),
$$

or

$$
v_{1}=2 v_{0} .
$$

The final kinetic energy is then

$$
T_{1}=\frac{m v_{1}^{2}}{2}=\frac{m\left(2 v_{0}\right)^{2}}{2}=2 m v_{0}^{2} .
$$

1017.Problem Statement:
When a $5000 \mathrm{lb}$ car driven at $60 \mathrm{mph}$ on a level road is suddenly put into neutral gear (i.e. allowed to coast), the velocity decreases in the following manner:

$$
V=\frac{60}{1+\left(\frac{t}{60}\right)} \mathrm{mph},
$$

where $t$ is the time in sec. Find the horsepower required to drive this car at $30 \mathrm{mph}$ on the same road.

Useful constants: $g=22 \mathrm{mph} / \mathrm{sec}, 1 \mathrm{H} . \mathrm{P} .=550 \mathrm{ft} . l \mathrm{~b} / \mathrm{sec}, 60 \mathrm{mph}=$ $88 \mathrm{ft} / \mathrm{sec}$.
1017.Solution:
Let $V_{0}=60 \mathrm{mph}$, then

$$
\frac{t}{60}=\frac{V_{0}}{V}-1 \text {. }
$$

Hence

$$
\frac{d V}{d t}=\frac{-V^{2}}{60 V_{0}},
$$

and the resistance acting on the car is $F=m V^{2} /\left(60 V_{0}\right)$, where $m$ is the mass of the car. The propulsive force must be equal to the resistance $F^{\prime}$ at the speed of $V^{\prime}=30 \mathrm{mph}$ in order to maintain this speed on the same road. It follows that the horsepower required is

$$
\begin{aligned}
P^{\prime} &=F^{\prime} V^{\prime}=\frac{m V^{\prime 3}}{60 V_{0}}=37500 \frac{\mathrm{mph}^{2} . l \mathrm{~b} .}{\mathrm{s}} \\
&=\frac{37500}{g} \frac{\mathrm{mph}^{2} . \mathrm{lb} \text { wt }}{\mathrm{s}}=\frac{37500}{22} \mathrm{mph} . \mathrm{lb} \text { wt } \\
&=\frac{37500}{22} \cdot \frac{88}{60} \frac{\mathrm{ft} . \mathrm{lb} \text { wt }}{\mathrm{s}} \\
&=2500 \frac{\mathrm{ft} . l \mathrm{~b} \text { wt }}{\mathrm{s}}=4.5 \text { H.P. }
\end{aligned}
$$

Note that pound weight (lb wt) is a unit of force and $1 \mathrm{lb} \mathrm{wt}=g \mathrm{ft} . \mathrm{lb} / \mathrm{s}^{2}$. The horsepower is defined as $550 \mathrm{ft} . l \mathrm{~b} \mathrm{wt} / \mathrm{s}$.

1019.Problem Statement:
A particle of mass $m$ is subjected to two forces: a central force $\mathbf{f}_{1}$ and a frictional force $\mathbf{f}_{2}$, with

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\mathbf{f}_{1}=\frac{\mathbf{r}}{r} f(r), \\
&\mathbf{f}_{2}=-\lambda \mathbf{v} \quad(\lambda>0),
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\mathbf{v}$ is the velocity of the particle. If the particle initially has angular momentum $\mathbf{J}_{0}$ about $r=0$, find its angular momentum for all subsequent times.
1019.Solution:
Write out the equations of motion of the particle in polar coordinates:

$$
\begin{aligned}
&m\left(\ddot{r}-r \dot{\theta}^{2}\right)=f(r)-\lambda \dot{r}, \\
&m(2 \dot{r} \dot{\theta}+r \ddot{\theta})=-\lambda r \dot{\theta},
\end{aligned}
$$

or

$$
\frac{1}{r} \frac{d\left(m r^{2} \dot{\theta}\right)}{d t}=-\lambda r \dot{\theta} .
$$

Letting $J=m r^{2} \dot{\theta}$, we rewrite the last equation as follows:

$$
\frac{d J}{d t}=\frac{-\lambda J}{m} .
$$

Integrating and making use of the initial angular momentum $\mathbf{J}_{0}$, we obtain

$$
\mathbf{J}=\mathbf{J}_{0} e^{-\frac{\lambda}{m} t} .
$$

1020.a.Problem Statement: A spherical object rotates with angular frequency $\omega$. If the only force preventing centrifugal disintegration of the object is gravity, what is the minimum density the object must have? Use this to estimate the minimum density of the Crab pulsar which rotates 30 times per second.
1020.a.Solution:
Consider the limiting case that the Crab pulsar is just about to disintegrate. Then the centripetal force on a test body at the equator of the Crab pulsar is just smaller than the gravitational force:

$$
\frac{m v^{2}}{R}=m R \omega^{2} \leq \frac{G m M}{R^{2}},
$$

or

$$
\frac{M}{R^{3}} \geq \frac{\omega^{2}}{G},
$$

where $m$ and $M$ are the masses of the test body and the Crab pulsar respectively, $R$ is the radius of the pulsar, $v$ is the speed of the test body, and $G$ is the gravitational constant. Hence the minimum density of the pulsar is

$$
\rho=\frac{M}{\frac{4}{3} \pi R^{3}} \geq \frac{3 \omega^{2}}{4 \pi G}=\frac{3(2 \pi \times 30)^{2}}{4 \pi \times 6.7 \times 10^{-11}} \sim 1.3 \times 10^{14} \mathrm{~kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3} .
$$

1020.b.Problem Statement:
(This is a remnant of a supernova in 1054 A.D. which was extensively observed in China!)

If the mass of the pulsar is about 1 solar mass $\left(\sim 2 \times 10^{30} \mathrm{~kg}\right.$ or $\sim 3 \times 10^{5} M_{\text {earth }}$ ), what is the maximum possible radius of the pulsar?
1020.b.Solution:
Consider the limiting case that the Crab pulsar is just about to disintegrate. Then the centripetal force on a test body at the equator of the Crab pulsar is just smaller than the gravitational force:

$$
\frac{m v^{2}}{R}=m R \omega^{2} \leq \frac{G m M}{R^{2}},
$$

or

$$
\frac{M}{R^{3}} \geq \frac{\omega^{2}}{G},
$$

where $m$ and $M$ are the masses of the test body and the Crab pulsar respectively, $R$ is the radius of the pulsar, $v$ is the speed of the test body, and $G$ is the gravitational constant. Hence the minimum density of the pulsar is

$$
\rho=\frac{M}{\frac{4}{3} \pi R^{3}} \geq \frac{3 \omega^{2}}{4 \pi G}=\frac{3(2 \pi \times 30)^{2}}{4 \pi \times 6.7 \times 10^{-11}} \sim 1.3 \times 10^{14} \mathrm{~kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3} .
$$$\operatorname{As} \frac{3 M}{4 \pi R^{3}} \geq \rho_{\min }$,

$$
R \leq\left(\frac{3 M}{4 \pi \rho_{\min }}\right)^{\frac{1}{3}}=\left(\frac{6 \times 10^{30}}{4 \pi \times 1.3 \times 10^{14}}\right)^{\frac{1}{3}}=1.5 \times 10^{5} \mathrm{~m}=150 \mathrm{~km}
$$

1021.Problem Statement:
Two weightless rings slide on a smooth circular loop of wire whose axis lies in a horizontal plane. A smooth string passes through the rings which carries weights at the two ends and at a point between the rings. If there is equilibrium when the rings are at points $30^{\circ}$ distant from the highest point of the circle as shown in Fig. 1.11, find the relation between the three weights.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-035.jpg?height=333&width=304&top_left_y=1470&top_left_x=573)

Fig. 1.11.
1021.Solution:
Assume the string is also weightless. As no friction is involved, the tensions in the segments $A C$ and $A E$ of the string must be the same. Let the magnitude be $T$. For the ring $A$ to be at rest on the smooth loop, the resultant force on it must be along $A O, O$ being the center of the loop; otherwise there would be a component tangential to the loop. Hence

$$
\angle O A E=\angle O A C=\angle A O E=30^{\circ} .
$$

The same argument applies to the segments $B D$ and $B E$. Then by symmetry the point $E$ at which the string carries the third weight must be on the radius $H O, H$ being the highest point of the loop, and the tensions in the segments $B D$ and $B E$ are also $T$.

Consider the point $E$. Each of the three forces acting on it, which are in equilibrium, is at an angle of $120^{\circ}$ to the adjacent one. As two of the forces have magnitude $T$, the third force must also have magnitude $T$. Therefore the three weights carried by the string are equal.

1022.Problem Statement:
Calculate the ratio of the mean densities of the earth and the sun from the following approximate data:

$\theta=$ angular diameter of the sun seen from the earth $=\frac{1}{2}^{\circ}$.

$l=$ length of $1^{\circ}$ of latitude on the earth's surface $=100 \mathrm{~km}$.

$t=$ one year $=3 \times 10^{7} \mathrm{~s}$.

$g=10 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}$.
1022.Solution:
Let $r$ be the distance between the sun and the earth, $M_{e}$ and $M_{s}$ be the masses and $R_{e}$ and $R_{s}$ be the radii of the earth and the sun respectively, and $G$ be the gravitational constant. We then have

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\frac{G M_{e} M_{s}}{r^{2}}=M_{e} r \omega^{2}, \\
&\frac{2 R_{s}}{r}=\frac{1}{2} \frac{2 \pi}{360}=\frac{\pi}{360} \mathrm{rad},
\end{aligned}
$$

i.e.

$$
r=\frac{720 R_{s}}{\pi} .
$$

The above gives

$$
\frac{G M_{s}}{\left(720 R_{s} / \pi\right)^{3}}=\omega^{2}
$$

or

$$
\frac{G M_{s}}{R_{s}^{3}}=\left(\frac{720}{\pi}\right)^{3}\left(\frac{2 \pi}{3 \times 10^{7}}\right)^{2} .
$$

For a mass $m$ on the earth's surface,

$$
\frac{G m M_{e}}{R_{e}^{2}}=m g,
$$

giving

$$
\frac{G M_{e}}{R_{e}^{3}}=\frac{g}{R_{e}}=\frac{g}{\left(\frac{360 \times 100}{2 \pi}\right)}=\frac{g \pi}{18 \times 10^{3}}
$$

Hence

$$
\frac{\rho_{e}}{\rho_{s}}=\frac{g \pi}{18 \times 10^{3}}\left(\frac{720}{\pi}\right)^{-3}\left(\frac{2 \pi}{3 \times 10^{7}}\right)^{-2}=3.31
$$

1024.a.Problem Statement:
A satellite in stationary orbit above a point on the equator is intended to send energy to ground stations by a coherent microwave beam of wavelength one meter from a one- $\mathrm{km}$ mirror.

What is the height of such a stationary orbit?
1024.a.Solution:
The revolving angular velocity $\omega$ of the synchronous satellite is equal to the spin angular velocity of the earth and is given by

$$
m(R+h) \omega^{2}=\frac{G M m}{(R+h)^{2}} .
$$

Hence the height of the stationary orbit is

$$
h=\left(\frac{G M}{\omega^{2}}\right)^{\frac{1}{3}}-R=3.59 \times 10^{4} \mathrm{~km} \text {, }
$$

using $G=6.67 \times 10^{-11} \mathrm{Nm}^{2} \mathrm{~kg}^{-2}, M=5.98 \times 10^{24} \mathrm{~kg}, R=6.37 \times 10^{4} \mathrm{~km}$.

1025.b.Problem Statement:
An inclined plane of mass $M$ rests on a rough floor with coefficient of static friction $\mu$. A mass $m_{1}$ is suspended by a string which passes over a smooth peg at the upper end of the incline and attaches to a mass $m_{2}$ which slides without friction on the incline. The incline makes an angle $\theta$ with the horizontal.

Find the smallest coefficient of friction for which the inclined plane will remain at rest.
1025.b.Solution:
When $\mu$ is large enough, the inclined plane remains at rest. The equations of motion of $m_{1}$ and $m_{2}$ are (see Fig. 1.12)

$$
\begin{gathered}
m_{1} g-T=m_{1} a, \\
T-m_{2} g \sin \theta=m_{2} a,
\end{gathered}
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-040.jpg?height=241&width=405&top_left_y=597&top_left_x=226)

Fig. 1.12.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-040.jpg?height=258&width=437&top_left_y=572&top_left_x=813)

Fig. 1.13.

giving

$$
\begin{aligned}
a &=\frac{\left(m_{1}-m_{2} \sin \theta\right) g}{m_{1}+m_{2}}, \\
T &=\frac{m_{1} m_{2}(1+\sin \theta) g}{m_{1}+m_{2}} .
\end{aligned}
$$

The inclined plane is subjected to horizontal and vertical forces (see Fig. 1.13) with

$$
\begin{aligned}
f &=T \cos \theta-N_{1} \sin \theta, \\
N &=N_{1} \cos \theta+M g+T(1+\sin \theta), \\
N_{1} &=m_{2} g \cos \theta
\end{aligned}
$$

For the inclined plane to remain at rest, we require

$$
f \leq \mu N \text {. }
$$

The smallest coefficient of friction for the plane to remain stationary is therefore

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mu_{\min } &=\frac{f}{N} \\
&=\frac{m_{2} \cos \theta\left(m_{1}-m_{2} \sin \theta\right)}{M\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right)+m_{1} m_{2}(1+\sin \theta)^{2}+\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right) m_{2} \cos ^{2} \theta} .
\end{aligned}
$$

1026.a.Problem Statement:
A particle of mass $m$ is constrained to move on the frictionless inner surface of a cone of half-angle $\alpha$, as shown in Fig. 1.14.

Find the restrictions on the initial conditions such that the particle moves in a circular orbit about the vertical axis.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-041.jpg?height=349&width=400&top_left_y=623&top_left_x=176)

Fig. $1.14$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-041.jpg?height=324&width=219&top_left_y=621&top_left_x=956)

Fig. 1.15.
1026.a.Solution:
In spherical coordinates $(r, \theta, \varphi)$, the equations of motion of the particle are

$$
\begin{aligned}
&m\left(\ddot{r}-r \dot{\theta}^{2}-r \dot{\varphi}^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta\right)=F_{r}, \\
&m\left(r \ddot{\theta}+2 \dot{r} \dot{\theta}-r \dot{\varphi}^{2} \sin \theta \cos \theta\right)=F_{\theta}, \\
&m(r \ddot{\varphi} \sin \theta+2 \dot{r} \dot{\varphi} \sin \theta+2 r \dot{\theta} \dot{\varphi} \cos \theta)=F_{\varphi} .
\end{aligned}
$$

As the particle is constrained to move on the inner surface of the cone,

$$
\theta=\text { constant }=\alpha .
$$

Then $\dot{\theta}=0, F_{r}=-m g \cos \alpha$, and Eq.
(1) becomes

$$
m\left(\ddot{l}-l \dot{\varphi}^{2} \sin ^{2} \alpha\right)=-m g \cos \alpha,
$$

where $l$ is its distance from the vertex $O$ (see Fig. 1.15). For motion in a circular orbit about the vertical axis, $i=\ddot{l}=0$. With $l=l_{0}, \mathrm{Eq}$.
(2) becomes

$$
l_{0} \dot{\varphi}^{2} \sin ^{2} \alpha=g \cos \alpha .
$$

The right-hand side of Eq.
(3) is constant so that $\dot{\varphi}=$ constant $=\dot{\varphi} 0$, say. The particle has velocity $v_{0}$ tangential to the orbit given by $v_{0}=l_{0} \dot{\varphi}_{0} \sin \alpha$. Equation (3) then gives

$$
v_{0}^{2}=g l_{0} \cos \alpha,
$$

which is the initial condition that must be satisfied by $v_{0}$ and $l_{0}$.

1026.b.Problem Statement:
A particle of mass $m$ is constrained to move on the frictionless inner surface of a cone of half-angle $\alpha$, as shown in Fig. 1.14.

Determine whether this kind of orbit is stable.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-041.jpg?height=349&width=400&top_left_y=623&top_left_x=176)

Fig. $1.14$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-041.jpg?height=324&width=219&top_left_y=621&top_left_x=956)

Fig. 1.15.
1026.b.Solution:
In spherical coordinates $(r, \theta, \varphi)$, the equations of motion of the particle are

$$
\begin{aligned}
&m\left(\ddot{r}-r \dot{\theta}^{2}-r \dot{\varphi}^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta\right)=F_{r}, \\
&m\left(r \ddot{\theta}+2 \dot{r} \dot{\theta}-r \dot{\varphi}^{2} \sin \theta \cos \theta\right)=F_{\theta}, \\
&m(r \ddot{\varphi} \sin \theta+2 \dot{r} \dot{\varphi} \sin \theta+2 r \dot{\theta} \dot{\varphi} \cos \theta)=F_{\varphi} .
\end{aligned}
$$

As the particle is constrained to move on the inner surface of the cone,

$$
\theta=\text { constant }=\alpha .
$$

Then $\dot{\theta}=0, F_{r}=-m g \cos \alpha$, and Eq.
(1) becomes

$$
m\left(\ddot{l}-l \dot{\varphi}^{2} \sin ^{2} \alpha\right)=-m g \cos \alpha,
$$

where $l$ is its distance from the vertex $O$ (see Fig. 1.15). For motion in a circular orbit about the vertical axis, $i=\ddot{l}=0$. With $l=l_{0}, \mathrm{Eq}$.
(2) becomes

$$
l_{0} \dot{\varphi}^{2} \sin ^{2} \alpha=g \cos \alpha .
$$

The right-hand side of Eq.
(3) is constant so that $\dot{\varphi}=$ constant $=\dot{\varphi} 0$, say. The particle has velocity $v_{0}$ tangential to the orbit given by $v_{0}=l_{0} \dot{\varphi}_{0} \sin \alpha$. Equation (3) then gives

$$
v_{0}^{2}=g l_{0} \cos \alpha,
$$

which is the initial condition that must be satisfied by $v_{0}$ and $l_{0}$.Suppose there is a small perturbation acting on the particle such that $l_{0}$ becomes $l_{0}+\Delta l, \dot{\varphi}_{0}$ becomes $\dot{\varphi}_{0}+\Delta \dot{\varphi}$. Equation (2) is now

$$
\frac{d^{2}\left(l_{B}+\Delta l\right)}{d t^{2}}-\left(l_{0}+\Delta l\right)\left(\dot{\varphi}_{0}+\Delta \dot{\varphi}\right)^{2} \sin ^{2} \alpha=-g \cos \alpha,
$$

or

$$
\Delta \ddot{l}-2 l_{0} \dot{\varphi}_{0} \Delta \dot{\varphi} \sin ^{2} \alpha-\Delta l \dot{\varphi}_{0}^{2} \sin ^{2} \alpha=l_{0} \dot{\varphi}^{2} \sin ^{2} \alpha-g \cos \alpha,
$$

where $\Delta \ddot{l}$ is shorthand for $d^{2}(\Delta l) / d t^{2}$, by neglecting terms of orders higher than the first order quantities $\Delta l$ and $\Delta \dot{\varphi}$. As the right-hand side of this equation vanishes on account of Eq.
(3), we have

$$
\Delta \ddot{l}-2 l_{0} \dot{\varphi}_{0} \Delta \dot{\varphi} \sin ^{2} \alpha-\Delta l \dot{\varphi}_{0}^{2} \sin ^{2} \alpha=0 .
$$

There is no force tangential to the orbit acting on the particle, so there is no torque about the vertical axis and the angular momentum of the particle about the axis is constant:

$$
m l v \sin \alpha=m l^{2} \dot{\varphi} \sin ^{2} \alpha=\text { constant }=k, \text { say, }
$$

or

$$
l^{2} \dot{\varphi}=\frac{k}{m \sin ^{2} \alpha} .
$$

Substituting $l=l_{0}+\Delta l, \dot{\varphi}=\dot{\varphi}_{0}+\Delta \dot{\varphi}$ into Eq.
(5) and neglecting terms of the second order or higher, we have

$$
l_{0} \Delta \dot{\varphi}+2 \Delta l \dot{\varphi}_{0}=0 .
$$

Eliminating $\Delta \dot{\varphi}$ from Eqs.
(4) and (6), we obtain

$$
\Delta \ddot{l}+\left(3 \dot{\varphi}_{0}^{2} \sin ^{2} \alpha\right) \Delta l=0 .
$$

As the factor in brackets is real and positive, this is the equation of a "simple harmonic oscillator". Hence the orbit is stable.

1027.b.Problem Statement:
Three point particles with masses $m_{1}, m_{2}$ and $m_{3}$ interact with each other through the gravitational force.

The system can rotate in its plane with constant and equal distances between all pairs of masses. Determine the angular frequency of the rotation when the masses are separated by a distance $d$.
1027.b.Solution:
Take the center of mass $C$ of the system as the origin of coordinates and let the position vectors of $m_{1}, m_{2}, m_{3}$ be $\mathbf{r}_{1}, \mathbf{r}_{2}, \mathbf{r}_{3}$ respectively as shown in Fig. 1.16. Denote

$$
\mathbf{r}_{i j}=\mathbf{r}_{i}-\mathbf{r}_{j} \quad(i, j=1,2,3) .
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-043.jpg?height=246&width=365&top_left_y=1100&top_left_x=557)

Fig. 1.16.

The motion of the ith particle is given by

$$
m_{i} \ddot{\mathbf{r}}_{i}=-\sum_{j \neq i}^{3} \frac{G m_{i} m_{j}}{r_{i j}^{3}} \mathbf{r}_{i j}
$$

or

$$
\ddot{\mathbf{r}}_{i}=-\sum_{j \neq i}^{3} \frac{G m_{j}}{r_{i j}^{3}} \mathbf{r}_{i j} \quad(i=1,2,3) .
$$

Note that the minus sign is to indicate that the forces are attractive.
With the given condition $r_{i j}=d$, Eq.
(1) is rewritten as

$$
\begin{aligned}
\ddot{\mathbf{r}}_{i} &=\frac{G}{d^{3}} \sum_{j \neq i}^{3} m_{j}\left(\mathbf{r}_{j}-\mathbf{r}_{i}\right) \\
&=\frac{G}{d^{3}}\left[-\sum_{j \neq i}^{3} m_{j} \mathbf{r}_{i}+\sum_{j \neq i}^{3} m_{j} \mathbf{r}_{j}\right] \\
&=\frac{G}{d^{3}}\left[-\sum_{j \neq i}^{3} m_{j} \mathbf{r}_{i}-m_{i} \mathbf{r}_{i}+\sum_{j=1}^{3} m_{j} \mathbf{r}_{j}\right] \\
&=\frac{G}{d^{3}}\left[-\mathbf{r}_{i} \sum_{j=1}^{3} m_{j}+\sum_{j=1}^{3} m_{j} \mathbf{r}_{j}\right] \\
&=-\frac{G M}{d^{3}} \mathbf{r}_{i},
\end{aligned}
$$

where $M=m_{1}+m_{2}+m_{3}$. Note that the choice of the center of mass as origin makes $\sum m_{j} \mathbf{r}_{j}$ vanish. Thus the force on each particle points towards the center of mass of the system and is a harmonic force. With $d$ constant, the system rotates about $C$ with angular frequency

$$
\omega=\sqrt{\frac{G M}{d^{3}}} .
$$

1027.c.Problem Statement:
Three point particles with masses $m_{1}, m_{2}$ and $m_{3}$ interact with each other through the gravitational force.

For $m_{1} \gg m_{3}$ and $m_{2} \gg m_{3}$, determine the stability condition for motion of the mass $m_{3}$ about the stationary position. Consider only motion in the orbital plane.
1027.c.Solution:
Take the center of mass $C$ of the system as the origin of coordinates and let the position vectors of $m_{1}, m_{2}, m_{3}$ be $\mathbf{r}_{1}, \mathbf{r}_{2}, \mathbf{r}_{3}$ respectively as shown in Fig. 1.16. Denote

$$
\mathbf{r}_{i j}=\mathbf{r}_{i}-\mathbf{r}_{j} \quad(i, j=1,2,3) .
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-043.jpg?height=246&width=365&top_left_y=1100&top_left_x=557)

Fig. 1.16.

The motion of the ith particle is given by

$$
m_{i} \ddot{\mathbf{r}}_{i}=-\sum_{j \neq i}^{3} \frac{G m_{i} m_{j}}{r_{i j}^{3}} \mathbf{r}_{i j}
$$

or

$$
\ddot{\mathbf{r}}_{i}=-\sum_{j \neq i}^{3} \frac{G m_{j}}{r_{i j}^{3}} \mathbf{r}_{i j} \quad(i=1,2,3) .
$$

Note that the minus sign is to indicate that the forces are attractive.
With the given condition $r_{i j}=d$, Eq.
(1) is rewritten as

$$
\begin{aligned}
\ddot{\mathbf{r}}_{i} &=\frac{G}{d^{3}} \sum_{j \neq i}^{3} m_{j}\left(\mathbf{r}_{j}-\mathbf{r}_{i}\right) \\
&=\frac{G}{d^{3}}\left[-\sum_{j \neq i}^{3} m_{j} \mathbf{r}_{i}+\sum_{j \neq i}^{3} m_{j} \mathbf{r}_{j}\right] \\
&=\frac{G}{d^{3}}\left[-\sum_{j \neq i}^{3} m_{j} \mathbf{r}_{i}-m_{i} \mathbf{r}_{i}+\sum_{j=1}^{3} m_{j} \mathbf{r}_{j}\right] \\
&=\frac{G}{d^{3}}\left[-\mathbf{r}_{i} \sum_{j=1}^{3} m_{j}+\sum_{j=1}^{3} m_{j} \mathbf{r}_{j}\right] \\
&=-\frac{G M}{d^{3}} \mathbf{r}_{i},
\end{aligned}
$$

where $M=m_{1}+m_{2}+m_{3}$. Note that the choice of the center of mass as origin makes $\sum m_{j} \mathbf{r}_{j}$ vanish. Thus the force on each particle points towards the center of mass of the system and is a harmonic force. With $d$ constant, the system rotates about $C$ with angular frequency

$$
\omega=\sqrt{\frac{G M}{d^{3}}} .
$$For $m_{3} \ll m_{1}$ and $m_{3} \ll m_{2}$, the equation of motion of either of the masses $m_{1}$ and $m_{2}$ can be written as

$$
\begin{aligned}
\ddot{\mathbf{r}}_{i} &=-\frac{G\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right)}{d^{3}} \mathbf{r}_{i} \\
&=-\frac{G\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right)}{r_{12}^{3}} \mathbf{r}_{i}, \quad i=1,2 .
\end{aligned}
$$

With the distance between $m_{1}$ and $m_{2}$ constant, the system rotates about its center of mass with a constant angular frequency

$$
w=\sqrt{\frac{G\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right)}{r_{12}^{3}}} .
$$

Use a rotating coordinate frame with origin at the center of mass of the system and angular frequency of rotation $\omega$ and let the quantities $\dot{\mathbf{r}}, \ddot{\mathbf{r}}$ refer to this rotating frame. Considering the motion of particle $m_{3}$ in the laboratory frame, we have

$$
m_{3}\left(\ddot{\mathbf{r}}_{3}-\omega^{2} \mathbf{r}_{3}\right)=-\frac{G m_{3} m_{1}}{r_{31}^{3}} \mathbf{r}_{31}-\frac{G m_{3} m_{2}}{r_{32}^{3}} \mathbf{r}_{32}-2 m_{3} \omega \times \dot{\mathbf{r}}_{3},
$$

or

$$
\ddot{\mathbf{r}}_{3}=-\frac{G m_{1}}{r_{31}^{3}} \mathbf{r}_{31}-\frac{G m_{2}}{r_{32}^{3}} \mathbf{r}_{32}+\omega^{2} \mathbf{r}_{3}-2 \omega \times \dot{\mathbf{r}}_{3} .
$$

If $m_{3}$ is stationary, $\ddot{\mathbf{r}}_{3}=\dot{\mathrm{r}}_{3}=0$ and the above becomes

$$
\frac{G m_{1}}{r_{31}^{3}}\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}-\mathbf{r}_{3}\right)+\frac{G m_{2}}{r_{32}^{2}}\left(\mathbf{r}_{2}-\mathbf{r}_{3}\right)+\omega^{2} \mathbf{r}_{3}=0 .
$$

With $m_{1}, m_{2} \gg m_{3}, \sum m_{j} \mathbf{r}_{j}=0$ gives $m_{1} \mathbf{r}_{1} \approx-m_{2} \mathbf{r}_{2}$ and the above becomes

$$
-G\left(\frac{m_{1}}{r_{31}^{3}}+\frac{m_{2}}{r_{32}^{3}}\right) \mathbf{r}_{3}+G\left(\frac{m_{1}}{r_{31}^{3}}-\frac{m_{1}}{r_{32}^{3}}\right) \mathbf{r}_{1}+\omega^{2} \mathbf{r}_{3}=0 .
$$

This relation shows that $\mathbf{r}_{3}$ is parallel to $\mathbf{r}_{1}$ and thus the stationary position of $m_{3}$ lies on the line joining $m_{1}$ and $m_{2}$. At this position, the attractions of $m_{1}$ and $m_{2}$ are balanced.

Consider now a small displacement being applied to $m_{3}$ at this stationary position. If the displacement is along the line joining $m_{1}$ and $m_{2}$, say toward $m_{1}$, the attraction by $m_{1}$ is enhanced and that by $m_{2}$ is reduced. Then $m_{3}$ will continue to move toward $m_{1}$ and the equilibrium is unstable. On the other hand, if the displacement is normal to the line joining $m_{1}$ and $m_{2}$, both the attractions by $m_{1}$ and $m_{2}$ will have a component toward the stationary position and will restore $m_{3}$ to this position. Thus the equilibrium is stable. Therefore the equilibrium is stable against a transverse perturbation but unstable against a longitudinal one.

1030.Problem Statement:
Paris and London are connected by a straight subway tunnel (see Fig. 1.19). A train travels between the two cities powered only by the gravitational force of the earth. Calculate the maximum speed of the train and the time taken to travel from London to Paris. The distance between the two cities is $300 \mathrm{~km}$ and the radius of the earth is $6400 \mathrm{~km}$. Neglect friction.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-050.jpg?height=246&width=432&top_left_y=1587&top_left_x=577)

Fig. 1.19.
1030.Solution:
Define $x, h, r$ as in Fig. $1.20$ and assume the earth to be a stationary homogeneous sphere of radius $R$. Taking the surface of the earth as reference level, the gravitational potential energy of the train at $x$ is

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-051.jpg?height=248&width=392&top_left_y=491&top_left_x=541)

Fig. 1.20.

$$
V=\int_{R}^{r} \frac{G m M}{R^{3}} r d r=\frac{G m M}{2 R^{3}}\left(r^{2}-R^{2}\right),
$$

where $m, M$ are the masses of the train and the earth respectively. Conservation of mechanical energy gives, as the train starts from rest at the earth's surface,

$$
\frac{m v^{2}}{2}+\frac{G m M\left(r^{2}-R^{2}\right)}{2 R^{3}}=0
$$

or

$$
v^{2}=\frac{g\left(R^{2}-r^{2}\right)}{R},
$$

where $g=G M / R^{2}$ is the acceleration of gravity at the earth's surface. As

$$
\begin{gathered}
r^{2}=h^{2}+(150-x)^{2}=\left(R^{2}-150^{2}\right)+(150-x)^{2}=R^{2}-300 x+x^{2}, \\
v^{2}=\frac{g x(300-x)}{R} .
\end{gathered}
$$

$v$ is maximum when $x=150 \mathrm{~km}$ :

$$
v_{\max }=\sqrt{\frac{9.8 \times 150 \times 150 \times 1000}{6400}}=185.6 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \text {. }
$$

The time from London to Paris is

$$
\begin{aligned}
T &=\int_{0}^{300} \frac{d x}{v}=\int_{0}^{300} \sqrt{\frac{R}{g}} \frac{d x}{\sqrt{x(300-x)}} \\
&=\int_{0}^{1} \sqrt{\frac{R}{g}} \frac{d t}{\sqrt{t(1-t)}}=\pi \sqrt{\frac{R}{g}}=42.3 \mathrm{~min} .
\end{aligned}
$$

1031.b.Problem Statement:
Three fixed point sources are equally spaced about the circumference of a circle of diameter $a$ centered at the origin (Fig. 1.21). The force exerted by each source on a point mass of mass $m$ is attractive and given by $\mathbf{F}=-k \mathbf{R}$, where $\mathbf{R}$ is a vector drawn from the source to the point mass. The point mass is placed in the force field at time $t=0$ with initial conditions $\mathbf{r}=\mathbf{r}_{0}$, $\dot{\mathbf{r}}=\mathbf{v}_{0}$

Use Newton's second law and solve the equation of motion for the initial conditions given above, namely, find $\mathbf{r}(t)$ in terms of $\mathbf{r}_{0}, \mathbf{v}_{0}$ and the parameters of the system.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-052.jpg?height=320&width=353&top_left_y=1282&top_left_x=588)

Fig. 1.21.
1031.b.Solution:
Let $\mathbf{r}_{1}, \mathbf{r}_{2}, \mathbf{r}_{3}$ be the position vectors of the three fixed point sources. As they are equally spaced on a circle, we have

$$
\mathbf{r}_{1}+\mathbf{r}_{2}+\mathbf{r}_{3}=0 .
$$

The force acting on the particle $m$ is

$$
\mathbf{F}=-k\left(\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}_{1}\right)-k\left(\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}_{2}\right)-k\left(\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}_{3}\right)=-3 k \mathbf{r} .
$$

The equation of the motion of the point mass is

$$
m \ddot{\mathbf{r}}+3 k \mathbf{r}=0,
$$

with the general solution

$$
\mathbf{r}(t)=\mathbf{a} \cos \left(\sqrt{\frac{3 k}{m}} t\right)+\mathbf{b} \sin \left(\sqrt{\frac{3 k}{m}} t\right),
$$

$\mathbf{a}, \mathbf{b}$ being constant vectors.

Using the initial conditions $\mathbf{r}(0)=\mathbf{r}_{0}, \dot{\mathbf{r}}(0)=\mathbf{v}_{0}$, we find

$$
\mathbf{a}=\mathbf{r}_{0}, \quad \mathbf{b}=\sqrt{\frac{m}{3 k}} \mathbf{v}_{0},
$$

and hence

$$
\mathbf{r}(t)=\mathbf{r}_{0} \cos \left(\sqrt{\frac{3 k}{m}} t\right)+\sqrt{\frac{m}{3 k}} \mathbf{v}_{0} \sin \left(\sqrt{\frac{3 k}{m}} t\right) .
$$

1032.c.Problem Statement:
A phonograph turntable in the $x y$ plane revolves at constant angular velocity $\omega$ around the origin. A small body sliding on the turntable has location $\mathrm{x}(t)=(x(t), y(t), 0)$. Here $x$ and $y$ are measured in an inertial frame, the lab frame. There are two forces in the lab frame: an elastic force of magnitude $k|\mathbf{x}|$ towards the origin, and a frictional force $-c(\dot{\mathbf{x}}-\mathbf{v})$, where $c$ is a constant and $\mathbf{v}$ is the velocity of the turntable at the body's location.

In (b), find $\mathbf{x}(t)$. Describe $\mathbf{x}(t)$ in words and/or with a rough sketch.
(UC, Berkeley)
1032.c.Solution:
The body has angular velocity $\omega$ around the origin so that $m \omega^{2}|\mathbf{x}|=$ $k|\mathbf{x}|$, giving $k=m \omega^{2}$.

In the lab frame the equation of motion for the small body is

$$
\begin{aligned}
m \ddot{\mathbf{x}} &=-k \mathbf{x}-c(\dot{\mathbf{x}}-\mathbf{v}) \\
&=-m \omega^{2} \mathbf{x}-c(\dot{\mathbf{x}}-\omega \times \mathbf{x})
\end{aligned}
$$

Let $x, y, \dot{x}, \dot{y}, \ddot{x}, \ddot{y}$ be the coordinates, velocity and acceleration components in the rotating frame attached to the turntable. In the lab frame we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\dot{\mathbf{x}} &=(\dot{x}-y \omega) \mathbf{i}+(\dot{y}+x \omega) \mathbf{j}, \\
\ddot{\mathbf{x}} &=\left(\ddot{x}-2 \dot{y} \omega-x \omega^{2}\right) \mathbf{i}+\left(\ddot{y}+2 \dot{x} \omega-y \omega^{2}\right) \mathbf{j}, \\
-k \mathbf{x} &=-k x \mathbf{i}-k y \mathbf{j} \\
-c(\dot{\mathbf{x}}-\omega \times \mathbf{x}) &=-c \dot{x} \mathbf{i}-x \dot{y} \mathbf{j}
\end{aligned}
$$

Note that in the above we have used $\omega \times \mathbf{i}=\omega \mathbf{j}, \boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{j}=-\omega \mathbf{i}$. The equation of motion in the lab frame is then written as

$$
\begin{aligned}
&m\left(\ddot{x}-2 \dot{y} \omega-x \omega^{2}\right)=-k x-c \dot{x}, \\
&m\left(\ddot{y}+2 \dot{x} \omega-y \omega^{2}\right)=-k y-c \dot{y} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Multiplying Eq.
(2) by $i \equiv \sqrt{-1}$, adding it to Eq.
(1) and setting $z=x+i y$, we obtain

$$
m \ddot{z}+(2 m \omega i+c) \dot{z}=0 .
$$

Integrating once we find

$$
\dot{z}=\dot{z}_{0} e^{-c t / m} e^{-i 2 \omega t},
$$

namely,

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\dot{x}=\left[\dot{x}_{0} \cos (2 \omega t)+\dot{y}_{0} \sin (2 \omega t)\right] e^{-c t / m}, \\
&\dot{y}=\left[-\dot{x}_{0} \sin (2 \omega t)+\dot{y}_{0} \cos (2 \omega t)\right] e^{-c t / m}
\end{aligned}
$$

By directly integrating Eqs.
(4) and (5) or by integrating Eq.
(3) and then using $z=x+i y$, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
x=& x_{0}+\frac{m\left(c \dot{x}_{0}+2 m \omega \dot{y}_{0}\right)}{c^{2}+4 m^{2} \omega^{2}} \\
&-\left[\frac{m\left(c \dot{x}_{0}+2 m \omega \dot{y}_{0}\right)}{c^{2}+4 m^{2} \omega^{2}} \cos (2 \omega t)-\frac{m\left(2 m \omega \dot{x}_{0}-c \dot{y}_{0}\right)}{c^{2}+4 m^{2} \omega^{2}} \sin (2 \omega t)\right] e^{-c t / m} \\
y=& y_{0}-\frac{m\left(2 m \omega \dot{x}_{0}-c \dot{y}_{0}\right)}{c^{2}+4 m^{2} \omega^{2}} \\
&+\left[\frac{m\left(2 m \omega \dot{x}_{0}-c \dot{y}_{0}\right)}{c^{2}+4 m^{2} \omega^{2}} \cos (2 \omega t)+\frac{m\left(c \dot{x}_{0}+2 m \omega \dot{y}_{0}\right)}{c^{2}+4 m^{2} \omega^{2}} \sin (2 \omega t)\right] e^{-c t / m}
\end{aligned}
$$

In the above, $\dot{x}_{0}, \dot{y}_{0}$ are the components of the velocity of the small body at $t=0$ in the rotating frame.

Equations (6) and (7) imply that, for the body on the turntable, even if $x, y$ may sometimes increase at first because of certain initial conditions, with the passage of time its velocity in the turntable frame will decrease and the body eventually stops at a fixed point on the turntable, with coordinates $\left(\left(x_{0}+m\left(c \dot{x}_{0}+2 m \omega \dot{y}_{0}\right)\right) /\left(c^{2}+4 m^{2} \omega^{2}\right),\left(y_{0}-m\left(2 m \omega \dot{x}_{0}-c \dot{y}_{0}\right)\right) /\left(c^{2}+4 m^{2} \omega^{2}\right)\right)$.

1033.Problem Statement:
A nonlinear oscillator has a potential given by

$$
U(x)=\frac{k x^{2}}{2}-\frac{m \lambda x^{3}}{3}, \quad \text { with } \lambda \text { small. }
$$

Find the solution of the equation of motion to first order in $\lambda$, assuming $x=0$ at $t=0$.
1033.Solution:
The equation of the motion of the nonlinear oscillator is

$$
\frac{m d^{2} x}{d t^{2}}=\frac{-d U(x)}{d x}=-k x+m \lambda x^{2}
$$

Neglecting the term $m \lambda x^{2}$, we obtain the zero-order solution of the equation

$$
x_{(0)}=A \sin (\omega t+\varphi),
$$

where $\omega=\sqrt{k / m}$ and $A$ is an arbitrary constant. As $x=0$ at $t=0, \varphi=0$ and we have

$$
x_{(0)}=A \sin (\omega t) .
$$

Suppose the first-order solution has the form $x_{(1)}=x_{(0)}+\lambda x_{1}$. Substituting it in the equation of motion and neglecting terms of orders higher $\operatorname{than} \lambda$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\ddot{x}_{1}+\omega^{2} x_{1} &=x_{(0)}^{2} \\
&=\frac{A^{2}}{2}[1-\cos (2 \omega t)] .
\end{aligned}
$$

To solve this equation, try a particular integral

$$
x_{1}=B+C \cos (2 \omega t) .
$$

Substitution gives

$$
-3 \omega^{2} C \cos (2 \omega t)+\omega^{2} B=\frac{A^{2}}{2}-\frac{A^{2}}{2} \cos (2 \omega t) .
$$

Comparison of coefficients gives

$$
B=\frac{A^{2}}{2 \omega^{2}}, \quad C=\frac{A^{2}}{6 \omega^{2}} .
$$

The homogeneous equation

$$
\ddot{x}_{1}+\omega^{2} x_{1}=0
$$

has solution

$$
x_{1}=D_{1} \sin (\omega t)+D_{2} \cos (\omega t) .
$$

Hence we have the complete solution

$$
x_{(1)}=\left(A+\lambda D_{1}\right) \sin (\omega t)+\lambda\left[\frac{A^{2}}{2 \omega^{2}}+D_{2} \cos (\omega t)+\frac{A^{2}}{6 \omega^{2}} \cos (2 \omega t)\right] .
$$

The initial condition $x=0$ at $t=0$ then gives

$$
D=-\frac{2 A^{2}}{3 \omega^{2}}
$$

and

$$
x_{(1)}=A^{\prime} \sin (\omega t)+\frac{\lambda A^{2}}{\omega^{2}}\left[\frac{1}{2}-\frac{2}{3} \cos (\omega t)+\frac{1}{6} \cos (2 \omega t)\right]
$$

where $A^{\prime}$ is an arbitrary constant. To determine $A^{\prime}$ and $A$, additional information such as the amplitude and the velocity at $t=0$ is required.

1035.a.Problem Statement:
A ball of mass $M$ is suspended from the ceiling by a massless spring with spring constant $k$ and relaxed length equal to zero. The spring will break if it is extended beyond a critical length $l_{c}\left(l_{c}>M g / k\right)$. An identical spring hangs below the ball (Fig. 1.22). If one slowly pulls on the end of the lower spring, the upper spring will break. If one pulls on the lower spring too rapidly, the lower spring will break. The object of this problem is to determine the force $F(t)$ which, when applied to the end of the lower spring, will cause both springs to break simultaneously.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-058.jpg?height=423&width=188&top_left_y=660&top_left_x=674)

Fig. 1.22.

Find an integral expression relating the length $x_{1}(t)$ of the upper spring to the applied force $F(t)$.
1035.a.Solution:
The equations of motion for the ball and the lower spring are

$$
\begin{aligned}
M \ddot{x}_{1} &=M g-k x_{1}+k x_{2}, \\
k x_{2} &=F(t) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Eliminating $x_{2}$, we obtain

$$
M \ddot{x}_{1}+k x_{1}=F(t)+M g .
$$

To eliminate the constant term, let $x_{1}=x+M g / k$. Equation (1) then becomes

$$
M \ddot{x}+k x=F(t) .
$$

Let $x=e^{i \omega t} y(t)$, where $\omega=\sqrt{k / M}$. The above becomes

$$
\ddot{y}+2 i \omega \dot{y}=\frac{F(t)}{M} e^{-i \omega t} .
$$

The homogeneous part of the above,

$$
\ddot{y}+2 i \omega \dot{y}=0,
$$

can be solved by letting $y=C_{1} e^{\alpha t}$, where $C_{1}$ and $\alpha$ are constants. Substitution gives $\alpha=-2 i \omega$.

A particular solution of (2) is obtained by letting $\dot{y}=e^{-2 i \omega t} f(t)$, which gives

$$
\frac{d f}{d t}=\frac{F(t)}{M} e^{i \omega t},
$$

or

$$
\dot{y}=e^{-2 i \omega t} \int \frac{F(t)}{M} e^{i \omega t} d t .
$$

Hence the general solution of (2) is

$$
\dot{y}=e^{-2 i \omega t}\left[\int \frac{F(t)}{M} e^{i \omega t} d t+C_{1}\right] \text {, }
$$

giving

$$
y=\int e^{-2 i \omega t}\left[\int \frac{F(\tau)}{M} e^{i \omega t} d \tau+C_{1}\right] d t+C_{2}
$$

and

$$
x_{1}=e^{i \omega t}\left\{\int e^{-2 i \omega t}\left[\int \frac{F(\tau)}{M} e^{i \omega \tau} d \tau+C_{1}\right] d t+C_{2}\right\}+\frac{M g}{k},
$$

where $C_{1}, C_{2}$ are constants of integration. For application to the problem, either the real or the imaginary part of the last expression is used as the general solution.
1035.a.Final Answer: $$e^{i \omega t}\left\{\int e^{-2 i \omega t}\left[\int \frac{F(\tau)}{M} e^{i \omega \tau} d \tau+C_{1}\right] d t+C_{2}\right\}+\frac{M g}{k}$$

1037.Solution:
Let $N_{\nu}$ be the number of photons of frequency $\nu$ passing through a unit area perpendicular to the direction of propagation in unit time, $I_{\nu}$ be the energy of sunlight of frequency $\nu$ radiated by the sun in unit time, and $R$ be the distance from the sun to the sphere. As $R \gg r$, the incident sunlight may be considered parallel and in a direction opposite to the $z$-axis, as shown in Fig. 1.26. Then

$$
I_{s}=\int I_{\nu} d \nu, \quad N_{\nu}=\frac{I_{\nu}}{4 \pi R^{2} h \nu} .
$$

The photons collide elastically with the perfectly reflecting sphere at its surface. During a time interval $\Delta t$, for an elementary surface $\Delta S$ at azimuth angle $\theta$, the change of the momentum of photons of frequency $\nu$ along the $z$-axis is

$$
\Delta P_{\nu z}=N_{\nu}\left[\frac{h \nu}{c}+\frac{h \nu}{c} \cos (2 \theta)\right] \cos \theta \Delta S \Delta t .
$$

This gives rise to a force of magnitude

$$
\Delta F_{\nu z}=\frac{\Delta P_{\nu z}}{\Delta t}=\frac{2 h \nu}{c} N_{\nu} \cos ^{3} \theta \Delta S .
$$

Then the total force exerted on the sphere by the sunlight of frequency $\nu$ is

$$
F_{\nu z}=\int d F_{\nu z}=\frac{2 h \nu}{c} \cdot \frac{I_{\nu}}{4 \pi R^{2} h \nu} \int_{0}^{\pi / 2} 2 \pi \cos ^{3} \theta \cdot \sin \theta \cdot r^{2} d \theta=\frac{I_{\nu} r^{2}}{4 R^{2} c} .
$$

Hence the total repelling force exerted by the sunlight is

$$
F_{z}=\int F_{\nu z} d \nu=\frac{I_{s} r^{2}}{4 R^{2} c} .
$$

The gravitational force the sun exerts on the sphere is

$$
F_{g}=\frac{G M_{s} m}{R^{2}},
$$

where $m=\rho \cdot(4 / 3) \pi r^{3}=(4 / 3) \pi r^{3}$ is the mass of the sphere. When the two forces balance, we have

$$
\frac{I_{s} r^{2}}{4 R^{2} \mathrm{c}}=\frac{4 G M_{s} \pi r^{3}}{3 R^{2}},
$$

or

$$
\begin{aligned}
r &=\frac{3 I_{s}}{16 \pi c G M_{s}} \\
&=\frac{3 \times 4 \times 10^{33}}{16 \times 3.14 \times 3 \times 10^{10} \times 6.67 \times 10^{-8} \times 2 \times 10^{33}} \\
&=5.97 \times 10^{-5} \mathrm{~cm} .
\end{aligned}
$$

1038.a.Problem Statement:
A particle of mass $m$ moves along a trajectory given by $x=x_{0} \cos \omega_{1} t$, $y=y_{0} \sin \omega_{2} t$.

Find the $x$ and $y$ components of the force. Under what condition is the force a central force?
1038.a.Solution:
Differentiating with respect to time, we obtain

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\dot{x}=-x_{0} \omega_{1} \sin \left(\omega_{1} t\right), & \ddot{x}=-x_{0} \omega_{1}^{2} \cos \left(\omega_{1} t\right), \\
\dot{y}=y_{0} \omega_{2} \cos \left(\omega_{2} t\right), & \ddot{y}=-y_{0} \omega_{2}^{2} \sin \left(\omega_{2} t\right) .
\end{array}
$$

Newton's second law gives

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{F} &=m(\ddot{x} \mathbf{i}+\ddot{y} \mathbf{j})=-m\left[x_{0} \omega_{1}^{2} \cos \left(\omega_{1} t\right) \mathbf{i}+y_{0} \omega_{2}^{2} \sin \left(\omega_{2} t\right) \mathbf{j}\right] \\
&=-m\left(\omega_{1}^{2} x \mathbf{i}+\omega_{2}^{2} y \mathbf{j}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

The $x$ and $y$ components of the force are therefore

$$
\begin{aligned}
&F_{x}=-m \omega_{1}^{2} x, \\
&F_{y}=-m \omega_{2}^{2} y .
\end{aligned}
$$

If $\omega_{1}=\omega_{2}, \mathbf{F}$ is a central force $\mathbf{F}=-m \omega_{1}^{2} \mathbf{r}$.

1038.b.Problem Statement:
A particle of mass $m$ moves along a trajectory given by $x=x_{0} \cos \omega_{1} t$, $y=y_{0} \sin \omega_{2} t$.

Find the potential energy as a function of $x$ and $y$.
1038.b.Solution:
Differentiating with respect to time, we obtain

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\dot{x}=-x_{0} \omega_{1} \sin \left(\omega_{1} t\right), & \ddot{x}=-x_{0} \omega_{1}^{2} \cos \left(\omega_{1} t\right), \\
\dot{y}=y_{0} \omega_{2} \cos \left(\omega_{2} t\right), & \ddot{y}=-y_{0} \omega_{2}^{2} \sin \left(\omega_{2} t\right) .
\end{array}
$$

Newton's second law gives

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{F} &=m(\ddot{x} \mathbf{i}+\ddot{y} \mathbf{j})=-m\left[x_{0} \omega_{1}^{2} \cos \left(\omega_{1} t\right) \mathbf{i}+y_{0} \omega_{2}^{2} \sin \left(\omega_{2} t\right) \mathbf{j}\right] \\
&=-m\left(\omega_{1}^{2} x \mathbf{i}+\omega_{2}^{2} y \mathbf{j}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

The $x$ and $y$ components of the force are therefore

$$
\begin{aligned}
&F_{x}=-m \omega_{1}^{2} x, \\
&F_{y}=-m \omega_{2}^{2} y .
\end{aligned}
$$

If $\omega_{1}=\omega_{2}, \mathbf{F}$ is a central force $\mathbf{F}=-m \omega_{1}^{2} \mathbf{r}$.From

$$
\mathbf{F}=-\nabla V,
$$

i.e.

$$
F_{x}=-\frac{\partial V}{\partial x}, \quad F_{y}=-\frac{\partial V}{\partial y},
$$

we obtain the potential energy

$$
V=\frac{1}{2} m\left(\omega_{1}^{2} x^{2}+\omega_{2}^{2} y^{2}\right)
$$

Note that we take the zero potential level at the origin.

1038.c.Problem Statement:
A particle of mass $m$ moves along a trajectory given by $x=x_{0} \cos \omega_{1} t$, $y=y_{0} \sin \omega_{2} t$.

Determine the kinetic energy of the particle. Show that the total energy of the particle is conserved.
1038.c.Solution:
Differentiating with respect to time, we obtain

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\dot{x}=-x_{0} \omega_{1} \sin \left(\omega_{1} t\right), & \ddot{x}=-x_{0} \omega_{1}^{2} \cos \left(\omega_{1} t\right), \\
\dot{y}=y_{0} \omega_{2} \cos \left(\omega_{2} t\right), & \ddot{y}=-y_{0} \omega_{2}^{2} \sin \left(\omega_{2} t\right) .
\end{array}
$$

Newton's second law gives

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{F} &=m(\ddot{x} \mathbf{i}+\ddot{y} \mathbf{j})=-m\left[x_{0} \omega_{1}^{2} \cos \left(\omega_{1} t\right) \mathbf{i}+y_{0} \omega_{2}^{2} \sin \left(\omega_{2} t\right) \mathbf{j}\right] \\
&=-m\left(\omega_{1}^{2} x \mathbf{i}+\omega_{2}^{2} y \mathbf{j}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

The $x$ and $y$ components of the force are therefore

$$
\begin{aligned}
&F_{x}=-m \omega_{1}^{2} x, \\
&F_{y}=-m \omega_{2}^{2} y .
\end{aligned}
$$

If $\omega_{1}=\omega_{2}, \mathbf{F}$ is a central force $\mathbf{F}=-m \omega_{1}^{2} \mathbf{r}$.From

$$
\mathbf{F}=-\nabla V,
$$

i.e.

$$
F_{x}=-\frac{\partial V}{\partial x}, \quad F_{y}=-\frac{\partial V}{\partial y},
$$

we obtain the potential energy

$$
V=\frac{1}{2} m\left(\omega_{1}^{2} x^{2}+\omega_{2}^{2} y^{2}\right)
$$

Note that we take the zero potential level at the origin.The kinetic energy of the particle is

$$
T=\frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{x}^{2}+\dot{y}^{2}\right)=\frac{1}{2} m\left[x_{0}^{2} \omega_{1}^{2} \sin ^{2}\left(\omega_{1} t\right)+y_{0}^{2} \omega_{2}^{2} \cos ^{2}\left(\omega_{2} t\right)\right] .
$$

The total energy is then

$$
\begin{aligned}
E=& T+V \\
=& \frac{1}{2} m\left[x_{0}^{2} \omega_{1}^{2} \sin ^{2}\left(\omega_{1} t\right)+y_{0}^{2} \omega_{2}^{2} \cos ^{2}\left(\omega_{2} t\right)\right] \\
&+\omega_{1}^{2} x_{0}^{2} \cos ^{2}\left(\omega_{1} t\right)+\omega_{2}^{2} y_{0}^{2} \sin ^{2}\left(\omega_{2} t\right) \\
=& \frac{1}{2} m\left(x_{0}^{2} \omega_{1}^{2}+y_{0}^{2} \omega_{2}^{2}\right) \\
=& \text { constant. }
\end{aligned}
$$

It is therefore conserved.
