1040.Problem Statement:
A long-range rocket is fired from the surface of the earth (radius $R$ ) with velocity $\mathbf{v}=\left(v_{r}, v_{\theta}\right)$ (Fig. 1.29). Neglecting air friction and the rotation of the earth (but using the exact gravitational field), obtain an equation to determine the maximum height $H$ achieved by the trajectory. Solve it to lowest order in $(H / R)$ and verify that it gives a familiar result for the case that $\mathbf{v}$ is vertical.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-069.jpg?height=258&width=204&top_left_y=400&top_left_x=621)

Fig. 1.29.
1040.Solution:
Both the angular momentum and mechanical energy of the rocket are conserved under the action of gravity, a central force. Considering the initial state and the final state when the rocket achieves maximum height, we have

$$
\begin{gathered}
m R v_{\theta}=m(R+H) v_{\theta}^{\prime} \\
\frac{1}{2} m\left(v_{\theta}^{2}+v_{r}^{2}\right)-\frac{G M m}{R}=\frac{1}{2} m v_{\theta}^{\prime 2}-\frac{G M m}{R+H},
\end{gathered}
$$

where the prime refers to the final state at which the radial component of its velocity vanishes, $m$ and $M$ are the masses of the rocket and the earth respectively. Combining the above two equations we obtain

$$
\frac{1}{2} m\left(v_{\theta}^{2}+v_{r}^{2}\right)-\frac{G M m}{R}=\frac{1}{2} m\left(\frac{R}{R+H}\right)^{2} v_{\theta}^{2}-\frac{G M m}{R+H},
$$

which gives the maximum height $H$. Considering only terms first order in $H / R$, we have

$$
\frac{1}{2} m\left(v_{r}^{2}+v_{\theta}^{2}\right)-\frac{G M m}{R} \approx \frac{1}{2} m\left(1-\frac{2 H}{R}\right) v_{\theta}^{2}-\frac{G M m}{R}\left(1-\frac{H}{R}\right),
$$

and hence

$$
H \approx \frac{v_{r}^{2} R}{2\left(\frac{G M}{R}-v_{\theta}^{2}\right)} .
$$

For vertical launching, $v_{\theta}=0, v_{r}=v$, and if $H / R$ is small, we can consider $g$ as constant with $g=G M / R^{2}$. We then obtain the familiar formula

$$
H \approx \frac{v^{2}}{2\left(\frac{G M}{R^{2}}\right)}=\frac{v^{2}}{2 g} .
$$

1041.a.Problem Statement:
In a few weeks Mariner 9 will be launched from Cape Kennedy on a mission to Mars. Assume that this spacecraft is launched into an elliptical orbit about the sun with perihelion at the earth's orbit and aphelion at Mar's orbit (Fig. 1.30).

Find the values of the parameters $\lambda$ and $\varepsilon$ of the orbit equation $r=\lambda(1+\varepsilon) /(1+\varepsilon \cos \theta)$ and sketch the orbit.

Mean distance of Mars from the sun $=1.5$ A.U.

Mean distance of the earth from the sun $=1 \mathrm{~A} . \mathrm{U}$.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-070.jpg?height=347&width=515&top_left_y=1262&top_left_x=610)

Fig. 1.30,
1041.a.Solution:
Let $R_{1}$ be the distance of the earth from the sun and $R_{2}$ that of Mars from the sun. Then 

$$
\begin{aligned}
&R_{1}=\frac{\lambda(1+\varepsilon)}{1+\varepsilon}=\lambda, \\
&R_{2}=\frac{\lambda(1+\varepsilon)}{1-\varepsilon} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Solving the equations, we obtain $\lambda=R_{1}=1$ A.U., $\varepsilon=0.2$.

1041.b.Problem Statement:
In a few weeks Mariner 9 will be launched from Cape Kennedy on a mission to Mars. Assume that this spacecraft is launched into an elliptical orbit about the sun with perihelion at the earth's orbit and aphelion at Mar's orbit (Fig. 1.30).

Use Kepler's third law to calculate the time duration of the mission to Mars on this orbit.

Mean distance of Mars from the sun $=1.5$ A.U.

Mean distance of the earth from the sun $=1 \mathrm{~A} . \mathrm{U}$.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-070.jpg?height=347&width=515&top_left_y=1262&top_left_x=610)

Fig. 1.30,
1041.b.Solution:
Let $R_{1}$ be the distance of the earth from the sun and $R_{2}$ that of Mars from the sun. Then 

$$
\begin{aligned}
&R_{1}=\frac{\lambda(1+\varepsilon)}{1+\varepsilon}=\lambda, \\
&R_{2}=\frac{\lambda(1+\varepsilon)}{1-\varepsilon} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Solving the equations, we obtain $\lambda=R_{1}=1$ A.U., $\varepsilon=0.2$.Let $T_{1}$ and $T$ be the revolutional periods of the earth and Mariner 9 respectively. According to Kepler's third law, $T^{2} / a^{3}=$ constant,

$$
\frac{T^{2}}{\left(\frac{R_{1}+R_{2}}{2}\right)^{3}}=\frac{T_{1}^{2}}{R_{1}^{3}}
$$

or

$$
T=\left(\frac{R_{1}+R_{2}}{2 R_{1}}\right)^{3 / 2} T_{1}=\left(\frac{1}{1-\varepsilon}\right)^{3 / 2} T_{1}=1.25^{3 / 2} T_{1}=1.40 \text { years } .
$$

The mission to Mars on this orbit takes $0.70$ year.

1042.Problem Statement:
A comet in an orbit about the sun has a velocity $10 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{sec}$ at aphelion and $80 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{sec}$ at perihelion (Fig. 1.31). If the earth's velocity in a circular orbit is $30 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{sec}$ and the radius of its orbit is $1.5 \times 10^{8} \mathrm{~km}$, find the aphelion distance $R_{a}$ for the comet.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-071.jpg?height=191&width=308&top_left_y=1627&top_left_x=575)

Fig. 1.31.
1042.Solution:
Let $v$ be the velocity of the earth, $R$ the radius of the earth's orbit, $m$ and $m_{s}$ the masses of the earth and the sun respectively. Then

$$
\frac{m v^{2}}{R}=\frac{G m m_{s}}{R^{2}},
$$

or

$$
G m_{s}=R v^{2} .
$$

By the conservation of the mechanical energy and of the angular momentum of the comet, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{-G m_{c} m_{s}}{R_{a}}+\frac{m_{c} v_{a}^{2}}{2} &=\frac{-G m_{c} m_{s}}{R_{p}}+\frac{m_{c} v_{p}^{2}}{2}, \\
m_{c} R_{a} v_{a} &=m_{c} R_{p} v_{p},
\end{aligned}
$$

where $m_{c}$ is the mass of the comet, and $v_{a}$ and $v_{p}$ are the velocities of the comet at aphelion and at perihelion respectively. The above equations give

$$
R_{a}=\frac{2 G m_{s}}{v_{a}\left(v_{a}+v_{p}\right)}=\frac{2 R v^{2}}{v_{a}\left(v_{a}+v_{p}\right)}=3 \times 10^{8} \mathrm{~km} \text {. }
$$

1043.a.Problem Statement:
A classical particle with energy $E_{0}$ and angular momentum $L$ about point $O$ enters a region in which there is an attractive central potential $V=-G(r)$ centered on point $O$. The particle is scattered by the potential.

Begin by assuming conservation of energy and angular momentum, and find the differential equation for $d x / d r$ in terms of $E_{0}, L, G(r)$, and $r$ (and the particle mass $m$ ).
1043.a.Solution:
$$
\begin{aligned}
E_{0} &=\frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{r}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}\right)-G(r), \\
L &=m r^{2} \dot{\theta},
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\theta$ is shown in Fig. 1.32. Then

$$
\dot{r}^{2}=\frac{2\left(E_{0}+G\right)}{m}-\frac{L^{2}}{m^{2} r^{2}} .
$$

As

$$
\frac{d r}{d t}=\frac{d r}{d \theta} \cdot \frac{d \theta}{d t}=\dot{\theta} \frac{d r}{d \theta}, \quad \dot{\theta}=\frac{L}{m r^{2}},
$$

the above equation can be written as

$$
\left(\frac{d r}{d \theta}\right)^{2}=\frac{m^{2} r^{4}}{L^{2}}\left[\frac{2\left(E_{0}+G\right)}{m}-\frac{L^{2}}{m^{2} r^{2}}\right]
$$

giving

$$
\frac{d r}{d \theta}=\pm \sqrt{\frac{2 m\left(E_{0}+G\right) r^{4}}{L^{2}}-r^{2}} .
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-073.jpg?height=363&width=314&top_left_y=967&top_left_x=578)

Fig. 1,32.

1043.b.Problem Statement:
A classical particle with energy $E_{0}$ and angular momentum $L$ about point $O$ enters a region in which there is an attractive central potential $V=-G(r)$ centered on point $O$. The particle is scattered by the potential.

Find an equation for the distance of closest approach, $r_{\min }$, in terms of $E, L, G\left(r_{\min }\right)$, and $m$.
1043.b.Solution:
$$
\begin{aligned}
E_{0} &=\frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{r}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}\right)-G(r), \\
L &=m r^{2} \dot{\theta},
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\theta$ is shown in Fig. 1.32. Then

$$
\dot{r}^{2}=\frac{2\left(E_{0}+G\right)}{m}-\frac{L^{2}}{m^{2} r^{2}} .
$$

As

$$
\frac{d r}{d t}=\frac{d r}{d \theta} \cdot \frac{d \theta}{d t}=\dot{\theta} \frac{d r}{d \theta}, \quad \dot{\theta}=\frac{L}{m r^{2}},
$$

the above equation can be written as

$$
\left(\frac{d r}{d \theta}\right)^{2}=\frac{m^{2} r^{4}}{L^{2}}\left[\frac{2\left(E_{0}+G\right)}{m}-\frac{L^{2}}{m^{2} r^{2}}\right]
$$

giving

$$
\frac{d r}{d \theta}=\pm \sqrt{\frac{2 m\left(E_{0}+G\right) r^{4}}{L^{2}}-r^{2}} .
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-073.jpg?height=363&width=314&top_left_y=967&top_left_x=578)

Fig. 1,32.At closest approach $r=r_{\mathrm{min}}, \dot{r}=0$. Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
E_{0} &=\frac{1}{2} m r_{\min }^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}-G\left(r_{\min }\right) \\
&=\frac{1}{2} m r_{\min }^{2} \cdot \frac{L^{2}}{m^{2} r_{\min }^{4}}-G\left(r_{\min }\right) \\
&=\frac{L^{2}}{2 m r_{\min }^{2}}-G\left(r_{\min }\right),
\end{aligned}
$$

or 

$$
r_{\min }=\frac{L}{\sqrt{2 m\left[E_{0}+G\left(r_{\min }\right)\right]}} .
$$

The result can also be obtained by putting $d r / d \theta=0$.

1044.Problem Statement: A comet moves toward the sun with initial velocity $v_{0}$. The mass of the sun is $M$ and its radius is $R$. Find the total cross section $\sigma$ for striking the sun. Take the sun to be at rest and ignore all other bodies.
1044.Solution:
Let the impact parameter of the comet be $b$. At the closest approach to the sun (closest distance $r$ from the sun's center), we have from the conservation of mechanical energy and angular momentum

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{m V_{0}^{2}}{2} &=\frac{m V^{2}}{2}-\frac{G M m}{r}, \\
m b V_{0} &=m r V,
\end{aligned}
$$

where $m$ is the mass of the comet and $V$ its velocity at closest approach. From these, we find

$$
b=r \sqrt{1+\frac{2 G M}{V_{0}^{2} r}} .
$$

If $r<R$, the comet will strike the sun. Hence the total cross section for striking the sun is

$$
\sigma=\pi[b(R)]^{2}=\pi R^{2}\left(1+\frac{2 G M}{V_{0}^{2} R}\right) .
$$

1046.a.Problem Statement:
A particle of mass $m$ is projected from infinity with a velocity $V_{0}$ in a manner such that it would pass a distance $b$ from a fixed center of inverse-square repulsive force (magnitude $k / r^{2}$, where $k$ is a constant) if it were not deflected. Find:

the distance of closest approach,
1046.a.Solution:
When the particle is at the closest distance from the fixed center of force, $\dot{r}=0$. Conservation of energy gives

$$
\frac{m V_{0}^{2}}{2}=\frac{k}{R}+\frac{m V^{2}}{2},
$$

where $R$ is the closest distance and $V(=R \dot{\theta})$ is the speed of the particle when it reaches the pericenter. Conservation of angular momentum gives

$$
J=V_{0} m b=m V R,
$$

i.e.,

$$
V=\frac{V_{0} b}{R} .
$$

Hence

$$
\frac{m V_{0}^{2}}{2}=\frac{k}{R}+\frac{m}{2} \frac{V_{0}^{2} b^{2}}{R^{2}},
$$

or

$$
R^{2}-\frac{2 k R}{m V_{0}^{2}}-b^{2}=0 \text {, }
$$

giving the closest distance

$$
R=\frac{k}{m V_{0}^{2}}+\sqrt{\left(\frac{k}{m V_{0}^{2}}\right)^{2}+b^{2}} .
$$

1046.b.Problem Statement:
A particle of mass $m$ is projected from infinity with a velocity $V_{0}$ in a manner such that it would pass a distance $b$ from a fixed center of inverse-square repulsive force (magnitude $k / r^{2}$, where $k$ is a constant) if it were not deflected. Find:

the angular deflection which actually occurs,
1046.b.Solution:
When the particle is at the closest distance from the fixed center of force, $\dot{r}=0$. Conservation of energy gives

$$
\frac{m V_{0}^{2}}{2}=\frac{k}{R}+\frac{m V^{2}}{2},
$$

where $R$ is the closest distance and $V(=R \dot{\theta})$ is the speed of the particle when it reaches the pericenter. Conservation of angular momentum gives

$$
J=V_{0} m b=m V R,
$$

i.e.,

$$
V=\frac{V_{0} b}{R} .
$$

Hence

$$
\frac{m V_{0}^{2}}{2}=\frac{k}{R}+\frac{m}{2} \frac{V_{0}^{2} b^{2}}{R^{2}},
$$

or

$$
R^{2}-\frac{2 k R}{m V_{0}^{2}}-b^{2}=0 \text {, }
$$

giving the closest distance

$$
R=\frac{k}{m V_{0}^{2}}+\sqrt{\left(\frac{k}{m V_{0}^{2}}\right)^{2}+b^{2}} .
$$The trajectory of the particle is shown in Fig. 1.33. The impulse of the force $\mathbf{F}$ acting on the particle is

$$
\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \mathbf{F} d t=m \Delta \mathbf{V},
$$

where $\Delta \mathbf{V}=\mathbf{V}_{f}-\mathbf{V}_{i}$ with $\left|\mathbf{V}_{f}\right|=\left|\mathbf{V}_{i}\right|=V_{0}$. Consider the component of the impulse in the direction of $V_{i}$. We have

$$
\begin{aligned}
-\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} F \cos \theta^{\prime} \frac{d t}{d \theta^{\prime}} d \theta^{\prime} &=\frac{m}{v_{0}}\left(\mathbf{V}_{f} \cdot \mathbf{V}_{i}-V_{i}^{2}\right) \\
&=m V_{0}(\cos 2 \theta-1) .
\end{aligned}
$$

As $F=\frac{k}{r^{2}}, m r^{2} \dot{\theta}^{\prime}=J$, the left-hand side is

$$
-\frac{m k}{J} \int_{0}^{\pi-2 \theta} \cos \theta^{\prime} d \theta^{\prime}=-\frac{m k}{J} \sin 2 \theta .
$$

Hence

$$
\frac{2 m k}{J} \sin \theta \cos \theta=2 m V_{0} \sin ^{2} \theta,
$$

or

$$
\cot \theta=\frac{J V_{0}}{k}=\frac{m V_{0}^{2} b}{k}=\frac{2 E b}{k}
$$

with $E=\frac{1}{2} m V_{0}^{2}$, which gives the angular deflection $2 \theta$.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-077.jpg?height=286&width=516&top_left_y=1004&top_left_x=479)

Fig, 1.33.

1046.c.Problem Statement:
A particle of mass $m$ is projected from infinity with a velocity $V_{0}$ in a manner such that it would pass a distance $b$ from a fixed center of inverse-square repulsive force (magnitude $k / r^{2}$, where $k$ is a constant) if it were not deflected. Find:

the differential scattering cross section $d \sigma / d \Omega$ for a homogeneous beam of particles scattered by this potential.
1046.c.Solution:
When the particle is at the closest distance from the fixed center of force, $\dot{r}=0$. Conservation of energy gives

$$
\frac{m V_{0}^{2}}{2}=\frac{k}{R}+\frac{m V^{2}}{2},
$$

where $R$ is the closest distance and $V(=R \dot{\theta})$ is the speed of the particle when it reaches the pericenter. Conservation of angular momentum gives

$$
J=V_{0} m b=m V R,
$$

i.e.,

$$
V=\frac{V_{0} b}{R} .
$$

Hence

$$
\frac{m V_{0}^{2}}{2}=\frac{k}{R}+\frac{m}{2} \frac{V_{0}^{2} b^{2}}{R^{2}},
$$

or

$$
R^{2}-\frac{2 k R}{m V_{0}^{2}}-b^{2}=0 \text {, }
$$

giving the closest distance

$$
R=\frac{k}{m V_{0}^{2}}+\sqrt{\left(\frac{k}{m V_{0}^{2}}\right)^{2}+b^{2}} .
$$The trajectory of the particle is shown in Fig. 1.33. The impulse of the force $\mathbf{F}$ acting on the particle is

$$
\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \mathbf{F} d t=m \Delta \mathbf{V},
$$

where $\Delta \mathbf{V}=\mathbf{V}_{f}-\mathbf{V}_{i}$ with $\left|\mathbf{V}_{f}\right|=\left|\mathbf{V}_{i}\right|=V_{0}$. Consider the component of the impulse in the direction of $V_{i}$. We have

$$
\begin{aligned}
-\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} F \cos \theta^{\prime} \frac{d t}{d \theta^{\prime}} d \theta^{\prime} &=\frac{m}{v_{0}}\left(\mathbf{V}_{f} \cdot \mathbf{V}_{i}-V_{i}^{2}\right) \\
&=m V_{0}(\cos 2 \theta-1) .
\end{aligned}
$$

As $F=\frac{k}{r^{2}}, m r^{2} \dot{\theta}^{\prime}=J$, the left-hand side is

$$
-\frac{m k}{J} \int_{0}^{\pi-2 \theta} \cos \theta^{\prime} d \theta^{\prime}=-\frac{m k}{J} \sin 2 \theta .
$$

Hence

$$
\frac{2 m k}{J} \sin \theta \cos \theta=2 m V_{0} \sin ^{2} \theta,
$$

or

$$
\cot \theta=\frac{J V_{0}}{k}=\frac{m V_{0}^{2} b}{k}=\frac{2 E b}{k}
$$

with $E=\frac{1}{2} m V_{0}^{2}$, which gives the angular deflection $2 \theta$.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-077.jpg?height=286&width=516&top_left_y=1004&top_left_x=479)

Fig, 1.33.The cross section corresponding to impact parameters between $b$ and $b+d b$ is $d \sigma=2 \pi b d b$.

As $b=\frac{k}{2 E} \cot \theta$

$$
d b=\frac{k}{2 E} \csc ^{2} \theta d \theta
$$

using the absolute value. Thus

$$
d \sigma=2 \pi\left(\frac{k}{2 E}\right)^{2} \frac{\cos \theta}{\sin ^{3} \theta} d \theta .
$$

Then, as the scattering angle is $2 \theta$,

$$
d \Omega=2 \pi \sin 2 \theta d(2 \theta)=8 \pi \cos \theta \sin \theta d \theta,
$$

and thus

$$
\frac{d \sigma}{d \Omega}=\frac{1}{4}\left(\frac{k}{2 E}\right)^{2} \frac{1}{\sin ^{4} \theta},
$$

which is just Rutherford's scattering formula.

1047.c.Problem Statement:
Consider a planet of mass $m$ in orbit around a sun of mass $M$. Assume further that there is a uniform distribution of dust, of density $\rho$, throughout the space surrounding the sun and the planet.

Assume $F^{\prime}$ is small compared with the solar attraction and consider an orbit just slightly deviating from the circular orbit of part (b). By considering the frequencies of the radial and the azimuthal motion, show that the orbit is a precessing ellipse and calculate the angular frequency of precession, $\omega_{\rho}$, in terms of $r_{0}, \rho, G$ and $M$.
1047.c.Solution:
The mass of the dust in a sphere of radius $r$ centered at the sun is

$$
M_{\text {dust }}=\frac{4 \pi r^{3} \rho}{3} .
$$

If $r$ is the distance of the planet from the sun, the gravitational force on the planet due to the attraction of the dust is, on account of the inverse distance square nature of gravitation, as if all the dust were concentrated at the sun. In other words, 

$$
F^{\prime}=\frac{-M_{\mathrm{dust}} m G}{r^{2}}=\frac{-4 \pi r^{3} \rho}{3} \frac{m G}{r^{2}}=\frac{-4 \pi \rho G m r}{3}=-m k r
$$

The planet has acceleration $\left(\ddot{r}-r \dot{\theta}^{2}, 2 \dot{r} \dot{\theta}+r \ddot{\theta}\right)$ in polar coordinates. Its equations of motion are therefore

$$
\begin{aligned}
&m \ddot{r}=\frac{-G M m}{r^{2}}-m k r+m r \dot{\theta}^{2}, \\
&m r \ddot{\theta}+2 m \dot{r} \dot{\theta}=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

Multiplying (2) by $r$, we have

$$
\frac{d\left(m r^{2} \dot{\theta}\right)}{d t}=0,
$$

or

$$
m r^{2} \dot{\theta}=L,
$$

where $L$ is a constant. Thus the angular momentum $L$ is a constant of the motion. Writing

$$
m r \dot{\theta}^{2}=\frac{L^{2}}{m r^{3}},
$$

the radial equation becomes

$$
m \ddot{r}=\frac{-G M m}{r^{2}}-m k r+\frac{L^{2}}{m r^{3}} .
$$

For a circular orbit, $\ddot{r}=0$, and we have the equation for the radius $r_{0}$ of the orbit:

$$
\frac{-G M m}{r_{0}^{2}}-m k r_{0}+\frac{L^{2}}{m r_{0}^{3}}=0 .
$$

Let $\eta$ express a small radial excursion around $r_{0}$, i.e. $\eta=r-r_{0}$, in terms of which (1) becomes

$$
\begin{aligned}
m \ddot{\eta} &=-\frac{G M m}{\left(\eta+r_{0}\right)^{2}}-m k\left(\eta+r_{0}\right)+\frac{L^{2}}{m\left(r_{0}+\eta\right)^{3}} \\
&=-\frac{G M m}{r_{0}^{2}\left(1+\frac{\eta}{r_{0}}\right)^{2}}-m k r_{0}\left(1+\frac{\eta}{r_{0}}\right)+\frac{L^{2}}{m r_{0}^{3}\left(1+\frac{\eta}{r_{0}}\right)^{3}} \\
& \approx-\frac{G M m}{r_{0}^{2}}\left(1-\frac{2 \eta}{r_{0}}\right)-m k r_{0}\left(1+\frac{\eta}{r_{0}}\right)+\frac{L^{2}}{m r_{0}^{3}}\left(1-\frac{3 \eta}{r_{0}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

as $\eta \ll r_{0}$. Making use of the equation for circular orbit, we rewrite the above as

$$
\begin{aligned}
m \ddot{\eta} &=\frac{2 \eta}{r_{0}}\left(\frac{G M m}{r_{0}^{2}}\right)-\frac{3 \eta}{r_{0}} \frac{L^{2}}{m r_{0}^{3}}-m k \eta \\
&=-\eta\left[\frac{L^{2}}{m r_{0}^{4}}+m k+\frac{2}{r_{0}}\left(-\frac{G M m}{r_{0}^{2}}+\frac{L^{2}}{m r_{0}^{3}}\right)\right] \\
&=-\eta\left[\frac{L^{2}}{m r_{0}^{4}}+3 k m\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

or

$$
\ddot{\eta}=-\left(\frac{L^{2}}{m^{2} r_{0}^{4}}+3 k\right) \eta .
$$

This is the equation of a harmonic oscillator with angular frequency

$$
\omega_{r}=\sqrt{\frac{L^{2}}{m^{2} r_{0}^{4}}+3 k} .
$$

As the radial oscillation frequency is slightly larger than the azimuthal frequency $\frac{L}{m r_{0}^{2}}$, the orbit is a precessing ellipse. of dust:

To first order in $\rho$ the azimuthal frequency is not affected by the presence

$$
\dot{\theta}=\frac{L}{m r_{0}^{2}}=\omega_{0} .
$$

The precession frequency is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\omega_{p} &=\omega_{r}-\omega_{0} \\
&=\sqrt{\frac{L^{2}}{m^{2} r_{0}^{4}}+3 k-\frac{L}{m r_{0}^{2}}} \\
&=\frac{L}{m r_{0}^{2}}\left(\sqrt{1+\frac{3 k m^{2} r_{0}^{4}}{L^{2}}}-1\right) \\
& \approx \frac{L}{m r_{0}^{2}} \cdot \frac{3}{2} \frac{k m^{2} r_{0}^{2}}{L^{2}} \\
&=\frac{3}{2} \frac{m k r_{0}^{2}}{L} .
\end{aligned}
$$

In order to express $\omega_{p}$ in terms of $\rho, G, m$ and $r_{0}$, use the expression of $L$ for $k=0$ (any error is second order in $\omega_{p}$ ):

$$
L=\sqrt{G M m^{2} r_{0}} .
$$

Then

$$
\omega_{p}=\frac{3}{2} m \cdot \frac{4 \pi}{3} \rho G \frac{r_{0}^{2}}{\sqrt{G M m^{2} r_{0}}}=2 \pi \rho\left(\frac{r_{0}^{3} G}{M}\right)^{1 / 2}
$$

1048.c.Problem Statement:
A meteorite of mass $1.6 \times 10^{3} \mathrm{~kg}$ moves about the earth in a circular orbit at an altitude of $4.2 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{~m}$ above the surface. It suddenly makes a head-on collision with another meteorite that is much lighter, and loses $2.0 \%$ of its kinetic energy without changing its direction of motion or its total mass.

Find the meteorite's distance of closest approach to the earth after the collision.
1048.c.Solution:
The laws of conservation of mechanical energy and conservation of angular momentum apply to the motion of the heavy meteorite after its collision.
For the initial circular motion, $E<0$, so after the collision we still have $E<0$. After it loses $2.0 \%$ of its kinetic energy, the heavy meteorite will move in an elliptic orbit.

From

$$
\frac{m v^{2}}{r}=\frac{G m M}{r^{2}},
$$

we obtain the meteorite's kinetic energy before collision:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{1}{2} m v^{2} &=\frac{G m M}{2 r}=\frac{m g R^{2}}{2 r} \\
&=\frac{m \times 9.8 \times 10^{3} \times 6400^{2}}{2(6400+4200)}=1.89 \times 10^{7} \mathrm{~m} \text { Joules },
\end{aligned}
$$

where $m$ is the mass of the meteorite in kg. The potential energy of the meteorite before collision is

$$
-\frac{G m M}{r}=-m v^{2}=-3.78 \times 10^{7} m \text { Joules } .
$$

During the collision, the heavy meteorite's potential energy remains constant, while its kinetic energy is suddenly reduced to

$$
1.89 \times 10^{7} \mathrm{~m} \times 98 \%=1.85 \times 10^{7} \mathrm{~m} \text { Joules. }
$$

Hence the total mechanical energy of the meteorite after the collision is

$$
E=(1.85-3.78) \times 10^{7} \mathrm{~m}=-1.93 \times 10^{7} \mathrm{~m} \text { Joules } .
$$

From

$$
E=\frac{-G m M}{2 a}=\frac{-m R^{2} g}{2 a},
$$

we obtain the major axis of the ellipse as

$$
\begin{aligned}
2 a &=\frac{R^{2} g}{1.93 \times 10^{7}}=\frac{\left(6400 \times 10^{3}\right)^{2} \times 9.8}{1.93 \times 10^{7}} \\
&=2.08 \times 10^{7} \mathrm{~m}=2.08 \times 10^{4} \mathrm{~km} .
\end{aligned}
$$

As after the collision, the velocity of the heavy meteorite is still perpendicular to the radius vector from the center of the earth, the meteorite is at the apogee of the elliptic orbit. Then the distance of the apogee from the center of the earth is $6400+4200=10600 \mathrm{~km}$ and the distance of the perigee from the center of the earth is

$$
r_{\min }=20800-10600=10200 \mathrm{~km} .
$$

Thus the meteorite's distance of closest approach to the earth after the collision is $10200-6400=3800 \mathrm{~km}$.

From the above calculations, we see that it is unnecessary to know the mass of the meteorite. Whatever the mass of the meteorite, the answer is the same as long as the conditions remain unchanged.

1050.b.Problem Statement:
The interaction between an atom and an ion at distances greater than contact is given by the potential energy $V(r)=-C r^{-4} . \quad\left(C=e^{2} P_{a}^{2} / 2\right.$, where $e$ is the charge and $P_{a}$ the polarizability of the atom.)

If the total energy of the ion exceeds $V_{0}$, the maximum value of the effective potential energy, the ion can strike the atom. Find $V_{0}$ in terms of the angular momentum $L$.
1050.b.Solution:
The effective potential energy as a function of $r$ is

$$
V_{\mathrm{eff}}(r)=\frac{-C}{r^{4}}+\frac{L^{2}}{2 m r^{2}},
$$

where $L$ is the angular momentum of the ion about the force center, and $m$ is the mass of the ion. Its variation with $r$ is shown in Fig. 1.35.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-084.jpg?height=599&width=533&top_left_y=1243&top_left_x=494)

Fig. 1.35.
To find the maximum of $V_{\text {eff }}, V_{0}$, we set

$$
\frac{d V_{\mathrm{eff}}}{d r}=\frac{4 C}{r^{5}}-\frac{L^{2}}{m r^{3}}=\left(\frac{4 C}{r^{2}}-\frac{L^{2}}{m}\right) \frac{1}{r^{3}}=0 .
$$

The solutions are

$$
r_{1}=\infty, \quad r_{2}=\frac{2}{L} \sqrt{C m} .
$$

Consider

$$
\frac{d^{2} V_{\mathrm{eff}}}{d r^{2}}=\frac{-20 C}{r^{6}}+\frac{3 L^{2}}{m r^{4}} .
$$

Substituting $r_{1}$ and $r_{2}$ in the above we obtain

$$
\left.\frac{d^{2} V_{\text {eff }}}{d r^{2}}\right|_{r=r_{1}}=0,\left.\quad \frac{d^{2} V_{\mathrm{eff}}}{d r^{2}}\right|_{r=r_{2}}<0 .
$$

Hence at $r=\frac{2}{L} \sqrt{C m}, V_{\text {eff }}$ has a maximum value $V_{0}=\frac{L^{4}}{16 m^{2}}$.

1050.c.Problem Statement:
The interaction between an atom and an ion at distances greater than contact is given by the potential energy $V(r)=-C r^{-4} . \quad\left(C=e^{2} P_{a}^{2} / 2\right.$, where $e$ is the charge and $P_{a}$ the polarizability of the atom.)

Find the cross section for an ion to strike an atom (i.e., to penetrate to $r=0$ ) in terms of its initial velocity $v_{0}$. Assume that the ion is much lighter than the atom.
1050.c.Solution:
The effective potential energy as a function of $r$ is

$$
V_{\mathrm{eff}}(r)=\frac{-C}{r^{4}}+\frac{L^{2}}{2 m r^{2}},
$$

where $L$ is the angular momentum of the ion about the force center, and $m$ is the mass of the ion. Its variation with $r$ is shown in Fig. 1.35.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-084.jpg?height=599&width=533&top_left_y=1243&top_left_x=494)

Fig. 1.35.
To find the maximum of $V_{\text {eff }}, V_{0}$, we set

$$
\frac{d V_{\mathrm{eff}}}{d r}=\frac{4 C}{r^{5}}-\frac{L^{2}}{m r^{3}}=\left(\frac{4 C}{r^{2}}-\frac{L^{2}}{m}\right) \frac{1}{r^{3}}=0 .
$$

The solutions are

$$
r_{1}=\infty, \quad r_{2}=\frac{2}{L} \sqrt{C m} .
$$

Consider

$$
\frac{d^{2} V_{\mathrm{eff}}}{d r^{2}}=\frac{-20 C}{r^{6}}+\frac{3 L^{2}}{m r^{4}} .
$$

Substituting $r_{1}$ and $r_{2}$ in the above we obtain

$$
\left.\frac{d^{2} V_{\text {eff }}}{d r^{2}}\right|_{r=r_{1}}=0,\left.\quad \frac{d^{2} V_{\mathrm{eff}}}{d r^{2}}\right|_{r=r_{2}}<0 .
$$

Hence at $r=\frac{2}{L} \sqrt{C m}, V_{\text {eff }}$ has a maximum value $V_{0}=\frac{L^{4}}{16 m^{2}}$.In terms of the total energy

$$
E=\frac{1}{2} m \dot{r}^{2}+\frac{L^{2}}{2 m r^{2}}+V,
$$

we can write $m \dot{r}=\sqrt{2 m(E-V)-\frac{L^{2}}{r^{2}}}$. In terms of $L$ we can write $\dot{\theta}=\frac{L}{m r^{2}}$. Then as

$$
\dot{\theta}=\frac{d \theta}{d t}=\dot{r} \frac{d \theta}{d r},
$$

we have

$$
\frac{d \theta}{d r}=\frac{\dot{\theta}}{\dot{r}}=\frac{L}{m r^{2} \dot{r}}=\frac{L}{r^{2} \sqrt{2 m(E-V)-\frac{L^{2}}{r^{2}}}} .
$$

We can then find the angular displacement of the ion with respect to the atom as it travels from infinity to the closest distance $r_{\text {min }}$ from the atom:

$$
\theta_{1}=L \int_{r_{\min }}^{\infty} \frac{d r}{r^{2} \sqrt{2 m(E-V)-\frac{L^{2}}{r^{2}}}} .
$$

As

$$
\begin{aligned}
E &=V_{0}=\frac{L^{4}}{16 m^{2} C}, \quad V=-\frac{C}{r^{4}}, \\
\theta_{1} &=L \int_{r_{\min }}^{\infty} \frac{d r}{r^{2}\left(\frac{L^{4}}{8 m C}-\frac{L^{2}}{r^{2}}+\frac{2 m C}{r^{4}}\right)^{1 / 2}} \\
&=\sqrt{8 m C} \int \frac{d(L r)}{\left(L^{2} r^{2}-4 m C\right)} \\
&=\left.\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \ln \frac{(L r-2 \sqrt{m C})}{(L r+2 \sqrt{m C})}\right|_{r_{\min }} ^{\infty}
\end{aligned}
$$

$r_{\min }$, the minimum distance of the ion to the atom, is determined by $\frac{d r}{d \theta}=0$, i.e.,

$$
2 m(E-V)-\frac{L^{2}}{r^{2}}=0,
$$

or

$$
2 m E r^{4}-L^{2} r^{2}+2 m C=0 .
$$

Hence

$$
r_{\min }^{2}=\frac{L^{2} \pm \sqrt{L^{4}-16 m^{2} E C}}{4 m E}=\frac{L^{2}}{4 m E}=\frac{4 m C}{L^{2}},
$$

or

$$
r_{\min }=\frac{2}{L} \sqrt{m C} .
$$

Substituting $r_{\min }$ in $\theta_{1}$ we obtain

$$
\theta_{1}=\infty \text {. }
$$

Why cannot we have a finite value for $\theta_{1}$ ? It is on account of the fact that, under the condition $E=V_{0}=\frac{L^{4}}{16 \mathrm{C}^{2}}$, while $\dot{r} \rightarrow 0$ as $r \rightarrow r_{\min }$, the transverse velocity $r \dot{\theta}=\frac{L}{m r} \rightarrow \frac{L}{m r_{\min }}$, a constant, so that with passage of time the trajectory will infinitely approach a circle of radius $r_{\text {min }}$ and no scattering occurs.

If $E>V_{0}, r_{\min }$ as given above is complex, implying that there is no minimum distance from the atom, i.e., the ion will approach the atom infinitely. Physically this can be seen as follows. When the ion reaches the position at which $V_{\text {eff }}=V_{0}, \dot{r} \neq 0$ and the ion continues approaching the atom. As $L$ is conserved, the speed of the ion, $\left(r^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+\dot{r}^{2}\right)^{1 / 2}=$ $\left(\frac{L^{2}}{m^{2} r^{2}}+\dot{r}^{2}\right)^{1 / 2}$, will become larger and larger as the atom is approached, if the expression for the potential energy $V(r)=-\frac{C}{r^{4}}$ continues to hold. But this is not so as other ion-atom interactions will come into play when the two bodies are close to each other.

Suppose the ion approaches the atom with impact parameter $b$ and initial velocity $v_{0}$. Then to strike the atom we require

$$
E=\frac{1}{2} m v_{0}^{2}>V_{0}=\frac{L^{4}}{16 C m^{2}}=\frac{m^{2} v_{0}^{4} b^{4}}{16 C},
$$

or

$$
b^{4}<\frac{8 C}{m v_{0}^{2}} .
$$

Hence the cross section for the ion to strike the atom is

$$
\sigma=\pi b^{2}=\frac{2 \pi}{v_{0}} \sqrt{\frac{2 C}{m}} .
$$

1051.a.Problem Statement:
Given a classical model of the tritium atom with a nucleus of charge $+1$ and a single electron in a circular orbit of radius $r_{0}$, suddenly the nucleus emits a negatron and changes to charge $+2$.
(The emitted negatron escapes rapidly and we can forget about it.) The electron in orbit suddenly has a new situation.

Find the ratio of the electron's energy after to before the emission of the negatron (taking the zero of energy, as usual, to be for zero kinetic energy at infinite distance).
1051.a.Solution:
As the negatron leaves the system rapidly, we can assume that its leaving has no effect on the position and kinetic energy of the orbiting electron.

From the force relation for the electron,

$$
\frac{m v_{0}^{2}}{r_{0}}=\frac{e^{2}}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r_{0}^{2}},
$$

we find its kinetic energy

$$
\frac{m v_{0}^{2}}{2}=\frac{e^{2}}{8 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r_{0}}
$$

and its total mechanical energy

$$
E_{1}=\frac{m v_{0}^{2}}{2}-\frac{e^{2}}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r_{0}}=\frac{-e^{2}}{8 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r_{0}}
$$

before the emission of the negatron. After the emission the kinetic energy of the electron is still $\frac{e^{2}}{8 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r_{0}}$, while its potential energy suddenly changes to

$$
\frac{-2 e^{2}}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r_{0}}=-\frac{-e^{2}}{2 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r_{0}} .
$$

Thus after the emission the total mechanical energy of the orbiting electron is

$$
E_{2}=\frac{m v_{0}^{2}}{2}-\frac{2 e^{2}}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r_{0}}=\frac{-3 e^{2}}{8 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r_{0}}
$$

giving

$$
\frac{E_{2}}{E_{1}}=3 .
$$

In other words, the total energy of the orbiting electron after the emission is three times as large as that before the emission.

1051.c.Problem Statement:
Given a classical model of the tritium atom with a nucleus of charge $+1$ and a single electron in a circular orbit of radius $r_{0}$, suddenly the nucleus emits a negatron and changes to charge $+2$.
(The emitted negatron escapes rapidly and we can forget about it.) The electron in orbit suddenly has a new situation.

Find the distance of closest and of farthest approach for the new orbit in units of $r_{0}$. of $r_{0}$.
1051.c.Solution:
As the negatron leaves the system rapidly, we can assume that its leaving has no effect on the position and kinetic energy of the orbiting electron.

From the force relation for the electron,

$$
\frac{m v_{0}^{2}}{r_{0}}=\frac{e^{2}}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r_{0}^{2}},
$$

we find its kinetic energy

$$
\frac{m v_{0}^{2}}{2}=\frac{e^{2}}{8 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r_{0}}
$$

and its total mechanical energy

$$
E_{1}=\frac{m v_{0}^{2}}{2}-\frac{e^{2}}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r_{0}}=\frac{-e^{2}}{8 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r_{0}}
$$

before the emission of the negatron. After the emission the kinetic energy of the electron is still $\frac{e^{2}}{8 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r_{0}}$, while its potential energy suddenly changes to

$$
\frac{-2 e^{2}}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r_{0}}=-\frac{-e^{2}}{2 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r_{0}} .
$$

Thus after the emission the total mechanical energy of the orbiting electron is

$$
E_{2}=\frac{m v_{0}^{2}}{2}-\frac{2 e^{2}}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r_{0}}=\frac{-3 e^{2}}{8 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r_{0}}
$$

giving

$$
\frac{E_{2}}{E_{1}}=3 .
$$

In other words, the total energy of the orbiting electron after the emission is three times as large as that before the emission.As $E_{2}=\frac{-3 e^{2}}{8 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r_{0}}$, the condition Eq.
(1) for circular motion is no longer satisfied and the new orbit is an ellipse.

Conservation of energy gives

$$
\frac{-3 e^{2}}{8 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r_{0}}=\frac{-e^{2}}{2 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r}+\frac{m\left(\dot{r}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}\right)}{2} .
$$

At positions where the orbiting electron is at the distance of closest or farthest approach to the atom, we have $\dot{r}=0$, for which

$$
\frac{-3 e^{2}}{8 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r_{0}}=\frac{m r^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}}{2}-\frac{e^{2}}{2 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r}=\frac{L^{2}}{2 m r^{2}}-\frac{e^{2}}{2 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r} .
$$

Then with

$$
L^{2}=m^{2} v_{0}^{2} r_{0}^{2}=\frac{m e^{2} r_{0}}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}}
$$

the above becomes

$$
3 r^{2}-4 r_{0} r+r_{0}^{2}=0
$$

with solutions

$$
r=\frac{r_{0}}{3}, \quad r=r_{0} .
$$

Hence the distances of closest and farthest approach in the new orbit are respectively

$$
r_{\min }=\frac{1}{3}, \quad r_{\max }=1
$$

in units of $r_{0}$.

E_{1}=\frac{m v_{0}^{2}}{2}-\frac{e^{2}}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r_{0}}=\frac{-e^{2}}{8 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r_{0}}
$$

before the emission of the negatron. After the emission the kinetic energy of the electron is still $\frac{e^{2}}{8 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r_{0}}$, while its potential energy suddenly changes to

$$
\frac{-2 e^{2}}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r_{0}}=-\frac{-e^{2}}{2 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r_{0}} .
$$

Thus after the emission the total mechanical energy of the orbiting electron is

$$
E_{2}=\frac{m v_{0}^{2}}{2}-\frac{2 e^{2}}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r_{0}}=\frac{-3 e^{2}}{8 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r_{0}}
$$

giving

$$
\frac{E_{2}}{E_{1}}=3 .
$$

In other words, the total energy of the orbiting electron after the emission is three times as large as that before the emission.As $E_{2}=\frac{-3 e^{2}}{8 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r_{0}}$, the condition Eq.
(1) for circular motion is no longer satisfied and the new orbit is an ellipse.

Conservation of energy gives

$$
\frac{-3 e^{2}}{8 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r_{0}}=\frac{-e^{2}}{2 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r}+\frac{m\left(\dot{r}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}\right)}{2} .
$$

At positions where the orbiting electron is at the distance of closest or farthest approach to the atom, we have $\dot{r}=0$, for which

$$
\frac{-3 e^{2}}{8 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r_{0}}=\frac{m r^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}}{2}-\frac{e^{2}}{2 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r}=\frac{L^{2}}{2 m r^{2}}-\frac{e^{2}}{2 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r} .
$$

Then with

$$
L^{2}=m^{2} v_{0}^{2} r_{0}^{2}=\frac{m e^{2} r_{0}}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}}
$$

the above becomes

$$
3 r^{2}-4 r_{0} r+r_{0}^{2}=0
$$

with solutions

$$
r=\frac{r_{0}}{3}, \quad r=r_{0} .
$$

Hence the distances of closest and farthest approach in the new orbit are respectively

$$
r_{\min }=\frac{1}{3}, \quad r_{\max }=1
$$

in units of $r_{0}$.Let $2 a$ and $2 b$ be the major and minor axes of the new elliptical orbit respectively, and $2 c$ the distance between its two focuses. We have

$$
\begin{aligned}
&2 a=r_{\min }+r_{\max }=\frac{4 r_{0}}{3}, \\
&2 c=r_{\max }-r_{\min }=\frac{2 r_{0}}{3}, \\
&2 b=2 \sqrt{a^{2}-c^{2}}=\frac{2 \sqrt{3} r_{0}}{3} .
\end{aligned}
$$

1053.a.Problem Statement:
By what arguments and using what measurable quantities can one determine the following quantities with good accuracy?

The mass of the earth.
1053.a.Solution:
The weight of a body on the earth arises from the gravitational attraction of the eartl. We have

$$
m g=\frac{G m_{e} m}{R^{2}},
$$

whence the mass of the earth is

$$
m_{e}=\frac{g R^{2}}{G},
$$

where the acceleration of gravity $g$, the radius of the earth $R$, and the gravitational constant $G$ are measurable quantities.

1053.b.Problem Statement:
By what arguments and using what measurable quantities can one determine the following quantities with good accuracy?

The mass of the moon.
1053.b.Solution:
The weight of a body on the earth arises from the gravitational attraction of the eartl. We have

$$
m g=\frac{G m_{e} m}{R^{2}},
$$

whence the mass of the earth is

$$
m_{e}=\frac{g R^{2}}{G},
$$

where the acceleration of gravity $g$, the radius of the earth $R$, and the gravitational constant $G$ are measurable quantities.Consider a 2-body system consisting of masses $m_{1}, m_{2}$, separated by $r$, under gravitational interaction. The force equation is

$$
\frac{G m_{1} m_{2}}{r^{2}}=\left(\frac{m_{1} m_{2}}{m_{1}+m_{2}}\right) r \omega^{2},
$$

or

$$
G\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right)=\frac{4 \pi^{2} r^{3}}{T^{2}},
$$

where $m_{1} m_{2} /\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right)$ is the reduced mass of the system. Applying this to the moon-earth system, we have

$$
G\left(m_{m}+m_{e}\right)=\frac{4 \pi a^{3}}{T^{2}},
$$

where $m_{m}, a$ and $T$ are the mass, semimajor axis and period of revolution of the moon respectively. With the knowledge of $m_{e}$ obtained in (a) and that of $a$ and $T$ determined by astronomical observations, $m_{m}$ can be obtained.

As

$$
\alpha_{2}=\lambda_{2}-\delta+\beta_{2}, \quad \alpha_{1}=\lambda_{1}-\delta+\beta_{1},
$$

giving

$$
\beta_{2}-\beta_{1}=\alpha_{2}-\alpha_{1}-\lambda_{2}+\lambda_{1},
$$

and

giving

\beta_{2}-\beta_{1} \approx \sin \beta_{2}-\sin \beta_{1}=\frac{R_{e}}{a_{1}-a}\left(\sin \alpha_{2}-\sin \alpha_{1}\right)

we have

1054.b.Problem Statement:
Two long concentric half-cylinders, with cross section as shown in Fig. 1.39, carry charges arranged to produce a radial electric field $\boldsymbol{E}=$ $k e_{r} / r$ between them. A particle of mass $m$, velocity $v$ and negative charge $-q$ enters the region between the plates from the left in a direction perpendicular to the axis of the half-cylinders and perpendicular to the radial direction as in the figure. Since the velocity $\mathbf{v}$ has no component along the axis of the half-cylinders, consider only motion in the plane of the diagram for all calculations.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-094.jpg?height=376&width=582&top_left_y=494&top_left_x=494)

Fig. 1.39.

Next consider a trajectory for which the particle enters the region between the plates at the same distance $r$ from the axis and the same speed as in (a), but at a small angle $\beta$ with the direction of the original path. For small $\beta$ the point $P$ at which this new trajectory again crosses the trajectory in (a) is independent of $\beta$. Find the location of that point $P$.
1054.b.Solution:
As the particle moves in a circular path, we have

$$
\frac{m v^{2}}{r}=q E=\frac{q k}{r},
$$

or

$$
v^{2}=\frac{q k}{m} .
$$

As long as the velocity $\mathbf{v}$ of the particle satisfies this relation, it will move in a circular path whose radius is equal to the distance between the incident line and the axis of the half-cylinders, while between the plates.

The particle enters the region between the half-cylinders at the same distance $r_{0}$ from the axis and with the same speed $v$ as in (a), but at a small angle $\beta$ with the direction of the original path. Conservation of angular momentum and energy gives

$$
\begin{aligned}
m r^{2} \dot{\theta} &=m r_{0} v, \\
\frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{r}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}\right)+q k \ln \left(\frac{r}{r_{0}}\right) &=\frac{1}{2} m v^{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$

As the new trajectory deviates from the original one slightly, we set

$$
\begin{aligned}
&r=r_{0}+\delta r, \\
&\dot{r}=\frac{d}{d t}(\delta r), \\
&\dot{\theta}=\omega_{0}+\delta \dot{\theta},
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\omega_{0}$ is the angular velocity for the original circular orbit, and $\delta r, \delta \dot{\theta}$ are small quantities. Substitution in (1) gives

$$
\dot{\theta}=\frac{r_{0} v}{r^{2}}=\frac{v}{r_{0}} \frac{1}{\left(1+\frac{\delta r}{r_{0}}\right)^{2}},
$$

or

$$
\begin{aligned}
\dot{\theta}^{2} &=\left(\frac{v}{r_{0}}\right)^{2} /\left(1+\frac{\delta r}{r_{0}}\right)^{4} \\
&=\left(\frac{v}{r_{0}}\right)^{2} \cdot\left[1-4 \frac{\delta r}{r_{0}}+10\left(\frac{\delta r}{r_{0}}\right)^{2}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

By a similar approximation,

$$
\ln \left(\frac{r}{r_{0}}\right)=\ln \left(1+\frac{\delta r}{r_{0}}\right)=\frac{\delta r}{r_{0}}-\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{\delta r}{r_{0}}\right)^{2} .
$$

We can also write

$$
r^{2}=\left(r_{0}+\delta r\right)^{2}=r_{0}^{2}\left[1+2 \frac{\delta r}{r_{0}}+\left(\frac{\delta r}{r_{0}}\right)^{2}\right]
$$

Hence (2) can be written, neglecting small quantities higher than the second order, as

$$
\frac{1}{2} m\left(\frac{d \delta r}{d t}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{3}{2} \frac{m v^{2}}{r_{0}^{2}}-\frac{q k}{2 r_{0}^{2}}\right)(\delta r)^{2}+\left(\frac{q k}{r_{0}}-\frac{m v^{2}}{r_{0}}\right) \delta r=0
$$

or, noting $q k=m v^{2}$,

$$
\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{d \delta r}{d t}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{v}{r_{0}}\right)^{2}(\delta r)^{2}=0 .
$$

Then taking the time derivative of both sides, we obtain

$$
\frac{d^{2} \delta r}{d t^{2}}+2\left(\frac{v}{r_{0}}\right)^{2} \delta r=0
$$

with solution

$$
\delta r=A \sin \left(\sqrt{2} \frac{v}{r_{0}} t+\varphi\right)
$$

where $A$ and $\varphi$ are constants of integration. The initial conditions

$$
r(0)=r_{0}, \quad \dot{r}(0)=v \sin \beta,
$$

or

$$
\delta r=0, \quad \frac{d}{d t} \delta r=v \sin \beta \quad \text { at } t=0,
$$

give

$$
\varphi=0, \quad A=\frac{r_{0}}{\sqrt{2}} \sin \beta .
$$

Hence

$$
\delta r=\frac{r_{0}}{\sqrt{2}} \sin \beta \sin \left(\sqrt{2} \frac{v}{r_{0}} t\right) .
$$

At the point where this new trajectory crosses the trajectory in (a), $\delta r=0$. The second crossing takes place at a time $t$ later given by

$$
\sqrt{2} \frac{v}{r_{0}} t=\pi, \quad \text { or } \quad t=\frac{\pi}{\sqrt{2}} \frac{r_{0}}{v},
$$

and the position of $P$ is given by

$$
\theta=\dot{\theta} t \approx \omega_{0} t=\frac{v}{r_{0}} t=\frac{\pi}{\sqrt{2}},
$$

which is independent of $\beta$.

1055.Problem Statement: The orbit of a particle moving under the influence of a central force is $r \theta=$ constant. Determine the potential energy as a function of $r$.
1055.Solution:
Consider a central force $\mathbf{F}=\mathbf{r} F(r)$ acting on a particle of mass $m$. Newton's second law gives

$$
\begin{aligned}
F &=m\left(\ddot{r}-r \dot{\theta}^{2}\right), \\
0 &=m(r \ddot{\theta}+2 \dot{r} \dot{\theta})
\end{aligned}
$$

in polar coordinates. Equation (2) gives

$$
r \ddot{\theta}+2 \dot{r} \dot{\theta}=\frac{1}{r} \frac{d}{d t}\left(r^{2} \dot{\theta}\right)=0,
$$

or

$$
r^{2} \dot{\theta}=\text { constant }=h, \text { say }
$$

or

$$
\dot{\theta}=h u^{2}
$$

by putting

$$
r=\frac{1}{u} .
$$

Then as

$$
\begin{aligned}
\dot{r} &=\frac{d r}{d t}=\ddot{\theta} \frac{d r}{d \theta}=h u^{2} \frac{d r}{d \theta}=-h \frac{d u}{d \theta}, \\
\ddot{r} &=\dot{\theta} \frac{d \dot{r}}{d \theta}=h u^{2} \frac{d}{d \theta}\left(-h \frac{d u}{d \theta}\right)=-h^{2} u^{2} \frac{d^{2} u}{d \theta^{2}}, \\
r \dot{\theta}^{2} &=\frac{1}{u} h^{2} u^{4}=h^{2} u^{3},
\end{aligned}
$$

Eq.
(1) becomes

$$
F=-m h^{2} u^{2}\left(\frac{d^{2} u}{d \theta^{2}}+u\right)
$$

which is often known as Binet's formula.

In this problem, let $r=\frac{1}{u}$ and write the equation of the trajectory as

$$
u=C \theta,
$$

where $C$ is a constant. Binet's formula then gives

$$
F=-m h^{2} u^{3}=\frac{-m h^{2}}{r^{3}} .
$$

The potential energy is by definition

$$
V=-\int_{\infty}^{r} F(r) d r=\int_{\infty}^{r} \frac{m h^{2}}{r^{3}} d r=\left[\frac{-m h^{2}}{2 r^{2}}\right]_{\infty}^{r}=\frac{-m h^{2}}{2 r^{2}},
$$

taking an infinity point as the zero potential level.

1059.a.Problem Statement:
You know that the acceleration due to gravity on the surface of the earth is $9.8 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{sec}^{2}$, and that the length of a great circle around the earth is $4 \times 10^{7} \mathrm{~m}$. You are given that the ratios of moon/earth diameters and masses are

$$
\frac{D_{m}}{D_{e}}=0.27 \quad \text { and } \quad \frac{M_{m}}{M_{e}}=0.0123
$$

respectively.

Compute the minimum velocity required to escape from the moon's gravitational field when starting from its surface.
1059.a.Solution:
Let the velocity required to escape from the moon's gravitational field be $v_{\min }$, then

$$
\frac{m v_{\min }^{2}}{2}=\frac{G M_{m} m}{r_{m}},
$$

giving

$$
\begin{aligned}
v_{\min } &=\sqrt{\frac{2 G M_{m}}{r_{m}}}=\sqrt{\left(\frac{0.0123}{0.27}\right)\left(\frac{G M_{e}}{r_{e}^{2}}\right) 2 r_{e}} \\
&=\sqrt{\left(\frac{0.0123}{0.27}\right) \cdot g \cdot D_{e}}=2.38 \times 10^{3 \cdot} \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}
\end{aligned}
$$

using $g=G M_{e} / r_{e}^{2}, D_{m} / D_{e}=0.27$ and $M_{m} / M_{e}=0.0123$.

1062.Problem Statement: Find the angular distribution and total cross section for the scattering of small marbles of mass $m$ and radius $r$ from a massive billiard ball of mass $M$ and radius $R(m \ll M)$. You should treat the scattering as elastic, involving no frictional forces.
1062.Solution:
As $m \ll M$, the massive billiard ball will remain stationary during scattering. As the scattering is elastic (see Fig. 1.41), the scattering angle $\theta$ is related to the angle of incidence by

$$
\theta=\pi-2 \theta,
$$

where $\theta$ is given by

$$
(R+r) \sin \theta=b .
$$

The differential scattering cross section is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{d \sigma}{d \Omega} &=\frac{|2 \pi b d b|}{d \Omega}=\frac{2 \pi\left|\sin \theta \cos \theta \cdot(R+r)^{2} d \theta\right|}{2 \pi d \cos \Theta} \\
&=\frac{\left|\frac{1}{4}(R+r)^{2} \sin \Theta d \Theta\right|}{d \cos \Theta}=\frac{\frac{1}{4}(R+r)^{2} d \cos \Theta}{d \cos \Theta} \\
&=\frac{1}{4}(R+r)^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

As $\frac{d \sigma}{d \Omega}$ is isotropic, the total cross section is

$$
\sigma_{t}=4 \pi \frac{d \sigma}{d \Omega}=\pi(R+r)^{2} .
$$

1063.a.Problem Statement:
A spaceship is in a circular orbit of radius $r_{0}$ around a star of mass $M$. The spaceship's rocket engine may be fired briefly to alter its velocity (instantaneously) by an amount $\Delta \mathbf{v}$. The direction of firing is specified by the angle $\theta$ between the ship's velocity $v$ and the vector from the tail to the nose of the ship (see Fig. 1.42). To conserve fuel in a sequence of $N$ firings, it is desirable to minimize $\Delta V=\sum_{i=1}^{N}\left|\Delta \mathbf{v}_{i}\right| . \Delta V$ is known as the specific impulse.

Suppose we want to use the ship's engine to escape from the star. What is the minimum specific impulse required if the engine is fired in a single rapid burst? In what direction should the engine be fired?
1063.a.Solution:
Let $v_{0}$ be the speed of the spaceship in the circular orbit of radius $r_{0}$, and $v_{0 e}$ be the escape velocity for the orbit. Then

$$
\frac{m v_{0}^{2}}{r_{0}}=\frac{G M m}{r_{0}^{2}}, \quad \frac{m v_{0 e}^{2}}{2}=\frac{G M m}{r_{0}}
$$

or

$$
v_{0}=\sqrt{\frac{G M}{r_{0}}}, \quad v_{0 e}=\sqrt{\frac{2 G M}{r_{0}}}
$$

As

$$
v_{0 e}=v_{0}+|\Delta \mathbf{v}| \cos \theta=v_{0}+\Delta V \cos \theta,
$$

the specific impulse required for escape is the least for $\theta=0$, i.e., the initial velocity of the spaceship and the impulse are in the same direction, and is given by

$$
\Delta V=v_{0 e}-v_{0}=\sqrt{\frac{G M}{r_{0}}}(\sqrt{2}-1) .
$$

Fig. 1.43.

Suppose we wish to visit a planet in a circular orbit of radius $r_{1}>r_{0}$. What is the minimum specific impulse required to reach the planet's orbit if the engine is again fired in a single rapid burst?
1063.b.Solution:
Let $v_{0}$ be the speed of the spaceship in the circular orbit of radius $r_{0}$, and $v_{0 e}$ be the escape velocity for the orbit. Then

$$
\frac{m v_{0}^{2}}{r_{0}}=\frac{G M m}{r_{0}^{2}}, \quad \frac{m v_{0 e}^{2}}{2}=\frac{G M m}{r_{0}}
$$

or

$$
v_{0}=\sqrt{\frac{G M}{r_{0}}}, \quad v_{0 e}=\sqrt{\frac{2 G M}{r_{0}}}
$$

As

$$
v_{0 e}=v_{0}+|\Delta \mathbf{v}| \cos \theta=v_{0}+\Delta V \cos \theta,
$$

the specific impulse required for escape is the least for $\theta=0$, i.e., the initial velocity of the spaceship and the impulse are in the same direction, and is given by

$$

$$

Fig. 1.43.After the first burst, the ship escapes from the circular orbit around the star and moves along a parabolic orbit. When the ship reaches the circular orbit $r=r_{1}$ of the planet, the engine is again fired in a single rapid burst (see Fig. 1.43). For the ship to move along the circular orbit of radius $r_{1}$, its speed must be

$$
v_{1}=\sqrt{\frac{G M}{r_{1}}} .
$$

Let $v_{1 e}$ be the speed of the ship as it arrives at $r=r_{1}$ and before the burst. Conservation of angular momentum requires

$$
v_{0 e} r_{0}=v_{1 e} r_{1} \cos \varphi
$$

or

$$
v_{1 e} \cos \varphi=\frac{r_{0} v_{0 e}}{r_{1}} .
$$

Conservation of energy gives

$$
\frac{1}{2} m v_{1 e}^{2}=\frac{G M m}{r_{1}},
$$

or

$$
v_{1 e}=\sqrt{\frac{2 G M}{r_{1}}} .
$$

Then the minimum specific impulse required is given by

$$
\Delta V=\left|\mathbf{v}_{1}-\mathbf{v}_{1 e}\right|
$$

or

$$
\begin{aligned}
(\Delta V)^{2} &=v_{1 e}^{2}+v_{1}^{2}-2 v_{1 e} v_{1} \cos \varphi \\
&=\frac{2 G M}{r_{1}}+\frac{G M}{r_{1}}-2 \frac{r_{0}}{r_{1}} v_{0 e} v_{1} \\
&=\frac{3 G M}{r_{1}}-2 \frac{r_{0}}{r_{1}} \sqrt{\frac{2 G M}{r_{0}}} \cdot \sqrt{\frac{G M}{r_{1}}} \\
&=\frac{G M}{r_{1}}\left(3-2 \sqrt{\frac{2 r_{0}}{r_{1}}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence

$$
\Delta V=\sqrt{\frac{G M}{r_{1}}\left(3-2 \sqrt{\frac{2 r_{0}}{r_{1}}}\right)}
$$
