Find the frequency of oscillation of the radius of the orbit when the orbit is only sightly different from circular.
1087.b.Solution:
The equations of motion of $m_{1}$ and $m_{2}$ are

$$
\begin{aligned}
&m_{1}\left(\ddot{r}-r \dot{\theta}^{2}\right)=-T, \\
&m_{1} r^{2} \dot{\theta}=m_{1} h, \\
&T-m_{2} g=m_{2} \ddot{r},
\end{aligned}
$$

where $m_{1} h$ is the angular momentum, a constant. Eliminating $T$ from (1) and (3), we obtain

$$
\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right) \ddot{r}-m_{1} r \dot{\theta}^{2}+m_{2} g=0 .
$$

Equations (2) and (4) give

$$
\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right) \ddot{r}-\frac{m_{1} h^{2}}{r^{3}}=-m_{2} g .
$$

As $\ddot{r}=\dot{r} \frac{d \dot{r}}{d r}=\frac{1}{2} \frac{d \dot{r}^{2}}{d r}$, the above can be readily integrated to give

$$
\frac{1}{2}\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right) \dot{r}^{2}+\frac{m_{1} h^{2}}{2 r^{2}}=-m_{2} g r+C .
$$

At $t=0, r=R_{0}, \dot{r}=V_{0} \cos \phi, r \dot{\theta}=V_{0} \sin \phi$, so that $h=R_{0} V_{0} \sin \phi$, where $\phi$ is the angle between $\mathbf{R}_{0}$ and $\mathbf{V}_{0}$. Then the constant of integration $C$ can be evaluated as

$$
C=\frac{1}{2}\left[\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right) V_{0}^{2} \cos ^{2} \phi+m_{1} V_{0}^{2} \sin ^{2} \phi\right]+m_{2} g R_{0} .
$$

For $r$ to be an extremum, $\dot{r}=0$, with which (6) becomes

$$
2 m_{2} g r^{3}-2 C r^{2}+m_{1} h^{2}=0,
$$

whose solution gives the maximum and minimum radial distances of $r$.When the orbit of $m_{1}$ is circular, $\ddot{r}=0$, and (5) gives

$$
h^{2}=\frac{m_{2} g r_{0}^{3}}{m_{1}},
$$

where $r_{0}$ is the radius of the circular orbit. When the orbit is slightly different from circular, let $r=r_{0}+x$, where $x \ll r_{0}$. Equation (5) then becomes

$$
\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right) \ddot{x}-m_{1} h^{2} /\left(r_{0}+x\right)^{3}=-m_{2} g .
$$

As

the above becomes

$$
\left(r_{0}+x\right)^{-3}=r_{0}^{-3}\left(1+\frac{x}{r_{0}}\right)^{-3} \approx r_{0}^{-3}\left(1-\frac{3 x}{r_{0}}\right),
$$

$$
\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right) \ddot{x}-m_{1} h^{2}\left(r_{0}^{-3}-3 x r_{0}^{-4}\right)=-m_{2} g .
$$

Then using (7) we have

$$
\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right) \ddot{x}+\frac{3 m_{2} g x}{r_{0}}=0 .
$$

This shows that $x$ oscillates simple-harmonically with frequency

$$
\frac{\omega}{2 \pi}=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \sqrt{\frac{3 m_{2} g}{\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right) r_{0}}} .
$$

1088.a.Problem Statement:
Consider a damped, driven harmonic oscillator (in one dimension) with equation of motion

$$
m \ddot{x}=-m \omega_{0}^{2} x-\gamma \dot{x}+A \cos (\omega t) .
$$

What is the time-averaged rate of energy dissipation?
1088.a.Solution:
The equation of motion is the real part of

$$
m \ddot{z}+m \omega_{0}^{2} z+\gamma \dot{z}=A e^{i \omega t} .
$$

For the steady-state solution we $\operatorname{try} z=z_{0} e^{i \omega t}$. Substitution gives

$$
z_{0}=\frac{A}{m\left(\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}\right)+i \gamma \omega}=B e^{-i \phi},
$$

with

$$
B=\frac{A}{\sqrt{m^{2}\left(\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}\right)^{2}+\gamma^{2} \omega^{2}}}, \quad \phi=\arctan \frac{\gamma \omega}{m\left(\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}\right)} .
$$

The rate of work done by the force $F=\operatorname{Re}\left(A e^{i \omega t}\right)$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
P &=\operatorname{Re} F \cdot \operatorname{Re} \dot{z}=\frac{1}{4}\left(F+F^{*}\right)\left(\dot{z}+\dot{z}^{*}\right) \\
&=\frac{1}{4}\left(F \dot{z}+F^{*} \dot{z}^{*}+F^{*} \dot{z}+F \dot{z}^{*}\right)=\frac{1}{4}\left(F^{*} \dot{z}+F \dot{z}^{*}\right),
\end{aligned}
$$

when averaged over one period as $F \dot{z}$ and $F^{*} \dot{z}^{*}$ each carries a time factor $e^{\pm 2 i \omega t}$ which vanishes on integration over one period. Thus the average work done is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\langle P\rangle &=\frac{i \omega A B}{4}\left(e^{-i \varphi}-e^{i \varphi}\right)=\frac{\omega A B}{2} \sin \varphi \\
&=\frac{\omega A B}{2} \frac{B}{A} \gamma \omega=\frac{\gamma \omega^{2} B^{2}}{2}=\frac{\gamma \omega^{2} A^{2}}{2\left[m^{2}\left(\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}\right)+\gamma^{2} \omega^{2}\right]}
\end{aligned}
$$

In steady state, this is equal to the rate of energy dissipation of the oscillator, which is given by the work done against the dissipative term, i.e.

$$
\left\langle P^{\prime}\right\rangle=\gamma(R e \dot{z})^{2}=\gamma \frac{\dot{z} \dot{z}^{*}}{2}=\gamma \frac{\omega^{2} B^{2}}{2} .
$$

As noted, the two approaches give the same result.

1090.a.Problem Statement:
A particle of mass $m$ moves under a conservative force with potential energy $V(x)=c x /\left(x^{2}+a^{2}\right)$, where $c$ and $a$ are positive constants. Find the position of stable equilibrium and the period of small oscillations about it.
(2) escapes to $-\infty$,
(3) escapes to $+\infty$
1090.a.Solution:
At the equilibrium position, $F=-d V / d x=0$, i.e.

$$
\frac{d V}{d x}=\frac{\mathrm{c}\left(a^{2}-x^{2}\right)}{\left(x^{2}+a^{2}\right)^{2}}=0 .
$$

Thus there are two equilibrium positions, $x_{1}=a, x_{2}=-a$. Consider

$$
\frac{d^{2} V}{d x^{2}}=\frac{2 \mathrm{c} x\left(x^{2}-3 a^{2}\right)}{\left(x^{2}+a^{2}\right)^{3}} .
$$

We have

$$
\left.\frac{d^{2} V}{d x^{2}}\right|_{x_{1}}<0,\left.\quad \frac{d^{2} V}{d x^{2}}\right|_{x_{2}}>0 .
$$

It follows that $x_{1}$ is a position of unstable equilibrium and $x_{2}$ is a position of stable equilibrium.

For small oscillations about the position of stable equilibrium, let $x=$ $-a+x^{\prime}$, where $x^{\prime} \ll a$. Then the equation of motion becomes

$$
m \frac{d^{2} x^{\prime}}{d t^{2}}=-\frac{c x^{\prime}\left(2 a-x^{\prime}\right)}{\left[\left(x^{\prime}-a\right)^{2}+a^{2}\right]^{2}} \approx-\frac{c x^{\prime}}{2 a^{3}} .
$$

Hence the period of small oscillations about $x=-a$ is

$$
T=\frac{2 \pi}{\omega}=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{2 m a^{3}}{c}}=2 \pi a \sqrt{\frac{2 m a}{c}} .
$$

1090.b.Problem Statement:
If the particle starts from this point with velocity $v$, find the range of values of $v$ for which it (1) oscillates,
(2) escapes to $-\infty$,
(3) escapes to $+\infty$
1090.b.Solution:
At the equilibrium position, $F=-d V / d x=0$, i.e.

$$
\frac{d V}{d x}=\frac{\mathrm{c}\left(a^{2}-x^{2}\right)}{\left(x^{2}+a^{2}\right)^{2}}=0 .
$$

Thus there are two equilibrium positions, $x_{1}=a, x_{2}=-a$. Consider

$$
\frac{d^{2} V}{d x^{2}}=\frac{2 \mathrm{c} x\left(x^{2}-3 a^{2}\right)}{\left(x^{2}+a^{2}\right)^{3}} .
$$

We have

$$
\left.\frac{d^{2} V}{d x^{2}}\right|_{x_{1}}<0,\left.\quad \frac{d^{2} V}{d x^{2}}\right|_{x_{2}}>0 .
$$

It follows that $x_{1}$ is a position of unstable equilibrium and $x_{2}$ is a position of stable equilibrium.

For small oscillations about the position of stable equilibrium, let $x=$ $-a+x^{\prime}$, where $x^{\prime} \ll a$. Then the equation of motion becomes

$$
m \frac{d^{2} x^{\prime}}{d t^{2}}=-\frac{c x^{\prime}\left(2 a-x^{\prime}\right)}{\left[\left(x^{\prime}-a\right)^{2}+a^{2}\right]^{2}} \approx-\frac{c x^{\prime}}{2 a^{3}} .
$$

Hence the period of small oscillations about $x=-a$ is

$$
T=\frac{2 \pi}{\omega}=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{2 m a^{3}}{c}}=2 \pi a \sqrt{\frac{2 m a}{c}} .
$$The total energy of the particle is

$$
E=\frac{m v^{2}}{2}+V(-a)=\frac{m v^{2}}{2}-\frac{\mathrm{c}}{2 a} .
$$

(1) For the particle to be confined in a region, we require $E<0$, i.e.

$$
v<\sqrt{\frac{\mathrm{c}}{m a}} .
$$

(2) As $E=\frac{m \dot{x}^{2}}{2}+V(x)$, for the particle to reach $x=-\infty$, we require $E>V(-\infty)=0$, i.e.

$$
v>\sqrt{\frac{\mathrm{c}}{m a}} .
$$

(3) To escape to $+\infty$, the particle must pass through the point $x_{2}=+a$ at which the potential energy is maximum. Hence we require $E>V(a)=$ $\frac{c}{2 a}$, i.e.

$$
v>\sqrt{\frac{2 c}{m a}} \text {. }
$$

1091.Problem Statement:
A 3-4-5 inclined plane is fixed to a rotating turntable. A block rests on the inclined plane and the coefficient of static friction between the inclined plane and the block is $\mu_{s}=1 / 4$. The block is to remain at a position $40 \mathrm{~cm}$ from the center of rotation of the turntable (see Fig. 1.62). Find the minimum angular velocity $\omega$ to keep the block from sliding down the plane (toward the center).

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-162.jpg?height=345&width=386&top_left_y=1025&top_left_x=311)

Fig. 1.62.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-162.jpg?height=344&width=335&top_left_y=997&top_left_x=919)

Fig. 1.63.
1091.Solution:
As shown in Fig. 1.63, the forces acting on the block are the gravitational force $m g$, the normal reaction $\mathbf{N}$, the static friction $\mathbf{f}$, and the centrifugal force with $f=\mu_{s} N, P=m \omega^{2} r$. Thus the conditions for equilibrium are

$$
\begin{aligned}
m g \sin \theta &=P \cos \theta+\mu_{s} N, \\
N &=m g \cos \theta+P \sin \theta .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence

$$
m g \sin \theta=P \cos \theta+\mu_{s} m g \cos \theta+\mu_{s} P \sin \theta,
$$

giving

$$
P=\left(\frac{\sin \theta-\mu_{s} \cos \theta}{\cos \theta+\mu_{s} \sin \theta}\right) m g=m \omega^{2} r
$$

or

$$
\omega^{2}=\left(\frac{\sin \theta-\mu_{s} \cos \theta}{\cos \theta+\mu_{s} \sin \theta}\right) \frac{g}{r}=\left(\frac{\frac{3}{5}-\frac{1}{4} \cdot \frac{4}{5}}{\frac{4}{5}+\frac{1}{4} \cdot \frac{3}{5}}\right) \cdot \frac{9.8}{0.4}=10.3
$$

i.e.

$$
\omega=3.2 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s} \text {. }
$$

1093.Problem Statement: A block of mass $m$ slides without friction on an inclined plane of mass $M$ which in turn is free to slide without friction on a horizontal table (Fig. 1.65). Write sufficient equations to find the motion of the block and the inclined plane. You do not need to solve these equations.
1093.Solution:
As shown in Fig. 1.65, let $x, y$ be a coordinate frame attached to the inclined plane, whose horizontal coordinate in the laboratory frame is denoted by $X$. The forces on the block and the inclined plane are as shown in the diagram. 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-165.jpg?height=340&width=540&top_left_y=222&top_left_x=458)

Fig. 1.65.

We have for the inclined plane

$$
M \ddot{X}=N \sin \alpha,
$$

for the motion of the block along the $x$ direction

$$
m(\ddot{x}+\ddot{X} \cos \alpha)=-m g \sin \alpha,
$$

and for the motion of the block along the $y$ direction

$$
-m \ddot{X} \sin \alpha=N-m g \cos \alpha .
$$

These three equations for the three unknowns $N, x$ and $X$ can be solved to find the motion of the system.

1094.Problem Statement: A merry-go-round (carousel) starts from rest and accelerates with a constant angular acceleration of $0.02$ revolution per second per second. A woman sitting on a chair 6 meters from the axis of revolution holds a $2 \mathrm{~kg}$ ball (see Fig. 1.66). Calculate the magnitude and direction of the force she must exert to hold the ball 5 seconds after the merry-go-round begins to rotate. Specify the direction with respect to the radius of the chair on which she is sitting.
1094.Solution:
Consider two coordinate frames $L, R$ with the same origin. $L$ is fixed to the laboratory and $R$ rotates with angular velocity $\omega$. The time derivatives of a vector $\mathbf{A}$ in the two frames are related by 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-166.jpg?height=239&width=256&top_left_y=255&top_left_x=642)

Fig. 1.66.

$$
\left(\frac{d \mathbf{A}}{d t}\right)_{L}=\left(\frac{d \mathbf{A}}{d t}\right)_{R}+\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{A} .
$$

Then for a point of radius vector $\mathbf{r}$ from the origin we have

$$
\left(\frac{d \mathbf{r}}{d t}\right)_{L}=\left(\frac{d \mathbf{r}}{d t}\right)_{R}+\omega \times \mathbf{r}
$$

and

$$
\left(\frac{d^{2} \mathbf{r}}{d t^{2}}\right)_{L}=\left(\frac{d}{d t}\right)_{L}\left(\frac{d \mathbf{r}}{d t}\right)_{R}+\omega \times\left(\frac{d \mathbf{r}}{d t}\right)_{L}+\left(\frac{d \omega}{d t}\right)_{L} \times \mathbf{r} .
$$

As

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(\frac{d}{d t}\right)_{L}\left(\frac{d \mathbf{r}}{d t}\right)_{R} &=\left(\frac{d^{2} \mathbf{r}}{d t^{2}}\right)_{R}+\omega \times\left(\frac{d \mathbf{r}}{d t}\right)_{R}, \\
\omega \times\left(\frac{d \mathbf{r}}{d t}\right)_{L}=\boldsymbol{\omega} \times\left(\frac{d \mathbf{r}}{d t}\right)_{R}+\omega \times(\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{r}) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Putting

$$
\left(\frac{d^{2} \mathbf{r}}{d t^{2}}\right)_{R}=\mathbf{a}^{\prime}, \quad\left(\frac{d \mathbf{r}}{d t}\right)_{R}=\mathbf{v}^{\prime}, \quad\left(\frac{d \omega}{d t}\right)_{L}=\dot{\omega},
$$

we have

$$
\left(\frac{d^{2} \mathbf{r}}{d t^{2}}\right)_{L}=\mathbf{a}^{\prime}+2 \boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{v}^{\prime}+\boldsymbol{\omega} \times(\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{r})+\dot{\boldsymbol{\omega}} \times \mathbf{r} .
$$

In the rotating frame attached to the carousel, the equation of the motion of the ball $\mathbf{F}=m\left(\frac{d^{2} \theta}{d t^{2}}\right)_{L}$ then gives

$$
m \mathbf{a}^{\prime}=\mathbf{F}+m \omega^{2} \mathbf{r}-m \dot{\omega} \times \mathbf{r}-2 m \boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{v}^{\prime},
$$

as $\boldsymbol{\omega} \perp \mathbf{r}$ so that $\mathbf{r} \times(\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{r})=-\omega^{2} \mathbf{r}$. As the ball is held stationary with respect to the carousel, $\mathbf{a}^{\prime}=0, \mathbf{v}^{\prime}=0$, and

$$
\mathbf{F}=-m \omega^{2} \mathbf{r}+m \dot{\boldsymbol{\omega}} \times \mathbf{r} .
$$

For the rotating frame $R$, take the $z$-axis along the axis of rotation and the $x$-axis from the center toward the chair. Then

$$
\dot{\omega}=\dot{\omega} \mathbf{k}, \quad \mathbf{r}=r \mathbf{i} .
$$

The force $\mathbf{F}$ acting on the ball is the resultant of the holding force $\mathbf{f}$ exerted by the woman and the gravity of the earth:

$$
\mathbf{F}=\mathbf{f}-m g \mathbf{k} .
$$

Hence

$$
\mathbf{f}=-m \omega^{2} r \mathbf{i}+m \dot{\omega} r \mathbf{j}+m g \mathbf{k} \text {. }
$$

With $\dot{\omega}=0.02 \times 2 \pi \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s}^{2}, \omega=5 \dot{\omega}, m=2 \mathrm{~kg}, r=6 \mathrm{~m}$, we have

$$
\mathbf{f}=-4.74 \mathbf{i}+1.51 \mathbf{j}+19.6 \mathbf{k} N
$$

of magnitude $=20.2 \mathrm{~N}$.

1095.Problem Statement:
A planet of uniform density spins about a fixed axis with angular velocity $\omega$. Due to the spin the planet's equatorial radius $R_{E}$ is slightly larger than its polar radius $R_{P}$ as described by the parameter $\varepsilon=\left(R_{E}-\right.$ $\left.E_{P}\right) / R_{E}$. The contribution to the gravitational potential resulting from this distortion is

$$
\Phi(R, \theta)=\frac{2 G M_{e} \varepsilon R_{E}^{2} P_{2}(\cos \theta)}{5 R^{3}}
$$

where $\theta$ is the polar angle and $P_{2}(\cos \theta)=\frac{3 \cos ^{2} \theta}{2}-\frac{1}{2}$. State a reasonable condition for equilibrium of the planet's surface and compute the value of $\varepsilon$ in terms of the parameter $\lambda=\frac{\omega^{2} R_{E}}{g}$, where $g$ is the gravitational acceleration. Make a numerical estimate of $\varepsilon$ for the earth. 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-168.jpg?height=429&width=603&top_left_y=221&top_left_x=507)

Fig. $1.67$.
1095.Solution:
The forces acting on a mass element $\Delta m$ on the surface of the planet are gravity, centrifugal force, and the constraint exerted by the rest of the planet. The condition for equilibrium of the surface is that the resultant of gravity and centrifugal force is perpendicular to the surface, i.e. it has no tangential component.

Suppose the surface of the planet is an ellipsoid of revolution with the $z$-axis as its axis of symmetry as shown in Fig. 1.67. The line of intersection of the ellipsoid with the $x z$-plane is an ellipse:

$$
z=R_{P} \cos \alpha, \quad x=R_{E} \sin \alpha,
$$

where $\alpha$ is a parameter. The polar angle $\theta$ of a point on the ellipse is given by

$$
\tan \theta=\frac{x}{z}=\frac{R_{E}}{R_{P}} \tan \alpha .
$$

The unit tangent $\tau$ to the ellipse at this point is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\boldsymbol{\tau} & \propto \mathbf{i} d x+\mathbf{k} d z=\left(\mathbf{i} \frac{d x}{d \alpha}+\mathbf{k} \frac{d z}{d \alpha}\right) d \alpha \\
&=\left(\mathbf{i} R_{E} \cos \alpha-\mathbf{k} R_{P} \sin \alpha\right) d \alpha=\frac{\cos \alpha}{R_{E}}\left(\mathbf{i} R_{E}^{2}-\mathbf{k} R_{P}^{2} \tan \theta\right) d \alpha .
\end{aligned}
$$

The centrifugal force $f_{1}$ on $\Delta m$ is

$$
\mathrm{f}_{1}=\mathrm{i} \Delta m R \omega^{2} \sin \theta
$$

and the gravitational force on it is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{f}_{2} &=-\nabla V=\nabla\left[\frac{G M_{e} \Delta m}{R}+\frac{2 G M_{e} \varepsilon R_{E}^{2} \Delta m}{5 R^{3}} P_{2}(\cos \theta)\right] \\
&=G M_{e} \Delta m\left(-\frac{1}{R^{2}}-\frac{6 \varepsilon R_{E}^{2}}{5 R^{4}} P_{2}(\cos \theta)\right) \mathbf{e}_{r}-\frac{6 G M_{e} \varepsilon R_{E}^{2} \Delta m}{5 R^{4}} \sin \theta \cos \theta \mathbf{e}_{\theta} .
\end{aligned}
$$

As

$$
\begin{gathered}
\mathbf{e}_{r}=\mathbf{i} \sin \theta+\mathbf{k} \cos \theta, \\
\mathbf{e}_{\theta}=\mathbf{i} \cos \theta-\mathbf{k} \sin \theta, \\
\mathbf{f}_{2}=G M_{e} \Delta m\left[-\frac{\sin \theta}{R^{2}}-\frac{6 \varepsilon R_{E}^{2}}{5 R^{4}} \sin \theta P_{2}(\cos \theta)-\frac{6 \varepsilon R_{E}^{2}}{5 R^{4}} \sin \theta \cos ^{2} \theta\right] \mathbf{i} \\
+G M_{e} \Delta m\left[-\frac{\cos \theta}{R^{2}}-\frac{6 \varepsilon R_{e}^{2}}{5 R^{4}} \cos \theta P_{2}(\cos \theta)+\frac{6 \varepsilon R_{E}^{2}}{5 R^{4}} \sin ^{2} \theta \cos \theta\right] \mathbf{k} \\
=G M_{e} \Delta m\left\{\mathbf{i}\left[-\frac{1}{R^{2}}-b\left(\frac{3}{2} \cos ^{2} \theta-\frac{1}{2}+\cos ^{2} \theta\right)\right] \sin \theta\right. \\
\left.+\mathbf{k}\left[-\frac{1}{R^{2}}-b\left(\frac{3}{2} \cos ^{2} \theta-\frac{1}{2}-\sin ^{2} \theta\right)\right] \cos \theta\right\},
\end{gathered}
$$

with $b=6 \varepsilon R_{E}^{2} / 5 R^{4}$.

The condition for equilibrium of the surface is

$$
\left(\mathbf{f}_{1}+\mathbf{f}_{2}\right) \cdot \boldsymbol{T}=0,
$$

which gives for $R \approx R_{P} \approx R_{E}$

$$
R_{E}^{3} \omega^{2} \sin \theta-R_{E}^{2} b G M_{e} \sin \theta \approx 0 .
$$

Hence

$$
\varepsilon=\frac{5 R_{E}^{2} b}{6} \approx \frac{5 R_{E}^{3} \omega^{2}}{6 G M_{e}}=\frac{5 R_{E} \omega^{2}}{6 g}=\frac{5 \lambda}{6}
$$

as $g=\frac{G M_{e}}{R_{E}^{2}}$. For earth, $R_{E}=6378 \times 10^{3} \mathrm{~m}, \omega=\frac{2 \pi}{24 \times 3600} \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s}, g=$ $9.8 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}$, we have

$$
\varepsilon \approx 2.9 \times 10^{-3} .
$$

1099.Problem Statement: A body is dropped from rest at a height $h$ above the surface of the earth and at a latitude $40^{\circ} \mathrm{N}$. For $h=100 \mathrm{~m}$, calculate the lateral displacement of the point of impact due to the Coriolis force.
1099.Solution:
If the body has mass $m$, in the rotating frame of the earth, a Coriolis force $-2 m \omega \times \dot{\mathbf{r}}$ is seen to act on the body. We choose a frame with origin at the point on the earth's surface below the starting point of the body, with $x$-axis pointing south, $y$-axis pointing east and $z$-axis pointing vertically up (Fig. 1.71). Then the equation of the motion of the body in the earth frame is

$$
\begin{aligned}
m \ddot{r} &=-m g \mathbf{k}-2 m \omega \times \dot{\mathbf{r}} \\
&=-m g \mathbf{k}-2 m\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
\mathbf{i} & \mathbf{j} & \mathbf{k} \\
-\omega \cos 40^{\circ} & 0 & \omega \sin 40^{\circ} \\
\dot{x} & \dot{y} & \dot{z}
\end{array}\right| .
\end{aligned}
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-177.jpg?height=378&width=349&top_left_y=1149&top_left_x=577)

Fig. 1,71

From the above, expressions for $\ddot{x}, \ddot{y}$ and $\ddot{z}$, can be obtained, which are readily integrated to give $\dot{x}, \dot{y}$ and $\dot{z}$. These results are then used in the expressions for $\ddot{x}, \ddot{y}$ and $\ddot{z}$. As the time of the drop of the body is short compared with the period of rotation of the earth, we can ignore terms of order $\omega^{2}$ and write the following: 

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\ddot{x}=0, \\
&\ddot{y}=2 g t \omega \cos 40^{\circ}, \\
&\ddot{z}=-g .
\end{aligned}
$$

Integrating the above twice and using the initial conditions, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
x &=0 \\
y &=\frac{1}{3} g t^{2} \omega \cos 40^{\circ}, \\
z-h &=-\frac{g t^{2}}{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$

The last equation gives the time of arrival of the body at the earth's surface $z=0$ :

$$
t=\sqrt{\frac{2 h}{g}} .
$$

Then the lateral displacement of the body at impact is

$$
y=\frac{1}{3} \sqrt{\frac{8 h^{3}}{g}} \omega \cos 40^{\circ}=0.017 \mathrm{~m} \text {. }
$$

1102.Problem Statement: A small celestial object, held together only by its self-gravitation, can be disrupted by the tidal forces produced by another massive body, if it comes near enough to that body. For an object of diameter $1 \mathrm{~km}$ and density $2 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{cm}^{3}$, find the critical distance from the earth (Roche limit).
1102.Solution:
Suppose the earth is fixed in space and the small celestial object orbits around it at a distance $l$ away as shown in Fig. 1.73. Let $M$ be the mass of the earth, $m$ the mass and $\rho$ the density of the small celestial object. Consider a unit mass of the object on the line $O C$ at distance $x$ from $C$. We have from the balance of forces on it

$$
(l-x) \omega^{2}=\frac{G M}{(l-x)^{2}}-\frac{G\left(\frac{4}{3}\right) \pi x^{3} \rho}{x^{2}} .
$$

We also have for the celestial body

$$
m l \omega^{2}=\frac{G M m}{l^{2}},
$$

which gives $\omega^{2}$ to be used in the above. Then as $\frac{x}{l} \ll 1$, retaining only the lowest order in $\frac{x}{l}$, we have

$$
l=\left(\frac{9 M}{4 \pi \rho}\right)^{\frac{1}{3}}
$$

With $M=6 \times 10^{27} \mathrm{~g}, \rho=2 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{cm}^{3}$, we find

$$
l=1.29 \times 10^{9} \mathrm{~cm}=1.29 \times 10^{4} \mathrm{~km} .
$$

If $l$ is less than this value, the earth's attraction becomes too large for the unit mass to be held by the celestial body and disruption of the latter occurs.

If the unit mass is located to the right of $C$ on the extended line of $O C$, $x$ is negative but the above conclusion still holds true. We may also consider a unit mass located off the line $O C$ such as the point $P$ in Fig. 1.74. We now have

$$
\sqrt{(l-x)^{2}+y^{2}} \omega^{2} \cos \theta=\frac{G M}{(l-x)^{2}+y^{2}} \cos \theta-\frac{4}{3} \pi \rho G \sqrt{x^{2}+y^{2}} \cos \varphi,
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-182.jpg?height=214&width=306&top_left_y=209&top_left_x=289)

Fig. 1.73.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-182.jpg?height=200&width=463&top_left_y=222&top_left_x=708)

Fig. $1.74$

with

$$
\cos \theta=\frac{l-x}{\sqrt{(l-x)^{2}+y^{2}}}, \quad \cos \varphi=\frac{x}{\sqrt{x^{2}+y^{2}}} \text {. }
$$

As $x / l \ll 1, y / l \ll 1$, and retaining only the first-order terms we would obtain the same result.

1108.b.Problem Statement:
Let $S$ be a set of axes centered at the earth's center, with the $z$-axis pointing north, forming an inertial frame. Let $S^{\prime}$ be similarly placed, but rotating with the earth.

In the northern hemisphere, find the direction of the Coriolis force on a body moving eastward and on one moving vertically upward.
1108.b.Solution:
Let $X Y Z$ be the inertial reference frame $S$ and $X^{\prime} Y^{\prime} Z^{\prime}$ the rotating frame $S^{\prime}$ fixed to the earth which rotates with angular velocity $\omega$. In $S^{\prime}$, an arbitrary vector $\mathbf{A}$ can be written as

$$
\mathbf{A}=A_{x} \mathbf{i}+A_{y} \mathbf{j}+A_{z} \mathbf{k} .
$$

In $S$, the time derivative of $\mathbf{A}$ is

$$
\frac{d \mathbf{A}}{d t}=\left(\frac{d A_{x}}{d t} \mathbf{i}+\frac{d A_{y}}{d t} \mathbf{j}+\frac{d A_{z}}{d t} \mathbf{k}\right)+\left(A_{x} \frac{d \mathbf{i}}{d t}+A_{y} \frac{d \mathbf{j}}{d t}+A_{z} \frac{d \mathbf{k}}{d t}\right) .
$$

Let $d^{*} / d t$ denote time derivative in $S^{\prime}$, then

$$
\frac{d^{*} \mathbf{A}}{d t}=\frac{d A_{x}}{d t} \mathbf{i}+\frac{d A_{y}}{d t} \mathbf{j}+\frac{d A_{z}}{d t} \mathbf{k} .
$$

The kinematics of a rigid body gives 

$$
\frac{d \mathbf{i}}{d t}=\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{i}, \quad \frac{d \mathbf{j}}{d t}=\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{j}, \quad \frac{d \mathbf{k}}{d t}=\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{k} .
$$

Hence

$$
\frac{d \mathbf{A}}{d t}=\frac{d^{*} A}{d t}+\omega \times\left(A_{x} \mathbf{i}+A_{y} \mathbf{j}+A_{z} \mathbf{k}\right)=\frac{d^{*} \mathbf{A}}{d t}+\omega \times \mathbf{A}
$$

Thus for the radius vector $\mathbf{r}$ to a point $P$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{d \mathbf{r}}{d t} &=\frac{d^{*} \mathbf{r}}{d t}+\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{r} \\
\frac{d^{2} r}{d t^{2}} &=\frac{d^{*}}{d t}\left(\frac{d^{*} \mathbf{r}}{d t}+\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{r}\right)+\boldsymbol{\omega} \times\left(\frac{d^{*} \mathbf{r}}{d t}+\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{r}\right) \\
&=\frac{d^{* 2} \mathbf{r}}{d t^{2}}+2 \boldsymbol{\omega} \times \frac{d^{*} \mathbf{r}}{d t}+\boldsymbol{\omega} \times(\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{r})+\frac{d^{*} \boldsymbol{\omega}}{d t} \times \mathbf{r}
\end{aligned}
$$

Note that in the above

$$
\frac{d^{*} \omega}{d t}=\frac{d \omega}{d t}-\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \boldsymbol{\omega}=\frac{d \omega}{d t} .
$$

Newton's second law applies to the inertial fraine, so for a particle of mass $m$ at $P$ acted on by a force $\mathbf{F}$, we have

$$
\mathbf{F}=m \frac{d^{2} \mathbf{r}}{d t^{2}}=m \frac{d^{* 2} \mathbf{r}}{d t^{2}}+2 m \boldsymbol{\omega} \times \frac{d^{*} \mathbf{r}}{d t}+m \boldsymbol{\omega} \times(\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{r})+m \frac{d^{*} \boldsymbol{\omega}}{d t} \times \mathbf{r} .
$$

Denoting $\frac{d^{*}}{d t}$ by a dot and noting that for the earth $\dot{\omega}=0$, we write the above as

$$
m \ddot{\mathbf{r}}=\mathbf{F}-2 m \boldsymbol{\omega} \times \dot{\mathbf{r}}-m \boldsymbol{\omega} \times(\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{r})
$$

for the rotating frame. This shows that Newton's second law can still be considered valid if, in addition to $F$, we introduce two fictitious forces: $-2 m \boldsymbol{\omega} \times \dot{\mathbf{r}}$, the Coriolis force, and $-m \boldsymbol{\omega} \times(\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{r})$, the centrifugal force. Thus a body of mass $m$ moving on earth with a velocity $\mathbf{v}^{\prime}$ is seen by an observer on the earth to suffer a Coriolis force $-2 m \omega \times \mathbf{v}^{\prime}$.

Choose for $S^{\prime}$ a frame fixed at a point on the surface of the earth at latitude $\lambda$ and let its orthogonal unit vectors $\mathbf{i}, \mathbf{j}, \mathbf{k}$ be directed toward the south, the east and vertically upward respectively. Then

$$
\boldsymbol{\omega}=-\omega \cos \lambda \mathbf{i}+\omega \sin \lambda \mathbf{k} .
$$

(1) When the body moves eastward, $\mathbf{v}^{\prime}=\dot{y} \mathbf{j}$, the Coriolis force is

$$
\mathbf{F}_{\varepsilon}=-2 m \boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{v}^{\prime}=2 m \boldsymbol{\omega} \dot{y} \sin \lambda \mathbf{i}+2 m \omega \dot{y} \cos \lambda \mathbf{k},
$$

which has magnitude

$$
\left|\mathbf{F}_{c}\right|=\sqrt{(2 m \omega \dot{y} \sin \lambda)^{2}+(2 m \omega \dot{y} \cos \lambda)^{2}}=2 m \omega \dot{y}
$$

and is pointing south at an inclination angle $\phi$ given by

$$
\tan \phi=\frac{\cos \lambda}{\sin \lambda}=\tan \left(\frac{\pi}{2}-\lambda\right) .
$$

(2) When the body moves upward, $\mathbf{v}^{\prime}=\dot{z} \mathbf{k}$, the Coriolis force is

$$
\mathbf{F}_{c}=-2 m \boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{v}^{\prime}=-2 m \omega \dot{z} \cos \lambda \mathbf{j} \text {, }
$$

which has magnitude $2 m \omega \dot{z} \cos \lambda$ and direction toward the west.

1108.c.Problem Statement:
Let $S$ be a set of axes centered at the earth's center, with the $z$-axis pointing north, forming an inertial frame. Let $S^{\prime}$ be similarly placed, but rotating with the earth.

Consider a body dropped from a height of 10 feet at a latitude of $30^{\circ} \mathrm{N}$. Find, approximately, the horizontal deflection due to the Coriolis effect when it reaches the ground. Neglect air resistance.
1108.c.Solution:
Let $X Y Z$ be the inertial reference frame $S$ and $X^{\prime} Y^{\prime} Z^{\prime}$ the rotating frame $S^{\prime}$ fixed to the earth which rotates with angular velocity $\omega$. In $S^{\prime}$, an arbitrary vector $\mathbf{A}$ can be written as

$$
\mathbf{A}=A_{x} \mathbf{i}+A_{y} \mathbf{j}+A_{z} \mathbf{k} .
$$

In $S$, the time derivative of $\mathbf{A}$ is

$$
\frac{d \mathbf{A}}{d t}=\left(\frac{d A_{x}}{d t} \mathbf{i}+\frac{d A_{y}}{d t} \mathbf{j}+\frac{d A_{z}}{d t} \mathbf{k}\right)+\left(A_{x} \frac{d \mathbf{i}}{d t}+A_{y} \frac{d \mathbf{j}}{d t}+A_{z} \frac{d \mathbf{k}}{d t}\right) .
$$

Let $d^{*} / d t$ denote time derivative in $S^{\prime}$, then

$$
\frac{d^{*} \mathbf{A}}{d t}=\frac{d A_{x}}{d t} \mathbf{i}+\frac{d A_{y}}{d t} \mathbf{j}+\frac{d A_{z}}{d t} \mathbf{k} .
$$

The kinematics of a rigid body gives 

$$
\frac{d \mathbf{i}}{d t}=\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{i}, \quad \frac{d \mathbf{j}}{d t}=\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{j}, \quad \frac{d \mathbf{k}}{d t}=\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{k} .
$$

Hence

$$
\frac{d \mathbf{A}}{d t}=\frac{d^{*} A}{d t}+\omega \times\left(A_{x} \mathbf{i}+A_{y} \mathbf{j}+A_{z} \mathbf{k}\right)=\frac{d^{*} \mathbf{A}}{d t}+\omega \times \mathbf{A}
$$

Thus for the radius vector $\mathbf{r}$ to a point $P$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{d \mathbf{r}}{d t} &=\frac{d^{*} \mathbf{r}}{d t}+\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{r} \\
\frac{d^{2} r}{d t^{2}} &=\frac{d^{*}}{d t}\left(\frac{d^{*} \mathbf{r}}{d t}+\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{r}\right)+\boldsymbol{\omega} \times\left(\frac{d^{*} \mathbf{r}}{d t}+\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{r}\right) \\
&=\frac{d^{* 2} \mathbf{r}}{d t^{2}}+2 \boldsymbol{\omega} \times \frac{d^{*} \mathbf{r}}{d t}+\boldsymbol{\omega} \times(\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{r})+\frac{d^{*} \boldsymbol{\omega}}{d t} \times \mathbf{r}
\end{aligned}
$$

Note that in the above

$$
\frac{d^{*} \omega}{d t}=\frac{d \omega}{d t}-\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \boldsymbol{\omega}=\frac{d \omega}{d t} .
$$

Newton's second law applies to the inertial fraine, so for a particle of mass $m$ at $P$ acted on by a force $\mathbf{F}$, we have

$$
\mathbf{F}=m \frac{d^{2} \mathbf{r}}{d t^{2}}=m \frac{d^{* 2} \mathbf{r}}{d t^{2}}+2 m \boldsymbol{\omega} \times \frac{d^{*} \mathbf{r}}{d t}+m \boldsymbol{\omega} \times(\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{r})+m \frac{d^{*} \boldsymbol{\omega}}{d t} \times \mathbf{r} .
$$

Denoting $\frac{d^{*}}{d t}$ by a dot and noting that for the earth $\dot{\omega}=0$, we write the above as

$$
m \ddot{\mathbf{r}}=\mathbf{F}-2 m \boldsymbol{\omega} \times \dot{\mathbf{r}}-m \boldsymbol{\omega} \times(\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{r})
$$

for the rotating frame. This shows that Newton's second law can still be considered valid if, in addition to $F$, we introduce two fictitious forces: $-2 m \boldsymbol{\omega} \times \dot{\mathbf{r}}$, the Coriolis force, and $-m \boldsymbol{\omega} \times(\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{r})$, the centrifugal force. Thus a body of mass $m$ moving on earth with a velocity $\mathbf{v}^{\prime}$ is seen by an observer on the earth to suffer a Coriolis force $-2 m \omega \times \mathbf{v}^{\prime}$.

Choose for $S^{\prime}$ a frame fixed at a point on the surface of the earth at latitude $\lambda$ and let its orthogonal unit vectors $\mathbf{i}, \mathbf{j}, \mathbf{k}$ be directed toward the south, the east and vertically upward respectively. Then

$$
\boldsymbol{\omega}=-\omega \cos \lambda \mathbf{i}+\omega \sin \lambda \mathbf{k} .
$$

(1) When the body moves eastward, $\mathbf{v}^{\prime}=\dot{y} \mathbf{j}$, the Coriolis force is

$$
\mathbf{F}_{\varepsilon}=-2 m \boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{v}^{\prime}=2 m \boldsymbol{\omega} \dot{y} \sin \lambda \mathbf{i}+2 m \omega \dot{y} \cos \lambda \mathbf{k},
$$

which has magnitude

$$
\left|\mathbf{F}_{c}\right|=\sqrt{(2 m \omega \dot{y} \sin \lambda)^{2}+(2 m \omega \dot{y} \cos \lambda)^{2}}=2 m \omega \dot{y}
$$

and is pointing south at an inclination angle $\phi$ given by

$$
\tan \phi=\frac{\cos \lambda}{\sin \lambda}=\tan \left(\frac{\pi}{2}-\lambda\right) .
$$

(2) When the body moves upward, $\mathbf{v}^{\prime}=\dot{z} \mathbf{k}$, the Coriolis force is

$$
\mathbf{F}_{c}=-2 m \boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{v}^{\prime}=-2 m \omega \dot{z} \cos \lambda \mathbf{j} \text {, }
$$

which has magnitude $2 m \omega \dot{z} \cos \lambda$ and direction toward the west.The equations of motion for the free-fall body in $S^{\prime}$ are

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
m \ddot{x}=2 m \omega \dot{y} \sin \lambda, \\
m \ddot{y}=-2 m \omega(\dot{x} \sin \lambda+\dot{z} \cos \lambda), \\
m \ddot{z}=-m g+2 m \omega \dot{y} \cos \lambda,
\end{array}\right.
$$

with initial conditions $x=y=0, z=h=10 \mathrm{ft}, \dot{x}=\dot{y}=\dot{z}=0$ at $t=0$. Integrating and using the initial conditions, we obtain

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\dot{x}=2 \omega y \sin \lambda, \\
\dot{y}=-2 \omega[x \sin \lambda+(z-h) \cos \lambda], \\
\dot{z}=-g t+2 \omega y \cos \lambda .
\end{array}\right.
$$

Substituting these into the original set of equations, we obtain

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\ddot{x}=-4 \omega^{2}[x \sin \lambda+(z-h) \cos \lambda] \sin \lambda, \\
\ddot{y}=2 g t \omega \cos \lambda-4 \omega^{2} y, \\
\ddot{z}=-g-4 \omega^{2}[x \sin \lambda+(z-h) \cos \lambda] \cos \lambda .
\end{array}\right.
$$

Neglecting the terms involving $\omega^{2}$, we have approximately

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\ddot{x}=0, \\
\ddot{y}=2 g t \omega \cos \lambda y, \\
\ddot{z}=-g .
\end{array}\right.
$$

Integrating, applying the initial conditions and eliminating $t$, we obtain

$$
y^{2}=\left(\frac{8 \omega^{2} \cos ^{2} \lambda}{9 g}\right)(h-z)^{3} .
$$

When the body reaches the ground, $z=0$,

$$
y=\left(\frac{2 \omega \cos \lambda}{3}\right) \sqrt{\frac{2 h^{3}}{g}} .
$$

With $h=10 \mathrm{ft}=3.05 \mathrm{~m}, \lambda=30^{\circ}$, we find $y=1.01 \times 10^{-4} \mathrm{~m}$. Hence the deflection due to the Coriolis effect is toward the east and has a magnitude $0.01 \mathrm{~cm}$.

1111.a.Problem Statement:
In terms of $G, L$ and the masses:

What is the rotational period of an equal-mass $\left(M_{1}=M_{2}=M\right)$ double star of separation $L$ ?
1111.a.Solution:
Equal-mass double star

The gravitational force on each star is $f=G M^{2} / L^{2}$. The radius of circular orbit of each star with respect to the center of mass frame of the double star is $R=L / 2$. The centripetal acceleration of each star is $a=v^{2} / R$, where $v$ is the speed of each star in the cms frame. Using these, we have

$$
\frac{M v^{2}}{R}=\frac{G M^{2}}{L^{2}},
$$

or

$$
v^{2}=\frac{G M R}{L^{2}}=\frac{G M}{2 L} .
$$

Hence the period of the double star is

$$
T=\frac{2 \pi R}{v}=\frac{\pi L}{\sqrt{\frac{G M}{2 L}}}=\pi L \sqrt{\frac{2 L}{G M}}
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-200.jpg?height=107&width=397&top_left_y=1671&top_left_x=578)

Fig. $1.82$.

1111.b.Problem Statement:
In terms of $G, L$ and the masses:

What is the period of an unequal-mass $\left(M_{1} \neq M_{2}\right)$ double star of separation $L$ ?
1111.b.Solution:
Equal-mass double star

The gravitational force on each star is $f=G M^{2} / L^{2}$. The radius of circular orbit of each star with respect to the center of mass frame of the double star is $R=L / 2$. The centripetal acceleration of each star is $a=v^{2} / R$, where $v$ is the speed of each star in the cms frame. Using these, we have

$$
\frac{M v^{2}}{R}=\frac{G M^{2}}{L^{2}},
$$

or

$$
v^{2}=\frac{G M R}{L^{2}}=\frac{G M}{2 L} .
$$

Hence the period of the double star is

$$
T=\frac{2 \pi R}{v}=\frac{\pi L}{\sqrt{\frac{G M}{2 L}}}=\pi L \sqrt{\frac{2 L}{G M}}
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-200.jpg?height=107&width=397&top_left_y=1671&top_left_x=578)

Fig. $1.82$.Unequal-mass double star

Let $O$ be the center of mass of the double star. Then, as in Fig. 1.82,

$$
l_{1}=\frac{M_{2} L}{M_{1}+M_{2}}, \quad l_{2}=\frac{M_{1} L}{M_{1}+M_{2}} .
$$

For $M_{1}, f=G M_{1} M_{2} / L^{2}$, the radius of circular motion is $l_{1}$, and the centripetal acceleration is $a_{1}=v_{1}^{2} / l_{1}$. Hence

$$
\frac{M_{1} v_{1}^{2}}{l_{1}}=\frac{G M_{1} M_{2}}{L^{2}},
$$

giving

$$
v_{1}^{2}=\frac{G M_{2}}{L} \frac{l_{1}}{L}=\frac{G M_{2}}{L} \frac{M_{2}}{M_{1}+M_{2}} .
$$

The rotational period of $M_{1}$ is then

$$
T_{1}=2 \pi \frac{l_{1}}{v_{1}}=2 \pi \frac{M_{2} L}{M_{1}+M_{2}} \frac{\sqrt{L\left(M_{1}+M_{2}\right)}}{M_{2} \sqrt{G}}=2 \pi L \sqrt{\frac{L}{G\left(M_{1}+M_{2}\right)}} .
$$

Interchange of the subscripts 1 and 2 shows that this is also the period $T_{2}$ of $M_{2}$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{r}_{c}=\frac{\sum_{i} M_{i} \mathbf{r}_{i}}{\sum_{i} M_{i}} &=\frac{L}{M_{1}+M_{2}+M_{3}}\left(M_{2} \mathbf{i}+\frac{1}{2} M_{3} \mathbf{i}+\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} M_{3} \mathbf{j}\right) \\
&=\frac{L}{M_{1}+M_{2}+M_{3}}\left[\left(M_{2}+\frac{1}{2} M_{3}\right) \mathbf{i}+\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} M_{3} \mathbf{j}\right] .
\end{aligned}
$$

The attractive forces exerted by $M_{2}$ and $M_{3}$ on $M_{1}$ are respectively

$$
\mathbf{f}_{12}=\frac{G M_{1} M_{2}}{L^{2}} \mathbf{i}
$$

and

$$
\mathbf{f}_{13}=\frac{G M_{1} M_{3}}{L^{2}}\left(\frac{1}{2} \mathbf{i}+\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \mathbf{j}\right) \text {, }
$$

so that the resultant force on $M_{1}$ is 

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{f}_{1} &=\mathbf{f}_{12}+\mathbf{f}_{13} \\
&=\frac{G M_{1}}{L^{2}}\left[\left(M_{2}+\frac{M_{3}}{2}\right) \mathbf{i}+\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} M_{3} \mathbf{j}\right] .
\end{aligned}
$$

This shows that $\mathbf{f}_{\mathbf{1}}$ is parallel to $\mathbf{r}_{c}$. Its magnitude is

$$
f_{1}=\frac{G M_{1}}{L^{2}} \sqrt{\left(\frac{M_{2}+M_{3}}{2}\right)^{2}+\frac{3 M_{3}^{2}}{4}}=\frac{G M_{1}}{L^{2}} \sqrt{M_{2}^{2}+M_{3}^{2}+M_{2} M_{3}} .
$$

The radius of the circular orbit about the center of mass in which $M_{1}$ moves is

$$
R_{1}=r_{\mathrm{c}}=\frac{L}{M_{1}+M_{2}+M_{3}} \sqrt{M_{2}^{2}+M_{3}^{2}+M_{2} M_{3}} .
$$

Then the equation of the motion of $M_{1}$ is

$$
\frac{M_{1} v_{1}^{2}}{R_{1}}=\left(\frac{G M_{1}}{L^{2}}\right) \sqrt{M_{2}^{2}+M_{3}^{2}+M_{2} M_{3}}
$$

giving for the speed $v_{1}$ of $M_{1}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
v_{1}^{2} &=\frac{G}{L} \sqrt{M_{2}^{2}+M_{3}^{2}+M_{2} M_{3}}\left(\frac{R_{1}}{L}\right) \\
&=\frac{G}{L}\left(\frac{M_{2}^{2}+M_{3}^{2}+M_{2} M_{3}}{M_{1}+M_{2}+M_{3}}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the rotational period of $M_{1}$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
T_{1} &=\frac{2 \pi R_{1}}{v_{1}} \\
&=2 \pi L \sqrt{\frac{L}{G\left(M_{1}+M_{2}+M_{3}\right)}},
\end{aligned}
$$

which is obviously also the period of $M_{2}$ and $M_{3}$.

1112.Problem Statement: A particle of mass $m$, charge $q$, and initial velocity $v$ collides head-on with an identical particle initially at rest. What is the distance of closest approach between the two particles (in classical mechanics)? What is the velocity of each particle at the instant of closest approach? What is the final velocity of each particle? Justify your answers.
1112.Solution:
The relative velocity is zero when the two particles are at closest approach. Conservation of momentum then gives $m v=2 m v^{\prime}$ and $v^{\prime}=$ $v / 2$ as the velocity of each particle at the instant of closest approach. Conservation of energy gives

$$
\frac{m v^{2}}{2}=\frac{m v^{\prime 2}}{2}+\frac{m v^{\prime 2}}{2}+\frac{q^{2}}{r}
$$

and thus

$$
r=\frac{4 q^{2}}{m v^{2}}
$$

as the distance of closest approach. The final velocity of the incident particle is zero and that of the particle initially at rest is $v$. This can be seen from the symmetry of the problem.

1113.Problem Statement:
Two steel spheres, the lower of radius $2 a$ and the upper of radius $a$, are dropped from a height $h$ (measured from the center of the large sphere) above a steel plate as shown in Fig. 1.85. Assuming the centers of the spheres always lie on a vertical line and all collisions are elastic, what is the maximum height the upper sphere will reach?

Hint: Assume the larger sphere collides with the plate and recoils before it collides with the small sphere.
1113.Solution:
Let the mass of the smaller sphere be $m_{1}$ and that of the larger one $m_{2}$. Then $m_{2}=8 m_{1}$. The landing velocity of the larger sphere is $v_{2}=$ $\sqrt{2 g(h-2 a)}$ and its velocity immediately after bouncing back from the steel plate is still $v$ in magnitude. At this point, the descending velocity of the smaller sphere is $v_{1}=\sqrt{2 g(h-2 a)}=v_{2}$. Let the velocities of the larger and smaller spheres after elastic collision be $v_{2}^{\prime}$ and $v_{1}^{\prime}$ respectively 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-205.jpg?height=419&width=250&top_left_y=249&top_left_x=610)

Fig. $1.85$.

and take the upward direction as positive. Conservation of momentum and of mechanical energy give

$$
\begin{aligned}
m_{2} v_{2}-m_{1} v_{1} &=m_{2} v_{2}^{\prime}+m_{1} v_{2}^{\prime} \\
\frac{m_{1} v_{1}^{2}}{2}+\frac{m_{2} v_{2}^{2}}{2} &=\frac{m_{2} v_{2}^{\prime 2}}{2}+\frac{m_{1} v_{1}^{\prime 2}}{2},
\end{aligned}
$$

whose solution is

$$
\begin{aligned}
&v_{2}^{\prime}=\frac{5 v_{2}}{9}=\frac{5}{9} \sqrt{2 g(h-2 a)}, \\
&v_{1}^{\prime}=\frac{23 v_{2}}{9}=\frac{23}{9} \sqrt{2 g(h-2 a)} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Conservation of the mechanical energy of the smaller sphere thus gives the maximum height (measured from the steel plate) of the smaller sphere as

$$
H=3 a+\frac{v_{1}^{\prime 2}}{2 g}=3 a+\frac{529}{81}(h-2 a) .
$$

1114.b.Problem Statement:
A railroad flatcar of mass $M$ can roll without friction along a straight horizontal track as shown in Fig. 1.86. $N$ men, each of mass $m$, are initially standing on the car which is at rest.

The $N$ men run off the car, one after the other (only one man running at a time), each reaching a speed $V_{r}$ relative to the car just before jumping off. Find an expression for the final velocity of the car.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-206.jpg?height=145&width=383&top_left_y=656&top_left_x=591)

Fig. 1.86.
1114.b.Solution:
As there is no horizontal external force acting, the center of mass of the system consisting of the flatcar and $N$ men remains stationary. Taking the $x$-axis along the track, we have for the center of mass,

$$
\begin{aligned}
x_{\mathrm{cm}} &=\frac{M x_{\mathrm{car}}+N m x_{\operatorname{man}}}{M+N m}, \\
\dot{x}_{\mathrm{cm}} &=0=M \dot{x}_{\mathrm{car}}+N m \dot{x}_{\operatorname{man}},
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\dot{x}_{\text {car }}$ and $\dot{x}_{\text {man }}$ are respectively the velocities of the car and each man after the men have jumped off. Writing $\dot{x}_{\text {car }}=V_{\text {car }}$ and noting that $\dot{x}_{\text {man }}=V_{\text {car }}-V_{r}$, we have

$$
M V_{\text {car }}+N m\left(V_{\text {car }}-V_{r}\right)=0,
$$

giving

$$
V_{\text {car }}=\frac{N m V_{r}}{M+N m} .
$$

Consider the transition from $n$ men to $(n-1)$ men on the car. Let $V_{n}$ be the velocity of the car when $n$ men are left on it. The total momentum of the car with the $n$ men is

$$
P_{n}=M V_{n}+n m V_{n} .
$$

When the $n$th man jumps off the car with a speed $V_{r}$ relative to the car, the momentum of the system consisting of the car and $n$ men is

$$
P_{n-1}=M V_{n-1}+(n-1) m V_{n-1}+m\left(V_{n-1}-V_{r}\right) .
$$

Momentum conservation $P_{n-1}=P_{n}$ gives

$$
(M+n m) V_{n}=(M+n m) V_{n-1}-m V_{r},
$$

or

$$
V_{n-1}=V_{n}+\frac{m V_{r}}{M+n m}
$$

Hence

$$
V_{n-s}=V_{n}+\sum_{i=1}^{s} \frac{m V_{r}}{M+(n-i+1) m} .
$$

As $n=N, V_{N}=0$ initially, we have for $s=N$,

$$
V_{0}=\sum_{i=1}^{N} \frac{m V_{r}}{M+(N-i+1) m}=\sum_{n=1}^{N} \frac{m V_{r}}{M+n m} .
$$

1115.Problem Statement:
A projectile of mass $m$ is shot (at velocity $V$ ) at a target of mass $M$, with a hole containing a spring of constant $k$. The target is initially at rest and can slide without friction on a horizontal surface (Fig. 1.87) . Find the distance $\Delta x$ that the spring compresses at maximum.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-207.jpg?height=143&width=518&top_left_y=1684&top_left_x=460)

Fig. 1.87.
1115.Solution:
At the instant the spring compresses at maximum, the projectile $m$ and the target $M$ move with the same velocity $V_{e}$. Conservation of energy

$$
\frac{m V^{2}}{2}=\frac{m V_{e}^{2}}{2}+\frac{M V_{e}^{2}}{2}+\frac{k(\Delta x)^{2}}{2},
$$

and conservation of momentum

$$
m V=(m+M) V_{e}
$$

give

$$
\Delta x=\sqrt{\frac{m M}{k(m+M)}} V .
$$

1116.Problem Statement:
A heavy star of mass $M$ and radius $R$ moves with velocity $\mathbf{V}$ through a very dilute gas of mass density $\rho$. It pulls particles toward itself by its gravitational field and captures all of the atoms that strike its surface. Find the drag force on the star with the approximation that the thermal velocities of the atoms are negligible relative to $|\mathbf{V}|$ and the interactions of atoms with each other can be neglected.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-208.jpg?height=206&width=499&top_left_y=1355&top_left_x=494)

Fig. $1.88$
1116.Solution:
In a frame moving with the star, gas atoms move with velocity $-\mathbf{V}$ toward the star from infinity. Under the influence of the star's gravitational field, the trajectories of the gas atoms are as shown in Fig. 1.88. Let $b$ be the largest impact parameter for which a gas atom can just be captured by the star and $v$ the velocity of the gas atom just before capturing. Conservation of angular momentum gives

$$
v R=b V,
$$

and conservation of energy gives

$$
\frac{v^{2}}{2}-\frac{G M}{R}=\frac{V^{2}}{2},
$$

from which we obtain

$$
b^{2}=\frac{R^{2}}{V^{2}}\left(V^{2}+\frac{2 G M}{R}\right) .
$$

The drag force on the star is equal to the momentum absorbed per unit time:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{F} &=\frac{d \mathbf{P}}{d t}=\lim _{\Delta t \rightarrow 0} \frac{\pi b^{2} V \Delta t \cdot \rho(-\mathbf{V})}{\Delta t} \\
&=-\pi b^{2} \rho V \mathbf{V}=-\frac{\pi R^{2} \rho}{V}\left(V^{2}+\frac{2 G M}{R}\right) \mathbf{V} .
\end{aligned}
$$

1117.Problem Statement:
Consider a collection of point particles of mass $m$ moving in circular orbits about a common center each with the same kinetic energy. If the only force present is the mutual (Newtonian) gravitational force, what is the particle density as a function of radius $r$ from the center in order that the density remains constant in time?

(Assume that the density is spherically symmetric.)
1117.Solution:
Let $T$ be the kinetic energy of each particle. As it moves in a circular orbit of radius $r$ under the action of the mutual gravitational forces, we have

$$
\frac{m v^{2}}{r}=\frac{G M m}{r^{2}} .
$$

Thus

$$
T=\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}=\frac{G M m}{2 r},
$$

giving

$$
M(r)=\frac{2 T r}{G m}
$$

as the total mass of the particles which move in a sphere of radius $r$ at the common center. As

$$
d M=4 \pi r^{2} \rho(r) d r
$$

we have

$$
\rho(r)=\frac{1}{4 \pi r^{2}} \frac{d M}{d r}=\frac{T}{2 \pi r^{2} G m},
$$

from which we obtain the particle density

$$
n(r)=\frac{\rho}{m}=\frac{T}{2 \pi r^{2} G m^{2}} .
$$

1121.c.Problem Statement:

Seek a solution to the equations of motion in which all particles oscillate with a common frequency (normal modes) and calculate the possible frequencies.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-215.jpg?height=140&width=305&top_left_y=692&top_left_x=275)

Fig. 1.90.

Fig. 1.91.
1121.c.Solution:
The system has two vibrational degrees of freedom.

Let $x_{1}, x_{2}$ and $x_{3}$ be the displacements of $\mathrm{O}^{-}, \mathrm{C}^{++}$, and $\mathrm{O}^{-}$ from their equilibrium positions respectively, as shown in Fig. 1.91. The equations of motion are

$$
\begin{aligned}
m \ddot{x}_{1} &=k\left(x_{2}-x_{1}\right), \\
M \ddot{x}_{2} &=k\left(x_{3}-x_{2}\right)-k\left(x_{2}-x_{1}\right)=k\left(x_{1}-2 x_{2}+x_{3}\right), \\
m \ddot{x}_{3} &=-k\left(x_{3}-x_{2}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$Let $x_{1}=A_{1} \cos \omega t, x_{2}=A_{2} \cos \omega t$ and $x_{3}=A_{3} \cos \omega t$ in the equations above. We have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(k-m \omega^{2}\right) A_{1}-k A_{2} &=0, \\
-k A_{1}+\left(2 k-M \omega^{2}\right) A_{2}-k A_{3} &=0, \\
-k A_{1}+\left(k-m \omega^{2}\right) A_{3} &=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

For $A_{1}, A_{2}, A_{3}$ not to be identically zero, we require

$$
\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
k-m \omega^{2} & -k & 0 \\
-k & 2 k-M \omega^{2} & -k \\
0 & -k & k-m \omega^{2}
\end{array}\right|=0
$$

which has solutions

$$
\omega_{1}=\sqrt{\frac{k}{m}}, \quad \omega_{2}=\sqrt{\frac{(2 m+M) k}{m M}}, \quad \text { and } \quad \omega_{3}=0 .
$$

Angular frequencies $\omega_{1}$ and $\omega_{2}$ correspond to possible vibrations, while $\omega_{3}$ corresponds to the translational oscillations of the molecule as a whole.

1122.a.Problem Statement:
Take a very long chain of beads connected by identical springs of spring constant $K$ and equilibrium length $a$, as shown in Fig. 1.93. Each bead is free to oscillate along the $x$ direction. All beads have mass $m$ except for one which has mass $m_{0}<m$. The mass of the spring is negligibly small.

Far from the "special" bead, what is the relation between the wave vector and the frequency of the resulting oscillation?

Hint for part (b): Try a solution of the form 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-217.jpg?height=221&width=779&top_left_y=220&top_left_x=346)

Fig, $1.93$.

$$
\begin{array}{lll}
x_{n}=A e^{i k a n}+B e^{-i k a n} & \text { for } & n<0, \\
x_{n}=C e^{i k a n} & \text { for } & n>0,
\end{array}
$$

where $A, B$, and $C$ are functions of time.
1122.a.Solution:
For $n \neq 0$,

$$
\ddot{x}_{n}=-\frac{K}{m}\left[\left(x_{n}-x_{n-1}\right)+\left(x_{n}-x_{n+1}\right)\right]=-\frac{K}{m}\left(2 x_{n}-x_{n+1}-x_{n-1}\right) .
$$

Setting $x_{n}=A e^{i(k a n-\omega t)}$ in the above, we obtain

$$
-\omega^{2} x_{n}=-\frac{K}{m}\left(2-e^{i k a}-e^{-i k a}\right) x_{n}=-\frac{2 K}{m}[1-\cos (k a)] x_{n},
$$

or

$$
\omega^{2}=\frac{2 K}{m}[1-\cos (k a)] .
$$

Fig, $1.93$.

$$
\begin{array}{lll}
x_{n}=A e^{i k a n}+B e^{-i k a n} & \text { for } & n<0, \\
x_{n}=C e^{i k a n} & \text { for } & n>0,
\end{array}
$$

where $A, B$, and $C$ are functions of time.
1122.b.Solution:
For $n \neq 0$,

$$
\ddot{x}_{n}=-\frac{K}{m}\left[\left(x_{n}-x_{n-1}\right)+\left(x_{n}-x_{n+1}\right)\right]=-\frac{K}{m}\left(2 x_{n}-x_{n+1}-x_{n-1}\right) .
$$

Setting $x_{n}=A e^{i(k a n-\omega t)}$ in the above, we obtain

$$
-\omega^{2} x_{n}=-\frac{K}{m}\left(2-e^{i k a}-e^{-i k a}\right) x_{n}=-\frac{2 K}{m}[1-\cos (k a)] x_{n},
$$

or

$$
\omega^{2}=\frac{2 K}{m}[1-\cos (k a)] .
$$Try a solution of the form

$$
\begin{aligned}
& x_{n}=\left(A e^{i k a n}+B e^{-i k a n}\right) e^{-i \omega t} \quad \text { for } \quad n \leq 0, \\
& x_{n}=C e^{i(k a n-\omega t)} \quad \text { for } \quad n \geq 0 \text {. }
\end{aligned}
$$

For $n=0$, the above implies $C=A+B$. Substituting the solution into the equation of the motion of the $n=0$ bead,

$$
\ddot{x}_{0}=-\frac{K}{m_{0}}\left(2 x_{0}-x_{1}-x_{-1}\right),
$$

we find

$$
\frac{\omega^{2} m_{0}}{K}(A+B)=2(A+B)-(A+B) e^{i k a}-A e^{-i k a}-B e^{i k a}
$$

or

$$
\begin{aligned}
A &=\left[\frac{m_{0}}{m-m_{0}}-\frac{m}{m-m_{0}} \frac{1-e^{i k a}}{1-\cos (k a)}\right] B \\
&=\left\{-1+\frac{i m \sin (k a)}{\left(m-m_{0}\right)[1-\cos (k a)]}\right\} B
\end{aligned}
$$

\left|\frac{B}{A}\right|^{2}=\left\{1+\left(\frac{m}{m-m_{0}}\right)^{2}\left[\frac{\sin (k a)}{1-\cos (k a)}\right]^{2}\right\}^{-1}
$$

1123.b.Problem Statement:
Three bodies of equal mass $m$ and indicated by $i=1,2,3$ are constrained to perform small oscillations along different coplanar axes forming $120^{\circ}$ angles at their common intersection, as shown in Fig. 1.94. Identical coupling springs hold these bodies near equilibrium positions which are at a distance $l$ from the intersection on each axis, that is, the equilibrium length of each spring is $\sqrt{3} l$. The following questions can be answered without resorting to general analytic procedures.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-218.jpg?height=492&width=479&top_left_y=1231&top_left_x=494)

Fig, 1.94.

Verify that one normal mode is totally symmetric:

$$
x_{1}(t)=x_{2}(t)=x_{3}(t),
$$

and determine its frequency.
1123.b.Solution:
Let the constant of each spring be $\eta$ and consider particles $i$ and $j$ which are located at $x_{i}$ and $x_{j}$ from their respective equilibrium positions. The stretch of the spring between the two particles is $\left(x_{i}+x_{j}\right) \cos 30^{\circ}$, so the potential energy of the system is

$$
U=\frac{3 \eta}{8}\left[\left(x_{1}+x_{2}\right)^{2}+\left(x_{2}+x_{3}\right)^{2}+\left(x_{3}+x_{1}\right)^{2}\right] .
$$

The force acting on the $i$ th particle is then

$$
-\frac{\partial U}{\partial x_{i}}=-\frac{3 \eta}{4}\left(x_{i}+\sum_{j} x_{j}\right)
$$

giving its equation of motion as

$$
m \ddot{x}_{i}=-K x_{i}-k\left(x_{1}+x_{2}+x_{3}\right)
$$

with $K=k=\frac{3 \eta}{4}$.

If $x_{1}=x_{2}=x_{3}$, all the three equations reduce to the uncoupled form

$$
m \ddot{x}_{i}=-(K+3 k) x_{i} .
$$

The solution is

$$
x_{i}=a \cos (\omega t+\varphi)
$$

with

$$
\omega=\sqrt{\frac{K+3 k}{m}} .
$$

U=\frac{3 \eta}{8}\left[\left(x_{1}+x_{2}\right)^{2}+\left(x_{2}+x_{3}\right)^{2}+\left(x_{3}+x_{1}\right)^{2}\right] .

$$

$$

$$

$$
x_{i}=a \cos (\omega t+\varphi)
$$

$$
\omega=\sqrt{\frac{K+3 k}{m}} .
$$The remaining two normal modes are orthogonal to the above symmetric mode. They satisfy the condition

$$
x_{1}+x_{2}+x_{3}=0,

\sum_{i} b_{i}=0, \quad \omega^{\prime 2}=\frac{K}{m} .
$$

If $x_{1}=x_{2}=x_{3}$, all the three equations reduce to the uncoupled form
