m \ddot{x}_{i}=-(K+3 k) x_{i} .
$$

The solution is

$$
x_{i}=a \cos (\omega t+\varphi)
$$

with

$$
\omega=\sqrt{\frac{K+3 k}{m}} .
$$The remaining two normal modes are orthogonal to the above symmetric mode. They satisfy the condition

$$
x_{1}+x_{2}+x_{3}=0,
$$

for which the equations of motion reduce to the uncoupled form

$$
m \ddot{x}_{i}=-K x_{i} .
$$

Setting $x_{i}=b_{i} \cos \left(\omega^{\prime} t+\varphi^{\prime}\right)$, we have

$$
\sum_{i} b_{i}=0, \quad \omega^{\prime 2}=\frac{K}{m} .
$$

The frequency is the same for both modes, and hence they are degenerate.The two orthogonal degenerate normal modes have amplitudes $b_{1}$, $b_{2}, b_{3}$ satisfying $\sum_{i} b_{i}=0$. Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
& b_{1}=0, \quad b_{2}=-b_{3}=c, \\
& b_{1}=c, \quad b_{2}=b_{3}=-\frac{c}{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

give a pair of real solutions, where $c$ is an arbitrary real number.

1123.e.Problem Statement:
Three bodies of equal mass $m$ and indicated by $i=1,2,3$ are constrained to perform small oscillations along different coplanar axes forming $120^{\circ}$ angles at their common intersection, as shown in Fig. 1.94. Identical coupling springs hold these bodies near equilibrium positions which are at a distance $l$ from the intersection on each axis, that is, the equilibrium length of each spring is $\sqrt{3} l$. The following questions can be answered without resorting to general analytic procedures.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-218.jpg?height=492&width=479&top_left_y=1231&top_left_x=494)

Fig, 1.94.

Find an alternative pair of complex conjugate solutions that represent orthogonal degenerate normal modes.
1123.e.Solution:
Let the constant of each spring be $\eta$ and consider particles $i$ and $j$ which are located at $x_{i}$ and $x_{j}$ from their respective equilibrium positions. The stretch of the spring between the two particles is $\left(x_{i}+x_{j}\right) \cos 30^{\circ}$, so the potential energy of the system is

$$
U=\frac{3 \eta}{8}\left[\left(x_{1}+x_{2}\right)^{2}+\left(x_{2}+x_{3}\right)^{2}+\left(x_{3}+x_{1}\right)^{2}\right] .
$$

The force acting on the $i$ th particle is then

$$
-\frac{\partial U}{\partial x_{i}}=-\frac{3 \eta}{4}\left(x_{i}+\sum_{j} x_{j}\right)
$$

giving its equation of motion as

$$
m \ddot{x}_{i}=-K x_{i}-k\left(x_{1}+x_{2}+x_{3}\right)
$$

with $K=k=\frac{3 \eta}{4}$.

If $x_{1}=x_{2}=x_{3}$, all the three equations reduce to the uncoupled form

$$
m \ddot{x}_{i}=-(K+3 k) x_{i} .
$$

The solution is

$$
x_{i}=a \cos (\omega t+\varphi)
$$

with

$$
\omega=\sqrt{\frac{K+3 k}{m}} .
$$The remaining two normal modes are orthogonal to the above symmetric mode. They satisfy the condition

$$
x_{1}+x_{2}+x_{3}=0,
$$

for which the equations of motion reduce to the uncoupled form

$$
m \ddot{x}_{i}=-K x_{i} .
$$

Setting $x_{i}=b_{i} \cos \left(\omega^{\prime} t+\varphi^{\prime}\right)$, we have

$$
\sum_{i} b_{i}=0, \quad \omega^{\prime 2}=\frac{K}{m} .
$$

The frequency is the same for both modes, and hence they are degenerate.The two orthogonal degenerate normal modes have amplitudes $b_{1}$, $b_{2}, b_{3}$ satisfying $\sum_{i} b_{i}=0$. Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
& b_{1}=0, \quad b_{2}=-b_{3}=c, \\
& b_{1}=c, \quad b_{2}=b_{3}=-\frac{c}{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

give a pair of real solutions, where $c$ is an arbitrary real number.Alternatively, allowing complex amplitudes,

$$
b_{1}=d, \quad b_{2}=d e^{\pm \frac{i 2 \pi}{3}}, \quad b_{3}=d e^{\mp \frac{i 2 \pi}{3}},
$$

where $d$ is a real number, give a pair of orthogonal degenerate normal mode solutions.

1124.Problem Statement:
Three identical objects, each of mass $m$, are connected by springs of spring constant $K$, as shown in Fig. 1.95. The motion is confined to one dimension.

At $t=0$, the masses are at rest at their equilibrium positions. Mass $A$ is then subjected to an external time-dependent driving force $F(t)=$ $f \cos (\omega t), t>0$. Calculate the motion of mass $C$. 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-221.jpg?height=213&width=419&top_left_y=225&top_left_x=544)

Fig. $1.95$.
1124.Solution:
Let $x_{A}, x_{B}, x_{C}$ be the coordinates of the three masses and $a$ the relaxed length of each spring. The equations of motion are

$$
\begin{aligned}
f \cos (\omega t)+K\left(x_{B}-x_{A}-a\right) &=m \ddot{x}_{A}, \\
K\left(x_{C}-x_{B}-a\right)-K\left(x_{B}-x_{A}-a\right) &=m \ddot{x}_{B}, \\
-K\left(x_{C}-x_{B}-a\right) &=m \ddot{x}_{C} .
\end{aligned}
$$

The above set of equations can be written as

$$
\begin{aligned}
f \cos (\omega t) &=m\left(\ddot{x}_{A}+\ddot{x}_{B}+\ddot{x}_{C}\right), \\
f \cos (\omega t)-2 a K &=m\left(\ddot{x}_{A}-\ddot{x}_{C}\right)+K\left(x_{A}-x_{C}\right), \\
f \cos (\omega t) &=m\left(\ddot{x}_{A}-2 \ddot{x}_{B}+\ddot{x}_{C}\right)+3 K\left(x_{A}-2 x_{B}+x_{C}\right),
\end{aligned}
$$

or

$$
\begin{aligned}
f \cos (\omega t) &=m \ddot{y}_{1}, \\
f \cos (\omega t)-2 a K &=m \ddot{y}_{2}+K y_{2}, \\
f \cos (\omega t) &=m \ddot{y}_{3}+3 K y_{3},
\end{aligned}
$$

with $y_{1}=x_{A}+x_{B}+x_{C}, y_{2}=x_{A}-x_{C}, y_{3}=x_{A}-2 x_{B}+x_{C}$. It can be seen that $y_{1}, y_{2}$ and $y_{3}$ are the three normal coordinates of this vibrational system. The initial conditions are that at $t=0$,

$$
x_{A}=0, \quad x_{B}=a, \quad x_{C}=2 a, \quad \dot{x}_{A}=\dot{x}_{B}=\dot{x}_{C}=0,
$$

or

$$
y_{1}=3 a, \quad y_{2}=-2 a, \quad y_{3}=0, \quad \dot{y}_{1}=\dot{y}_{2}=\dot{y}_{3}=0 .
$$

Equation (1) can be integrated, with the use of initial conditions, to give

$$
y_{1}=\frac{f}{m \omega^{2}}[1-\cos (\omega t)]+3 a .
$$

To solve (2), we try a particular solution

$$
y_{2}=A_{2} \cos (\omega t)+B_{2}
$$

and obtain $A_{2}=\frac{f}{K-m \omega^{2}}, B_{2}=-2 a$. The general solution is

$$
y_{2}=\frac{f \cos (\omega t)}{K-m \omega^{2}}-2 a+C_{2} \cos \left(\omega_{2} t\right)+D_{2} \sin \left(\omega_{2} t\right)
$$

where $\omega_{2}=\sqrt{\frac{K}{m}}$. Initial conditions then give

$$
C_{2}=-\frac{f}{K-m \omega^{2}}, \quad D_{2}=0 .
$$

To solve (3), we try a particular solution

$$
y_{3}=A_{3} \cos (\omega t)
$$

and obtain $A_{3}=f /\left(3 K-m \omega^{2}\right)$. The general solution is

$$
y_{3}=\frac{f \cos (\omega t)}{3 K-m \omega^{2}}+C_{3} \cos \left(\omega_{3} t\right)+D_{3} \sin \left(\omega_{3} t\right),
$$

where $\omega_{3}=\sqrt{\frac{3 K}{m}}$. Initial conditions then give

$$
C_{3}=-\frac{f}{3 K-m \omega^{2}}, \quad D_{3}=0 .
$$

Therefore the solutions are as follows:

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
y_{1}=\frac{f}{m \omega^{2}}[1-\cos (\omega t)]+3 a \\
y_{2}=\frac{f}{K-m \omega^{2}}\left[\cos (\omega t)-\cos \left(\omega_{2} t\right)\right]-2 a \\
y_{3}=\frac{f}{3 K-m \omega^{2}}\left[\cos (\omega t)-\cos \left(\omega_{3} t\right)\right]
\end{array}\right.
$$

The motion of $C$ is a linear combination of $y_{1}, y_{2}$ and $y_{3}$ : 

$$
\begin{aligned}
x_{C}=\frac{y_{1}}{3}-\frac{y_{2}}{2}+\frac{y_{3}}{6}=& 2 a+\frac{f}{3 m \omega^{2}}[1-\cos (\omega t)] \\
&+\frac{f}{2 m\left(\omega_{2}^{2}-\omega^{2}\right)}\left[\cos (\omega t)-\cos \left(\omega_{2} t\right)\right] \\
&+\frac{f}{6 m\left(\omega_{3}^{2}-\omega^{2}\right)}\left[\cos (\omega t)-\cos \left(\omega_{3} t\right)\right] .
\end{aligned}
$$

Note that $\omega_{2}$ and $\omega_{3}$ are the normal frequencies of the system.
1124.Final Answer: $$2 a+\frac{f}{3 m \omega^{2}}[1-\cos (\omega t)] +\frac{f}{2 m\left(\omega_{2}^{2}-\omega^{2}\right)}\left[\cos (\omega t)-\cos \left(\omega_{2} t\right)\right] +\frac{f}{6 m\left(\omega_{3}^{2}-\omega^{2}\right)}\left[\cos (\omega t)-\cos \left(\omega_{3} t\right)\right]$$

1127.Problem Statement:
Three masses $m_{1}, m_{2}$ and $m_{3}$, placed at the corners of an equilateral triangle of side $s$, attract each other according to Newton's law of gravitation. Determine the rotational motion which leaves the relative separation of each mass unchanged.

Hint: Write down the force in c.m. system on one of the particles.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-227.jpg?height=341&width=371&top_left_y=879&top_left_x=556)

Fig. 1.99.
1127.Solution:
In the Cartesian frame shown in Fig. 1.99, the three mass $m_{1}, m_{2}, m_{3}$ have coordinates $(0,0),(s, 0)$ and $\left(\frac{s}{2}, \frac{\sqrt{3} s}{2}\right)$ respectively. The position of the center of mass $C$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{r}_{0} &=\frac{\sum_{i} m_{i} r_{i}}{\sum_{i} m_{i}} \\
&=\frac{s}{m_{1}+m_{2}+m_{3}}\left[\left(m_{2}+\frac{m_{3}}{2}\right) \mathbf{i}+\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} m_{3} \mathbf{j}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Now consider the forces acting on $m_{1}$. There are two attractive forces 

$$
\mathbf{f}_{12}=\frac{G m_{1} m_{2}}{s^{2}} \mathbf{i} \quad \text { and } \quad \mathbf{f}_{13}=\frac{G m_{1} m_{3}}{s^{2}}\left(\frac{\mathbf{i}}{2}+\frac{\sqrt{3} \mathbf{j}}{2}\right)
$$

due to $m_{2}$ and $m_{3}$ respectively. Their resultant is

$$
\mathbf{f}_{1}=\mathbf{f}_{12}+\mathbf{f}_{13}=\frac{G m_{1}}{s^{2}}\left[\left(m_{2}+\frac{m_{3}}{2}\right) \mathbf{i}+\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} m_{3} \mathbf{j}\right]
$$

As $\mathbf{f}_{1}$ is parallel to $\mathbf{r}_{0}$ and both originate from the same point $O, \mathbf{f}_{1}$ passes through the center of mass $C$. Thus $m_{1}$ is acted upon by a central force with center at $C$ and hence $m_{1}$ moves in a circle about the center of mass C. The radius of this circular orbit is

$$
R_{1}=\left|\mathbf{r}_{0}\right|=\left(\frac{s}{m_{1}+m_{2}+m_{3}}\right) \sqrt{m_{2}^{2}+m_{3}^{2}+m_{2} m_{3}} .
$$

The linear velocity of $m_{1}$ is $v_{1}$ given by $\frac{m v_{1}^{2}}{R_{1}}=\left|\mathbf{f}_{1}\right|$, or

$$
v_{1}^{2}=\frac{R_{1}}{m_{1}}\left|\mathbf{f}_{1}\right|=\frac{G}{s}\left(\frac{m_{2}^{2}+m_{3}^{2}+m_{2} m_{3}}{m_{1}+m_{2}+m_{3}}\right) .
$$

By permutation of the indices, the above result applies also to $m_{2}$ and $m_{3}$. Hence the rotational motion which leaves the separation of each pair of masses unchanged is a circular motion of period

$$
T=\frac{2 \pi R_{1}}{v_{1}}=2 \pi s \sqrt{\frac{s}{G\left(m_{1}+m_{2}+m_{3}\right)}},
$$

which is the same for all three masses.

1128.a.Problem Statement:
Two non-relativistic particles of equal energy and equal mass as shown in Fig. $1.100$ collide almost head-on. In a coordinate frame (the center of mass frame) moving with velocity $\mathbf{V}$, the particles appear to collide head-on.

Find V, the velocity of the center of mass frame.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-229.jpg?height=258&width=374&top_left_y=210&top_left_x=571)

Fig. 1,100.

Express your answers in terms of the velocity $u$ and the collision angle $\theta_{0}$.
1128.a.Solution:
Use the laboratory frame as shown in Fig. $1.100$ and take the instant of the collision to be $t=0$. The position vectors of $m_{1}$ and $m_{2}$ at $t<0$ are

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\mathbf{r}_{1}=u t \mathbf{i} \\
&\mathbf{r}_{2}=-u t\left(\cos \theta_{0} \mathbf{i}+\sin \theta_{0} \mathbf{j}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Then the position vector of the center of mass is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{r}_{\mathrm{c}} &=\frac{m_{1} \mathbf{r}_{1}+m_{2} \mathbf{r}_{2}}{m_{1}+m_{2}}=\frac{\mathbf{r}_{1}+\mathbf{r}_{2}}{2} \\
&=\frac{1}{2} u t\left[\left(1-\cos \theta_{0}\right) \mathbf{i}-\sin \theta_{0} \mathbf{j}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

as $m_{1}=m_{2}=m$, say.

The velocity of the center of mass, i.e. of the center of mass frame, is

$$
\mathbf{V}=\dot{\mathbf{r}}_{\mathrm{c}}=\frac{u}{2}\left[\left(1-\cos \theta_{0}\right) \mathbf{i}-\sin \theta_{0} \mathbf{j}\right] .
$$

1129.Problem Statement:
A rocket is projected straight up and explodes into three equally massive fragments just as it reaches the top of its flight (Fig. 1.101). One of the fragments is observed to come straight down in a time $t_{1}$, while the other two land at a time $t_{2}$, after the burst. Find the height $h\left(t_{1}, t_{2}\right)$ at which the fragmentation occurred.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-230.jpg?height=256&width=324&top_left_y=1359&top_left_x=623)

Fig. $1.101$.
1129.Solution:
The velocity and momentum of the rocket are zero when it reaches the top of its flight. Conservation of momentum gives, after the burst, 

$$
m_{1} \mathbf{v}_{1}+m_{2} \mathbf{v}_{2}+m_{3} \mathbf{v}_{3}=0 .
$$

As

$$
m_{1}=m_{2}=m_{3}, \quad v_{1}+v_{2}+v_{3}=0 .
$$

As the second and third fragments land at the same time, the vertical components of $\mathbf{v}_{2}$ and $\mathbf{v}_{3}$ are the same. As $\mathbf{v}_{1}$ is vertically downward the vertical components of $\mathbf{v}_{2}$ and $\mathbf{v}_{3}$ are each $-v_{1} / 2$. Hence for the first and second fragments we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
&h=v_{1} t_{1}+\frac{g t_{1}^{2}}{2}, \\
&h=\frac{-v_{1} t_{2}}{2}+\frac{g t_{2}^{2}}{2},
\end{aligned}
$$

giving

$$
\begin{aligned}
v_{1} &=\frac{g\left(t_{2}^{2}-t_{1}^{2}\right)}{2 t_{1}+t_{2}}, \\
h &=\frac{g t_{1} t_{2}}{2} \cdot \frac{t_{1}+2 t_{2}}{2 t_{1}+t_{2}} .
\end{aligned}
$$

1130.Problem Statement: A satellite of mass $m$ moves in a circular orbit of radius $R$ with speed $v$ about the earth. It abruptly absorbs a small mass $\delta m$ which was stationary prior to the collision. Find the change in the total energy of the satellite and, assuming the new orbit is roughly circular, find the radius of the new orbit.
1130.Solution:
Before picking up the small mass, the satellite moves in a circular orbit so that

$$
\frac{m v^{2}}{R}=\frac{G M m}{R^{2}},
$$

giving $R v^{2}=G M$, where $M$ is the mass of the earth. Hence its total energy is

$$
E=\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}-\frac{G M m}{R}=-\frac{1}{2} m v^{2} .
$$

After absorbing the stationary small mass $\delta m$, the speed of the satellite changes to (considering the new orbit as roughly circular, although it is actually elliptic)

$$
v^{\prime}=\frac{m v}{m+\delta m},
$$

and its total energy becomes

$$
E^{\prime}=-\frac{1}{2}(m+\delta m) v^{\prime 2}=-\frac{1}{2} \frac{m^{2} v^{2}}{m+\delta m} .
$$

Hence the energy loss due to the collision is

$$
\begin{aligned}
E^{\prime}-E &=\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}\left(1-\frac{m}{m+\delta m}\right)=\frac{1}{2} m v^{2} \frac{\delta m}{m+\delta m} \\
& \approx \frac{1}{2} v^{2} \delta m .
\end{aligned}
$$

If the new radius is $R^{\prime}$ we also have

$$
R^{\prime} v^{\prime 2}=G M=R v^{2},
$$

giving

$$
R^{\prime}=\left(\frac{v}{v^{\prime}}\right)^{2} R=\left(\frac{m+\delta m}{m}\right)^{2} R \approx\left(1+\frac{2 \delta m}{m}\right) R .
$$

1131.Problem Statement:
For the system of 2 identical masses and massless springs shown in Fig. 1.102, calculate the period of oscillation if the masses are released from the initial symmetrical configuration shown.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-232.jpg?height=153&width=436&top_left_y=1646&top_left_x=571)

Fig, 1,102.
1131.Solution:
Due to symmetry, the oscillations of the two masses are the same. Consider one of them and write down the equation of motion

$$
m \ddot{x}=-K x-K^{\prime}(x+x)=-\left(K+2 K^{\prime}\right) x,
$$

where $x$ is the displacement from the respective equilibrium position. Then the angular frequency of oscillation is

$$
\omega=\sqrt{\frac{K+2 K^{\prime}}{m}},
$$

and the period of oscillation is

$$
T=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{m}{K+2 K^{\prime}}} .
$$

Note that generally speaking, there are two modes of linear vibration for this system corresponding to two normal modes. But the symmetrical initial condition determines that only one mode is excited.

1134.Problem Statement:
A chain with mass/length $=u$ hanging vertically from one end, where an upward force $F$ is applied to it, is lowered onto a table as shown in Fig. 1.103. Find the equation of motion for $h$, the height of the end above the table ( $h$ is the length of chain hanging freely).

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-236.jpg?height=323&width=275&top_left_y=1207&top_left_x=639)

Fig. 1.103.
1134.Solution:
As this problem involves variable mass it is more convenient to work with momentum. Consider the change of momentum of the chain during a time interval $t$ to $t+\Delta t$. If $h$ and $v$ are respectively the height and velocity of the freely-hanging portion of the chain at time $t$, its momentum is $\mu h v$ at $t$ and $\mu(h-\Delta h)(v+\Delta v)$ at $t+\Delta t$ (see Fig. 1.104). As a portion $\Delta h$ of the chain has reached the table and transferred a momentum $\approx \mu \Delta h v$ to the latter during the interval, the momentum theorem gives

$$
\mu(h-\Delta h)(v+\Delta v)+\mu \Delta h v-\mu h v=(\mu h g-F) \Delta t,
$$

or, retaining only the first-order terms,

$$
\mu h \Delta v=(\mu h g-F) \Delta t .
$$

With $\Delta t \rightarrow 0$, the above becomes

$$
\mu h \dot{v}=\mu h g-F .
$$

As $v=-\dot{h}$, we have the equation of motion

$$
\ddot{h}=\frac{F}{\mu h}-g .
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-237.jpg?height=325&width=402&top_left_y=924&top_left_x=559)

Fig. 1.104.

1135.Problem Statement: Use the rocket equation to find the rocket residual mass $m$ (in terms of the initial mass) at which the momentum of the rocket is a maximum, for a rocket of mass $m$ starting at rest in free space. The exhaust velocity is a constant $v_{0}$.
1135.Solution:
The equation of motion for a rocket, velocity $v$, in free space is

$$
\frac{m d v}{d t}=\frac{-v_{0} d m}{d t},
$$

i.e.

Integrating, we obtain

$$
d v=\frac{-v_{0} d m}{m} .
$$

$$
v=-v_{0} \ln \left(\frac{m}{m_{0}}\right),
$$

where $m_{0}$ is the rocket mass at firing. The momentum of the rocket is

$$
P=m v=-m v_{0} \ln \left(\frac{m}{m_{0}}\right) .
$$

For it to be a maximum, we require

$$
\frac{d P}{d m}=-v_{0} \ln \left(\frac{m}{m_{0}}\right)-v_{0}=0 .
$$

Hence the rocket has maximum momentum when its residual mass is

$$
m=\frac{m_{0}}{e} .
$$

1136.a.Solution:
Let $v$ be the velocity of the rocket. The equation of motion is

$$
\frac{m d v}{d t}=-\frac{u d m}{d t}-m g .
$$

As $d m / d t=$ constant and $m=m_{0}, d v / d t=0$ at $t=0$, the above gives

$$
\frac{d m}{d t}=-\frac{m_{0} g}{u}
$$

at any time $t$ after firing. Integrating we obtain

$$
m=m_{0}\left(1-\frac{g t}{u}\right) .
$$

The equation of motion now becomes

$$
m_{0}\left(1-\frac{g t}{u}\right) \frac{d v}{d t}=\left(m_{0}-m\right) g=\frac{m_{0} g^{2} t}{u},
$$

or

$$
\frac{d v}{d t}=\frac{g^{2} t}{u-g t},
$$

which expresses the acceleration of the rocket as a function of time.

1136.b.Problem Statement:
A rocket is fired straight up with no initial velocity. It is propelled by ejection of mass with a constant velocity of ejection $u$ relative to the rocket and at a constant rate so determined that the initial acceleration is zero. Assuming constant acceleration due to gravity,

show how you would find the height of the rocket as a function of time.

(It is not necessary to do the integrals.)
1136.b.Solution:
Let $v$ be the velocity of the rocket. The equation of motion is

$$
\frac{m d v}{d t}=-\frac{u d m}{d t}-m g .
$$

As $d m / d t=$ constant and $m=m_{0}, d v / d t=0$ at $t=0$, the above gives

$$
\frac{d m}{d t}=-\frac{m_{0} g}{u}
$$

at any time $t$ after firing. Integrating we obtain

$$
m=m_{0}\left(1-\frac{g t}{u}\right) .
$$

The equation of motion now becomes

$$
m_{0}\left(1-\frac{g t}{u}\right) \frac{d v}{d t}=\left(m_{0}-m\right) g=\frac{m_{0} g^{2} t}{u},
$$

or

$$
\frac{d v}{d t}=\frac{g^{2} t}{u-g t},
$$

which expresses the acceleration of the rocket as a function of time.The velocity at time $t$ is

$$
v=\int_{0}^{t} g\left(\frac{g t^{\prime}}{u-g t^{\prime}}\right) d t^{\prime}=-g t+u \ln \left(\frac{u}{u-g t}\right) .
$$

Further integration gives the height of the rocket as a function of time:

$$
h=\int_{0}^{t}\left(-g t^{\prime}+u \ln \frac{u}{u-g t^{\prime}}\right) d t^{\prime}=-\frac{1}{2} g t^{2}+u \int_{0}^{t} \ln \frac{u}{u-g t^{\prime}} d t^{\prime} .
$$

1137.Problem Statement: A bucket of mass $M$ (when empty) initially at rest and containing a mass of water is being pulled up a well by a rope exerting a steady force $P$. The water is leaking out of the bucket at a steady rate such that the bucket is empty after a time $T$. Find the velocity of the bucket at the instant it becomes empty,
1137.Solution:
Let the total mass of the bucket and water be $M^{\prime}$. Then

$$
M^{\prime}=M+m-\frac{m t}{T},
$$

where $m$ is the initial mass of the water. As the leaking water has zero velocity relative to the bucket, the equation of motion is

$$
M^{\prime} \frac{d v}{d t}=P-M^{\prime} g,
$$

or

$$
d v=\frac{P-M^{\prime} g}{M^{\prime}} d t=\left(\frac{P}{M+m-\frac{m}{T} t}-g\right) d t
$$

The velocity of the bucket at the instant it becomes empty is

$$
v=\int_{0}^{T} \frac{P d t}{M+m-\frac{m}{T} t}-g T=\frac{P T}{m} \ln \left(\frac{M+m}{M}\right)-g T .
$$

1138.a.Problem Statement:
A rocket ship with mass $M_{0}$ and loaded with fuel of mass $m_{0}$ takes off vertically in a uniform gravitational field as shown in Fig. 1.105. It ejects fuel with velocity $U_{0}$ with respect to the rocket ship. The fuel is completely ejected during a time $T_{0}$.

Find the equation of motion of the rocket in terms of $d M / d t, U_{0}, g$, and $M$, where $M$ is the mass of the rocket at time $t$.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-240.jpg?height=303&width=159&top_left_y=1505&top_left_x=705)

Fig. $1.105$.
1138.a.Solution:
Consider a rocket, having mass $M$ and velocity $V$, in time interval $\Delta t$ ejecting a mass $\Delta M$ at a velocity $U_{0}$ relative to the rocket and gaining an additional velocity $\Delta V$. Taking the vertical upward direction as positive, we have by the momentum theorem

$$
(M-\Delta M)(V+\Delta V)+\left(V+U_{0}\right) \Delta M-M V=-M g \Delta t,
$$

i.e.

or, in the limit $\Delta t \rightarrow 0$

$$
M \frac{\Delta V}{\Delta t}=-U_{0} \frac{\Delta M}{\Delta t}-M g,
$$

$$
M \frac{d V}{d t}=-U_{0} \frac{d M}{d t}-M g .
$$

1138.b.Problem Statement:
A rocket ship with mass $M_{0}$ and loaded with fuel of mass $m_{0}$ takes off vertically in a uniform gravitational field as shown in Fig. 1.105. It ejects fuel with velocity $U_{0}$ with respect to the rocket ship. The fuel is completely ejected during a time $T_{0}$.

What is the velocity of the vehicle at the instant $t_{0}$ when all the fuel has been ejected, in terms of $M_{0}, m_{0}, g$ and $t_{0}$ ?

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-240.jpg?height=303&width=159&top_left_y=1505&top_left_x=705)

Fig. $1.105$.
1138.b.Solution:
Consider a rocket, having mass $M$ and velocity $V$, in time interval $\Delta t$ ejecting a mass $\Delta M$ at a velocity $U_{0}$ relative to the rocket and gaining an additional velocity $\Delta V$. Taking the vertical upward direction as positive, we have by the momentum theorem

$$
(M-\Delta M)(V+\Delta V)+\left(V+U_{0}\right) \Delta M-M V=-M g \Delta t,
$$

i.e.

or, in the limit $\Delta t \rightarrow 0$

$$
M \frac{\Delta V}{\Delta t}=-U_{0} \frac{\Delta M}{\Delta t}-M g,
$$

$$
M \frac{d V}{d t}=-U_{0} \frac{d M}{d t}-M g .
$$The equation can be rewritten as

$$
d V=-U_{0} \frac{d M}{M}-g d t .
$$

Integrating we obtain

$$
V=-U_{0} \ln M-g t+K .
$$

As $M=M_{0}+m_{0}, V=0$ at $t=0$,

$$
K=U_{0} \ln \left(M_{0}+m_{0}\right) .
$$

Hence when $M=M_{0}$ at $t=t_{0}$, we have

$$
V=U_{0} \ln \left(\frac{M_{0}+m_{0}}{M_{0}}\right)-g t_{0} .
$$

1143.Problem Statement: A spherical dust particle falls through a water mist cloud of uniform density such that the rate of accretion onto the droplet is proportional to the volume of the mist cloud swept out by the droplet per unit time. If the droplet starts from rest in the cloud, find the value of the acceleration of the drop for large times.
1143.Solution:
Suppose the spherical dust particle initially has mass $M_{0}$ and radius $R_{0}$. Take the initial position of the dust particle as the origin and the $x$-axis along the downward vertical. Let $M(t)$ and $R(t)$ be the mass and radius of the droplet at time $t$ respectively. Then

$$
M(t)=M_{0}+\frac{4}{3} \pi\left(R^{3}-R_{0}^{3}\right) \rho,
$$

where $\rho$ is the density of the water mist, giving

$$
\frac{d M}{d t}=\rho 4 \pi R^{2} \frac{d R}{d t} .
$$

The droplet has a cross section $\pi R^{2}$ and sweeps out a cylinder of volume $\pi R^{2} \dot{x}$ in unit time, where $\dot{x}$ is its velocity. As the rate of accretion is proportional to this volume, we have

$$
\frac{d M}{d t}=\alpha \pi R^{2} \dot{x},
$$

$\alpha$ being a positive constant. Hence

$$
\dot{x}=\frac{4 \rho}{\alpha} \dot{R} .
$$

The momentum theorem gives

$$
M(t+d t) \dot{x}(t+d t)-M(t) \dot{x}(t)=M g d t .
$$

Using Taylor's theorem to expand $M(t+d t)$ and $\dot{x}(t+d t)$ and retaining only the lowest-order terms, we obtain

$$
\dot{x} \frac{d M}{d t}+M \ddot{x}=M g .
$$

For large $t, M(t) \approx \frac{4}{3} \pi R^{3} \rho, d M / d t \approx 3 M \dot{R} / R$, and the above becomes

$$
\ddot{R}+\frac{3 \dot{R}^{2}}{R}=\frac{\alpha g}{4 \rho} .
$$

For a particular solution valid for large $t$, setting

$$
R(t)=a t^{2},
$$

where $a$ is a constant, in the above we obtain

$$
a=\frac{\alpha g}{56 \rho} .
$$

Thus for large $t$,

$$
\dot{x}=\frac{4 \rho}{\alpha} \cdot 2 a t=\frac{g t}{7} .
$$

Hence the acceleration for large times is $g / 7$.

1146.Problem Statement: Given that the moment of inertia of a cube about an axis that passes through the center of mass and the center of one face is $I_{0}$, find the moment of inertia about an axis through the center of mass and one corner of the cube.
1146.Solution:
Use Cartesian coordinates with origin at the center of mass and the axes through the centers of the three pairs of faces of the cube. We have

$$
\begin{aligned}
&I_{x x}=I_{y y}=I_{z z}=I_{0}, \\
&I_{x y}=I_{y z}=I_{z x}=0,
\end{aligned}
$$

The moment of inertia about an axis having direction cosines $\lambda, \mu, \nu$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
I &=\lambda^{2} I_{x x}+\mu^{2} I_{y y}+\nu^{2} I_{z z}-2 \mu \nu I_{y z}-2 \nu \lambda I_{z x}-2 \lambda \mu I_{x y} \\
&=\left(\lambda^{2}+\mu^{2}+\nu^{2}\right) I_{0} .
\end{aligned}
$$

To find the direction cosines of a radius vector $\mathbf{r}$ from the origin to one corner of the cube, without loss of generality, we can just consider the corner with its $x, y, z$ coordinates all positive. Then

$$
\mathbf{r}=a \mathbf{i}+a \mathbf{j}+a \mathbf{k},
$$

where we have taken $2 a$ as the length of a side of the cube. As $|\mathbf{r}|=\sqrt{3} a$ we have

$$
\lambda=\mu=\nu=\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}},
$$

so that

$$
I=I_{0} \text {. }
$$

1147.a.Problem Statement:
A thin disk of radius $R$ and mass $M$ lying in the $x y$-plane has a point mass $m=5 M / 4$ attached on its edge (as shown in Fig. 1.109). The moment of inertia of the disk about its center of mass is (the $z$-axis is out of the paper) 

$$
I=\frac{M R^{2}}{4}\left[\begin{array}{lll}
1 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 1 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 2
\end{array}\right]
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-251.jpg?height=269&width=347&top_left_y=423&top_left_x=611)

Fig. 1.109.

Find the moment of inertia tensor of the combination of disk and point mass about point $A$ in the coordinate system shown.
1147.a.Solution:
The contribution of a mass element $\Delta m$ at radius vector $\mathbf{r}=\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right.$, $\left.x_{3}\right)$ to the moments and products of inertia about the origin is

$$
I_{i j}=\Delta m\left(r^{2} \delta_{i j}-x_{i} x_{j}\right),
$$

where $\delta_{i j}=1$ if $i=j, \delta_{i j}=0$ if $i \neq j$. Thus the moment of inertia tensor of the point mass about $A$ is

$$
\frac{5 M R^{2}}{4}\left(\begin{array}{rrr}
1 & -1 & 0 \\
-1 & 1 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 2
\end{array}\right) \text {. }
$$

The moment of inertia tensor of the disk about $A$, according to the theorem of parallel axes, is

$$
\frac{M R^{2}}{4}\left(\begin{array}{lll}
5 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 1 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 6
\end{array}\right)
$$

Hence the moment of inertia tensor of the disk and point mass about $A$ is

$$
\frac{M R^{2}}{4}\left(\begin{array}{rrr}
10 & -5 & 0 \\
-5 & 6 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 16
\end{array}\right) \text {. }
$$

1147.b.Problem Statement:
A thin disk of radius $R$ and mass $M$ lying in the $x y$-plane has a point mass $m=5 M / 4$ attached on its edge (as shown in Fig. 1.109). The moment of inertia of the disk about its center of mass is (the $z$-axis is out of the paper) 

$$
I=\frac{M R^{2}}{4}\left[\begin{array}{lll}
1 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 1 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 2
\end{array}\right]
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-251.jpg?height=269&width=347&top_left_y=423&top_left_x=611)

Fig. 1.109.

Find the principal moments and the principal axes about point $A$.
1147.b.Solution:
The contribution of a mass element $\Delta m$ at radius vector $\mathbf{r}=\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right.$, $\left.x_{3}\right)$ to the moments and products of inertia about the origin is

$$
I_{i j}=\Delta m\left(r^{2} \delta_{i j}-x_{i} x_{j}\right),
$$

where $\delta_{i j}=1$ if $i=j, \delta_{i j}=0$ if $i \neq j$. Thus the moment of inertia tensor of the point mass about $A$ is

$$
\frac{5 M R^{2}}{4}\left(\begin{array}{rrr}
1 & -1 & 0 \\
-1 & 1 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 2
\end{array}\right) \text {. }
$$

The moment of inertia tensor of the disk about $A$, according to the theorem of parallel axes, is

$$
\frac{M R^{2}}{4}\left(\begin{array}{lll}
5 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 1 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 6
\end{array}\right)
$$

Hence the moment of inertia tensor of the disk and point mass about $A$ is

$$
\frac{M R^{2}}{4}\left(\begin{array}{rrr}
10 & -5 & 0 \\
-5 & 6 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 16
\end{array}\right) \text {. }
$$To find the principal axes and moments of inertia, solve the secular equation

$$
\frac{M R^{2}}{4}\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
10-\gamma & -5 & 0 \\
-5 & 6-\gamma & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 16-\gamma
\end{array}\right|=0
$$

or

$$
(16-\gamma)\left(\gamma^{2}-16 \gamma+35\right)=0
$$

The solutions are

$$
\gamma_{1}=16, \quad \gamma_{2}=8-\sqrt{29}, \quad \gamma_{3}=8+\sqrt{29} .
$$

Hence the three principal moments of inertia about $A$ are

$$
I_{1}=4 M R^{2}, \quad I_{2}=\left(2-\frac{\sqrt{29}}{4}\right) M R^{2}, \quad I_{3}=\left(2+\frac{\sqrt{29}}{4}\right) M R^{2} .
$$

The direction cosines $(\lambda, \mu, \nu)$ of the principal axes corresponding to $I_{1}$ are given by

$$
\left(\begin{array}{rrr}
-6 & -5 & 0 \\
-5 & -10 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 0
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
\lambda \\
\mu \\
\nu
\end{array}\right)=0
$$

i.e.

$$
\begin{gathered}
-6 \lambda-5 \mu=0 \\
-5 \lambda-10 \mu=0 \\
0 \nu=0 .
\end{gathered}
$$

The solution is $\lambda=\mu=0, \nu=$ arbitrary. As

$$
\lambda^{2}+\mu^{2}+\nu^{2}=1,
$$

by definition, the direction cosines are

$$
\lambda=0, \quad \mu=0, \quad \nu=1 .
$$

The principal axes for $I_{2}$ and $I_{3}$ have direction cosines given by

$$
\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
2 \pm \sqrt{29} & -5 & 0 \\
-5 & -2 \pm \sqrt{29} & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 8 \pm \sqrt{29}
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
\lambda \\
\mu \\
\nu
\end{array}\right)=0
$$

i.e.

$$
\begin{aligned}
(2 \pm \sqrt{29})) \lambda-5 \mu &=0, \\
-5 \lambda+(-2 \pm \sqrt{29}) \mu &=0 \\
(8 \pm \sqrt{29}) \nu &=0
\end{aligned}
$$

where the top sign is for $I_{2}$ and the bottom sign, $I_{3}$.

The solutions are

$$
\frac{\lambda}{\mu}=\frac{-2 \pm \sqrt{29}}{5}=\left\{\begin{array}{l}
0.677 \\
-1.477
\end{array}, \quad \nu=0 .\right.
$$

Then as $\lambda^{2}+\mu^{2}+\nu^{2}=\lambda^{2}+\mu^{2}=1$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
&|\mu|=\left(\frac{\lambda^{2}}{\mu^{2}}+1\right)^{-\frac{1}{2}}=\left\{\begin{array}{l}
0.828 \\
0.561
\end{array}\right. \\
&|\nu|=\left(1-\mu^{2}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}}=\left\{\begin{array}{l}
0.561 \\
0.828
\end{array}\right.
\end{aligned}
$$

We also require that the principal axes for $I_{2}$ and $I_{3}$ be orthogonal:

$$
\lambda_{2} \lambda_{3}+\mu_{2} \mu_{3}+\nu_{2} \nu_{3}=0 .
$$

We therefore take the principal axes as

$$
\begin{aligned}
&(0,0,1), \\
&(0.561,0.828,0), \\
&(-0.828,0.561,0)
\end{aligned}
$$

1148.a.Problem Statement:
Four masses, all of value $m$, lie in the $x y$-plane at positions $(x, y)=$ $(a, 0),(-a, 0),(0,+2 a),(0,-2 a)$. These are joined by massless rods to form a rigid body.

Find the inertial tensor, using the $x-, y-, z$-axes as reference system. Exhibit the tensor as a matrix.
1148.a.Solution:
The elements $I_{i j}$ of the inertial tensor are given by

$$
I_{i j}=\sum_{n} m_{n}\left(r_{n}^{2} \delta_{i j}-x_{n_{i}} n_{n_{j}}\right)
$$

where

$$
r_{n}^{2}=x_{n_{1}}^{2}+x_{n_{2}}^{2}+x_{n_{3}}^{2} .
$$

As at least one of the coordinates of each mass is zero, $x_{i} x_{j}=0$ so that $I_{i j}=0$ for all $i \neq j$. For $i=j$, because of symmetry we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
&I_{11}=2 m\left(a^{2}-a^{2}\right)+2 m\left(4 a^{2}-0\right)=8 m a^{2}, \\
&I_{22}=2 m\left(a^{2}-0\right)+2 m\left(4 a^{2}-4 a^{2}\right)=2 m a^{2}, \\
&I_{33}=2 m\left(a^{2}-0\right)+2 m\left(4 a^{2}-0\right)=10 m a^{2},
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the inertial tensor is given by the matrix

$$
\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
8 m a^{2} & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 2 m a^{2} & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 10 m a^{2}
\end{array}\right) \text {. }
$$

1148.b.Problem Statement:
Four masses, all of value $m$, lie in the $x y$-plane at positions $(x, y)=$ $(a, 0),(-a, 0),(0,+2 a),(0,-2 a)$. These are joined by massless rods to form a rigid body.

Consider a direction given by unit vector $\hat{\mathbf{n}}$ that lies "equally between" the positive $x$-, $y$-, $z$-axes, i.e. it makes equal angles with these three directions. Find the moment of inertia for rotation about this axis.
1148.b.Solution:
The elements $I_{i j}$ of the inertial tensor are given by

$$
I_{i j}=\sum_{n} m_{n}\left(r_{n}^{2} \delta_{i j}-x_{n_{i}} n_{n_{j}}\right)
$$

where

$$
r_{n}^{2}=x_{n_{1}}^{2}+x_{n_{2}}^{2}+x_{n_{3}}^{2} .
$$

As at least one of the coordinates of each mass is zero, $x_{i} x_{j}=0$ so that $I_{i j}=0$ for all $i \neq j$. For $i=j$, because of symmetry we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
&I_{11}=2 m\left(a^{2}-a^{2}\right)+2 m\left(4 a^{2}-0\right)=8 m a^{2}, \\
&I_{22}=2 m\left(a^{2}-0\right)+2 m\left(4 a^{2}-4 a^{2}\right)=2 m a^{2}, \\
&I_{33}=2 m\left(a^{2}-0\right)+2 m\left(4 a^{2}-0\right)=10 m a^{2},
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the inertial tensor is given by the matrix

$$
\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
8 m a^{2} & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 2 m a^{2} & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 10 m a^{2}
\end{array}\right) \text {. }
$$As the given direction makes the same angle with the axes, its direction cosines $\lambda, \mu, \nu$ are equal. The moment of inertia about this direction is then

$$
\begin{aligned}
I &=\lambda^{2} I_{11}+\mu^{2} I_{22}+\nu^{2} I_{33}-2 \mu \nu I_{23}-2 \nu \lambda I_{31}-2 \lambda \mu I_{12} \\
&=\left(8 m a^{2}+2 m \omega^{2}+10 m a^{2}\right) \lambda^{2} \\
&=20 m a^{2} \lambda^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

The direction cosines are subject to the condition

$$
\lambda^{2}+\mu^{2}+\nu^{2}=3 \lambda^{2}=1,
$$

giving $\lambda^{2}=\frac{1}{3}$. Hence

$$
I=\frac{20}{3} m a^{2} .
$$

1148.c.Problem Statement:
Four masses, all of value $m$, lie in the $x y$-plane at positions $(x, y)=$ $(a, 0),(-a, 0),(0,+2 a),(0,-2 a)$. These are joined by massless rods to form a rigid body.

Given that at a certain time $t$ the angular velocity vector lies along the above direction $\hat{\mathbf{n}}$, find, for that instant, the angle between the angular momentum vector and $\hat{\mathbf{n}}$.
1148.c.Solution:
The elements $I_{i j}$ of the inertial tensor are given by

$$
I_{i j}=\sum_{n} m_{n}\left(r_{n}^{2} \delta_{i j}-x_{n_{i}} n_{n_{j}}\right)
$$

where

$$
r_{n}^{2}=x_{n_{1}}^{2}+x_{n_{2}}^{2}+x_{n_{3}}^{2} .
$$

As at least one of the coordinates of each mass is zero, $x_{i} x_{j}=0$ so that $I_{i j}=0$ for all $i \neq j$. For $i=j$, because of symmetry we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
&I_{11}=2 m\left(a^{2}-a^{2}\right)+2 m\left(4 a^{2}-0\right)=8 m a^{2}, \\
&I_{22}=2 m\left(a^{2}-0\right)+2 m\left(4 a^{2}-4 a^{2}\right)=2 m a^{2}, \\
&I_{33}=2 m\left(a^{2}-0\right)+2 m\left(4 a^{2}-0\right)=10 m a^{2},
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the inertial tensor is given by the matrix

$$
\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
8 m a^{2} & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 2 m a^{2} & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 10 m a^{2}
\end{array}\right) \text {. }
$$As the given direction makes the same angle with the axes, its direction cosines $\lambda, \mu, \nu$ are equal. The moment of inertia about this direction is then

$$
\begin{aligned}
I &=\lambda^{2} I_{11}+\mu^{2} I_{22}+\nu^{2} I_{33}-2 \mu \nu I_{23}-2 \nu \lambda I_{31}-2 \lambda \mu I_{12} \\
&=\left(8 m a^{2}+2 m \omega^{2}+10 m a^{2}\right) \lambda^{2} \\
&=20 m a^{2} \lambda^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

The direction cosines are subject to the condition

$$
\lambda^{2}+\mu^{2}+\nu^{2}=3 \lambda^{2}=1,
$$

giving $\lambda^{2}=\frac{1}{3}$. Hence

$$
I=\frac{20}{3} m a^{2} .
$$The direction $\hat{\mathbf{n}}$ is given by

$$
\hat{\mathbf{n}}=\left(\begin{array}{l}
\lambda \\
\mu \\
\nu
\end{array}\right)=\lambda\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
1 \\
1
\end{array}\right) \text {. }
$$

At time $T, \omega$ is parallel to $\hat{\mathbf{n}}$ :

$$
\omega=\omega \hat{\mathbf{n}}=\lambda \omega\left(\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
1 \\
1
\end{array}\right) .
$$

The angular momentum at this instant is given by

$$
L=I \omega,
$$

or

$$
\mathbf{L}=\lambda m a^{2} \omega\left(\begin{array}{c}
8 \\
2 \\
10
\end{array}\right)
$$

with magnitude

$$
L=\lambda m a^{2} \omega \sqrt{8^{2}+2^{2}+10^{2}}=\sqrt{168} \lambda m a^{2} \omega .
$$

The angle $\phi$ between $\mathrm{L}$ and $\hat{\mathbf{n}}$ is then given by

$$
\cos \phi=\frac{\mathbf{L} \cdot \hat{\mathbf{n}}}{L}=\frac{\lambda^{2} m a^{2} \omega(8+2+10)}{\lambda m a^{2} \omega \sqrt{168}}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \frac{20}{\sqrt{168}}=0.891
$$

i.e.

$$
\phi=27^{\circ}
$$

1150.Problem Statement: A flywheel in the form of a uniformly thick disk $4 \mathrm{ft}$ in diameter weighs $600 \mathrm{lbs}$ and rotates at $1200 \mathrm{rpm}$. Calculate the constant torque necessary to stop it in $2.0 \mathrm{~min}$.
1150.Solution:
The equation of motion for the flywheel is

$$
I \ddot{\theta}=-M,
$$

where $I$ is the moment of inertia and $M$ is the stopping torque. Hence

$$
\dot{\theta}=\omega_{0}-\frac{M t}{I} .
$$

When the flywheel stops at time $t, \dot{\theta}=0$ and 

$$
M=\frac{I \omega_{0}}{t} .
$$

With $I=\frac{M R^{2}}{2}=1200 \mathrm{lb} \mathrm{ft}^{2}, \omega_{0}=40 \pi \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s}, t=120 \mathrm{~s}$,

$$
M=400 \pi \mathrm{pdl} \mathrm{ft}=39 \mathrm{lb} \mathrm{ft} .
$$

1151.Problem Statement:
A structure is made of equal-length beams, 1 to 11 , as shown in Fig. 1.112, hinged at the joints $A, B, \ldots, G$. Point $A$ is supported rigidly while $G$ is only supported vertically. Neglect the beam weights. A weight $w$ is placed at $E$. Each member is under pure tension $T$ or compression $C$. Solve for the vertical support forces at $A$ and $G$ and find the tension $T$ or compression $C$ in each member.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-262.jpg?height=230&width=468&top_left_y=1025&top_left_x=212)

Fig. 1.112.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-262.jpg?height=308&width=502&top_left_y=1007&top_left_x=819)

Fig. 1.113.
1151.Solution:
Consider the structure as a whole. The equilibrium conditions for forces at $A$ and $G$ and for torques about $A$ give

$$
\begin{aligned}
N_{A X} &=0, \\
N_{A Y}+N_{G Y}-W &=0 \\
\overline{A E} \cdot W-\overline{A G} \cdot N_{G Y} &=0
\end{aligned}
$$

whence

$$
N_{A X}=0, \quad N_{A Y}=\frac{W}{3}, \quad N_{G Y}=\frac{2 W}{3} .
$$

Then let the tensions and compressions in the rods be as shown in Fig. 1.113. Considering the equilibrium conditions for joint $A$ we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
N_{A Y}-T_{1} \sin 60^{\circ} &=0, \\
C_{2}-T_{1} \cos 60^{\circ} &=0,
\end{aligned}
$$

yielding

$$
T_{1}=\frac{2 \sqrt{3}}{9} W, \quad C_{2}=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{9} W .
$$

Consider the balance of vertical forces at $B, C, D, G, F$. We obtain by inspection of Fig. $1.113$

$$
\begin{gathered}
C_{3}=T_{1}=\frac{2 \sqrt{3}}{9} W, \quad T_{5}=C_{3}=\frac{2 \sqrt{3}}{9} W, \quad C_{7}=T_{5}=\frac{2 \sqrt{3}}{9} W, \\
T_{11}=\frac{N_{G Y}}{\sin 60^{\circ}}=\frac{4 \sqrt{3}}{9} W, \quad C_{9}=T_{11}=\frac{4 \sqrt{3}}{9} W .
\end{gathered}
$$

Then considering the balance of horizontal forces at $B, C, E, F$ we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
&T_{4}-\left(T_{1}+C_{3}\right) \cos 60^{\circ}=0 \\
&C_{6}-\left(C_{3}+T_{5}\right) \cos 60^{\circ}-C_{2}=0 \\
&C_{10}-\left(C_{9}-C_{7}\right) \cos 60^{\circ}-C_{6}=0 \\
&T_{8}-\left(T_{11}+C_{9}\right) \cos 60^{\circ}=0
\end{aligned}
$$

yielding

$$
T_{4}=\frac{2 \sqrt{3}}{9} W, \quad C_{6}=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{3} W, \quad C_{10}=\frac{2 \sqrt{3}}{9} W, \quad T_{8}=\frac{4 \sqrt{3}}{9} W .
$$

1152.b.Problem Statement:
A uniform thin rigid rod of mass $M$ is supported by two rapidly rotating rollers, whose axes are separated by a fixed distance $a$. The rod is initially placed at rest asymmetrically, as shown in Fig. $1.114$.

Now consider the case in which the directions of rotation of the rollers are reversed, as shown in Fig. 1.115. Calculate the displacement $x(t)$, again assuming $x(0)=x_{0}$ and $\dot{x}(0)=0$.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-264.jpg?height=225&width=424&top_left_y=895&top_left_x=573)

Fig. 1.116.
1152.b.Solution:
The forces exerted by the rollers on the rod are as shown in Fig. 1.116. For equilibrium along the vertical direction we require

$$
N_{1}+N_{2}=M g, \quad a N_{2}=x M_{g},
$$

giving

$$
N_{1}=\left(1-\frac{x}{a}\right) M g, \quad N_{2}=\frac{x}{a} M g .
$$

The kinetic friction forces are

$$
f_{1}=\mu N_{1}, \quad f_{2}=\mu N_{2},
$$

with directions as shown in the figure. Note that as the rollers rotate rapidly, a change in the direction of motion of the rod will not affect the directions of these forces. Newton's second law then gives 

$$
M \ddot{x}=f_{1}-f_{2}=\frac{\mu M g}{a}(a-2 x) .
$$

With $\xi=2 x-a$, the above becomes

$$
\ddot{\xi}=-\frac{2 \mu g}{a} \xi,
$$

which is the equation of motion of a harmonic oscillator. With the initial conditions $\xi=2 x_{0}-a, \dot{\xi}=0$ at $t=0$, the solution is

$$
\xi=\left(2 x_{0}-a\right) \cos (\omega t),
$$

where

$$
\omega=\sqrt{\frac{2 \mu g}{a}} .
$$

Hence

$$
x=\left(x_{0}-\frac{a}{2}\right) \cos (\omega t)+\frac{a}{2} .
$$

With the directions of rotation of the rollers reversed, the friction forces also reverse directions and we have

$$
M \ddot{x}=f_{2}-f_{1},
$$

or

$$
\ddot{\xi}=\frac{2 \mu g}{a} \xi,
$$

where $\xi=2 x-a$ as before. The motion is no longer simple harmonic. With the same initial conditions, the solution is

$$
\xi=\left(x_{0}-\frac{a}{2}\right)\left(e^{-\omega t}+e^{\omega t}\right)=\left(2 x_{0}-a\right) \cosh (\omega t),
$$

i.e.

$$
x=\left(x_{0}-\frac{a}{2}\right) \cosh (\omega t)+\frac{a}{2},
$$

where $\omega=\sqrt{\frac{2 \mu g}{a}}$. Note that if $x_{0} \neq \frac{a}{2}$, the rod will move in one direction until it loses contact with one roller, at which time the equation ceases to apply.

1155.Problem Statement:
A coin with its plane vertical and spinning with angular velocity $\omega$ in its plane as shown in Fig. $1.120$ is set down on a flat surface. What is the final angular velocity of the coin? (Assume the coin stays vertical; neglect rolling friction.)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-269.jpg?height=261&width=287&top_left_y=561&top_left_x=577)

Fig. 1.120.
1155.Solution: The spinning coin is on a horizontal plane. As the forces acting on the coin, namely, the supporting force $\mathbf{F}$ and gravity $\mathbf{P}$, both pass through the center of mass, the angular momentum of the coin about its center of mass is conserved. Hence the angular velocity is still $\omega$ after it is set down on the surface.

1156.Problem Statement: Human legs are such that a person of normal size finds it comfortable to walk at a natural, swinging pace of about one step per second, but uncomfortable to force a pace substantially faster or slower. Neglecting the effect of the knee joint, use the simplest model you can to estimate the frequency which determines this pace, and to find what characteristic of the leg it depends on.
1156.Solution:
Consider the human leg to be a uniform pole of length $l$. In the simplest model, the swinging frequency of the leg should be equal to the characteristic frequency of the pole when it swings about its end as a fixed point. The motion is that of a compound pendulum described by

$$
\frac{1}{3} m l^{2} \ddot{\theta}=-\frac{1}{2} m g l \sin \theta,
$$

or

$$
\ddot{\theta}+\frac{3 g}{2 l} \theta=0,
$$

for $\theta$ small. Then the frequency of swing is $\nu=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \sqrt{\frac{3 g}{2 l}}$. If we take $l \approx 0.4 \mathrm{~m}, \nu \approx 1 \mathrm{~s}^{-1}$.

1158.Problem Statement: A uniform hoop of mass $M$ and radius $R$ hangs in a vertical plane supported by a knife edge at one point on the inside circumference. Calculate the natural frequency of small oscillations.
1158.Solution:
The moment of inertia of the hoop about the supporting knife edge is

$$
I=M R^{2}+M R^{2}=2 M R^{2} .
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-272.jpg?height=277&width=200&top_left_y=213&top_left_x=660)

Fig. 1.122.

Referring to Fig. 1.122, we have the equation of motion

$$
I \ddot{\theta}=-M g R \sin \theta,
$$

or

$$
I \ddot{\theta}=-M g R \theta
$$

for small oscillations. Hence the frequency is

$$
\nu=\frac{\omega}{2 \pi}=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \sqrt{\frac{M g R}{I}}=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \sqrt{\frac{g}{2 R}} .
$$

1159.Problem Statement:
An ultra-high speed rotor consists of a homogeneous disc of mass $M$, radius $R$ and width $2 l$. It is mounted on a shaft supported on bearings separated by a distance $2 d$ as shown in Fig. 1.123. The two additional masses, of equal mass $m$, are arranged symmetrically so that the rotor remains in "static" balance. Find the time-varying force on the bearings if the rotor turns at angular velocity $\omega$.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-272.jpg?height=241&width=371&top_left_y=1569&top_left_x=589)

Fig. 1.123.
1159.Solution: In the rotating frame attached to the disk, the additional masses each suffers a centrifugal force $m R \omega^{2}$, resulting in a torque $T=2 m R \omega^{2} l$. This torque is balanced by a torque of the same magnitude but opposite in direction, supplied by the bearings which are separated by a distance $2 d$. Hence the bearings each suffers a force $\frac{T}{2 d}=\frac{m R \omega^{2} l}{d}$ in the same direction as that of the centrifugal force on the nearer mass. In the fixed frame these rotate with angular velocity $\omega$.

1162.Problem Statement:
The two flywheels in Fig. $1.127$ are on parallel frictionless shafts but initially do not touch. The larger wheel has $f=2000 \mathrm{rev} / \mathrm{min}$ while the smaller is at rest. If the two parallel shafts are moved until contact occurs, find the angular velocity of the second wheel after equilibrium occurs (i.e. no further sliding at the point of contact), given that $R_{1}=2 R_{2}, I_{1}=16 I_{2}$. 
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-277.jpg?height=248&width=374&top_left_y=238&top_left_x=524)

Fig, 1.127.
1162.Solution:
Suppose the impulse of the interacting force between the two wheels from contact to equilibrium is $J$. Then the torque of the impulse acting on the larger wheel is $J R_{1}$ and that on the smaller wheel is $J R_{2}$.

We have $I_{1}\left(\omega_{1}-\omega_{1}^{\prime}\right)=J R_{1}, I_{2} \omega_{2}^{\prime}=J R_{2}$, where $\omega_{1}$ and $\omega_{1}^{\prime}$ are the angular velocities of the larger wheel before contact and after equilibrium respectively, and $\omega_{2}^{\prime}$ is the angular velocity of the smaller wheel after equilibrium. As there is no sliding between the wheels when equilibrium is reached,

$$
\omega_{1}^{\prime} R_{1}=\omega_{2}^{\prime} R_{2} .
$$

The above equations give

$$
\omega_{2}^{\prime}=\frac{I_{1} R_{1} R_{2} \omega_{1}^{\prime}}{I_{1} R_{2}^{2}+I_{2} R_{1}^{2}}=1.6 \omega_{1}=3200 \mathrm{rev} / \mathrm{min} .
$$

1163.Problem Statement: Two uniform cylinders are spinning independently about their axes, which are parallel. One has radius $R_{1}$ and mass $M_{1}$, the other $R_{2}$ and $M_{2}$. Initially they rotate in the same sense with angular speeds $\Omega_{1}$ and $\Omega_{2}$ respectively as shown in Fig. 1.128. They are then displaced until they touch along a common tangent. After a steady state is reached, what is the final angular velocity of each cylinder?
1163.Solution:
Let $\omega_{1}, \omega_{2}$ be the final angular velocities of the two cylinders respectively after steady state is reached. Then 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-278.jpg?height=188&width=317&top_left_y=225&top_left_x=595)

Fig. 1.128.

$$
\omega_{1} R_{1}=-\omega_{2} R_{2} .
$$

Let $J_{1}$ and $J_{2}$ be the time-integrated torque 2 exerts on 1 and 1 on 2 , then

$$
\begin{gathered}
\frac{J_{1}}{R_{1}}=\frac{J_{2}}{R_{2}}, \\
J_{1}=I_{1}\left(\omega_{1}-\Omega_{1}\right), \quad J_{2}=I_{2}\left(\omega_{2}-\Omega_{2}\right) ;
\end{gathered}
$$

or

$$
\frac{I_{1}\left(\omega_{1}-\Omega_{1}\right)}{R_{1}}=\frac{I_{2}\left(\omega_{2}-\Omega_{2}\right)}{R_{2}} .
$$

As $I \propto M R^{2}$, the last equation becomes

$$
M_{1} R_{1}\left(\omega_{1}-\Omega_{1}\right)=M_{2} R_{2}\left(\omega_{2}-\Omega_{2}\right),
$$

i.e.

$$
M_{1} R_{1} \omega_{1}-M_{2} R_{2} \omega_{2}=M_{1} R_{1} \Omega_{1}-M_{2} R_{2} \Omega_{2}
$$

Hence

$$
\begin{gathered}
\omega_{1}=\frac{M_{1} R_{1} \Omega_{1}-M_{2} R_{2} \Omega_{2}}{R_{1}\left(M_{1}+M_{2}\right)}, \\
\omega_{2}=\frac{M_{2} R_{2} \Omega_{2}-M_{1} R_{1} \Omega_{1}}{R_{2}\left(M_{1}+M_{2}\right)} .
\end{gathered}
$$

1165.Problem Statement:
Find the ratio of the periods of the two torsion pendula shown in Fig. 1.130. The two differ only by the addition of cylindrical masses as shown in the figure. The radius of each additional mass is $1 / 4$ the radius of the disc. Each cylinder and disc have equal mass.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-280.jpg?height=390&width=518&top_left_y=528&top_left_x=522)

Fig. 1.130.
1165.Solution:
Let $I_{1}$ and $I_{2}$ be the moments of inertia of the two torsion pendula respectively. If $A$ is the restoring coefficient of each wire, then the equations of motion are $I_{1} \ddot{\theta}+A \theta=0, I_{2} \ddot{\theta}+A \theta=0$. Hence the angular frequencies of oscillation of the torsion pendula are $\omega_{1}=\sqrt{A / I_{1}}$ and $\omega_{2}=\sqrt{A / I_{2}}$. For the first pendulum, $I_{1}=M R^{2} / 2$, and for the second,

$$
I_{2}=\frac{M R^{2}}{2}+2\left[\frac{M}{2}\left(\frac{R}{4}\right)^{2}+M\left(\frac{3 R}{4}\right)^{2}\right]=\frac{27}{16} M R^{2} \text {. }
$$

Hence the ratio of the periods is

$$
\frac{T_{1}}{T_{2}}=\frac{\omega_{2}}{\omega_{1}}=\sqrt{\frac{I_{1}}{I_{2}}}=\left(\frac{2}{3}\right)^{\frac{3}{2}} .
$$

1166.a.Problem Statement:
A long thin uniform bar of mass $M$ and length $L$ is hung from a fixed (assumed frictionless) axis at $A$ as shown in Fig. 1.131. The moment of inertia about $A$ is $M L^{2} / 3$.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-281.jpg?height=271&width=234&top_left_y=470&top_left_x=613)

Fig. 1.131.

An instantaneous horizontal impulse $J$ is delivered at $B$, a distance $a$ below $A$. What is the initial angular velocity of the bar?
1166.a.Solution:
$J a=I\left(\omega-\omega_{0}\right)$, where $\omega_{0}$ is the angular velocity of the bar before the impulse is delivered. As $\omega_{0}=0$, the initial angular velocity is

$$
\omega=\frac{J a}{I}=\frac{3 J a}{M L^{2}} .
$$

1166.b.Problem Statement:
A long thin uniform bar of mass $M$ and length $L$ is hung from a fixed (assumed frictionless) axis at $A$ as shown in Fig. 1.131. The moment of inertia about $A$ is $M L^{2} / 3$.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-281.jpg?height=271&width=234&top_left_y=470&top_left_x=613)

Fig. 1.131.

In general, as a result of $J$, there will be an impulse $J^{\prime}$ on the bar from the axis at $A$. What is $J^{\prime}$ ?
1166.b.Solution:
$J a=I\left(\omega-\omega_{0}\right)$, where $\omega_{0}$ is the angular velocity of the bar before the impulse is delivered. As $\omega_{0}=0$, the initial angular velocity is

$$
\omega=\frac{J a}{I}=\frac{3 J a}{M L^{2}} .
$$The initial velocity of the center of mass of the bar is $v=\omega L / 2$. So the change in the momentum of the bar is $M v=M \omega L / 2$. As this is equal to the total impulse on the bar, we have

$$
J+J^{\prime}=\frac{M \omega L}{2} .
$$

Hence

$$
J^{\prime}=\frac{M \omega L}{2}-J=J\left(\frac{3 a}{2 L}-1\right) .
$$

1167.Problem Statement:
The crankshaft shown in Fig. $1.132$ rotates with constant angular velocity $\omega$. Calculate the resultant forces on the bearings. In a sketch show the directions of these reactions and the direction of the angular momentum.

(Assume the crankshaft is made of thin rods with uniform density).

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-282.jpg?height=235&width=517&top_left_y=752&top_left_x=227)

Fig. 1.132.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-282.jpg?height=207&width=483&top_left_y=795&top_left_x=824)

Fig. $1.133$.
1167.Solution:
Consider the motion in a frame attached to the crankshaft as shown in Fig. 1.133. As the rods are either parallel or perpendicular to the axis of rotation, the centrifugal force on each rod can be considered as that on a point of the same mass located at its center of mass. Let $N$ denote the constraint force exerted by the bearing on each shaft. As there is no rotation about the $z$-axis, we require that the moments of the forces about $O$ should balance:

$$
2 b \cdot N+\frac{b}{2} \cdot \rho b \cdot a \omega^{2}=\frac{3 b}{2} \cdot \rho b \cdot a \omega^{2}+2 b \cdot \rho a \cdot \frac{a}{2} \omega^{2},
$$

giving

$$
N=\frac{\rho a \omega^{2}}{2}(a+b),
$$

where $\rho$ is the mass per unit length of the rods. The reactions on the bearings are equal and opposite to $N$ as shown in Fig. 1.131. In a fixed frame these forces are rotating, together with the crankshaft, with angular velocity $\omega$ about the axle. The angular momentum of the crankshaft is given by

$$
\left(\begin{array}{l}
L_{x} \\
L_{y} \\
L_{z}
\end{array}\right)=I\left(\begin{array}{c}
\omega \\
0 \\
0
\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{c}
I_{x x} \omega \\
I_{y x} \omega \\
I_{z x} \omega
\end{array}\right),
$$

where $I$ is the moment of inertia tensor about $O$ with elements

$$
I_{i j}=\sum_{n} \Delta m_{n}\left(r^{2} \delta_{i j}-x_{i} x_{j}\right) .
$$

As all $z=0, I_{z x}=0$. Furthermore it can be seen that $I_{x x}>0, I_{y x}<0$. Hence the angular momentum $L$ has direction in the rotating coordinate frame as shown in Fig. 1.133. Note that gravity has been neglected in the calculation, otherwise there is an additional constant force acting on each bearing, $(2 a+b) \rho g$ in magnitude and vertically downward in direction in the fixed frame.

1168.a.Problem Statement:
Two equal point masses $M$ are connected by a massless rigid rod of length $2 A$ (a dumbbell) which is constrained to rotate about an axle fixed to the center of the rod at an angle $\theta$ (Fig. 1.134). The center of the rod is at the origin of coordinates, the axle along the $z$-axis, and the dumbbell lies in the $x z$-plane at $t=0$. The angular velocity $\omega$ is a constant in time and is directed along the $z$-axis.

Calculate all elements of the inertia tensor.
1168.a.Solution:
Use a coordinate frame $x y z$ attached to the dumbbell such that the two point masses are in the $x z$-plane. The elements of the inertia tensor about $O$, given by $I_{i j}=\sum_{n} m_{n}\left(r^{2} \delta_{i j}-x_{i} x_{j}\right)$, are 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-284.jpg?height=281&width=366&top_left_y=213&top_left_x=610)

Fig. 1.134.

$$
\begin{gathered}
I_{x x}=2 M A^{2} \cos ^{2} \theta, \quad I_{y y}=2 M A^{2}, \quad I_{z z}=2 M A^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta, \\
I_{x y}=I_{y z}=0, \quad I_{z x}=-2 M A^{2} \cos \theta \sin \theta=-M A^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta
\end{gathered}
$$

Thus

$$
\mathbb{I}=\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
2 M A^{2} \cos ^{2} \theta & 0 & -M A^{2} \sin 2 \theta \\
0 & 2 M A^{2} & 0 \\
-M A^{2} \sin 2 \theta & 0 & 2 M A^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta
\end{array}\right) \text {. }
$$
1168.a.Final Answer: $$\left(\begin{array}{ccc}2 M A^{2} \cos ^{2} \theta  0  -M A^{2} \sin 2 \theta 0  2 M A^{2}  0 -M A^{2} \sin 2 \theta  0  2 M A^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta\end{array}\right)$$

1168.b.Problem Statement:

1169.Problem Statement:
A squirrel of mass $m$ runs at a constant speed $V_{0}$ relative to a cylindrical exercise cage of radius $R$ and moment of inertia $I$ as shown in Fig. 1.135. The cage has a damping torque proportional to its angular velocity. Neglect the dimensions of the squirrel compared with $R$. If initially the cage is at rest and the squirrel is at the bottom and running, find the motion of the squirrel relative to a fixed coordinate system in the small oscillation, underdamped case. Find the squirrel's angular velocity in terms of its angle relative to the vertical for arbitrary angular displacements for the undamped case. Discuss any design criteria for the cage in this case.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-286.jpg?height=250&width=201&top_left_y=573&top_left_x=358)

Fig. 1.135.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-286.jpg?height=361&width=248&top_left_y=522&top_left_x=958)

Fig. 1.136.
1169.Solution:
In a fixed coordinate frame, define $\theta$ as shown in Fig. 1.136. For the squirrel, the equation of motion is

$$
m R \ddot{\theta}=f-m g \sin \theta,
$$

and for the cage the equation of motion is

$$
I \ddot{\varphi}=-f R-k \dot{\varphi},
$$

where $f$ is the friction between the squirrel and the cage and $k$ is a constant. In addition, as the squirrel has a constant speed $V_{0}$ relative to the cage, we have

$$
R(\dot{\theta}-\dot{\varphi})=V_{0},
$$

which means $\ddot{\varphi}=\ddot{\theta}, \dot{\varphi}=\dot{\theta}-\frac{V_{0}}{R}$. Making use of these and eliminating $f$ from the equations of motion give

$$
\left(I+m R^{2}\right) \ddot{\theta}+k \dot{\theta}+m g R \sin \theta=\frac{k V_{0}}{R} .
$$

For small oscillations, $\theta \ll 1$ and the above reduces to

$$
\left(I+m R^{2}\right) \ddot{\theta}+k \dot{\theta}+m g R \theta=\frac{k V_{0}}{R} .
$$

A particular solution of this equation is

$$
\theta=\frac{k V_{0}}{m g R^{2}},
$$

while for underdamping the general solution for the homogeneous equation is

$$
\theta=e^{-b t}(A \sin \omega t+B \cos \omega t)
$$

where

$$
b=\frac{k}{2\left(I+m R^{2}\right)}, \quad \omega=\sqrt{\frac{m g R}{I+m R^{2}}-b^{2}} .
$$

Hence the general solution of the above equation is

$$
\theta=\frac{k V_{0}}{m g R^{2}}+e^{-b t}(A \sin \omega t+B \cos \omega t) .
$$

Using the initial condition that at $t=0, \theta=0, \varphi=0, \dot{\varphi}=0, \dot{\theta}=\frac{V_{0}}{R}$, we find

$$
\theta=\frac{k V_{0}}{m g R^{2}}-\frac{k V_{0}}{m g R^{2}}\left[\cos \omega t+\left(\frac{b}{\omega}-\frac{m g R}{\omega K}\right) \sin \omega t\right] e^{-b t}
$$

For the undamped case $(k=0)$, the differential equation is

$$
\left(I+m R^{2}\right) \ddot{\theta}+m g R \theta=0
$$

or, as $\ddot{\theta}=\frac{1}{2} \frac{d \dot{\theta}^{2}}{d \theta}$,

$$
\left(I+m R^{2}\right) d \dot{\theta}^{2}=-2 m g R \theta d \theta,
$$

which integrates to

$$
\dot{\theta}^{2}=\left(\frac{V_{0}}{R}\right)^{2}-\frac{m g R}{I+m R^{2}} \theta^{2}
$$

using the initial condition for $\dot{\theta}$. Hence

$$
\dot{\theta}=\pm \sqrt{\left(\frac{V_{0}}{R}\right)^{2}-\frac{m g R}{I+m R^{2}} \theta^{2}} \text {. }
$$

We require $I+m R^{2} \gg k$ for the undamped case to hold. Hence the cage should be designed with a large moment of inertia.

Take origin at the center $O$ of the square. For a coordinate frame attached to the square, take the plane of the square as the $x y$-plane with the $x$ - and $y$-axis parallel to the sides. The $z$-axis, which is along the normal, makes an angle $\theta$ with the $z^{\prime}$-axis of the laboratory frame about which the square rotates, as shown in Fig. 1.137. We also assume that the $x$-, $z$ - and $z^{\prime}$-axes are coplanar.

Then by symmetry the $x$-, $y$ - and $z$-axes are the principal axes of inertia about $O$, with corresponding moments of inertia

$$
I_{x x}=I_{y y}=\frac{m a^{2}}{12}, \quad I_{z z}=\frac{m a^{2}}{6},
$$

where $m$ is the mass of the square.

1170.b.Problem Statement:
A thin square plate with side length $a$ rotates at a constant angular frequency $\omega$ about an axis through the center tilted by an angle $\theta$ with respect to the normal to the plate.

Find the angular momentum $\mathbf{J}$ in the laboratory system.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-288.jpg?height=378&width=552&top_left_y=664&top_left_x=577)

Fig. 1.137.
1170.b.Solution:
Take origin at the center $O$ of the square. For a coordinate frame attached to the square, take the plane of the square as the $x y$-plane with the $x$ - and $y$-axis parallel to the sides. The $z$-axis, which is along the normal, makes an angle $\theta$ with the $z^{\prime}$-axis of the laboratory frame about which the square rotates, as shown in Fig. 1.137. We also assume that the $x$-, $z$ - and $z^{\prime}$-axes are coplanar.

Then by symmetry the $x$-, $y$ - and $z$-axes are the principal axes of inertia about $O$, with corresponding moments of inertia

$$
I_{x x}=I_{y y}=\frac{m a^{2}}{12}, \quad I_{z z}=\frac{m a^{2}}{6},
$$

where $m$ is the mass of the square.The angular momentum $\mathbf{J}$ resolved along the rotating frame coordinate axes is 

$$
\left(\begin{array}{l}
J_{x} \\
J_{y} \\
J_{z}
\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
\frac{m a^{2}}{12} & 0 & 0 \\
0 & \frac{m a^{2}}{12} & 0 \\
0 & 0 & \frac{m a^{2}}{6}
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{c}
\omega \sin \theta \\
0 \\
\omega \cos \theta
\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{c}
\frac{m a^{2}}{12} \omega \sin \theta \\
0 \\
\frac{m a^{2}}{6} \omega \cos \theta
\end{array}\right) \text {. }
$$

We can choose the laboratory frame so that its $y^{\prime}$-axis coincides with the $y$-axis at $t=0$. Then the unit vectors of the two frames are related by

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\mathbf{e}_{x}=\cos \theta \cos \omega t \mathbf{e}_{x^{\prime}}+\cos \theta \sin \omega t \mathbf{e}_{y^{\prime}}+\sin \theta \mathbf{e}_{z^{\prime}} \\
\mathbf{e}_{y}=-\sin \omega t \mathbf{e}_{x^{\prime}}+\cos \omega t \mathbf{e}_{y^{\prime}} \\
\mathbf{e}_{z}=-\sin \theta \cos \omega t \mathbf{e}_{x^{\prime}}-\sin \theta \sin \omega t \mathbf{e}_{y^{\prime}}+\cos \theta \mathbf{e}_{z^{\prime}}
\end{array}\right.
$$

Hence the angular momentum resolved along the laboratory frame coordinate axes is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(\begin{array}{c}
J_{x^{\prime}} \\
J_{y^{\prime}} \\
J_{z^{\prime}}
\end{array}\right) &=\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
\cos \theta \cos \omega t & -\sin \omega t & -\sin \theta \cos \omega t \\
\cos \theta \sin \omega t & \cos \omega t & -\sin \theta \sin \omega t \\
\sin \theta & 0 & \cos \theta
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{c}
\frac{m a^{2}}{12} \omega \sin \theta \\
0 \\
\frac{m a^{2}}{6} \omega \cos \theta
\end{array}\right) \\
&=\left(\begin{array}{c}
-\frac{m a^{2}}{12} \omega \sin \theta \cos \theta \cos \omega t \\
-\frac{m a^{2}}{12} \omega \sin \theta \cos \theta \sin \omega t \\
\frac{m a^{2}}{12} \omega\left(1+\cos ^{2} \theta\right)
\end{array}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

1170.c.Problem Statement:
A thin square plate with side length $a$ rotates at a constant angular frequency $\omega$ about an axis through the center tilted by an angle $\theta$ with respect to the normal to the plate.

Calculate the torque on the axis.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-288.jpg?height=378&width=552&top_left_y=664&top_left_x=577)

Fig. 1.137.
1170.c.Solution:
Take origin at the center $O$ of the square. For a coordinate frame attached to the square, take the plane of the square as the $x y$-plane with the $x$ - and $y$-axis parallel to the sides. The $z$-axis, which is along the normal, makes an angle $\theta$ with the $z^{\prime}$-axis of the laboratory frame about which the square rotates, as shown in Fig. 1.137. We also assume that the $x$-, $z$ - and $z^{\prime}$-axes are coplanar.

Then by symmetry the $x$-, $y$ - and $z$-axes are the principal axes of inertia about $O$, with corresponding moments of inertia

$$
I_{x x}=I_{y y}=\frac{m a^{2}}{12}, \quad I_{z z}=\frac{m a^{2}}{6},
$$

where $m$ is the mass of the square.The angular momentum $\mathbf{J}$ resolved along the rotating frame coordinate axes is 

$$
\left(\begin{array}{l}
J_{x} \\
J_{y} \\
J_{z}
\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
\frac{m a^{2}}{12} & 0 & 0 \\
0 & \frac{m a^{2}}{12} & 0 \\
0 & 0 & \frac{m a^{2}}{6}
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{c}
\omega \sin \theta \\
0 \\
\omega \cos \theta
\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{c}
\frac{m a^{2}}{12} \omega \sin \theta \\
0 \\
\frac{m a^{2}}{6} \omega \cos \theta
\end{array}\right) \text {. }
$$

We can choose the laboratory frame so that its $y^{\prime}$-axis coincides with the $y$-axis at $t=0$. Then the unit vectors of the two frames are related by

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\mathbf{e}_{x}=\cos \theta \cos \omega t \mathbf{e}_{x^{\prime}}+\cos \theta \sin \omega t \mathbf{e}_{y^{\prime}}+\sin \theta \mathbf{e}_{z^{\prime}} \\
\mathbf{e}_{y}=-\sin \omega t \mathbf{e}_{x^{\prime}}+\cos \omega t \mathbf{e}_{y^{\prime}} \\
\mathbf{e}_{z}=-\sin \theta \cos \omega t \mathbf{e}_{x^{\prime}}-\sin \theta \sin \omega t \mathbf{e}_{y^{\prime}}+\cos \theta \mathbf{e}_{z^{\prime}}
\end{array}\right.
$$

Hence the angular momentum resolved along the laboratory frame coordinate axes is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(\begin{array}{c}
J_{x^{\prime}} \\
J_{y^{\prime}} \\
J_{z^{\prime}}
\end{array}\right) &=\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
\cos \theta \cos \omega t & -\sin \omega t & -\sin \theta \cos \omega t \\
\cos \theta \sin \omega t & \cos \omega t & -\sin \theta \sin \omega t \\
\sin \theta & 0 & \cos \theta
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{c}
\frac{m a^{2}}{12} \omega \sin \theta \\
0 \\
\frac{m a^{2}}{6} \omega \cos \theta
\end{array}\right) \\
&=\left(\begin{array}{c}
-\frac{m a^{2}}{12} \omega \sin \theta \cos \theta \cos \omega t \\
-\frac{m a^{2}}{12} \omega \sin \theta \cos \theta \sin \omega t \\
\frac{m a^{2}}{12} \omega\left(1+\cos ^{2} \theta\right)
\end{array}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$The torque on the axis is given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbf{M}=\left(\frac{d \mathbf{J}}{d t}\right)_{\mathrm{lab}}=\left(\frac{d \mathbf{J}}{d t}\right)_{\text {rot }}+\omega \times \mathbf{J}=\omega \times \mathbf{J} \\
& =\left|\begin{array}{ccc}\mathbf{e}_{x} & \mathbf{e}_{y} & \mathbf{e}_{z} \\\omega \sin \theta & 0 & \omega \cos \theta \\\frac{m a^{2}}{12} \omega \sin \theta & 0 & \frac{m a^{2}}{6} \omega \cos \theta\end{array}\right| \\
& =-\frac{m a^{2}}{12} \omega^{2} \sin \theta \cos \theta e_{y} \text {. }
\end{aligned}
$$

The torque can be expressed in terms of components in the laboratory frame:

$$
\mathbf{M}=-\frac{m a^{2}}{12} \omega^{2} \sin \theta \cos \theta\left(-\sin \omega t \mathbf{e}_{x^{\prime}}+\cos \omega t \mathbf{e}_{y^{\prime}}\right) .
$$

This can also be obtained by differentiating $\mathbf{L}$ in the laboratory frame:

$$
\mathbf{M}=\left(\frac{d \mathbf{J}}{d t}\right)_{\text {Iab }} .
$$

1171.Problem Statement:
A thin flat rectangular plate, of mass $M$ and sides $a$ by $2 a$, rotates with constant angular velocity $\omega$ about an axle through two diagonal corners, as shown in Fig. 1.138. The axle is supported at the corners of the plate by bearings which can exert forces only on the axle. Ignoring gravitational and frictional forces, find the force exerted by each bearing on the axle as a function of time.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-290.jpg?height=314&width=464&top_left_y=605&top_left_x=561)

Fig. 1.138.
1171.Solution:
Use a coordinate frame attached to the plate with the origin at the center of mass $O$, the $y$-axis along the normal, and the $z$-axis parallel to the long side of the rectangle, as shown in Fig. 1.138. Then the $x$-, $y$ - and $z$-axes are the principal axes with principal moments of inertia

$$
I_{x x}=\frac{M a^{2}}{12}, \quad I_{y y}=\frac{5 M a^{2}}{12}, \quad I_{z z}=\frac{4 M a^{2}}{12} .
$$

Let $z^{\prime}$ denote the axis of rotation and $\alpha$ the angle between the $z$ - and $z^{\prime}$-axes. The angular momentum of the plate is

$$
\mathbf{L}=\frac{M a^{2}}{12}\left(\begin{array}{lll}
1 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 5 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 4
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{c}
\omega \sin \alpha \\
0 \\
\omega \cos \alpha
\end{array}\right)=\frac{M a^{2} \omega}{12}\left(\begin{array}{c}
\sin \alpha \\
0 \\
4 \cos \alpha
\end{array}\right)
$$

The torque on the axle of the plate is then 

$$
\begin{aligned}
\boldsymbol{\tau} &=\left(\frac{d \mathbf{L}}{d t}\right)_{\text {fxed }}=\left(\frac{d \mathbf{L}}{d t}\right)_{\text {rot }}+\omega \times \mathbf{L}=\omega \times \mathbf{L} \\
&=\frac{M a^{2} \omega^{2}}{12}\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
\mathbf{e}_{x} & \mathbf{e}_{y} & \mathbf{e}_{z} \\
\sin \alpha & 0 & \cos \alpha \\
\sin \alpha & 0 & 4 \cos \alpha
\end{array}\right| \\
&=-\frac{M a^{2} \omega^{2}}{4} \cos \alpha \sin \alpha \mathbf{e}_{y}=-\frac{M a^{2} \omega^{2}}{10} \mathbf{e}_{y}
\end{aligned}
$$

as $\sin \alpha=\frac{1}{\sqrt{5}}, \cos \alpha=\frac{2}{\sqrt{5}}$. Let $N_{A}, N_{B}$ be the constraint forces exerted by the bearings on the axle at $A, B$ respectively. Rotate the coordinate frame $O x y z$ about the $y$-axes so that the $z$ and $z^{\prime}$-axis coincide. The new coordinate axes are the $x^{\prime}$-axis, $y^{\prime}$-axis which is identical with the $y$-axis, and $z^{\prime}$-axis shown in Fig. 1.138. As the center of mass is stationary, we have

$$
N_{A x^{\prime}}+N_{B x^{\prime}}=0, \quad N_{A y^{\prime}}+N_{B y^{\prime}}=0 .
$$

Considering the torque about $O$ we have

$$
N_{B x^{\prime}} d-N_{A x^{\prime}} d=-\frac{M a^{2} \omega^{2}}{10}, \quad N_{A y^{\prime}} d-N_{B y^{\prime}} d=0,
$$

where $d=\frac{1}{2} \overline{A B}=\frac{\sqrt{5}}{2} a$. The above equations give

$$
\begin{aligned}
&N_{A y^{\prime}}=N_{B y^{\prime}}=0 \\
&N_{A x^{\prime}}=\frac{M a^{2} \omega^{2}}{20 d}=\frac{M a \omega^{2}}{10 \sqrt{5}}, \\
&N_{B x^{\prime}}=-\frac{M a^{2} \omega^{2}}{20 d}=-\frac{M a \omega^{2}}{10 \sqrt{5}} .
\end{aligned}
$$

These forces are fixed in the rotating frame. In a fixed coordinate frame they rotate with angular velocity $\omega$. In a fixed frame $O x^{\prime \prime} y^{\prime \prime} z^{\prime \prime}$ with the same $z^{\prime}$-axis and the $x^{\prime \prime}$-axis coinciding with the $x^{\prime}$-axis at $t=0$,

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
N_{A x^{\prime \prime}}=\frac{M a \omega^{2}}{10 \sqrt{5}} \cos \omega t, & N_{A y^{\prime \prime}}=-\frac{M a \omega^{2}}{10 \sqrt{5}} \sin \omega t, \\
N_{B x^{\prime \prime}}=-\frac{M a \omega^{2}}{10 \sqrt{5}} \cos \omega t, & N_{B y^{\prime \prime}}=\frac{M a \omega^{2}}{10 \sqrt{5}} \sin \omega t .
\end{array}
$$

1172.a.Problem Statement:
A homogeneous thin rod of mass $M$ and length $b$ is attached by means of an inextensible cord to a spring whose spring constant is $k$. The cord passes over a very small and smooth pulley fixed at $P$. The rod is free to rotate about $A$ without friction throughout the angular range $-\pi<\theta \leq \pi$ (Fig. 1.139). When $c=0$ the spring has its natural length. It is assumed that $b<a$ and that gravity acts downward.

Find the values of $\theta$ for which the system is in static equilibrium, and determine in each case if the equilibrium is stable, unstable or neutral.

(Note: line $P A$ is parallel to $\mathbf{g}$ ).

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-292.jpg?height=300&width=366&top_left_y=833&top_left_x=577)

Fig. 1.139.
1172.a.Solution:
Take the direction pointing out of the paper as the positive direction of the torques. The torque about point $A$ due to gravity is

$$
L_{g}=-\frac{M g b}{2} \sin \theta,
$$

and that caused by the restoring force due to the spring is $L_{k}=k c b \sin \theta_{1}$, where $\theta_{1}$ is the angle formed by the rod with the rope, or, using the sine theorem

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\frac{c}{\sin \theta}=\frac{a}{\sin \theta_{1}}, \\
&L_{k}=k b a \sin \theta .
\end{aligned}
$$

For equilibrium, we require $L_{g}+L_{k}=0$, or $k a \sin \theta=\frac{M g}{2} \sin \theta$. i) If $k a=M g / 2$, the equilibrium condition is satisfied for all $\theta$ and the equilibrium is neutral.

ii) If $k a<M g / 2$, the equilibrium condition is satisfied if $\theta=0$ or $\theta=\pi$. Consider the equilibrium at $\theta=0$. Let $\theta=0 \pm \epsilon$, where $\epsilon>0$ is a small angle. Then

$$
L=L_{k}+L_{g} \approx \mp b\left(\frac{M g}{2}-k a\right) \epsilon
$$

Thus

$$
\begin{aligned}
&L<0 \text { for } \theta=+\epsilon \\
&L>0 \text { for } \theta=-\epsilon .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence $L$ tends to increase $\epsilon$ in both cases and the equilibrium is unstable. For the equilibrium at $\theta=\pi \pm \epsilon$, we have

$$
L=\pm\left(\frac{M g}{2}-k a\right) \epsilon
$$

Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
&L<0 \text { for } \theta=\pi-\epsilon, \\
&L>0 \text { for } \theta=\pi+\epsilon .
\end{aligned}
$$

In the case $L$ tends to reduce $\epsilon$ and the equilibrium is stable.

iii) If $k a>M g / 2$, the situation is opposite to that of (ii). Hence in this case $\theta=0$ is a position of stable equilibrium and $\theta=\pi$ is a position of unstable equilibrium.

1172.b.Problem Statement:
A homogeneous thin rod of mass $M$ and length $b$ is attached by means of an inextensible cord to a spring whose spring constant is $k$. The cord passes over a very small and smooth pulley fixed at $P$. The rod is free to rotate about $A$ without friction throughout the angular range $-\pi<\theta \leq \pi$ (Fig. 1.139). When $c=0$ the spring has its natural length. It is assumed that $b<a$ and that gravity acts downward.

Find the frequencies for small oscillations about the points of stable equilibrium.

(Note: line $P A$ is parallel to $\mathbf{g}$ ).

1172.b.Solution:
Take the direction pointing out of the paper as the positive direction of the torques. The torque about point $A$ due to gravity is

and that caused by the restoring force due to the spring is $L_{k}=k c b \sin \theta_{1}$, where $\theta_{1}$ is the angle formed by the rod with the rope, or, using the sine theorem
