\begin{aligned}
&\frac{c}{\sin \theta}=\frac{a}{\sin \theta_{1}}, \\
&L_{k}=k b a \sin \theta .
\end{aligned}
$$

For equilibrium, we require $L_{g}+L_{k}=0$, or $k a \sin \theta=\frac{M g}{2} \sin \theta$. i) If $k a=M g / 2$, the equilibrium condition is satisfied for all $\theta$ and the equilibrium is neutral.

ii) If $k a<M g / 2$, the equilibrium condition is satisfied if $\theta=0$ or $\theta=\pi$. Consider the equilibrium at $\theta=0$. Let $\theta=0 \pm \epsilon$, where $\epsilon>0$ is a small angle. Then

$$
L=L_{k}+L_{g} \approx \mp b\left(\frac{M g}{2}-k a\right) \epsilon
$$

Thus

$$
\begin{aligned}
&L<0 \text { for } \theta=+\epsilon \\
&L>0 \text { for } \theta=-\epsilon .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence $L$ tends to increase $\epsilon$ in both cases and the equilibrium is unstable. For the equilibrium at $\theta=\pi \pm \epsilon$, we have

$$
L=\pm\left(\frac{M g}{2}-k a\right) \epsilon
$$

Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
&L<0 \text { for } \theta=\pi-\epsilon, \\
&L>0 \text { for } \theta=\pi+\epsilon .
\end{aligned}
$$

In the case $L$ tends to reduce $\epsilon$ and the equilibrium is stable.

iii) If $k a>M g / 2$, the situation is opposite to that of (ii). Hence in this case $\theta=0$ is a position of stable equilibrium and $\theta=\pi$ is a position of unstable equilibrium.Take the case of $k a>M g / 2$ where $\theta=0$ is a position of stable equilibrium. Let $\theta=\epsilon$ where $\epsilon$ is a small angle. The equation of motion is

$$
b\left(k a-\frac{M g}{2}\right) \sin \epsilon=-\frac{M b^{2}}{3} \ddot{\epsilon},
$$

or for small oscillations

$$
b(2 k a-M g) \epsilon+\frac{2 M b^{2}}{3} \ddot{\epsilon}=0 .
$$

Hence the frequency of oscillation is

$$
f=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \sqrt{\frac{3(2 k a-M g)}{2 M b}} .
$$

Similarly in the case $k a<M g / 2$, the frequency of small oscillations about the position of stable equilibrium at $\theta=\pi$ is

$$
f=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \sqrt{\frac{3(M g-2 k a)}{2 M b}} .
$$

1174.a.Problem Statement:
A cone of height $h$ and base radius $R$ is constrained to rotate about its vertical axis, as shown in Fig. 1.141. A thin, straight groove is cut in the surface of the cone from apex to base as shown. The cone is set rotating with initial angular velocity $\omega_{0}$ around its axis and a small (point-like) bead of mass $m$ is released at the top of the frictionless groove and is permitted to slide down under gravity. Assume that the bead stays in the groove, and that the moment of inertia of the cone about its axis is $I_{0}$.

What is the angular velocity of the cone when the bead reaches the bottom?

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-295.jpg?height=357&width=303&top_left_y=1232&top_left_x=522)

Fig. 1.141.
1174.a.Solution:
As the total angular momentum of the system is conserved, the angular velocity $\omega$ of the cone at the time when the bead reaches the bottom satisfies the relation 

$$
I_{0} \omega_{0}=\left(I_{0}+m R^{2}\right) \omega .
$$

Hence

$$
\omega=\frac{I_{0} \omega_{0}}{I_{0}+m R^{2}} .
$$

1174.b.Problem Statement:
A cone of height $h$ and base radius $R$ is constrained to rotate about its vertical axis, as shown in Fig. 1.141. A thin, straight groove is cut in the surface of the cone from apex to base as shown. The cone is set rotating with initial angular velocity $\omega_{0}$ around its axis and a small (point-like) bead of mass $m$ is released at the top of the frictionless groove and is permitted to slide down under gravity. Assume that the bead stays in the groove, and that the moment of inertia of the cone about its axis is $I_{0}$.

Find the speed of the bead in the laboratory just as it leaves the cone.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-295.jpg?height=357&width=303&top_left_y=1232&top_left_x=522)

Fig. 1.141.
1174.b.Solution:
As the total angular momentum of the system is conserved, the angular velocity $\omega$ of the cone at the time when the bead reaches the bottom satisfies the relation 

$$
I_{0} \omega_{0}=\left(I_{0}+m R^{2}\right) \omega .
$$

Hence

$$
\omega=\frac{I_{0} \omega_{0}}{I_{0}+m R^{2}} .
$$As the energy of the system is conserved, the velocity $v$ of the bead when it reaches the bottom satisfies

$$
\frac{1}{2} I_{0} \omega_{0}^{2}+m g h=\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}+\frac{1}{2} I_{0} \omega^{2}
$$

with

$$
v^{2}=v_{\|}^{2}+v_{\perp}^{2}=v_{\|}^{2}+R^{2} \omega^{2},
$$

where $v_{\|}$is velocity of the bead parallel to the groove and $v_{\perp}$ is that perpendicular to the groove. Thus

$$
\frac{1}{2} m v_{\|}^{2}=\frac{1}{2} I_{0} \omega_{0}^{2}+m g h-\frac{1}{2} I_{0} \omega^{2}-\frac{1}{2} m R^{2} \omega^{2},
$$

giving

$$
v_{\|}^{2}=I_{0} \omega_{0}^{2}-\frac{\left(I_{0}+m R^{2}\right)}{m} \frac{I_{0}^{2} \omega^{2}}{\left(I_{0}+m R^{2}\right)^{2}}+2 g h=\frac{I_{0} \omega_{0}^{2} R^{2}}{I_{0}+m R^{2}}+2 g h .
$$

Hence the velocity of the bead when it reaches the bottom is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{v} &=v_{\perp} \mathbf{i}+v_{\|} \mathbf{j} \\
&=\frac{I_{0} \omega_{0} R}{I_{0}+m R^{2}} \mathbf{i}+\sqrt{\frac{I_{0} \omega_{0}^{2} R^{2}}{I_{0}+m R^{2}}+2 g h} \mathbf{j},
\end{aligned}
$$

$i$ and $j$ being unit vectors along and perpendicular to the groove respectively, with magnitude

$$
v=\sqrt{\left(\frac{I_{0} \omega_{0} R}{I_{0}+m R^{2}}\right)^{2}+\frac{I_{0} \omega_{0}^{2} R^{2}}{I_{0}+m R^{2}}+2 g h} .
$$

This speed could have been obtained directly by substituting the expression for $\omega$ in the energy equation.

1175.Problem Statement:
A thin uniform disc, radius $a$ and mass $m$, is rotating freely on a frictionless bearing with uniform angular velocity $\omega$ about a fixed vertical axis passing through its center, and inclined at angle $\alpha$ to the symmetry axis of the disc. What is the magnitude and direction of the torque, and of the net force acting between the disc and the axis?

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-297.jpg?height=357&width=318&top_left_y=466&top_left_x=593)

Fig. $1.142$.
1175.Solution:
Take a coordinate frame $O x y z$ attached to the disc with the origin at its center $O$, the $z$-axis along the normal to the disc, and the $x$-axis in the plane of the $z$-axis and the axis of rotation $z^{\prime}$, as shown in Fig. 1.142. The $x$-, $y$ - and $z$-axes are the principal axes of the disc with principal moments of inertia

$$
I_{x}=\frac{1}{4} m a^{2}, \quad I_{y}=\frac{1}{4} m a^{2}, \quad I_{z}=\frac{1}{2} m a^{2} .
$$

The angular momentum about $O$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{L} &=\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
\frac{1}{4} m a^{2} & 0 & 0 \\
0 & \frac{1}{4} m a^{2} & 0 \\
0 & 0 & \frac{1}{2} m a^{2}
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{c}
\omega \sin \alpha \\
0 \\
\omega \cos \alpha
\end{array}\right) \\
&=\frac{1}{4} m a^{2}\left(\omega \sin \alpha \mathbf{e}_{x}+2 \omega \cos \alpha \mathbf{e}_{z}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the torque is 

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{M} &=\left(\frac{d \mathbf{L}}{d t}\right)_{\text {fixed }}=\left(\frac{d \mathbf{L}}{d t}\right)_{\text {rot }}+\omega \times \mathbf{L}=\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{L} \\
&=\left(\omega \sin \alpha \mathbf{e}_{x}+\omega \cos \alpha \mathbf{e}_{z}\right) \times \frac{1}{4} m a^{2} \omega\left(\sin \alpha \mathbf{e}_{x}+2 \cos \alpha \mathbf{e}_{z}\right) \\
&=-\frac{1}{4} m a^{2} \omega \sin \alpha \cos \alpha \mathbf{e}_{y}
\end{aligned}
$$

The torque is in the plane of the disc and is perpendicular to the plane formed by the normal to the disc and the axis of rotation. It rotates with the disc. As the center of mass of the disc is stationary, the net force on the disc is zero.

1176.a.Problem Statement:
A moon of mass $m$ orbits with angular velocity $\omega$ around a planet of mass $M$. Assume $m \ll M$. The rotation of the moon can be neglected but the planet rotates about its axis with angular velocity $S$. The axis of rotation of the planet is perpendicular to the plane of the orbit. Let $I=$ moment of the inertia of the planet about its axis and $D=$ distance from the moon to the center of the planet.

Find expressions for the total angular momentum $L$ of the system about its center of mass and for the total energy $E$. Eliminate $D$ from both these expressions.

Famous examples of this effect occur in the orbits of the moons of Mercury and Venus.
(However, it is the lighter body whose rotation is relevant in these examples.)

1177.a.Problem Statement:
A pendulum consists of a uniform rigid rod of length $L$, mass $M$, a bug of mass $M / 3$ which can crawl along the rod. The rod is pivoted at one end and swings in a vertical plane. Initially the bug is at the pivot-end of the rod, which is at rest at an angle $\theta_{0}\left(\theta_{0} \ll 1 \mathrm{rad}\right)$ from the vertical as shown in Fig. 1.143, is released. For $t>0$ the bug crawls slowly with constant speed $V$ along the rod towards the bottom end of the rod.

Find the frequency $\omega$ of the swing of the pendulum when the bug has crawled a distance $l$ along the rod.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-300.jpg?height=387&width=237&top_left_y=1242&top_left_x=658)

Fig. 1.143.
1177.a.Solution:
When the bug has crawled a distance $l$, the moment of inertia of the rod and bug about the pivot is 

$$
I=\frac{1}{3} M L^{2}+\frac{1}{3} M l^{2}=\frac{1}{3} M\left(L^{2}+l^{2}\right) .
$$

The equation of motion of the pendulum is

$$
\frac{\dot{d}}{d t}(I \dot{\theta})=-M g \frac{L}{2} \sin \theta-\frac{1}{3} M g l \sin \theta,
$$

or

$$
\frac{1}{3} M\left(L^{2}+l^{2}\right) \ddot{\theta}+\frac{2}{3} M l \dot{\theta}=-M g \sin \theta\left(\frac{L}{2}+\frac{l}{3}\right) .
$$

For small oscillations it becomes

$$
\ddot{\theta}+\frac{2 l i \dot{\theta}}{L^{2}+l^{2}}+\frac{g\left(l+\frac{3 L}{2}\right) \theta}{L^{2}+l^{2}}=0 .
$$

If the bug crawls so slowly that the change in $l$ in a period of oscillation is negligible, i.e. $i=v \ll l \omega$, we can ignore the second term and write

$$
\ddot{\theta}+\frac{g(2 l+3 L)}{2\left(L^{2}+l^{2}\right)} \theta=0
$$

Hence the angular frequency of oscillation $\omega$ is

$$
\omega=\sqrt{\frac{g(2 l+3 L)}{2\left(L^{2}+l^{2}\right)}} .
$$

1177.b.Problem Statement:
A pendulum consists of a uniform rigid rod of length $L$, mass $M$, a bug of mass $M / 3$ which can crawl along the rod. The rod is pivoted at one end and swings in a vertical plane. Initially the bug is at the pivot-end of the rod, which is at rest at an angle $\theta_{0}\left(\theta_{0} \ll 1 \mathrm{rad}\right)$ from the vertical as shown in Fig. 1.143, is released. For $t>0$ the bug crawls slowly with constant speed $V$ along the rod towards the bottom end of the rod.

Find the amplitude of the swing of the pendulum when the bug has crawled to the bottom end of the $\operatorname{rod}(l=L)$.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-300.jpg?height=387&width=237&top_left_y=1242&top_left_x=658)

Fig. 1.143.
1177.b.Solution:
When the bug has crawled a distance $l$, the moment of inertia of the rod and bug about the pivot is 

$$
I=\frac{1}{3} M L^{2}+\frac{1}{3} M l^{2}=\frac{1}{3} M\left(L^{2}+l^{2}\right) .
$$

The equation of motion of the pendulum is

$$
\frac{\dot{d}}{d t}(I \dot{\theta})=-M g \frac{L}{2} \sin \theta-\frac{1}{3} M g l \sin \theta,
$$

or

$$
\frac{1}{3} M\left(L^{2}+l^{2}\right) \ddot{\theta}+\frac{2}{3} M l \dot{\theta}=-M g \sin \theta\left(\frac{L}{2}+\frac{l}{3}\right) .
$$

For small oscillations it becomes

$$
\ddot{\theta}+\frac{2 l i \dot{\theta}}{L^{2}+l^{2}}+\frac{g\left(l+\frac{3 L}{2}\right) \theta}{L^{2}+l^{2}}=0 .
$$

If the bug crawls so slowly that the change in $l$ in a period of oscillation is negligible, i.e. $i=v \ll l \omega$, we can ignore the second term and write

$$
\ddot{\theta}+\frac{g(2 l+3 L)}{2\left(L^{2}+l^{2}\right)} \theta=0
$$

Hence the angular frequency of oscillation $\omega$ is

$$
\omega=\sqrt{\frac{g(2 l+3 L)}{2\left(L^{2}+l^{2}\right)}} .
$$Consider the motion of the bug along the rod,

$$
\frac{M}{3}\left(\ddot{l}-l \dot{\theta}^{2}\right)=\frac{M g \cos \theta}{3}-f,
$$

where $f$ is the force exerted on the bug by the rod. As the bug crawls with constant speed, $\ddot{l}=0$. Also for small oscillations, $\cos \theta \approx 1-\frac{\theta^{2}}{2}$. The above gives

$$
f=\frac{M g}{3}-\frac{M g}{6} \theta^{2}+\frac{M l \dot{\theta}^{2}}{3} .
$$

The work done by $f$ as the bug crawls a distance $d l$ is then

$$
d W=-f d l=-\frac{M g}{3} d l+\frac{M}{3}\left(\frac{g \theta^{2}}{2}-l \dot{\theta}^{2}\right) d l
$$

which is stored as energy of the system. The first term on the right-hand side is the change in the potential energy of the bug, while the second term is the change in the energy of oscillation $E$ of the system, 

$$
d E=\frac{M}{3}\left(\frac{g \theta^{2}}{2}-l \dot{\theta}^{2}\right) d l .
$$

Under the condition $i \ll l \omega, l$ hardly changes in a period of oscillation and can be taken to be constant. For each $l$, when we consider a full period, the kinematic quantities in the above equation can be replaced by their average values

$$
d E=\frac{M}{3}\left(\frac{g \overline{\theta^{2}}}{2}-\overline{\overrightarrow{\theta^{2}}}\right) d l .
$$

Now, in single harmonic oscillations the potential and kinetic energy are equal on average, so that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\bar{T} &=\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{M}{3}\left(L^{2}+l^{2}\right) \dot{\theta}^{2}=\frac{E}{2}, \\
\bar{V} &=\frac{M g L}{2}(1-\overline{\cos \theta})+\frac{M g l}{3}(1-\overline{\cos \theta}) \\
&=\frac{M g}{2}\left(\frac{L}{2}+\frac{l}{3}\right) \overline{\theta^{2}}=\frac{E}{2} ;
\end{aligned}
$$

or

$$
\begin{aligned}
\overline{\theta^{2}} &=\frac{3 E}{M\left(L^{2}+l^{2}\right)}, \\
\overline{\theta^{2}} &=\frac{6 E}{M g(3 L+2 l)} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Substituting these in the energy equation we have

$$
\frac{d E}{E}=\left(\frac{1}{3 L+2 l}-\frac{l}{L^{2}+l^{2}}\right) d l
$$

or

$$
\ln E=\frac{1}{2} \ln \left(\frac{3 L+2 l}{L^{2}+l^{2}}\right)+K,
$$

where $K$ is a constant. Initially, $l=0, E=E_{0}$, i.e.

$$
\ln E_{0}=\frac{1}{2} \ln \left(\frac{3}{L}\right)+K,
$$

and we thus have

$$
\ln \frac{E}{E_{0}}=\frac{1}{2} \ln \left[\frac{(3 L+2 l) L}{3\left(L^{2}+l^{2}\right)}\right] .
$$

When $l=L$

$$
\ln \frac{E}{E_{0}}=\frac{1}{2} \ln \frac{5}{6},
$$

i.e.

$$
E=\sqrt{\frac{5}{6}} E_{0} .
$$

$\theta$ is equal to the amplitude when $\dot{\theta}=0$ i.e. $T=0$ and $E=V$. When $l=L$, the amplitude $\theta_{\max }$ is given by

$$
\frac{1}{2} M g\left(\frac{L}{2}+\frac{L}{3}\right) \theta_{\max }^{2}=E .
$$

When $l=0$, we have

$$
\frac{1}{2} M g \cdot \frac{L}{2} \theta_{0}^{2}=E_{0} .
$$

Then as $E=\sqrt{\frac{5}{6}} E_{0}$, the above expressions give

$$
\theta_{\max }=\left(\frac{3}{10}\right)^{\frac{1}{4}} \theta_{0} .
$$

1180.Problem Statement: A bowling ball of uniform density is thrown along a horizontal alley with initial velocity $v_{0}$ in such a way that it initially slides without rolling. The ball has mass $m$, coefficient of static friction $\mu_{s}$ and coefficient of sliding friction $\mu_{d}$ with the floor. Ignore the effect of air friction. Compute the velocity of the ball when it begins to roll without sliding. (Princeton)
1180.Solution:
When the bowling ball slides without rolling the friction $f=\mu_{d} m g$ gives rise to an acceleration

$$
a=-\frac{f}{m}=-\mu_{d} g .
$$

The moment of $f$ gives rise to an angular acceleration $\alpha$ given by

$$
f R=\frac{2}{5} M R^{2} \alpha
$$

as the ball has a moment of inertia $\frac{2}{5} m R^{2}$ about an axis through its center, $R$ being its radius. Suppose at time $t$ the ball begins to roll without sliding. We require

$$
R \alpha t=v_{0}+a t,
$$

giving

$$
t=\frac{v_{0}}{R \alpha-a}=\frac{2 m v_{0}}{7 f}=\frac{2 v_{0}}{7 \mu_{d} g} .
$$

The velocity of the ball when this happens is

$$
v=v_{0}+a t=v_{0}-\mu_{d} g t=\frac{5}{7} v_{0} .
$$

1182.b.Problem Statement:
A wheel of mass $M$ and radius $R$ is projected along a horizontal surface with an initial linear velocity $V_{0}$ and an initial angular velocity $\omega_{0}$ as shown in Fig. 1.150, so it starts sliding along the surface $\left(\omega_{0}\right.$ tends to produce rolling in the direction opposite to $V_{0}$ ). Let the coefficient of friction between the wheel and the surface be $\mu$.

What is the velocity of the center of mass of the wheel at the time when the slipping stops?

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-310.jpg?height=196&width=404&top_left_y=573&top_left_x=672)

Fig. 1.150.
1182.b.Solution:
Take the positive $x$ direction as towards the right and the angular velocity $\dot{\theta}$ as positive when the wheel rotates clockwise. Assume the wheel has moment of inertia $\frac{1}{2} M R^{2}$ about the axle. We then have two equations of motion:

$$
\begin{aligned}
M \ddot{x} &=-\mu M g, \\
\frac{1}{2} M R^{2} \ddot{\theta} &=\mu M g R .
\end{aligned}
$$

Making use of the initial conditions $\dot{x}_{c}=V_{0}, \dot{\theta}_{c}=-\omega_{0}$ at $t=0$ we obtain by integration

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\dot{x}=V_{0}-\mu g t, \\
&\dot{\theta}=-\omega_{0}+\frac{2 \mu g t}{R} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Let $T$ be the time when sliding ceases. Then at $T$

$$
\dot{x}=R \dot{\theta},
$$

or

$$
V_{0}-\mu g T=-R \omega_{0}+2 \mu g T,
$$

giving

$$
T=\frac{V_{0}+R \omega_{0}}{3 \mu g} .
$$

The velocity of the center of mass of the wheel at the time when slipping stops is

$$
\dot{x}=V_{0}-\mu g T=\frac{1}{3}\left(2 V_{0}-R \omega_{0}\right) .
$$

1183.Problem Statement:
A thin hollow cylinder of radius $R$ and mass $M$ slides across a frictionless floor with speed $V_{0}$. Initially the cylinder is spinning backward with angular velocity $\omega_{0}=2 V_{0} / R$ as shown in Fig. 1.151. The cylinder passes onto a rough area and continues moving in a straight line. Due to friction, it eventually rolls. What is the final velocity $\mathbf{V}_{f}$ ?

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-311.jpg?height=179&width=332&top_left_y=1067&top_left_x=313)

Fig. 1.151.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-311.jpg?height=182&width=269&top_left_y=1088&top_left_x=923)

Fig. 1.152.
1183.Solution:
Suppose the cylinder enters the rough area at time $t=0$ and starts to roll without slipping at time $t=t_{0}$. At $0<t<t_{0}$ the equations of motion of the cylinder are (Fig. 1.152)

$$
\begin{aligned}
&-f=M \frac{d V}{d t}, \\
&f R=I \frac{d \omega}{d t}
\end{aligned}
$$

with $I=M R^{2}$. Integrating we obtain 

$$
M\left(V_{f}-V_{0}\right)=-\int_{0}^{t_{0}} f d t,
$$

or

$$
I\left[\omega_{f}-\left(-\omega_{0}\right)\right]=R \int_{0}^{t_{0}} f d t
$$

giving

$$
I\left(\omega_{f}+\omega_{0}\right)=M R\left(V_{0}-V_{f}\right) .
$$

The cylinder rolls without slipping at $t=t_{0}$, when $V_{f}=\omega_{f} R$. We are also given $\omega_{0} R=2 V_{0}$. The last equation then gives

$$
V_{f}=-\frac{1}{2} V_{0} .
$$

Hence the cylinder will eventually move backward with a speed $\frac{1}{2} V_{0}$.

1184.Problem Statement:
Calculate the minimum coefficient of friction necessary to keep a thin circular ring from sliding as it rolls down a plane inclined at an angle $\theta$ with respect to the horizontal plane.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-312.jpg?height=270&width=399&top_left_y=1255&top_left_x=544)

Fig. 1.153.
1184.Solution:
Use coordinates as shown in Fig. $1.153$ and write down the equations of motion for the ring:

$$
m \ddot{x}=m g \sin \theta-f, \quad I \ddot{\varphi}=f R,
$$

where $m$ and $R$ are the mass and radius of the ring respectively, $I=m R^{2}$ is the moment of inertia of the ring about its axis of symmetry and $f$ is the static friction on the ring. The above equations combine to give

$$
\ddot{x}+R \ddot{\varphi}=g \sin \theta .
$$

The condition for no sliding is $R \dot{\varphi}=\dot{x}$, or $R \ddot{\varphi}=\ddot{x}$, giving

$$
\ddot{x}=\frac{1}{2} g \sin \theta .
$$

Hence

$$
f=m g \sin \theta-m \ddot{x}=\frac{1}{2} m g \sin \theta .
$$

The normal reaction of the inclined plane is $N=m g \cos \theta$, and for no slipping we require $f<\mu N$, or

$$
\frac{1}{2} m g \sin \theta<\mu m g \cos \theta \text {, }
$$

i.e.

$$
\frac{1}{2} \tan \theta<\mu .
$$

Hence the minimum coefficient of friction necessary to keep the ring from slipping is $\mu=\frac{1}{2} \tan \theta$.

1185.a.Problem Statement:
A solid uniform cylinder of mass $m$, radius $R$ is placed on a plane inclined at angle $\theta$ relative to the horizonte] as shown in Fig. 1.154. Let $g$ denote the usual acceleration due to gravity, and let $a$ be the acceleration along the incline of the axis of the cylinder. The coefficient of friction between cylinder and plane is $\mu$.

For $\theta$ less than some critical angle $\theta_{c}$, the cylinder will roll down the incline without slipping.

What is the angle $\theta_{c}$ ?
1185.a.Solution:
Let $f$ denote the frictional force and $\alpha$ the angular acceleration about the axis of the cylinder. The equations of motion are 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-314.jpg?height=207&width=238&top_left_y=233&top_left_x=641)

Fig. 1.154.

$$
\begin{aligned}
m g \sin \theta-f &=m a, \\
f R &=I \alpha,
\end{aligned}
$$

with

$$
I=\frac{1}{2} M R^{2} .
$$

If there is no slipping, we require $a=R \alpha, f<\mu N$, where $N$, the normal reaction of the inclined plane, equals $m g \cos \theta$. The equations of motion give

$$
f=\frac{1}{3} m g \sin \theta .
$$

Hence we require

$$
\mu m g \cos \theta>\frac{1}{3} m g \sin \theta,
$$

or

$$
3 \mu>\tan \theta .
$$

Let $\tan \theta_{c}=3 \mu$. Then we require $\tan \theta<\tan \theta_{c}$ for no slipping. Therefore the critical angle is $\theta_{c}=\arctan 3 \mu$.

1185.b.Problem Statement:
A solid uniform cylinder of mass $m$, radius $R$ is placed on a plane inclined at angle $\theta$ relative to the horizonte] as shown in Fig. 1.154. Let $g$ denote the usual acceleration due to gravity, and let $a$ be the acceleration along the incline of the axis of the cylinder. The coefficient of friction between cylinder and plane is $\mu$.

For $\theta$ less than some critical angle $\theta_{c}$, the cylinder will roll down the incline without slipping.

For $\theta<\theta_{c}$, what is the acceleration $a$ ?
1185.b.Solution:
Let $f$ denote the frictional force and $\alpha$ the angular acceleration about the axis of the cylinder. The equations of motion are 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-314.jpg?height=207&width=238&top_left_y=233&top_left_x=641)

Fig. 1.154.

$$
\begin{aligned}
m g \sin \theta-f &=m a, \\
f R &=I \alpha,
\end{aligned}
$$

with

$$
I=\frac{1}{2} M R^{2} .
$$

If there is no slipping, we require $a=R \alpha, f<\mu N$, where $N$, the normal reaction of the inclined plane, equals $m g \cos \theta$. The equations of motion give

$$
f=\frac{1}{3} m g \sin \theta .
$$

Hence we require

$$
\mu m g \cos \theta>\frac{1}{3} m g \sin \theta,
$$

or

$$
3 \mu>\tan \theta .
$$

Let $\tan \theta_{c}=3 \mu$. Then we require $\tan \theta<\tan \theta_{c}$ for no slipping. Therefore the critical angle is $\theta_{c}=\arctan 3 \mu$.For $\theta<\theta_{c}$, the cylinder rolls without slipping and the above gives

$$
a=g \sin \theta-\frac{f}{m}=\frac{2}{3} g \sin \theta .
$$

1186.a.Problem Statement:
A wheel of radius $r$, mass $m$, and moment of inertia $I=m R^{2}$ is pulled along a horizontal surface by application of a horizontal force $\mathbf{F}$ to a rope unwinding from an axle of radius $b$ as shown in Fig. 1.155. You may assume there is a frictional force between the wheel and the surface such that the wheel rolls without slipping. In the expression $I=m R^{2}$ the quantity $R$ is a constant with dimensions of length.

What is the linear acceleration of the wheel?
1186.a.Solution:
Let $x$ be the displacement of the center of mass of the wheel along the horizontal direction and $\theta$ the angular displacement of the wheel from an initial direction through its center of mass.

The equations of motion of the wheel are (Fig. 1.155)

$$
\begin{aligned}
m \ddot{x} &=F-f, \\
I \ddot{\theta} &=F b+f r .
\end{aligned}
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-315.jpg?height=242&width=422&top_left_y=931&top_left_x=590)

Fig. 1.155.

The constraint for no sliding is $\dot{x}=r \dot{\theta}$ or $\ddot{x}=r \ddot{\theta}$. Hence

$$
\frac{m R^{2}}{r} \ddot{x}=F b+(F-m \ddot{x}) r,
$$

or

$$
\ddot{x}=\frac{F(b+r) r}{m\left(R^{2}+r^{2}\right)},
$$

which is the linear acceleration of the wheel.

1186.b.Problem Statement:
A wheel of radius $r$, mass $m$, and moment of inertia $I=m R^{2}$ is pulled along a horizontal surface by application of a horizontal force $\mathbf{F}$ to a rope unwinding from an axle of radius $b$ as shown in Fig. 1.155. You may assume there is a frictional force between the wheel and the surface such that the wheel rolls without slipping. In the expression $I=m R^{2}$ the quantity $R$ is a constant with dimensions of length.

Calculate the frictional force that acts on the wheel.
1186.b.Solution:
Let $x$ be the displacement of the center of mass of the wheel along the horizontal direction and $\theta$ the angular displacement of the wheel from an initial direction through its center of mass.

The equations of motion of the wheel are (Fig. 1.155)

$$
\begin{aligned}
m \ddot{x} &=F-f, \\
I \ddot{\theta} &=F b+f r .
\end{aligned}
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-315.jpg?height=242&width=422&top_left_y=931&top_left_x=590)

Fig. 1.155.

The constraint for no sliding is $\dot{x}=r \dot{\theta}$ or $\ddot{x}=r \ddot{\theta}$. Hence

$$
\frac{m R^{2}}{r} \ddot{x}=F b+(F-m \ddot{x}) r,
$$

or

$$
\ddot{x}=\frac{F(b+r) r}{m\left(R^{2}+r^{2}\right)},
$$

which is the linear acceleration of the wheel.The frictional force is

$$
\begin{aligned}
f &=F-m \ddot{x} \\
&=F\left[1-\frac{(b+r) r}{R^{2}+r^{2}}\right]=\frac{F\left(R^{2}-b r\right)}{R^{2}+r^{2}} .
\end{aligned}
$$

1187.Problem Statement:
A flat disc of mass $m=1.8 \mathrm{~kg}$ and radius $r=0.2 \mathrm{~m}$ lies on a frictionless horizontal table. A string wound around the cylindrical surface of the disc exerts a force of 3 Newtons in the northerly direction (Fig. 1.156). Find the acceleration (magnitude and direction) of the center of mass $a$ and the angular acceleration $\alpha$ about the center of mass. Is $a=r \alpha$ ? Explain.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-316.jpg?height=203&width=221&top_left_y=615&top_left_x=674)

Fig. 1.156.
1187.Solution:
The equations of motion are

$$
\begin{aligned}
f &=m a \\
f r &=I \alpha
\end{aligned}
$$

where $I=m r^{2} / 2$, giving

$$
\begin{aligned}
&a=\frac{f}{m}=1.7 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \\
&\alpha=\frac{2 f}{m r}=17 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s} .
\end{aligned}
$$

The direction of $a$ is the same as that of $f$. It is seen that $a \neq \alpha r$. This is because as the disc lies on its flat surface the two motions are not related even though they are due to the same force.

1188.Problem Statement:
A wheel of radius $R$ and moment of inertia $I$ is mounted on a frictionless axle at $O$. A flexible, weightless cord is wrapped around the rim of the 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-317.jpg?height=413&width=225&top_left_y=246&top_left_x=639)

Fig. 1.157.

wheel and carries a body of mass $M$ which begins descending as shown in Fig. 1.157. What is the tension in the cord?
1188.Solution:
Let $F$ be the tension in the cord, $x$ the position of the center of mass of the body and $\dot{\theta}$ the angular velocity of the body as shown in Fig. 1.157. We have the following equations:

$$
\begin{aligned}
I \ddot{\theta} &=F R, \\
M \ddot{x} &=M g-F, \\
\ddot{x} &=R \ddot{\theta},
\end{aligned}
$$

which yield

$$
F=\frac{M g I}{I+M R^{2}} .
$$

1189.Problem Statement:
Two uniform discs in a vertical plane of masses $M_{1}$ and $M_{2}$ with radii $R_{1}$ and $R_{2}$ respectively have a thread wound about their circumferences, and are thus connected as shown in Fig. 1.158.

The first disc has fixed frictionless horizontal axis of rotation through its center. Set up the equations to determine the acceleration of the center of mass of the second disc if it falls freely. 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-318.jpg?height=370&width=383&top_left_y=254&top_left_x=628)

Fig. 1.158.

(You need not solve the equations.)
1189.Solution:
Let $F$ be the tension in the thread, $x_{1}$ the distance of the center of mass of disc 2 from that of disc 1 , and $\dot{\theta}_{1}, \dot{\theta}_{2}$ the angular velocities of the discs, as shown in Fig. 1.158. We have the equations of motion

$$
\begin{aligned}
M_{2} \ddot{x} &=M_{2} g-F, \\
I_{1} \ddot{\theta}_{1} &=F R_{1}, \\
I_{2} \ddot{\theta}_{2} &=F R_{2},
\end{aligned}
$$

where $I_{1}=m_{1} R_{1}^{2} / 2, I_{2}=m_{2} R_{2}^{2} / 2$. $W_{2}$ also have the constraint

$$
\dot{x}=R_{1} \dot{\theta}_{1}+R_{2} \dot{\theta}_{2} \text {, }
$$

or

$$
\ddot{x}=R_{1} \ddot{\theta}_{1}+R_{2} \ddot{\theta}_{2} .
$$

From the four equations the unknowns $\ddot{\theta}_{1}, \ddot{\theta}_{2}, \ddot{x}$ and $F$ can be determined.

1190.Problem Statement: A yo-yo of mass $M$ is composed of 2 large disks of radius $R$ and thickness $t$ separated by a distance $t$ with a shaft of radius $r$. Assume a uniform density throughout. Find the tension in the massless string as the yo-yo descends under the influence of gravity.
1190.Solution:
Let the density of the yo-yo be $\rho$, then its moment of inertia and mass are respectively

$$
\begin{aligned}
I &=2 \cdot \frac{1}{2} \pi t \rho R^{4}+\frac{1}{2} \pi t \rho r^{4}, \\
M &=2 \pi t \rho R^{2}+\pi t \rho r^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

whence

$$
I=\frac{1}{2} M\left(\frac{2 R^{4}+r^{4}}{2 R^{2}+r^{2}}\right) .
$$

The equations of motion of the yo-yo are

$$
\begin{aligned}
M \ddot{x} &=M g-F, \\
I \ddot{\theta} &=F r,
\end{aligned}
$$

where $F$ is the tension in the string. We also have the constraint $\ddot{x}=r \ddot{\theta}$. From the above we obtain

$$
F=\frac{I M g}{I+M r^{2}}=\frac{\left(2 R^{4}+r^{4}\right) M g}{2 R^{4}+4 R^{2} r^{2}+3 r^{4}} .
$$

1191.Problem Statement:
A sphere of mass $M$ and radius $R\left(I=\frac{2}{5} M R^{2}\right)$ rests on the platform of a truck. The truck starts from rest and has a constant acceleration $A$. Assuming that the sphere rolls without slipping, find the acceleration of the center of mass of the ball relative to the truck.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-319.jpg?height=240&width=532&top_left_y=1602&top_left_x=509)

Fig. 1.159.
1191.Solution:
Let $O x y$ and $O^{\prime} x^{\prime} y^{\prime}$ be coordinate frames attached to the truck and fixed in space respectively with the $x$ - and $x^{\prime}$-axes along the horizontal as shown in Fig. 1.159. Denoting $\overline{O^{\prime} O}=\xi$, we have for the center of mass of the sphere

$$
x^{\prime}=x+\xi, \quad \text { or } \quad \ddot{x^{\prime}}=\ddot{x}+\ddot{\xi} \text {. }
$$

As the force acting on the sphere is the friction $f$, Newton's second law gives, writing $A$ for $\ddot{\xi}$,

$$
f=M \ddot{x^{\prime}}=M \ddot{x}+M A,
$$

or

$$
M \ddot{x}=f-M A .
$$

Thus in the moving frame there is a fictitious force $F=-M A$ acting on the sphere through the center of mass, in addition to the friction $f$. Considering the torque about the center of mass, we have

$$
I \ddot{\theta}=f R
$$

with $I=\frac{2}{5} M R^{2}$. We also have the constraint for no slipping, $\dot{x}=-R \dot{\theta}$, or $\ddot{x}=-R \ddot{\theta}$. These three equations give $\ddot{x}=-\frac{5}{7} A$, which is the acceleration of the center of mass of the sphere relative to the truck.

1192.Problem Statement: Referring to Fig. 1.160, find the minimum height $h$ (above the top position in the loop) that will permit a spherical ball of radius $r$ (which rolls without slipping) to maintain constant contact with the rail of the loop. (The moment of inertia of a sphere about the center is $\frac{2}{5} m r^{2}$.)
1192.Solution:
Conservation of mechanical energy requires that the kinetic energy of the sphere at the top position in the loop is equal to the decrease $m g h$ in potential energy as it falls from the initial position to this position. The kinetic energy of the sphere is composed of two parts: the translational kinetic energy of the sphere and the rotational kinetic energy of the sphere 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-321.jpg?height=260&width=403&top_left_y=213&top_left_x=505)

Fig. $1.160$.

about its center of mass. Let $m, T, v, \omega$ be respectively the mass, kinetic energy, velocity of the center of mass, and angular velocity about the center of mass of the sphere. Then

$$
T=\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}+\frac{1}{2} I \omega^{2}
$$

with $I=\frac{2}{5} m r^{2}$. As the sphere rolls without slipping, $v=\omega r$ and

$$
T=\frac{1}{2}\left(m v^{2}+\frac{2}{5} m r^{2} \frac{v^{2}}{r^{2}}\right)=\frac{7}{10} m v^{2} .
$$

In the critical case, the force exerted by the loop on the sphere is zero when the latter reaches the top of the loop. In other words, the centripetal force needed for the circular motion of the sphere is supplied entirely by gravity:

$$
\frac{m v^{2}}{R}=m g,
$$

whence $v^{2}=R g$ and

$$
T=\frac{7}{10} m R g=m g h .
$$

Hence $h=7 R / 10$ is the minimum initial height required.

1193.d.Problem Statement:
A sphere of radius $b$ is at rest at $\theta=0$ upon a fixed sphere of radius $a>b$. The upper sphere is moved slightly to roll under the influence of gravity as shown in Fig. 1.161. The coefficient of static friction is $\mu_{s}>0$, the coefficient of sliding friction is $\mu=0$.

Find a related equation between $\dot{\theta}$ and $\theta$.
1193.d.Solution:
At first the upper sphere rolls without slipping, the angular velocity becoming larger and the normal pressure on it smaller with increasing $\theta$. When the condition for pure rolling is not satisfied, the sphere begins to slide and finally when the centripetal force is not large enough to maintain the circular motion of the upper sphere, it will separate from the lower sphere.

Suppose initially $O, A, O^{\prime}, B$ are on the same vertical line. As the upper sphere rolls by an angle $\varphi$, its center has traveled through a path $\overline{O O^{\prime}} \theta$, as shown in Fig. 1.161. Hence the condition for pure rolling is

$$
(a+b) \theta=b \varphi .
$$

The equations of motion of the upper sphere are

$$
\begin{aligned}
m(a+b) \ddot{\theta} &=m g \sin \theta-f, \\
I \ddot{\varphi} &=\frac{2}{5} m b^{2} \ddot{\varphi}=f b,
\end{aligned}
$$

where $f$ is the static friction on the sphere. When the sphere rolls without slipping, we have from (b)

$$
(a+b) \ddot{\theta}=b \ddot{\varphi} \text {. }
$$

Then the equations of motion give

$$
\ddot{\theta}=\frac{5 g \sin \theta}{7(a+b)} .
$$

As

$$
\ddot{\theta}=\frac{1}{2} \frac{d \dot{\theta}^{2}}{d \theta},
$$

the last equation gives

$$
\dot{\theta}^{2}=-\frac{10 g \cos \theta}{7(a+b)}+K .
$$

With $\dot{\theta}=0$ at $\theta=0, K=\frac{10 g}{7(a+b)}$. Hence

$$
\dot{\theta}^{2}=\frac{10 g(1-\cos \theta)}{7(a+b)}
$$

1194.a.Problem Statement:
A sphere of mass $m$, radius $a$, and moment of inertia $\frac{2}{5} m a^{2}$ rolls without slipping from its initial position at rest atop a fixed cylinder of radius $b$ (see Fig. 1.162).

Determine the angle $\theta_{\max }$ at which the sphere leaves the cylinder.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-324.jpg?height=299&width=382&top_left_y=1032&top_left_x=627)

Fig. $1.162$.
1194.a.Solution:
The forces on the sphere are as shown in Fig. 1.162. The equations of motion for the center of mass of the sphere are

$$
\begin{aligned}
m(a+b) \ddot{\theta} &=m g \sin \theta-f, \\
m(a+b) \dot{\theta}^{2} &=m g \cos \theta-N,
\end{aligned}
$$

and that for the rotation of the sphere is

$$
\frac{2}{5} m a^{2} \ddot{\varphi}=f a .
$$

The condition for it to roll without slipping is

$$
(a+b) \dot{\theta}=a \dot{\varphi}, \quad \text { or } \quad(a+b) \ddot{\theta}=a \ddot{\varphi} .
$$

From (3) and (4), we found

$$
f=\frac{2}{5} m(a+b) \ddot{\theta} .
$$

Substitution in (1) gives

$$
\ddot{\theta}=\frac{5 g \sin \theta}{7(a+b)} .
$$

As $\theta=\dot{\theta}=0$ at $t=0$ and $\ddot{\theta}=\frac{1}{2} \frac{d \dot{\theta}^{2}}{d \theta}$, it gives

$$
\dot{\theta}^{2}=\frac{10 g(1-\cos \theta)}{7(a+b)} .
$$

Substitution in (2) gives

$$
N=m g \cos \theta-\frac{10}{7} m g(1-\cos \theta)=m g\left(\frac{17 \cos \theta}{7}-\frac{10}{7}\right) \text {. }
$$

After the sphere leaves the cylinder, $N=0$. We assume that the coefficient of friction is large enough for the period of both rolling and slipping which occurs before the sphere leaves the cylinder to be negligible. Then at the instant $N$ becomes zero, $\theta=\theta_{\max }$ given by

$$
\cos \theta_{\max }=\frac{10}{17} \text {. }
$$

1195.a.Problem Statement:
In Fig. 1.163, the ball on the left rolls horizontally without slipping at speed $V$ toward an identical ball initially at rest. Each ball is a uniform sphere of mass $M$. Assuming that all the frictional forces are small enough to have a negligible effect during the instant of collision, and that the instantaneous collision is perfectly elastic, calculate:

The velocity of each ball a long enough time after the collision when each ball is again rolling without slipping.

The moment of inertia of a sphere of mass $M$, radius $R$ about its center is $\frac{2}{5} M R^{2}$.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-326.jpg?height=159&width=330&top_left_y=672&top_left_x=626)

Fig. 1,163.
1195.a.Solution:
Before the collision

$$
V_{1}=V, \quad V_{2}=0, \quad \omega_{1}=\frac{V}{R}, \quad \omega_{2}=0 .
$$

During the collision, as friction can be neglected, the forces with which the balls interact are directed through the centers so that the angular momentum about the center of each ball is conserved. Thus

$$
\omega_{1}^{\prime}=\omega_{1}, \quad \omega_{2}^{\prime}=0 .
$$

As the collision is elastic, conservation of translational momentum and that of kinetic energy then require

$$
V_{1}^{\prime}=0, \quad V_{2}^{\prime}=V_{1}=V .
$$

In the above, single primes denote quantities immediately after the collision. After some time, the balls again roll without slipping. Let the quantities at this time be denoted by double primes. The positive directions of these quantities are shown in Fig. 1.164.

The angular momentum of each ball about some fixed point in the plane of motion is conserved. Consider the angular momentum of each ball about the point of contact with the horizontal plane. For ball 1 ,

$$
M R V_{1}^{\prime}+I \omega_{1}^{\prime}=M R V_{1}^{\prime \prime}+I \omega_{1}^{\prime \prime} \text {, }
$$

or

$$
\frac{I V}{R}=\left(M R+\frac{I}{R}\right) V_{1}^{\prime \prime},
$$

giving

$$
V_{1}^{\prime \prime}=\frac{V}{\frac{M R^{2}}{I}+1}=\frac{2}{7} V .
$$

For ball 2 ,

$$
M R V_{2}^{\prime}+I \omega_{2}^{\prime}=M R V_{2}^{\prime \prime}+I \omega_{2}^{\prime \prime}
$$

or

$$
M R V=\left(M R+\frac{I}{R}\right) V_{2}^{\prime \prime},
$$

giving

$$
V_{2}^{\prime \prime}=\frac{V}{1+\frac{I}{M R^{2}}}=\frac{5}{7} V .
$$
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-327.jpg?height=594&width=288&top_left_y=1248&top_left_x=577)

Fig. 1.164.

1195.b.Problem Statement:
In Fig. 1.163, the ball on the left rolls horizontally without slipping at speed $V$ toward an identical ball initially at rest. Each ball is a uniform sphere of mass $M$. Assuming that all the frictional forces are small enough to have a negligible effect during the instant of collision, and that the instantaneous collision is perfectly elastic, calculate:

The fraction of the initial energy transformed by the frictional forces to thermal energy.

The moment of inertia of a sphere of mass $M$, radius $R$ about its center is $\frac{2}{5} M R^{2}$.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-326.jpg?height=159&width=330&top_left_y=672&top_left_x=626)

Fig. 1,163.
1195.b.Solution:
Before the collision

$$
V_{1}=V, \quad V_{2}=0, \quad \omega_{1}=\frac{V}{R}, \quad \omega_{2}=0 .
$$

During the collision, as friction can be neglected, the forces with which the balls interact are directed through the centers so that the angular momentum about the center of each ball is conserved. Thus

$$
\omega_{1}^{\prime}=\omega_{1}, \quad \omega_{2}^{\prime}=0 .
$$

As the collision is elastic, conservation of translational momentum and that of kinetic energy then require

$$
V_{1}^{\prime}=0, \quad V_{2}^{\prime}=V_{1}=V .
$$

In the above, single primes denote quantities immediately after the collision. After some time, the balls again roll without slipping. Let the quantities at this time be denoted by double primes. The positive directions of these quantities are shown in Fig. 1.164.

The angular momentum of each ball about some fixed point in the plane of motion is conserved. Consider the angular momentum of each ball about the point of contact with the horizontal plane. For ball 1 ,

$$
M R V_{1}^{\prime}+I \omega_{1}^{\prime}=M R V_{1}^{\prime \prime}+I \omega_{1}^{\prime \prime} \text {, }
$$

or

$$
\frac{I V}{R}=\left(M R+\frac{I}{R}\right) V_{1}^{\prime \prime},
$$

giving

$$
V_{1}^{\prime \prime}=\frac{V}{\frac{M R^{2}}{I}+1}=\frac{2}{7} V .
$$

For ball 2 ,

$$
M R V_{2}^{\prime}+I \omega_{2}^{\prime}=M R V_{2}^{\prime \prime}+I \omega_{2}^{\prime \prime}
$$

or

$$
M R V=\left(M R+\frac{I}{R}\right) V_{2}^{\prime \prime},
$$

giving

$$
V_{2}^{\prime \prime}=\frac{V}{1+\frac{I}{M R^{2}}}=\frac{5}{7} V .
$$
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-327.jpg?height=594&width=288&top_left_y=1248&top_left_x=577)

Fig. 1.164.The initial and final energies of the system are

$$
\begin{aligned}
W_{i} &=\frac{1}{2} M V_{1}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} I \omega_{1}^{2}=\frac{1}{2}\left(M V^{2}+\frac{2}{5} M R^{2} \cdot \frac{V^{2}}{R^{2}}\right) \\
&=\frac{1}{2} M V^{2} \cdot \frac{7}{5}, \\
W_{f} &=\frac{1}{2} M\left(V_{1}^{\prime \prime 2}+V_{2}^{\prime \prime 2}\right)+\frac{1}{2} I\left(\omega_{1}^{\prime \prime 2}+\omega_{2}^{\prime \prime 2}\right) \\
&=\frac{1}{2} M\left[V_{1}^{\prime \prime 2}+V_{2}^{\prime \prime 2}+\frac{2}{5}\left(V_{1}^{\prime \prime 2}+V_{2}^{\prime \prime 2}\right)\right] \\
&=\frac{1}{2} M V^{2} \cdot \frac{7}{5} \cdot \frac{29}{49} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the loss of energy is

$$
W_{i}-W_{f}=\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{7}{5} M V^{2} \cdot \frac{20}{49},
$$

and the fractional loss is $\frac{20}{49}$.

1196.a.Problem Statement:
A small homogeneous sphere of mass $m$ and radius $r$ rolls without sliding on the outer surface of a larger stationary sphere of radius $R$ as shown in Fig. 1.165. Let $\theta$ be the polar angle of the small sphere with respect to a coordinate system with origin at the center of the large sphere and $z$-axis vertical. The smaller sphere starts from rest at the top of the larger sphere $(\theta=0)$

Calculate the velocity of the center of the small sphere as a function of $\theta$
1196.a.Solution:
As the sum of the kinetic and potential energies of the small sphere is a constant of the motion when it rolls without sliding, we have 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-329.jpg?height=314&width=271&top_left_y=221&top_left_x=604)

Fig. 1.165.

$$
\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}+\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{2}{5} m r^{2} \cdot \dot{\varphi}^{2}+m g(R+r) \cos \theta=m g(R+r)
$$

with $v=r \dot{\varphi}=(R+r) \dot{\theta}$, whence

$$
\dot{\theta}=\sqrt{\frac{10}{7} \frac{(1-\cos \theta) g}{(R+r)}} .
$$

The velocity of the center of the small sphere is

$$
v=(R+r) \dot{\theta}=\sqrt{\frac{10}{7}(R+r)(1-\cos \theta) g} .
$$

1196.b.Problem Statement:
A small homogeneous sphere of mass $m$ and radius $r$ rolls without sliding on the outer surface of a larger stationary sphere of radius $R$ as shown in Fig. 1.165. Let $\theta$ be the polar angle of the small sphere with respect to a coordinate system with origin at the center of the large sphere and $z$-axis vertical. The smaller sphere starts from rest at the top of the larger sphere $(\theta=0)$

Calculate the angle at which the small sphere flies off the large one.
1196.b.Solution:
As the sum of the kinetic and potential energies of the small sphere is a constant of the motion when it rolls without sliding, we have 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-329.jpg?height=314&width=271&top_left_y=221&top_left_x=604)

Fig. 1.165.

$$
\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}+\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{2}{5} m r^{2} \cdot \dot{\varphi}^{2}+m g(R+r) \cos \theta=m g(R+r)
$$

with $v=r \dot{\varphi}=(R+r) \dot{\theta}$, whence

$$
\dot{\theta}=\sqrt{\frac{10}{7} \frac{(1-\cos \theta) g}{(R+r)}} .
$$

The velocity of the center of the small sphere is

$$
v=(R+r) \dot{\theta}=\sqrt{\frac{10}{7}(R+r)(1-\cos \theta) g} .
$$At the moment of flying off, the support force on the small sphere $N=0$. From the force equation

$$
m g \cos \theta-N=\frac{m v^{2}}{R+r},
$$

we find the angle $\theta_{c}$ at which the small sphere flies off the large sphere as given by

$$
\cos \theta_{c}=\frac{10}{17} .
$$

Thus

$$
\theta_{c}=\arccos \left(\frac{10}{17}\right) .
$$

Note that this derivation applies only for sufficiently large coefficient of friction.

1198.a.Problem Statement:
A uniform plank of length $2 a$ is held temporarily so that one end leans against a frictionless vertical wall and the other end rests on a frictionless floor making an angle $\theta=\theta_{0}$ with the floor. When the plank is released, it will slide down under the influence of gravity.

Find the expression (as an integral if you like) for the time that it will take for the plank to reach a new angle $\theta$.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-333.jpg?height=285&width=403&top_left_y=1264&top_left_x=538)

Fig. 1.167.
1198.a.Solution:
As no friction is involved mechanical energy is conserved, which gives

$$
\frac{1}{2} m a^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{1}{3} m a^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+m g a \sin \theta=m g a \sin \theta_{0},
$$

i.e.

$$
\frac{2}{3} a \dot{\theta}^{2}=g\left(\sin \theta_{0}-\sin \theta\right)
$$

or

$$
\dot{\theta}=-\sqrt{\frac{3 g}{2 a}\left(\sin \theta_{0}-\sin \theta\right)} .
$$

Note that the factor $\frac{1}{3} m a^{2}$ is the moment of inertia of the plank about a horizontal axis through its center of mass, and that the negative sign is to be used for $\dot{\theta}$ as $\theta$ decreases as $t$ increases.

Thus

$$
t=\int_{0}^{t} d t=-\int_{\theta_{0}}^{\theta} \frac{d \theta}{\sqrt{\frac{3 g}{2 a}\left(\sin \theta_{0}-\sin \theta\right)}} .
$$

1199.Problem Statement:
A thin uniform stick of mass $m$ with its bottom end resting on a frictionless table is released from rest at an angle $\theta_{0}$ to the vertical (Fig. 1.168). Find the force exerted by the table upon the stick at an infinitesimally small time after its release.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-335.jpg?height=292&width=283&top_left_y=562&top_left_x=579)

Fig. $1.168$.
1199.Solution:
As there is no friction, the forces acting on the stick are the normal support $N$ and the gravity $m g$ as shown in Fig. 1.168. Within an infinitesimal time of the release of the stick, the equations of motion are

$$
\begin{aligned}
N-m g &=m \ddot{y}, \\
\frac{1}{2} N L \sin \theta_{0} &=\frac{1}{12} m L^{2} \ddot{\theta}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $y$ is the vertical coordinate of the center of mass and $\frac{1}{12} m L^{2}$ is the moment of inertia about a horizontal axis through the center of mass of the stick. As

$$
\begin{aligned}
&y=\frac{1}{2} L \cos \theta, \\
&\ddot{y}=-\frac{1}{2} L\left(\dot{\theta}^{2} \cos \theta+\ddot{\theta} \sin \theta\right)=-\frac{1}{2} L \ddot{\theta} \sin \theta_{0},
\end{aligned}
$$

as initially

$$
\dot{\theta}=0, \quad \theta=\theta_{0} .
$$

Hence 

$$
\begin{aligned}
N &=m g+m \ddot{y} \\
&=m g-\frac{1}{2} m L \ddot{\theta} \sin \theta_{0} \\
&=m g-3 N \sin ^{2} \theta_{0},
\end{aligned}
$$

or

$$
N=\frac{m g}{1+3 \sin ^{2} \theta_{0}} .
$$

1200.Problem Statement:
Two long uniform rods $A$ and $B$ each $1 \mathrm{~m}$ long and of masses $1 \mathrm{~kg}(A)$ and $2 \mathrm{~kg}(B)$ lie parallel to each other on a frictionless horizontal plane $(x, y) . \operatorname{Rod} B$ is initially at rest at $y=0, x=0$ to $x=1 \mathrm{~m}$. Rod $A$ is moving at $10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$ in the positive $y$ direction, and it extends from $x=(-1+\epsilon) \mathrm{m}$ to $x=\epsilon \mathrm{m},(\epsilon \ll 1 \mathrm{~m})$ as shown in Fig. 1.169. $\operatorname{Rod} A$ reaches $y=0$ at $t=0$ and collides elastically with $B$. Find the subsequent motion of the rods, ignoring the possibility of subsequent collisions. Check for equality of energy before and after collision.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-336.jpg?height=234&width=337&top_left_y=1345&top_left_x=341)

Fig. 1.169.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-336.jpg?height=300&width=424&top_left_y=1283&top_left_x=902)

Fig. 1.170.
1200.Solution:
Let I be the impulse $\operatorname{rod} A$ exerts on rod $B$ during the collision. Its direction is the direction of the motion of $A$, i.e. the positive $y$ direction. Let $v_{A}, \omega_{A}, v_{B}, \omega_{B}$, be the velocity of the center of mass and the angular velocity about the center of mass of $A$ and $B$ respectively, as shown in Fig. 1.170. Denoting the masses of $A, B$ by $m_{A}, m_{B}$ respectively, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
-I &=m_{A}\left(v_{A}-10\right) \\
\frac{1}{2} I &=\frac{1}{12} m_{A} \omega_{A} \\
I &=m_{B} v_{B} \\
\frac{1}{2} I &=\frac{1}{12} m_{B} \omega_{B}
\end{aligned}
$$

The condition of elastic collision means that the relative velocity of the points of collision remains the same in magnitude but reverses in direction:

$$
\left(v_{B}+\frac{1}{2} \omega_{B}\right)-\left(v_{A}-\frac{1}{2} \omega_{A}\right)=10 .
$$

The above equations give

$$
\begin{aligned}
I &=\frac{5 m_{A} m_{B}}{m_{A}+m_{B}}=\frac{10}{3} \mathrm{Ns} \\
v_{A} &=10-\frac{I}{m_{A}}=\frac{20}{3} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \\
\omega_{A} &=\frac{6 I}{m_{A}}=20 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s} \\
v_{B} &=\frac{I}{m_{B}}=\frac{5}{3} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \\
\omega_{B} &=\frac{6 I}{m_{B}}=10 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s}
\end{aligned}
$$

for the subsequent motion. The energy of the two rods before collision is

$$
E_{i}=\frac{1}{2} \cdot 1 \cdot 10^{2}=50 \mathrm{~J}
$$

and after collision is

$$
\begin{aligned}
E_{f} &=\frac{1}{2} m_{A} v_{A}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m_{B} v_{B}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{1}{12} m_{A} \omega_{A}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{1}{12} m_{B} \omega_{B}^{2} \\
&=\frac{225}{9}+\frac{300}{12}=50 \mathrm{~J}=E_{i}
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the equality of energy holds.

1201.Problem Statement:
A billiard ball of radius $R$ and mass $M$ is struck with a horizontal cue stick at a height $h$ above the billiard table as shown in Fig. 1.171. Given that the moment of inertia of a sphere is $\frac{2}{5} M R^{2}$, find the value of $h$ for which the ball will roll without slipping.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-338.jpg?height=176&width=371&top_left_y=567&top_left_x=594)

Fig. 1.171.
1201.Solution:
Suppose that $f$ is the impact force on the ball exerted by the stick and that it acts for a time $\Delta t$ causing a change of momentum of the ball of $M \Delta v$ and a change of its angular momentum about the center of mass of $I \Delta \omega$. We have the equations of motion

$$
\begin{aligned}
M \Delta v &=f \Delta t, \\
I \Delta \omega &=f(h-R) \Delta t
\end{aligned}
$$

with $I=\frac{2}{5} M R^{2}$, which yield

$$
\Delta v=\frac{2 R^{2} \Delta \omega}{5(h-R)} .
$$

As the ball is at rest initially, the velocity of its center of mass and the angular velocity after impact satisfy

$$
v=\frac{2 R^{2} \omega}{5(h-R)} .
$$

The ball will roll without slipping if $v=R \omega$. Hence we require

$$
5(h-R)=2 R,
$$

or

$$
h=\frac{7}{5} R .
$$

1202.Problem Statement:
A uniform solid ball of radius $a$ rolling with velocity $v$ on a level surface collides inelastically with a step of height $h<a$, as shown in Fig. 1.172. Find, in terms of $h$ and $a$, the minimum velocity for which the ball will "trip" up over the step. Assume that no slipping occurs at the impact point, and remember that the moment of inertia of a solid sphere with respect to an axis through its center is $\frac{2}{5} M a^{2}$.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-339.jpg?height=205&width=369&top_left_y=653&top_left_x=561)

Fig. 1.172.
1202.Solution:
Let $\omega$ and $\omega^{\prime}, J$ and $J^{\prime}$ be the angular velocity of the ball with respect to its center of mass and its angular momentum about the point of impact $A$ before and after collision with the step, respectively. We have

$$
J=m v(a-h)+\frac{2}{5} m a^{2} \omega=\frac{7}{5} m v a-m v h
$$

as $v=a \omega$ for rolling without slipping, and

$$
J^{\prime}=\left(\frac{2}{5} m a^{2}+m a^{2}\right) \omega^{\prime}=\frac{7}{5} m a^{2} \omega^{\prime}
$$

as the center of mass of the ball is momentarily at rest after the collision. Conservation of angular momentum requires

$$
\frac{7}{5} m a^{2} \omega^{\prime}=\frac{7}{5} m v a-m v h,
$$

yielding

$$
\omega^{\prime}=\left(1-\frac{5 h}{7 a}\right) \frac{v}{a} .
$$

In order that the ball can just trip up over the step, its kinetic energy must be sufficient to provide for the increase in potential energy:

$$
\frac{1}{2} I^{\prime} \omega^{\prime 2}=m g h,
$$

where $I^{\prime}=\frac{2}{5} m a^{2}+m a^{2}=\frac{7}{5} m a^{2}$ is the moment of inertia of the ball about a horizontal axis through $A$. Hence the minimum velocity required is given by

$$
\frac{7}{10} m a^{2}\left(1-\frac{5 h}{7 a}\right)^{2}\left(\frac{v}{a}\right)^{2}=m g h,
$$

yielding

$$
v=\frac{a \sqrt{70 g h}}{7 a-5 h} .
$$

1205.Problem Statement:
A stepladder consists of two legs held together by a hinge at the top and a horizontal rope near the bottom, and it rests on a horizontal surface at $60^{\circ}$ as shown in Fig. $1.175$. If the rope is suddenly cut, what is the acceleration of the hinge at that instant? Assume the legs to be uniform, identical to each other, and neglect all friction.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-344.jpg?height=184&width=273&top_left_y=1166&top_left_x=293)

Fig. 1.175.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-344.jpg?height=318&width=368&top_left_y=1041&top_left_x=923)

Fig. 1.176.
1205.Solution:
Consider the instant when the horizontal rope is suddenly cut.

By symmetry the forces which the two legs exert on each other at the hinge $A$ are horizontal and the acceleration of $A, \mathbf{a}_{A}$, is vertically downward.

Consider one leg of the stepladder. The forces acting on it are as shown in Fig. 1.176. Let $l$ be the length of the leg and $\mathbf{a}_{C}$ the acceleration of its center of mass $C$ at the instant the rope is cut. We have 

$$
\begin{gathered}
m g-N=m a_{C y}, \\
F=m a_{C x}, \\
\frac{1}{2} N l \cos 60^{\circ}-\frac{1}{2} F l \sin 60^{\circ}=I \ddot{\theta}
\end{gathered}
$$

with $I=\frac{1}{12} m l^{2}$, or

$$
N-\sqrt{3} F=\frac{1}{3} m l \ddot{\theta} .
$$

The velocity of $A$ in terms of the velocity of $C$ are given by

$$
\dot{x}_{A}=\dot{x}_{C}-\frac{1}{2} l \dot{\theta} \sin 60^{\circ}, \quad \dot{y}_{A}=\dot{y}_{C}+\frac{1}{2} l \dot{\theta} \cos 60^{\circ} .
$$

Hence $\mathbf{a}_{\boldsymbol{A}}$, which is in the $y$ direction, has components

$$
\begin{aligned}
0 &=a_{C x}-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} l \ddot{\theta}, \\
a_{A} &=a_{C y}+\frac{1}{4} l \ddot{\theta} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Consider now the acceleration $\mathbf{a}_{B}$ of point $B$. At the instant the rope is cut it has only a horizontal component. Thus $a_{B_{y}}=0$, i.e.

$$
a_{C y}-\frac{1}{2} l \ddot{\theta} \cos 60^{\circ}=a_{C y}-\frac{1}{4} l \ddot{\theta}=0 .
$$

The above consideration gives

$$
a_{C x}=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} l \ddot{\theta}, \quad a_{C y}=\frac{1}{4} l \ddot{\theta} .
$$

Using these in the equations of motion for $C$ we find

$$
\ddot{\theta}=\frac{3 g}{4 l},
$$

which gives the acceleration of the hinge as

$$
a_{A}=\frac{1}{2} l \ddot{\theta}=\frac{3}{8} g,
$$

directed vertically downward.

1206.Problem Statement:
A particle of mass $m$ and speed $v$ collides elastically with the end of a uniform thin rod of mass $M$ as shown in Fig. 1.177. After the collision, $m$ is stationary. Calculate $M$.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-346.jpg?height=213&width=134&top_left_y=498&top_left_x=695)

Fig. 1.177.
1206.Solution:
Let $v_{c}$ be the velocity of the center of mass of the rod and $\omega$ the angular velocity of the rod about the center of mass. Conservation of momentum and that of energy of this system give

$$
\begin{aligned}
m v &=M v_{c}, \\
\frac{1}{2} m v^{2} &=\frac{1}{2} M v_{c}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} I \omega^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

with $I=\frac{1}{12} M l^{2}, l$ being the length of the rod. Conservation of the angular momentum of the system about a fixed point located at the center of the rod before collision gives

$$
\frac{1}{2} l m v=I \omega .
$$

The above equations give

$$
M=4 m .
$$

1211.Problem Statement:
A rigid square massless frame contains 4 disks rotating as shown in Fig. 1.183. Each disk has mass $m$, moment of inertia $I_{0}$, and rotational velocity $\omega_{0}$. The frame is horizontal and pivots freely about a support at one corner. What is the precession rate?

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-353.jpg?height=295&width=486&top_left_y=1534&top_left_x=162)

Fig. 1.183.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-353.jpg?height=297&width=398&top_left_y=1541&top_left_x=807)

Fig. 1.184.
1211.Solution:
The angular momentum of each disk about its axis of rotation is $I_{0} \omega_{0}$ with directions as shown in Fig. 1.184. The total angular momentum of the system about the pivot has magnitude $L=2 \sqrt{2} I_{0} \omega_{0}$ and a direction along $\overline{\mathbf{O C}}, C$ being the center of mass of the system. Note that $\mathbf{L}$ is horizontal as the frame is horizontal. The torque due to gravity is

$$
\mathbf{M}=\overline{\mathbf{O C}} \times 4 m g=\frac{D}{\sqrt{2}} \frac{\mathbf{L}}{L} \times 4 m \mathbf{g} .
$$

Hence

$$
\frac{d \mathbf{L}}{d t}=\mathbf{M}=-\frac{2 \sqrt{2} D m}{L} \mathbf{g} \times \mathbf{L}=\Omega \times \mathbf{L},
$$

where

$$
\boldsymbol{\Omega}=-\frac{2 \sqrt{2} D m \mathbf{g}}{2 \sqrt{2} I_{0} \omega_{0}}=-\frac{D m}{I_{0} \omega_{0}} \mathbf{g}
$$

is the precessional angular velocity. Hence the precession has a rate $\frac{D m g}{I_{0} \omega_{0}}$ and is anticlockwise when seen from above.

1215.Problem Statement:
A gyroscope at latitude $45^{\circ} \mathrm{N}$ is mounted on bearings in such a way that the axis of spin is constrained to be horizontal but otherwise no torques occur in the bearings. Taking into account the rotation of the earth, show that an orientation with the axis of spin along the local north-south is stable and find the period for small oscillations of the spin axis about this direction. Assume that the rotor can be approximated by a thin circular ring (i.e. the spokes and other parts are of negligible mass). (In working out this problem it is simpler when writing the angular velocity of the rotor 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-361.jpg?height=448&width=337&top_left_y=222&top_left_x=538)

Fig. 1.188.

about the $x$-axis (Fig. 1.188) to lump together the spin term and the term due to rotation of the earth).
1215.Solution:
Use an inertial frame $O x^{\prime} y^{\prime} z^{\prime}$ fixed with respect to a distant star which, at the instant under consideration, has the origin $O$ at the center of mass of the rotor, the $z^{\prime}$-axis pointing vertically up and the $x^{\prime}$-axis pointing north, and a rotating frame Oxyz attached to the earth with the same $z$-axis but with the $x$-axis at that instant along the spin axis of the rotor as shown in Fig. 1.188. Denote the spin angular velocity by $\omega$, and the moments of inertia about the $x$-, $y$-, $z$-axes, which are the principal axes of the gyroscope, by $C, A, A$ respectively. The angular momentum then has components

$$
(C \omega, 0, A \dot{\theta})
$$

in the rotating frame, and

$$
(C \omega \cos \theta, C \omega \sin \theta, A \dot{\theta})
$$

in the fixed frame. Note that the $z$ component which is the same in both frames is contributed by the precession. In the fixed frame, the earth's rotational angular velocity at latitude $\lambda=45^{\circ} \mathrm{N}$ has components

$$
\Omega\left(\cos 45^{\circ}, 0, \sin 45^{\circ}\right)=\frac{\Omega}{\sqrt{2}}(1,0,1) .
$$

Also, the only torques are those that constrain the spin axis to the horizontal so that

$$
M_{z^{\prime}}=0 .
$$

As

$$
\mathbf{M}=\left(\frac{d \mathbf{L}}{d t}\right)_{\mathrm{fix}}=\left(\frac{d \mathbf{L}}{d t}\right)_{\text {rot }}+\Omega \times \mathbf{L}=0,
$$

its $z$ component is

$$
A \ddot{\theta}+\frac{C \omega \Omega \sin \theta}{\sqrt{2}}=0,
$$

or

$$
A \ddot{\theta}+\frac{C \omega \Omega}{\sqrt{2}} \theta=0
$$

for small $\theta$. Note that for $\Omega \times \mathrm{L}$ we have resolved the vectors in the fixed frame. The last equation shows that the spin axis oscillates harmonically about the local north-south direction with angular frequency

$$
\omega^{\prime}=\sqrt{\frac{C \omega \Omega}{\sqrt{2} A}}
$$

and the orientation is stable. The period is

$$
T=\frac{2 \pi}{\omega}=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{\sqrt{2} A}{C \omega \Omega}} .
$$

If the rotor is approximated by a thin circular ring of mass $M$ and radius $R$, we have

$$
C=M R^{2}, \quad A=\frac{M R^{2}}{2}, \quad T=\frac{2 \pi}{\sqrt{\sqrt{2} \omega \Omega}} .
$$

1217.b.Problem Statement:
A simple symmetrical top consists of a disk of mass $M$ and radius $r$ mounted on the center $C$ of the massless cylindrical rod of length $l$ and radius $a$ as shown in Fig. 1.192. The top is rotated with large angular velocity $\omega(t)$ and is placed at an angle $\theta$ to the vertical on a horizontal surface with a small coefficient of friction. Neglect nutation and assume that the rate of slowing of $\omega(t)$ is small in one period of procession.

Compute the angular frequency of the (slow) precession.
1217.b.Solution:
The motion of the top consists mainly of three components:

(1) spinning with angular velocity $\omega$ about its axis of symmetry,

(2) a slow procession $\Omega$ about the vertical axis due to gravity,

(3) motion of the axis of symmetry to come to the vertical gradually due to the effect of the frictional torque.

Use two coordinate frames with origin $O$ as shown in Fig. 1.192: a fixed frame Oxyz with the $z$-axis along the upward vertical, and a rotating frame $O x^{\prime} y^{\prime} z^{\prime}$ with the $z^{\prime}$-axis along the axis of symmetry in the same direction as the spin angular velocity $\omega$, both the $x$ - and $x^{\prime}$-axes being taken in the plane of the $z$ - and $z^{\prime}$-axes at the instant under consideration. We have

$$
\left(\frac{d \mathbf{L}}{d t}\right)_{\mathrm{fix}}=\left(\frac{d \mathbf{L}}{d t}\right)_{\mathrm{rot}}+\mathbf{\Omega} \times \mathbf{L} .
$$

Under the condition that the spin angular velocity $\omega$ is very large, the total angular momentum can be taken to be approximately

$$
\mathbf{L}=I_{3} \omega \mathbf{k}^{\prime} .
$$

Further, as $\omega$ does not change appreciably in a period of precession, $\left(\frac{d \mathbf{L}}{d t}\right)_{\text {rot }} \approx 0$. We then have 

$$
\left(\frac{d \mathbf{L}}{d t}\right)_{\mathrm{fix}}=\mathbf{\Omega} \times \mathbf{L}=\mathbf{r}_{C} \times M \mathbf{g}
$$

with

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\boldsymbol{\Omega}=\Omega(-\sin \theta, 0, \cos \theta), \\
&\mathbf{L}=\left(0,0, I_{3} \omega\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

in the rotating frame, and

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{r}_{C} &=\left(0,0, \frac{l}{2}\right), \\
\mathbf{g} &=g(\sin \theta, 0, \cos \theta) .
\end{aligned}
$$

In the fixed frame, the above gives

$$
I_{3} \omega \Omega \sin \theta=\frac{1}{2} M l g \sin \theta,
$$

i.e.

$$
\Omega=\frac{M l g}{2 I_{3} \omega}=\frac{l g}{r^{2} \omega},
$$

as

$$
I_{3}=\frac{1}{2} M r^{2} .
$$

1222.a.Problem Statement:
A horizontal bar of mass $m$ and length $2 a$ hangs by 2 parallel strings of length $2 a$ attached to its two ends. The rod is suddenly given an angular velocity $\omega$ about a vertical axis through its center. Calculate

the distance $h$ to which the bar rises,
1222.a.Solution:
Use a fixed coordinate frame as shown in Fig. $1.199$ with origin at the center of the bar, the $z$-axis vertically upward and the $x$-axis along the initial direction of the bar. 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-375.jpg?height=227&width=221&top_left_y=215&top_left_x=641)

Fig, 1.199.

Take the $x y$-plane as the reference level for potential energy. The total mechanical energy of the bar at $t=0$ at which instant it is given an angular velocity $\omega$ is

$$
E=\frac{1}{2} I \omega^{2}=\frac{m a^{2} \omega^{2}}{6}
$$

as $I=\frac{1}{3} m a^{2}$. When the bar is at its highest position $h$, it has only a potential energy $m g h$. Conservation of mechanical energy then gives

$$
m g h=\frac{1}{6} m a^{2} \omega^{2},
$$

or

$$
h=\frac{a^{2} \omega^{2}}{6 g} .
$$

1222.b.Problem Statement:
A horizontal bar of mass $m$ and length $2 a$ hangs by 2 parallel strings of length $2 a$ attached to its two ends. The rod is suddenly given an angular velocity $\omega$ about a vertical axis through its center. Calculate

the initial increase in tension in each string.
1222.b.Solution:
Use a fixed coordinate frame as shown in Fig. $1.199$ with origin at the center of the bar, the $z$-axis vertically upward and the $x$-axis along the initial direction of the bar. 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-375.jpg?height=227&width=221&top_left_y=215&top_left_x=641)

Fig, 1.199.

Take the $x y$-plane as the reference level for potential energy. The total mechanical energy of the bar at $t=0$ at which instant it is given an angular velocity $\omega$ is

$$
E=\frac{1}{2} I \omega^{2}=\frac{m a^{2} \omega^{2}}{6}
$$

as $I=\frac{1}{3} m a^{2}$. When the bar is at its highest position $h$, it has only a potential energy $m g h$. Conservation of mechanical energy then gives

$$
m g h=\frac{1}{6} m a^{2} \omega^{2},
$$

or

$$
h=\frac{a^{2} \omega^{2}}{6 g} .
$$Due to symmetry, the bar is always horizontal during the motion while it rotates about the $z$-axis. Let the height of the bar be $z$ and the angle it makes with the $x$-axis be $\theta$ at time $t$. Assume the strings to be unstretchable then the distance between a point of support $A^{\prime}$ and the corresponding end of the bar $A$ is constant. The coordinates of $A$ and $A^{\prime}$ are respectively $(a \cos \theta, a \sin \theta, z)$ and $(a, 0,2 a)$. Thus

$$
a^{2}(1-\cos \theta)^{2}+a^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta+(2 a-z)^{2}=4 a^{2},
$$

i.e.

$$
z^{2}-4 a z+2 a^{2}(1-\cos \theta)=0 .
$$

Differentiating twice with respect to time we obtain

$$
\dot{z}^{2}+z \ddot{z}-2 a \ddot{z}+a^{2} \ddot{\theta} \sin \theta+a^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2} \cos \theta=0,
$$

or

$$
\ddot{z}=\frac{1}{2 a-z}\left[\dot{z}^{2}+a^{2} \ddot{\theta} \sin \theta+a^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2} \cos \theta\right] .
$$

At $t=0, \theta=0, z=0, \dot{z}=0, \dot{\theta}=\omega$, we have $\ddot{z}=\frac{1}{2} a \omega^{2}$. Thus the vertical force on the bar is increased by $m \ddot{z}=\frac{1}{2} m a \omega^{2}$. As this is shared equally by the two supporting strings the initial increase in the tension of each string is

$$
\Delta T=\frac{1}{2} m \ddot{z}=\frac{1}{4} m a \omega^{2} .
$$

1224.Problem Statement: A string is stretched between two rigid supports $100 \mathrm{~cm}$ apart. In the frequency range between 100 and $350 \mathrm{cps}$ only the following frequencies can be excited: $160,240,320 \mathrm{cps}$. What is the wavelength of each of these modes of vibration?
1224.Solution:
As the two ends of the string are fixed, we have $n \lambda=2 L$, where $L$ is the length of the string and $n$ an integer. Let the wavelengths corresponding to frequencies $160,240,320 \mathrm{~Hz}$ be $\lambda_{0}, \lambda_{1}, \lambda_{2}$ respectively. Then

$$
\begin{gathered}
n \lambda_{0}=(n+1) \lambda_{1}=(n+2) \lambda_{2}=200 \\
160 \lambda_{0}=240 \lambda_{1}=320 \lambda_{2} .
\end{gathered}
$$

Hence $n=2$, and

$$
\lambda_{0}=100 \mathrm{~cm}, \quad \lambda_{1}=67 \mathrm{~cm}, \quad \lambda_{2}=50 \mathrm{~cm} .
$$

1226.a.Problem Statement:
A violin string on a violin is of length $L$ and can be considered to be fastened at both ends. The fundamental of the open string has a frequency $f_{0}$. The violinist bows the string at a distance $L / 4$ from one end and touches the string lightly at the midpoint.

Under these conditions, what is the lowest frequency he can excite? Sketch the shape of the string.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-382.jpg?height=91&width=374&top_left_y=529&top_left_x=606)

Fig. 1.204.
1226.a.Solution: For the open string, the wavelength $\lambda_{0}$ corresponding to the fundamental frequency $f_{0}$ is given by $\lambda_{0} / 2=L$. When the violinist bows at $L / 4$ from one end and touches the string at $L / 2$, the former point is a node and the latter point an antinode so that $\lambda_{0}=L$. Hence the string has the shape shown in Fig. $1.204$ and, as $f_{0} \propto 1 / \lambda_{0}$, the fundamental frequency is $2 f_{0}$.

1226.b.Problem Statement:
A violin string on a violin is of length $L$ and can be considered to be fastened at both ends. The fundamental of the open string has a frequency $f_{0}$. The violinist bows the string at a distance $L / 4$ from one end and touches the string lightly at the midpoint.

What is the frequency of the first overtone under these conditions? (Wisconsin)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-382.jpg?height=91&width=374&top_left_y=529&top_left_x=606)

Fig. 1.204.
1226.b.Solution: For the open string, the wavelength $\lambda_{0}$ corresponding to the fundamental frequency $f_{0}$ is given by $\lambda_{0} / 2=L$. When the violinist bows at $L / 4$ from one end and touches the string at $L / 2$, the former point is a node and the latter point an antinode so that $\lambda_{0}=L$. Hence the string has the shape shown in Fig. $1.204$ and, as $f_{0} \propto 1 / \lambda_{0}$, the fundamental frequency is $2 f_{0}$.The frequency of the first overtone is $4 f_{0}$.

1227.Problem Statement:
A guitar string is $80 \mathrm{~cm}$ long and has a fundamental frequency of $400 \mathrm{~Hz}$. In its fundamental mode the maximum displacement is $2 \mathrm{~cm}$ at the middle. If the tension in the string is $10^{6}$ dynes, what is the maximum of that component of the force on the end support which is perpendicular to the equilibrium position of the string?

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-382.jpg?height=233&width=479&top_left_y=1606&top_left_x=576)

Fig, 1,205.
1227.Solution:
Use Cartesian coordinates with the $x$-axis along the equilibrium position of the string and the origin at one of its fixed ends. Then the two fixed ends are at $x=0$ and $x=l=80 \mathrm{~cm}$, as shown in Fig. 1.205. At $x=0$, the $y$-component of the force on the support is

$$
F_{y}=T \sin \theta \simeq T \theta \simeq T \frac{\partial y}{\partial x},
$$

where $T$ is the tension in the string. The guitar string has a sinusoidal form

$$
y=y_{0} \sin \left[\omega\left(t-\frac{x}{v}\right)\right]
$$

with $\omega=\frac{2 \pi v}{\lambda}=\frac{2 \pi v}{2 l}=\frac{\pi v}{80}, y_{0}=2 \mathrm{~cm}$. Thus

$$
y=2 \sin \left(\omega t-\frac{\pi x}{80}\right) \mathrm{cm} \text {. }
$$

Hence at $x=0$,

$$
F_{y}=-\frac{2 \pi T}{80} \cos (\omega t)
$$

and

$$
F_{y \max }=\frac{\pi T}{40}=7.85 \times 10^{4} \text { dynes } .
$$

1231.b.Problem Statement:
A spring of rest length $X$ and force constant $k$ has a mass $m$. One end is fixed and the other end is attached to a mass $M$. The orientation is horizontal, and $M$ moves on a frictionless surface.

Find the frequency of the lowest mode as a function of mass for the case where $M$ and $k$ are finite and $m \ll M$.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-389.jpg?height=141&width=519&top_left_y=662&top_left_x=461)

Fig. 1.209.
1231.b.Solution:
Take the $x$-axis along the length of the spring with origin at the fixed end and consider a section of length $\Delta x$ extending from $x$ to $x+\Delta x$ as shown in Fig. 1.209. Then as $M$ moves to the right, the point $x$ moves to $x+\xi$ and the point $x+\Delta x$ moves to $x+\Delta x+\xi+\Delta \xi$ as shown in Fig. 1.210.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-389.jpg?height=114&width=650&top_left_y=1367&top_left_x=478)

Fig. 1.210.

Let $\sigma$ be the Young's modulus of the spring. The restoring force $F$ is given by $F=a \sigma \Delta l / l$, where $a$ is the area of the cross section of the spring and $\Delta l / l$ is the extension per unit length. Write $K_{0}$ for $a \sigma$. The net force on the section under consideration is

$$
F_{x+\Delta x}-F_{x}=K_{0}\left(\frac{\partial \xi}{\partial x}\right)_{x+\Delta x}-K_{0}\left(\frac{\partial \xi}{\partial x}\right)_{x}
$$

which by Newton's second law is equal to $\rho \Delta x\left(\partial^{2} \xi / \partial t^{2}\right)_{x}, \rho$ being the mass per unit length of the spring, assumed constant for small extensions. Thus

$$
\left(\frac{\partial^{2} \xi}{\partial t^{2}}\right)_{x}=\frac{K_{0}}{\rho} \frac{\left(\frac{\partial \xi}{\partial x}\right)_{x+\Delta x}-\left(\frac{\partial \xi}{\partial x}\right)_{x}}{\Delta x}=\frac{K_{0}}{\rho}\left(\frac{\partial^{2} \xi}{\partial x^{2}}\right)_{x},
$$

or

$$
\frac{\partial^{2} \xi}{\partial x^{2}}-\frac{m}{K_{0} X} \frac{\partial^{2} \xi}{\partial t^{2}}=0 .
$$

This is the equation for propagation of longitudinal waves along the spring and gives the velocity of propagation as

$$
v=\sqrt{\frac{K_{0} X}{m}}=X \sqrt{\frac{k}{m}},
$$

as $k=K_{0} / X$ by definition.

Try a solution of the form

$$
\xi(x, t)=\xi_{0}(x) \cos (\omega t+\varphi),
$$

where $\omega, \varphi$ are constants. Substitution in the wave equation gives

$$
\frac{\partial^{2} \xi_{0}}{\partial x^{2}}+K^{2} \xi_{0}=0,
$$

where

$$
K^{2}=\frac{m \omega^{2}}{K_{0} X}=\frac{\omega^{2}}{v^{2}} .
$$

Its general solution is

$$
\xi_{0}=A \sin (K x)+B \cos (K x),
$$

$A, B$ being constants of integration. The boundary condition $\xi_{0}=0$ at $x=0$ gives $B=0$. We also have from Newton's second law

$$
M\left(\frac{\partial^{2} \xi}{\partial t^{2}}\right)_{X}=-K_{0}\left(\frac{\partial \xi}{\partial x}\right)_{X}
$$

or

$$
K X \tan (K X)=\frac{m}{M},
$$

which can be solved to give a series of $K$, and hence of the vibrational frequencies of the spring.

For $m \ll M$ and the lowest frequency, $\tan (K X) \simeq K X$ and the above becomes

$$
\frac{\omega^{2} m}{k} \approx \frac{m}{M},
$$

giving the lowest angular frequency as

$$
\omega=\sqrt{\frac{k}{M}} .
$$

Note that this is just the vibrational frequency of an oscillator which consists of a massless spring of force constant $k$ with one end fixed and the other end connected to a mass $M$.

To obtain a more accurate approximate solution, expand

$$
\tan (K X)=K X+\frac{1}{3}(K X)^{3}+\cdots
$$

and retain the first two terms only. We then have

$$
(K X)^{2}=\frac{m}{M}\left[1+\frac{1}{3}(K X)^{2}\right]^{-1} \approx \frac{m}{M}\left[1-\frac{1}{3}(K X)^{2}\right]
$$

or

$$
K^{2}=\frac{3 m}{(3 M+m) X^{2}},
$$

giving

$$
\omega=\sqrt{\frac{3 k}{3 M+m}} .
$$

1235.a.Problem Statement:
A common lecture demonstration is as follows: hold or clamp a onemeter long thin aluminium bar at the center, strike one end longitudinally (i.e. parallel to the axis of the bar) with a hammer, and the result is a sound wave of frequency $2500 \mathrm{~Hz}$.

From this experiment, calculate the speed of sound in air.
1235.a.Solution:
The point where the bar is struck is an antinode and the point where it is held a node. With the bar held at the center and its one end struck, the wavelength $\lambda$ is related to its length $L$ by $\lambda=2 L$. Hence the speed of sound propagation in the aluminium bar is

$$
v_{\mathrm{Al}}=\nu \lambda=2 \nu L=2 \times 2500 \times 1=5000 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \text {. }
$$

The speed of sound in a solid is

$$
v=\sqrt{\frac{Y}{\rho}},
$$

where $Y$ is the Young's modulus of its material and $\rho$ its density. The speed of sound in a fluid is

$$
v=\sqrt{\frac{M}{\rho}}
$$

where $M$ is its bulk modulus and $\rho$ its density. For adiabatic compression of a gas, $M=\gamma p$, where $p$ is its pressure and $\gamma$ the ratio of its principal specific heats; $\gamma=1.4$ for air, a diatomic gas. Hence

$$
\frac{v_{\text {air }}}{v_{\mathrm{Al}}}=\sqrt{\frac{1.4 p \rho_{\mathrm{Al}}}{Y \rho_{\mathrm{air}}}} .
$$

With

$$
\begin{aligned}
p &=1.013 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{dyn} / \mathrm{cm}^{2} \quad(\text { standard atmosphere) }\\
Y &=7.05 \times 10^{11} \mathrm{dyn} / \mathrm{cm}^{2} \\
\rho_{\mathrm{Al}} &=2.7 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{cm}^{3} \\
\rho_{\text {air }} &=1.165 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{cm}^{3} \quad\left(\text { at } 30^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\right) \\
v_{\text {air }} &=6.83 \times 10^{-2} \times 5000=341 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} .
\end{aligned}
$$
