2001.b.Problem Statement:
A massless spring of rest length $l_{0}$ (with no tension) has a point mass $m$ connected to one end and the other end fixed so the spring hangs in the gravity field as shown in Fig. 2.1. The motion of the system is only in one vertical plane.

Find Lagrange's equations using variables $\theta, \lambda=\left(r-r_{0}\right) / r_{0}$, where $r_{0}$ is the rest length (hanging with mass $m$ ). Use $\omega_{s}^{2}=k / m, \omega_{p}^{2}=g / r_{0}$.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-473.jpg?height=295&width=204&top_left_y=1034&top_left_x=654)

Fig, 2,1.
2001.b.Solution:
In polar coordinates $(r, \theta)$ as shown in Fig. 2.1, the mass $m$ has velocity $\mathbf{v}=(\dot{r}, r \dot{\theta})$. Thus

$$
\begin{aligned}
&T=\frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{r}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}\right), \\
&V=-m g r \cos \theta+\frac{1}{2} k\left(r-l_{0}\right)^{2},
\end{aligned}
$$

$k$ being the spring constant. The Lagrangian of $m$ is therefore

$$
L=T-V=\frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{r}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}\right)+m g r \cos \theta-\frac{1}{2} k\left(r-l_{0}\right)^{2} .
$$

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{r}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial r}=0
$$

gives

$$
\begin{gathered}
m \ddot{r}-m r \dot{\theta}^{2}-m g \cos \theta+k\left(r-l_{0}\right)=0 . \\
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\theta}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial \theta}=0
\end{gathered}
$$

gives

$$
m r^{2} \ddot{\theta}+2 m r \dot{r} \dot{\theta}+m g r \sin \theta=0 .
$$

The rest length of the spring with mass $m$ hanging, $r_{0}$, is given by Hooke's law

$$
k\left(r_{0}-l_{0}\right)=m g .
$$

Thus with $\lambda=\left(r-r_{0}\right) / r_{0}$ we have

$$
\begin{gathered}
r-l_{0}=\lambda r_{0}+\frac{m g}{k}, \\
r=r_{0}(1+\lambda), \quad \dot{r}=r_{0} \dot{\lambda}, \quad \ddot{r}=r_{0} \ddot{\lambda},
\end{gathered}
$$

and the equations of motion becone

$$
\begin{array}{r}
\ddot{\lambda}+\frac{k \lambda}{m}-(1+\lambda) \dot{\theta}^{2}+\frac{g}{r_{0}}(1-\cos \theta)=0, \\
(1+\lambda) \ddot{\theta}+2 \dot{\lambda} \dot{\theta}+\frac{g}{r_{0}} \sin \theta=0
\end{array}
$$

or, with $\omega_{s}^{2}=\frac{k}{m}, \omega_{p}^{2}=\frac{g}{r_{0}}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\ddot{\lambda}+\left(\omega_{s}^{2}-\dot{\theta}^{2}\right) \lambda-\dot{\theta}^{2}+\omega_{p}^{2}(1-\cos \theta) &=0, \\
(1+\lambda) \ddot{\theta}+2 \dot{\lambda} \dot{\theta}+\omega_{p}^{2} \sin \theta &=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

2003.a.Problem Statement:
A uniform solid cylinder of radius $R$ and mass $M$ rests on a horizontal plane and an identical cylinder rests on it, touching it along the highest generator as shown in Fig 2.4. The upper cylinder is given an infinitesimal displacement so that both cylinders roll without slipping.

What is the Lagrangian of the system?
2003.a.Solution:
The system possesses two degrees of freedom so that two generalized coordinates are required. For these we use $\theta_{1}$, the angle of rotation of the lower cylinder, and $\theta$, the angle made by the plane containing the two axes of the cylinders and the vertical.

Initially the plane containing the two axes of the cylinders is vertical. At a later time, this plane makes an angle $\theta$ with the vertical. The original point of contact, $A$, now moves to $A^{\prime}$ on the lower cylinder and to $A^{\prime \prime}$ on the upper cylinder. With the angles so defined we have from Fig. 2.4

$$
\theta_{1}+\theta=\theta_{2}-\theta,
$$

or

$$
\theta_{2}=\theta_{1}+2 \theta .
$$

Taking Cartesian coordinates $(x, y)$ in the vertical plane normal to the axes of the cylinders and through their centers of mass, as shown in Fig. 2.4, we have, at $t>0$, for the lower cylinder

$$
x_{1}=-R \theta_{1}, \quad y_{1}=R,
$$

and for the upper cylinder

$$
\begin{aligned}
&x_{2}=x_{1}+2 R \sin \theta, \\
&y_{2}=3 R-2(R-\cos \theta)=R+2 R \cos \theta .
\end{aligned}
$$

The corresponding velocity components are

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\dot{x}_{1}=-R \dot{\theta}_{1}, \quad \dot{y}_{1}=0, \\
&\dot{x}_{2}=-R \dot{\theta}_{1}+2 R \dot{\theta} \cos \theta, \quad \dot{y}_{2}=-2 R \dot{\theta} \sin \theta .
\end{aligned}
$$

The kinetic energy of the lower cylinder is thus

$$
T_{1}=\frac{1}{2} M \dot{x}_{1}^{2}+\frac{1}{4} M R^{2} \dot{\theta}_{1}^{2}=\frac{3}{4} M R^{2} \dot{\theta}_{1}^{2},
$$

and that of the upper cylinder is

$$
\begin{aligned}
T_{2} &=\frac{1}{2} M\left(\dot{x}_{2}^{2}+\dot{y}_{2}^{2}\right)+\frac{1}{4} M R^{2} \dot{\theta}_{2}^{2} \\
&=\frac{1}{2} M R^{2}\left(\dot{\theta}_{1}^{2}-4 \dot{\theta}_{1} \dot{\theta} \cos \theta+4 \dot{\theta}^{2}\right)+\frac{1}{4} M R^{2}\left(\dot{\theta}_{1}^{2}+4 \dot{\theta}_{1} \dot{\theta}+4 \dot{\theta}^{2}\right) \\
&=\frac{1}{4} M R^{2}\left[3 \dot{\theta}_{1}^{2}+4 \dot{\theta}_{1} \dot{\theta}(1-2 \cos \theta)+12 \dot{\theta}^{2}\right] .
\end{aligned}
$$

The potential energy of the system, taking the horizontal plane as level of reference, is

$$
V=M g\left(y_{1}+y_{2}\right)=2 M R(1+\cos \theta) g .
$$

Hence the Lagrangian of the system is

$$
\begin{aligned}
L &=T-V \\
&=\frac{1}{2} M R^{2}\left[3 \dot{\theta}_{1}^{2}+2 \dot{\theta}_{1} \dot{\theta}(1-2 \cos \theta)+6 \dot{\theta}^{2}\right]-2 M R(1+\cos \theta) g .
\end{aligned}
$$

2004.Problem Statement: Two particles of the same mass $m$ are constrained to slide along a thin rod of mass $M$ and length $L$, which is itself free to move in any manner. Two identical springs link the particles with the central point of the rod. Consider only motions of this system in which the lengths of the springs (i.e. the distances of the two particles from the center of the rod) are equal. Taking this to be an isolated system in space, find equations of motion for it and solve them (up to the point of doing integrations). Describe qualitatively the motion.
2004.Solution:
Use a fixed Cartesian coordinate frame, and a moving frame with origin at the midpoint $O$ of the rod and its Cartesian axes parallel to those of 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-481.jpg?height=282&width=464&top_left_y=206&top_left_x=495)

Fig. 2.5.

the former respectively. Let $(r, \theta, \varphi)$ be the spherical coordinates of a point referring to the moving frame, as shown in Fig. 2.5. Then the point $O$ has coordinates $(x, y, z)$ in the fixed frame and the two masses have spherical coordinates $(r, \theta, \varphi)$ and $(-r, \theta, \varphi)$ in the moving frame.

The kinetic energy of a system is equal to the kinetic energy it would have if all its mass were concentrated at the center of mass plus the kinetic energy of motion about the center of mass. As $O$ is the center of mass of the system, we have

$$
T=\frac{1}{2}(M+2 m)\left(\dot{x}^{2}+\dot{y}^{2}+\dot{z}^{2}\right)+m\left(\dot{r}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\varphi}^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta\right)+T_{\text {rot }},
$$

where $T_{\text {rot }}$ is the rotational kinetic energy of the rod. The angular velocity of the rod about $O$ is

$$
\boldsymbol{\omega}=\dot{\varphi} \cos \theta \mathbf{e}_{r}-\dot{\varphi} \sin \theta \mathbf{e}_{\theta}-\dot{\theta} \mathbf{e}_{\varphi},
$$

resolved along its principal axes, the corresponding moments of inertia being

$$
I_{r}=0, \quad I_{\theta}=\frac{1}{12} M L^{2}, \quad I_{\varphi}=\frac{1}{12} M L^{2} .
$$

Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
T_{\text {rot }} &=\frac{1}{2}\left(I_{r} \omega_{r}^{2}+I_{\theta} \omega_{\theta}^{2}+I_{\varphi} \omega_{\varphi}^{2}\right) \\
&=\frac{1}{24} M L^{2}\left(\dot{\theta}^{2}+\dot{\varphi}^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

The system is in free space so the only potential energy is that due to the action of the springs,

$$
V=2 \cdot \frac{1}{2} K\left(r-r_{0}\right)^{2}=K\left(r-r_{0}\right)^{2},
$$

where $K$ and $r_{0}$ are the spring constant and the natural length of each spring respectively. Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
L=& T-V \\
=& \frac{1}{2}(M+2 m)\left(\dot{x}^{2}+\dot{y}^{2}+\dot{z}^{2}\right)+m\left(\dot{r}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\varphi}^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta\right) \\
&+\frac{1}{24} M L^{2}\left(\dot{\theta}^{2}+\dot{\varphi}^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta\right)-K\left(r-r_{0}\right)^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Lagrange's equations

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}}=0
$$

then give the following constants of motion:

$$
\begin{aligned}
(M+2 m) \dot{x} &=\text { constant } \\
(M+2 m) \dot{y} &=\text { constant } \\
(M+2 m) \dot{z} &=\text { constant } \\
\left(2 m r^{2}+\frac{1}{12} M L^{2}\right) \dot{\varphi} \sin ^{2} \theta &=\text { constant }
\end{aligned}
$$

The first three equations show that the velocity $(\dot{x}, \dot{y}, \dot{z})$ of the center of mass of the system is a constant vector. Thus the center of mass moves in a uniform rectilinear motion with whatever velocity it had initially. The last equation shows that the component of the angular momentum about the $z^{\prime}$-axis is a constant of the motion. Since the axis has been arbitrarily chosen, this means that the angular momentum is conserved.

Lagrange's equations also give the following equations of motion:

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\ddot{r}-r \dot{\theta}^{2}-r \dot{\varphi}^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta+\frac{K}{m}\left(r-r_{0}\right)=0, \\
&\left(r^{2}+\frac{M L^{2}}{24 m}\right) \ddot{\theta}+2 r \dot{r} \dot{\theta}-\left(r^{2}+\frac{M L^{2}}{24 m}\right) \dot{\varphi}^{2} \sin \theta \cos \theta=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

These and the $\dot{\varphi}$ equation above describe the motion about the center of mass of the system.

Thus under the constraint that the two masses $m$ slide along the rod symmetrically with respect to the midpoint $O$, the motion of the center of mass $O$ of the system is a uniform rectilinear motion, and the motion of the system about $O$ is such that the total angular momentum about $O$ is conserved.

2005.Problem Statement: A rectangle coordinate system with axes $x, y, z$ is rotating relative to an inertial frame with constant angular velocity $\omega$ about the $z$-axis. A particle of mass $m$ moves under a force whose potential is $V(x, y, z)$. Set up the Lagrange equations of motion in the coordinate system $x, y, z$. Show that their equations are the same as those for a particle in a fixed coordinate system acted on by the force $-\nabla V$ and a force derivable from a velocity-dependent potential $U$. Find $U$.
2005.Solution:
Let the inertial frame have the same origin as the rotating frame and axes $x^{\prime}, y^{\prime}, z^{\prime}$. Denote the velocities of the particle in the two frames by $\mathbf{v}$ and $\mathbf{v}^{\prime}$. As

$$
\mathbf{v}^{\prime}=\mathbf{v}+\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{r}
$$

with

$$
\boldsymbol{\omega}=(0,0, \omega), \quad \mathbf{r}=(x, y, z), \quad \mathbf{v}=(\dot{x}, \dot{y}, \dot{z}),
$$

we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
v^{\prime 2} &=v^{2}+2 \mathbf{v} \cdot \boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{r}+(\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{r})^{2} \\
&=\dot{x}^{2}+\dot{y}^{2}+\dot{z}^{2}+2 \omega(x \dot{y}-\dot{x} y)+\omega^{2}\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right),
\end{aligned}
$$

and the Lagrangian of the particle in the inertial frame, expressed in quantities referring to the rotating frame,

$$
\begin{aligned}
L &=T-V \\
&=\frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{x}^{2}+\dot{y}^{2}+\dot{z}^{2}\right)+m \omega(x \dot{y}-\dot{x} y)+\frac{1}{2} m \omega^{2}\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)-V .
\end{aligned}
$$

Lagrange's equations

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}}=0
$$

then give

$$
\begin{aligned}
&m \ddot{x}-2 m \omega \dot{y}-m \omega^{2} x+\frac{\partial V}{\partial x}=0, \\
&m \ddot{y}+2 m \omega \dot{x}-m \omega^{2} y+\frac{\partial V}{\partial y}=0, \\
&m \ddot{z}+\frac{\partial V}{\partial z}=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

For a particle of mass $m$ moving in a fixed frame $(x, y, z)$ under a force $-\nabla V$ and an additional velocity-dependent potential $U$, the Lagrangian is

$$
L=\frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{x}^{2}+\dot{y}^{2}+\dot{z}^{2}\right)-V-U .
$$

A comparison of this with the Lagrangian obtained previously gives

$$
U=-m \omega(x \dot{y}-\dot{x} y)-\frac{1}{2} m \omega^{2}\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right) .
$$

This Lagrangian would obviously give rise to the same equations of motion.

2007.b.Problem Statement:
A block of mass $M$ is rigidly connected to a massless circular track of radius $a$ on a frictionless horizontal table as shown in Fig. 2.7. A particle of mass $m$ is confined to move without friction on the circular track which is vertical.

Find the equations of motion.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-486.jpg?height=246&width=520&top_left_y=1562&top_left_x=459)

Fig. 2.7.
2007.b.Solution:
As the motion of the system is confined to a vertical plane, use a fixed coordinate frame $x, y$ and choose the $x$ coordinate of the center of the circular track and the angle $\theta$ giving the location of $m$ on the circular track as the generalized coordinates as shown in Fig. 2.7. The coordinates of the mass $m$ are then $(x+a \sin \theta,-a \cos \theta)$. As $M$ is rigidly connected to the circular track its velocity is $(\dot{x}, 0)$. Hence the Lagrangian is

$$
\begin{aligned}
L &=T-V=\frac{1}{2} M \dot{x}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m\left[(\dot{x}+a \dot{\theta} \cos \theta)^{2}+a^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta\right]+m g a \cos \theta \\
&=\frac{1}{2} M \dot{x}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m\left[\dot{x}^{2}+a^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+2 a \dot{x} \dot{\theta} \cos \theta\right]+m g a \cos \theta .
\end{aligned}
$$

As

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\frac{\partial L}{\partial x}=0 \\
&\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{x}}=M \dot{x}+m \dot{x}+m a \dot{\theta} \cos \theta \\
&\frac{\partial L}{\partial \theta}=-m a \dot{x} \dot{\theta} \sin \theta-m g a \sin \theta, \\
&\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\theta}}=m a^{2} \dot{\theta}+m a \dot{x} \cos \theta
\end{aligned}
$$

Lagrange's equations

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}}=0
$$

give

$$
\begin{aligned}
&(M+m) \ddot{x}+m a \ddot{\theta} \cos \theta-m a \dot{\theta}^{2} \sin \theta=0, \\
&a \ddot{\theta}+\ddot{x} \cos \theta+g \sin \theta=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

2008.a.Problem Statement:
Consider a particle of mass $m$ moving in a bound orbit with potential $V(r)=-k / r$. Using polar coordinates in the plane of the orbit:

Find $p_{r}$ and $p_{\theta}$ as functions of $r, \theta, \dot{r}$ and $\dot{\theta}$. Is either one constant?

$$
\tau=\pi k \sqrt{\frac{m}{-2 E^{3}}} .
$$
2008.a.Solution:
We have

$$
L=T-V=\frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{r}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}\right)+\frac{k}{r} .
$$

The generalized momenta are

$$
\begin{aligned}
&p_{r}=\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{r}}=m \dot{r}, \\
&p_{\theta}=\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\theta}}=m r^{2} \dot{\theta} .
\end{aligned}
$$

As there is no $\theta$ in $L, p_{\theta}=m r^{2} \dot{\theta}$ is a constant of the motion.

2010.Problem Statement:
A thin, uniform rod of length $2 L$ and mass $M$ is suspended from a massless string of length $l$ tied to a nail. As shown in Fig. 2.9, a horizontal force $F$ is applied to the rod's free end.

Write the Lagrange equations for this system. For very short times (so that all angles are small) determine the angles that the string and the rod make with the vertical. Start from rest at $t=0$. Draw a diagram to illustrate the initial motion of the rod.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-493.jpg?height=281&width=204&top_left_y=981&top_left_x=588)

Fig. 2.9.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-493.jpg?height=339&width=320&top_left_y=1458&top_left_x=654)

Fig. 2.10.
2010.Solution:
As the applied force $F$ is horizontal and initially the string and rod are vertical, the motion is confined to a vertical plane. Take Cartesian coordinates as shown in Fig. $2.10$ and denote the angles made by the string and the rod with the vertical by $\theta_{1}, \theta_{2}$ respectively. The center of mass of the rod has coordinates $\left(l \sin \theta_{1}+L \sin \theta_{2},-l \cos \theta_{1}-L \cos \theta_{2}\right)$ and thus velocity $\left(l \dot{\theta}_{1} \cos \theta_{1}+L \dot{\theta}_{2} \cos \theta_{2}, l \dot{\theta}_{1} \sin \theta_{1}+L \dot{\theta}_{2} \sin \theta_{2}\right)$. Its moment of inertia about a perpendicular axis through its center is $M L^{2} / 3$. Hence its kinetic energy is

$$
T=\frac{1}{2} M\left[l^{2} \dot{\theta}_{1}^{2}+L^{2} \dot{\theta}_{2}^{2}+2 L l \dot{\theta}_{1} \dot{\theta}_{2} \cos \left(\theta_{1}-\theta_{2}\right)\right]+\frac{1}{6} M L^{2} \dot{\theta}_{2}^{2}
$$

and its potential energy is

$$
V=-M g\left(l \cos \theta_{1}+L \cos \theta_{2}\right) .
$$

The potential $U$ of the horizontal force is by definition

$$
U=-\int \mathbf{F} \cdot d \mathbf{r}=-F\left(l \sin \theta_{1}+2 L \sin \theta_{2}\right)
$$

The Lagrangian is therefore

$$
\begin{aligned}
L=& T-V-U \\
=& \frac{1}{2} M\left[l^{2} \dot{\theta}_{1}^{2}+L^{2} \dot{\theta}_{2}^{2}+2 L l \dot{\theta}_{1} \dot{\theta}_{2} \cos \left(\theta_{1}-\theta_{2}\right)\right]+\frac{1}{6} M L^{2} \dot{\theta}_{2}^{2} \\
&+M g\left(l \cos \theta_{1}+L \cos \theta_{2}\right)+F\left(l \sin \theta_{1}+2 L \sin \theta_{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Lagrange's equations

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}}=0
$$

then give

$$
\begin{aligned}
M l \ddot{\theta}_{1} &+M L \ddot{\theta}_{2} \cos \left(\theta_{1}-\theta_{2}\right)+M L \dot{\theta}_{2}^{2} \sin \left(\theta_{1}-\theta_{2}\right) \\
&+M g \sin \theta_{1}-F \cos \theta_{1}=0, \\
\frac{4}{3} M L \ddot{\theta}_{2} &+M l \ddot{\theta}_{1} \cos \left(\theta_{1}-\theta_{2}\right)-M l \dot{\theta}_{1}^{2} \sin \left(\theta_{1}-\theta_{2}\right) \\
&+M g \sin \theta_{2}-2 F \cos \theta_{2}=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

Note that if $F$ is small so that $\theta_{1}, \theta_{2}, \dot{\theta}_{1}, \dot{\theta}_{2}$ can be considered small then, retaining only first order terms, the above become

$$
\begin{aligned}
M l \ddot{\theta}_{1}+M L \ddot{\theta}_{2}+M g \theta_{1}-F &=0, \\
\frac{4}{3} M L \ddot{\theta}_{2}+M l \ddot{\theta}_{1}+M g \theta_{2}-2 F &=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

The motion starts from rest at $t=0$. For a very short time $\Delta t$ afterwards, the force can be considered as giving rise to a horizontal impulse $F \Delta t$ and an impulsive torque $F L \Delta t$ about the center of mass of the rod. We then have

$$
\begin{aligned}
F \Delta t &=M\left(i \dot{\theta}_{1} \cos \theta_{1}+L \dot{\theta}_{2} \cos \theta_{2}\right) \\
& \approx M l \dot{\theta}_{1}+M L \dot{\theta}_{2},
\end{aligned}
$$

as the angle $\theta_{1}, \theta_{2}$ are still small, and

$$
F L \Delta t=\frac{1}{3} M L^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2} .
$$

Eliminating $F \Delta t$ from the above, we have

$$
\dot{\theta}_{1} \approx-\frac{2 L}{3 l} \dot{\theta}_{2} .
$$

As $\theta_{1}=\overline{\dot{\theta}_{1}} \Delta t \approx \dot{\theta}_{1} \Delta t / 2, \theta_{2} \approx \dot{\theta}_{2} \Delta t / 2$, the above gives

$$
\theta_{1} \approx-\frac{2 L}{3 l} \theta_{2} .
$$

The initial configuration of the system is shown in Fig. 2.11.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-495.jpg?height=349&width=222&top_left_y=1484&top_left_x=673)

Fig. 2.11.

2011.c.Problem Statement:
Consider a binary star system.

$$
V\left(\alpha \mathbf{r}_{1}, \alpha \mathbf{r}_{2}\right)=\alpha^{-1} V\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}, \mathbf{r}_{2}\right),
$$

where $\alpha$ is a real scaling parameter.

Find a transformation which leaves the Lagrangian the same up to a multiplication constant (thereby leaving the physics unchanged) and thus find Kepler's third law relating the period of revolution of the system to the size of its orbit.
2011.c.Solution:
Let $\mathbf{r}_{1}, \mathbf{r}_{2}$ be the radius vectors of the binary stars, masses $m_{1}, m_{2}$ respectively, from the origin of a fixed coordinate frame. Then

$$
T=\frac{1}{2} m_{1}\left|\dot{\mathbf{r}}_{1}\right|^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m_{2}\left|\dot{\mathbf{r}}_{2}\right|^{2}, \quad V=-\frac{G m_{1} m_{2}}{\left|\mathbf{r}_{1}-\mathbf{r}_{2}\right|},
$$

and the Lagrangian is

$$
L=T-V=\frac{1}{2}\left(m_{1}\left|\dot{\mathbf{r}}_{1}\right|^{2}+m_{2}\left|\dot{\mathbf{r}}_{2}\right|^{2}\right)+\frac{G m_{1} m_{2}}{\left|\mathbf{r}_{1}-\mathbf{r}_{2}\right|} .
$$

$$
V\left(\alpha \mathbf{r}_{1}, \alpha \mathbf{r}_{2}\right)=-\frac{G m_{1} m_{2}}{\left|\alpha \mathbf{r}_{1}-\alpha \mathbf{r}_{2}\right|}=-\frac{1}{\alpha} \frac{G m_{1} m_{2}}{\left|\mathbf{r}_{1}-\mathbf{r}_{2}\right|}=\frac{1}{\alpha} V\left(\mathbf{r}_{1}, \mathbf{r}_{2}\right),
$$

i.e. the potential energy is a homogeneous function of the coordinates of degree $-1$

Let $\mathbf{R}$ be the radius vector of the center of mass of the binary system from the origin of the fixed coordinate frame, and $\mathbf{r}_{1}^{\prime}, \mathbf{r}_{2}^{\prime}$ be the radius vectors of $m_{1}, m_{2}$ from the center of mass respectively. By definition

$$
\begin{gathered}
\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right) \mathbf{R}=m_{2} \mathbf{r}_{1}+m_{2} \mathbf{r}_{2}, \\
\mathbf{r}_{1}=\mathbf{R}+\mathbf{r}_{1}^{\prime}, \quad \mathbf{r}_{2}=\mathbf{R}+\mathbf{r}_{2}^{\prime},
\end{gathered}
$$

so

$$
\mathbf{r}_{1}^{\prime}=\frac{m_{2} \mathbf{r}}{m_{1}+m_{2}}, \quad \mathbf{r}_{2}^{\prime}=-\frac{m_{1} \mathbf{r}}{m_{1}+m_{2}}
$$

where $r=\mathbf{r}_{1}-\mathbf{r}_{2}=\mathbf{r}_{1}^{\prime}-\mathbf{r}_{2}^{\prime}$.

We can then write the Lagrangian as

$$
L=\frac{m_{1}+m_{2}}{2}|\dot{\mathbf{R}}|^{2}+\frac{m_{1} m_{2}}{2\left(m_{2}+m_{2}\right)}|\dot{\mathbf{r}}|^{2}+\frac{G m_{1} m_{2}}{|\mathbf{r}|}
$$

As $L$ does not depend on $\mathbf{R}=(x, y, z)$ explicitly, $\partial L / \partial \dot{x}, \partial L / \partial \dot{y}, \partial L / \partial \dot{z}$ and hence $\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right) \dot{R}$ are constant. Therefore the first term of $L$, which is the kinetic energy of the system as a whole, is constant. This terms can be neglected when we are interested only in the internal motion of the system. Thus

$$
\begin{aligned}
L &=\left(\frac{m_{1} m_{2}}{m_{1}+m_{2}}\right)\left[\frac{1}{2}|\dot{\mathbf{r}}|^{2}+\frac{G\left(M_{1}+M_{2}\right)}{|\mathbf{r}|}\right] \\
&=\left(\frac{m_{1}}{m_{1}+m_{2}}\right)\left[\frac{1}{2} m_{2}|\dot{\mathbf{r}}|^{2}+\frac{G m_{2}\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right)}{|\mathbf{r}|}\right] \\
&=\left(\frac{m_{2}}{m_{1}+m_{2}}\right)\left[\frac{1}{2} m_{1}|\dot{\mathbf{r}}|^{2}+\frac{G m_{1}\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right)}{|\mathbf{r}|}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

which may be consider as the Lagrangian, apart from a multiplicative constant, of the motion of one star in the gravitational field of a fixed star of mass $m_{1}+m_{2}$. Let $m_{1}$ be this "moving" star and consider its centripetal force:

$$
m_{1} r \dot{\theta}^{2}=\frac{G m_{1}\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right)}{r^{2}}
$$

Or

$$
\frac{T^{2}}{r^{3}}=\frac{4 \pi^{2}}{G\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right)},
$$

where $T=2 \pi / \dot{\theta}$ is the period of $m_{1}$ about $m_{2}$, which is Kepler's third law. The same is of course true for the motion of $m_{2}$ about $m_{1}$.

2012.a.Problem Statement:
Two thin beams of mass $m$ and length $l$ are connected by a frictionless hinge and a thread. The system rests on a smooth surface in the way shown in Fig. 2.12. At $t=0$ the thread is cut. In the following you may neglect the thread and the mass of the hinge.

Find the speed of the hinge when it hits the floor.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-498.jpg?height=248&width=454&top_left_y=607&top_left_x=558)

Fig. 2.12.
2012.a.Solution:
Due to symmetry, the hinge will fall vertically. Take coordinates as shown in Fig. $2.12$ and let $\theta$ be the angle each beam makes with the floor. Then the centers of mass of the beams have coordinates

$$
\begin{aligned}
& x_{1}=\frac{1}{2} l \cos \theta, \quad y_{1}=\frac{1}{2} l \sin \theta, \\
& x_{2}=-\frac{1}{2} l \cos \theta, \quad y_{2}=\frac{1}{2} l \sin \theta,
\end{aligned}
$$

and velocity components

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\dot{x}_{1}=-\frac{1}{2} l \dot{\theta} \sin \theta, & \dot{y}_{1}=\frac{1}{2} l \dot{\theta} \cos \theta, \\
\dot{x}_{2}=\frac{1}{2} l \dot{\theta} \sin \theta, & \dot{y}_{2}=\frac{1}{2} l \dot{\theta} \cos \theta .
\end{array}
$$

Each beam has a moment of inertial $m l^{2} / 12$ about a horizontal axis through its center of mass. The Lagrangian of the system is 

$$
\begin{aligned}
L &=T-V \\
&=\frac{1}{4} m l^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+\frac{1}{12} m l^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}-m g l \sin \theta \\
&=\frac{1}{3} m l^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}-m g l \sin \theta .
\end{aligned}
$$

Lagrange's equation

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\theta}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial \theta}=0
$$

Then gives

$$
\ddot{\theta}+\frac{3 g}{2 l} \cos \theta=0 .
$$

As

the above integrates to

$$
\ddot{\theta}=\frac{1}{2} \frac{d \dot{\theta}^{2}}{d \theta} \quad \text { and } \quad \dot{\theta}=0 \quad \text { when } \theta=30^{\circ},
$$

$$
\dot{\theta}^{2}=\frac{3 g}{2 l}(1-2 \sin \theta) .
$$

Hence when the hinge hits the floor, $\theta=0$ and

$$
\dot{\theta}=-\sqrt{\frac{3 g}{2 l}},
$$

i.e.

$$
|\mathbf{v}|=|\dot{\theta}|=\sqrt{\frac{3 g l}{2}} .
$$

2012.b.Problem Statement:
Two thin beams of mass $m$ and length $l$ are connected by a frictionless hinge and a thread. The system rests on a smooth surface in the way shown in Fig. 2.12. At $t=0$ the thread is cut. In the following you may neglect the thread and the mass of the hinge.

Find the time it takes for the hinge to hit the floor, expressing this in terms of a concrete integral which you need not evaluate explicitly.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-498.jpg?height=248&width=454&top_left_y=607&top_left_x=558)

Fig. 2.12.
2012.b.Solution:
Due to symmetry, the hinge will fall vertically. Take coordinates as shown in Fig. $2.12$ and let $\theta$ be the angle each beam makes with the floor. Then the centers of mass of the beams have coordinates

$$
\begin{aligned}
& x_{1}=\frac{1}{2} l \cos \theta, \quad y_{1}=\frac{1}{2} l \sin \theta, \\
& x_{2}=-\frac{1}{2} l \cos \theta, \quad y_{2}=\frac{1}{2} l \sin \theta,
\end{aligned}
$$

and velocity components

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\dot{x}_{1}=-\frac{1}{2} l \dot{\theta} \sin \theta, & \dot{y}_{1}=\frac{1}{2} l \dot{\theta} \cos \theta, \\
\dot{x}_{2}=\frac{1}{2} l \dot{\theta} \sin \theta, & \dot{y}_{2}=\frac{1}{2} l \dot{\theta} \cos \theta .
\end{array}
$$

Each beam has a moment of inertial $m l^{2} / 12$ about a horizontal axis through its center of mass. The Lagrangian of the system is 

$$
\begin{aligned}
L &=T-V \\
&=\frac{1}{4} m l^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+\frac{1}{12} m l^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}-m g l \sin \theta \\
&=\frac{1}{3} m l^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}-m g l \sin \theta .
\end{aligned}
$$

Lagrange's equation

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\theta}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial \theta}=0
$$

Then gives

$$
\ddot{\theta}+\frac{3 g}{2 l} \cos \theta=0 .
$$

As

the above integrates to

$$
\ddot{\theta}=\frac{1}{2} \frac{d \dot{\theta}^{2}}{d \theta} \quad \text { and } \quad \dot{\theta}=0 \quad \text { when } \theta=30^{\circ},
$$

$$
\dot{\theta}^{2}=\frac{3 g}{2 l}(1-2 \sin \theta) .
$$

Hence when the hinge hits the floor, $\theta=0$ and

$$
\dot{\theta}=-\sqrt{\frac{3 g}{2 l}},
$$

i.e.

$$
|\mathbf{v}|=|\dot{\theta}|=\sqrt{\frac{3 g l}{2}} .
$$The time taken for the hinge to hit the floor is given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
t &=\int_{30^{\circ}}^{0} \frac{d \theta}{\dot{\theta}}=\int_{30^{\circ}}^{0} \frac{d \theta}{-\sqrt{\frac{3 g}{2 l}(1-2 \sin \theta)}} \\
&=\sqrt{\frac{2 l}{3 g}} \int_{0}^{30^{\circ}} \frac{d \theta}{1-2 \sin \theta} .
\end{aligned}
$$

2013.Problem Statement:
A uniform rod of the length $L$ and mass $M$ moves in the vertical $x z$-plane, one of its end-points. $A$ being subject to the constraint $z=$ $x \tan \alpha$ ( $\alpha=$ constant inclination to the horizontal $x$-axis). Derive the Lagrangian equations of motion in terms of the generalized coordinates $q_{1}=s$ and $q_{2}=\theta$ (see Fig. 2.13). Use these to determine if a pure translational motion ( $\theta=$ constant) is possible and, if so, for which values of $\theta$.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-500.jpg?height=366&width=419&top_left_y=548&top_left_x=588)

Fig. 2.13.
2013.Solution:
The coordinates and velocity components of the center of mass of the rod are

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
x=s \cos \alpha-\frac{1}{2} L \sin \theta, & z=s \sin \alpha-\frac{1}{2} L \cos \theta, \\
\dot{x}=\dot{s} \cos \alpha-\frac{1}{2} L \dot{\theta} \cos \theta, & \dot{z}=\dot{s} \sin \alpha+\frac{1}{2} L \dot{\theta} \sin \theta,
\end{array}
$$

and the moment of inertia of the rod about a perpendicular axis through the center of mass is $M L^{2} / 12$, so the Lagrangian is

$$
\begin{aligned}
L &=T-V \\
&=\frac{1}{2} M\left(\dot{x}^{2}+\dot{z}^{2}\right)+\frac{1}{24} M L^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}-M g z \\
&=\frac{1}{2} M\left[\dot{s}^{2}-L \dot{s} \dot{\theta} \cos (\theta+\alpha)\right]+\frac{1}{6} M L^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}-M g\left(s \sin \alpha-\frac{1}{2} L \cos \theta\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Lagrange's equations

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}}=0
$$

then give

$$
\begin{array}{r}
\ddot{s}-\frac{1}{2} L \ddot{\theta} \cos (\theta+\alpha)+\frac{1}{2} L \dot{\theta}^{2} \sin (\theta+\alpha)+g \sin \alpha=0, \\
\ddot{s} \cos (\theta+\alpha)-\frac{2}{3} L \ddot{\theta}-g \sin \theta=0 .
\end{array}
$$

If the motion is pure translational, $\theta=$ constant, $\dot{\theta}=0, \ddot{\theta}=0$ and the above become

$$
\begin{aligned}
\ddot{s}+g \sin \alpha &=0, \\
\ddot{s} \cos (\theta+\alpha)-g \sin \theta &=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

Eliminating $\ddot{s}$ gives

$$
\sin \alpha \cos (\theta+\alpha)=-\sin \theta
$$

or

$$
\theta=-\alpha .
$$

2016.b.Problem Statement:
A particle is constrained to be in a plane. It is attracted to a fixed point $P$ in this plane; the force is always directed exactly at $P$ and is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from $P$.

Write Lagrangian equations for this particle and find at least one first integral.
2016.b.Solution:
Choose polar coordinates with origin at $P$ in the plane in which the particle is constrained to move. The force acting on the particle is

$$
\mathbf{F}=-\frac{k \mathbf{r}}{r^{3}},
$$

$k$ being a positive constant. Its potential energy with respect to infinity is

$$
V=-\int_{\infty}^{r} \mathbf{F} \cdot d \mathbf{r}=-\frac{k}{r} .
$$

The kinetic energy of the particle is

$$
T=\frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{r}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}\right) .
$$

Hence the Lagrangian is

$$
L=T-V=\frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{r}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}\right)+\frac{k}{r} .
$$

Lagrange's equations

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}}=0
$$

then give the equations of motion

$$
m \ddot{r}+\frac{k}{r^{2}}=0, \quad \frac{d}{d t}\left(m r^{2} \dot{\theta}\right)=0 .
$$

The second equation gives immediately a first integral

$$
m r^{2} \dot{\theta}=\text { constant },
$$

which means that the angular momentum with respect to $P$ is conserved.

2017.b.Problem Statement:
Consider two particles interacting by way of a central force (potential $=V(r)$ where $\mathbf{r}$ is the relative position vector).

Suppose that the potential is $V=k r^{2} / 2$, where $k$ is a positive constant, and that the total energy $E$ is known. Find expressions for the minimum and maximum values that $r$ will have in the course of the motion.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-507.jpg?height=289&width=337&top_left_y=797&top_left_x=604)

Fig. 2.16.
2017.b.Solution:
As the forces acting on the particles always direct along the line of separation, the motion is confined to whatever plane the particles initially move in. Use polar coordinates in this plane as shown in Fig. $2.16$ with origin at the center of mass of the particles. By definition of the center of mass,

$$
m_{1} \mathbf{r}_{1}+m_{2} \mathbf{r}_{2}=0,
$$

i.e.

$$
m_{1} \mathbf{r}_{1}=-m_{2} \mathbf{r}_{2},
$$

or

$$
m_{1} r_{1}=m_{2} r_{2}
$$

for the magnitudes.
The kinetic energy of the particle are

$$
\begin{aligned}
T &=\frac{m_{1}}{2}\left|\dot{\mathbf{r}}_{1}\right|^{2}+\frac{m_{2}}{2}\left|\dot{\mathbf{r}}_{2}\right|^{2} \\
&=\frac{m_{2}^{2}}{2 m_{1}}\left|\dot{\mathbf{r}}_{2}\right|^{2}+\frac{m_{2}}{2}\left|\dot{\mathbf{r}}_{2}\right|^{2} \\
&=\frac{m_{2}\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right)}{2 m_{1}}\left|\dot{\mathbf{r}}_{2}\right|^{2}=\frac{m_{2}^{2}}{2 \mu}\left|\dot{\mathbf{r}}_{2}\right|^{2},
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\mu=m_{1} m_{2} /\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right)$ is the reduced mass of the system. The potential energy is

$$
V\left(r_{1}+r_{2}\right)=V\left(\frac{m_{2} r_{2}}{m_{1}}+r_{2}\right)=V\left(\frac{m_{2} r_{2}}{\mu}\right) .
$$

Hence the Lagrangian is

$$
L=T-V=\frac{m_{2}^{2}}{2 \mu}\left(\dot{r}_{2}^{2}+r_{2}^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}\right)-V\left(\frac{m_{2} r_{2}}{\mu}\right),
$$

using $r_{2}$ and $\theta$ as the generalized coordinates.

The Lagrangian $L$ does not depend on $t$ explicitly. So

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{d L}{d t} &=\sum_{j}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{j}} \frac{d \dot{q}_{j}}{d t}+\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{j}} \dot{q}_{j}\right) \\
&=\sum_{j}\left[\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{j}} \frac{d \dot{q}_{j}}{d t}+\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{j}}\right) \dot{q}_{j}\right] \\
&=\frac{d}{d t} \sum_{j} \frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{j}} \dot{q}_{j},
\end{aligned}
$$

use having been made of Lagrange's equations. Hence

$$
\sum_{j} \frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{j}} \dot{q}_{j}-L=\text { constant }
$$

In the present case,

$$
\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{r}_{2}} \dot{r}_{2}=\frac{m_{2}^{2} \dot{r}_{2}^{2}}{\mu}, \quad \frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\theta}} \dot{\theta}=\frac{m_{2}^{2} r_{2}^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}}{\mu},
$$

and the above gives

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{m_{2}^{2}}{\mu}\left(\dot{r}_{2}^{2}+r_{2}^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}\right)-T+V &=\frac{m_{2}^{2}}{2 \mu}\left(\dot{r}_{2}^{2}+r_{2}^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}\right)+V \\
&=T+V=\text { constant }
\end{aligned}
$$

showing that the total energy is conserved. Note that this proof is possible because $V$ does not depend on the velocities explicitly.

As $L$ does not depend on $\theta$ explicitly, Lagrange's equation gives

$$
\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\theta}}=\frac{m_{2}^{2} r_{2}^{2} \dot{\theta}}{\mu}=\text { constant }=J, \text { say } .
$$

The angular momentum of the system about the center of mass is

$$
m_{2} r_{2}^{2} \dot{\theta}+m_{1} r_{1}^{2} \dot{\theta}=\frac{\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right) m_{2} r_{2}^{2} \dot{\theta}}{m_{1}}=\frac{m_{2}^{2} r_{2}^{2} \dot{\theta}}{\mu}=J .
$$

Hence the angular momentum is conserved. The above also implies

$$
r^{2} \dot{\theta}=\left(r_{1}+r_{2}\right)^{2} \dot{\theta}=\left(\frac{m_{1}+m_{2}}{m_{1}}\right)^{2} r_{2}^{2} \dot{\theta}=\frac{m_{2}^{2} r_{2}^{2} \dot{\theta}}{\mu^{2}}=\text { constant }
$$

i.e.

$$
\frac{r^{2} \Delta \theta}{\Delta t}=\frac{2 \Delta S}{\Delta t}=\text { constant }
$$

where $\Delta S$ is the area swept out by $\mathbf{r}$ in time $\Delta t$. Thus Kepler's second law is satisfied.

The total energy

$$
\begin{aligned}
E &=T+V=\frac{m_{2}^{2}}{2 \mu}\left(\dot{r}_{2}^{2}+r_{2}^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}\right)+\frac{1}{2} k r^{2} \\
&=\frac{m_{2}^{2} \dot{r}_{2}^{2}}{2 \mu}+\frac{J^{2} \mu}{2 m_{2}^{2}} \frac{1}{r_{2}^{2}}+\frac{1}{2} k r^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

can be written as

$$
E=\frac{1}{2} \mu \dot{r}^{2}+\frac{J^{2}}{2 \mu} \frac{1}{r^{2}}+\frac{1}{2} k r^{2} .
$$

When $r$ is a maximum or minimum, $\dot{r}=0$. Hence the extreme values of $r$ are given by

$$
k \mu r^{4}-2 E \mu r^{2}+J^{2}=0 .
$$

2022.a.Problem Statement:
A sphere of mass $M$ and radius $R$ rolls without slipping down a triangular block of mass $m$ that is free to move on a frictionless horizontal surface, as shown in Fig. 2.18.

Find the Lagrangian and state Lagrange's equations for this system subject to the force of gravity at the surface of the earth.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-519.jpg?height=314&width=601&top_left_y=223&top_left_x=460)

Fig. 2.18.
2022.a.Solution:
Use a fixed coordinate frame as shown in Fig. $2.18$ and let $\theta$ be the angle of rotation of the sphere. As the sphere rolls without slipping down the inclined plane, its center will have coordinates

$$
\left(x+\left(\xi_{0}+R \theta\right) \cos \varphi, H-R \theta \sin \varphi\right)
$$

and velocity

$$
(\dot{x}+R \dot{\theta} \cos \varphi,-R \dot{\theta} \sin \varphi) \text {. }
$$

Note that at $t=0, x=0, \theta=0, \xi=\xi_{0}, y=H, \dot{x}=\dot{\theta}=0$. Then the Lagrangian is

$$
\begin{aligned}
L=T-V=& \frac{1}{2} m \dot{x}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} M\left(\dot{x}^{2}+R^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+2 R \dot{x} \dot{\theta} \cos \varphi\right) \\
&+\frac{1}{5} M R^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}-M g(H-R \theta \sin \varphi) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Lagrange's equations

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}}=0
$$

give

$$
\begin{aligned}
&(m+M) \ddot{x}+M R \ddot{\theta} \cos \varphi=0, \\
&\ddot{x} \cos \varphi+\frac{7}{5} R \ddot{\theta}-g \sin \varphi=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

2022.b.Problem Statement:
A sphere of mass $M$ and radius $R$ rolls without slipping down a triangular block of mass $m$ that is free to move on a frictionless horizontal surface, as shown in Fig. 2.18.

Find the motion of the system by integrating Lagrange's equation, given that all objects are initially at rest and the sphere's center is at a distance $H$ above the surface.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-519.jpg?height=314&width=601&top_left_y=223&top_left_x=460)

Fig. 2.18.
2022.b.Solution:
Use a fixed coordinate frame as shown in Fig. $2.18$ and let $\theta$ be the angle of rotation of the sphere. As the sphere rolls without slipping down the inclined plane, its center will have coordinates

$$
\left(x+\left(\xi_{0}+R \theta\right) \cos \varphi, H-R \theta \sin \varphi\right)
$$

and velocity

$$
(\dot{x}+R \dot{\theta} \cos \varphi,-R \dot{\theta} \sin \varphi) \text {. }
$$

Note that at $t=0, x=0, \theta=0, \xi=\xi_{0}, y=H, \dot{x}=\dot{\theta}=0$. Then the Lagrangian is

$$
\begin{aligned}
L=T-V=& \frac{1}{2} m \dot{x}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} M\left(\dot{x}^{2}+R^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+2 R \dot{x} \dot{\theta} \cos \varphi\right) \\
&+\frac{1}{5} M R^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}-M g(H-R \theta \sin \varphi) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Lagrange's equations

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}}=0
$$

give

$$
\begin{aligned}
&(m+M) \ddot{x}+M R \ddot{\theta} \cos \varphi=0, \\
&\ddot{x} \cos \varphi+\frac{7}{5} R \ddot{\theta}-g \sin \varphi=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$Eliminating $\ddot{x}$ from the above gives

$$
\left(\frac{7}{5}-\frac{M \cos ^{2} \varphi}{m+M}\right) \ddot{\theta}=\frac{g \sin \varphi}{R},
$$

or, on integration and use of initial conditions,

$$
\theta=\frac{5(m+M) \sin \varphi}{2\left[7(m+M)-5 M \cos ^{2} \varphi\right]} \frac{g t^{2}}{R},
$$

and thus

$$
x=-\frac{M R \cos \varphi}{m+M} \theta=-\frac{5 M \sin (2 \varphi)}{4\left[7(m+M)-5 M \cos ^{2} \varphi\right]} g t^{2} .
$$

Note that, as the sphere rolls down the plane, the block moves to the left as expected from momentum conservation.

2023.b.Problem Statement:
Two mass points $m_{1}$ and $m_{2}\left(m_{1} \neq m_{2}\right)$ are connected by a string of length $l$ passing through a hole in a horizontal table. The string and mass points move without friction with $m_{1}$ on the table and $m_{2}$ free to move in a vertical line.

If $m_{2}$ is slightly displaced in a vertical direction, small oscillations ensue. Use Lagrange's equations to find the period of these oscillations.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-520.jpg?height=392&width=325&top_left_y=1307&top_left_x=606)

Fig. 2.19.
2023.b.Solution:
$m_{1}$ must have a velocity $v$ perpendicular to the string such that the centripetal force on it is equal to the gravitational force on $m_{2}$ :

$$
\frac{m_{1} v^{2}}{l-d}=m_{2} g
$$

or

$$
v=\sqrt{\frac{m_{2}(l-d) g}{m_{1}}} .
$$

Use a frame of polar coordinates fixed in the horizontal table as shown in Fig. 2.19. $m_{2}$ has $z$-coordinate $-(l-r)$ and thus velocity $\dot{r}$. The Lagrangian of the system is then

$$
L=T-V=\frac{1}{2} m_{1}\left(\dot{r}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}\right)+\frac{1}{2} m_{2} \dot{r}^{2}+m_{2} g(l-r) .
$$

Lagrange's equations give

$$
\begin{gathered}
m_{1} r^{2} \dot{\theta}=\text { constant }, \\
\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right) \ddot{r}-m_{1} r \dot{\theta}^{2}+m_{2} g=0 .
\end{gathered}
$$

At $t=0, r=l-d, v=\sqrt{m_{2}(l-d) g / m_{1}}=v_{0}$, say, so

$$
\dot{\theta}_{0}=\frac{v_{0}}{l-d}=\sqrt{\frac{m_{2}}{m_{1}} \frac{g}{l-d}} .
$$

Hence

$$
m_{1} r^{2} \dot{\theta}=m_{1}(l-d)^{2} \dot{\theta}_{0}=m_{1} \sqrt{\frac{m_{2}}{m_{1}}(l-d)^{3} g},
$$

giving

$$
r \dot{\theta}^{2}=\frac{r^{4} \dot{\theta}^{2}}{r^{3}}=\frac{m_{2}}{m_{1}}\left(\frac{l-d}{r}\right)^{3} g
$$

and

$$
\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right) \ddot{r}-m_{2}\left(\frac{l-d}{r}\right)^{3} g+m_{2} g=0 .
$$

Let $r=(l-d)+\rho$, where $\rho \ll(l-d)$. Then

$$
\ddot{r}=\ddot{\rho}, \quad r^{-3}=(l-d)^{-3}\left(1+\frac{\rho}{l-d}\right)^{-3} \approx(l-d)^{-3}\left(1-\frac{3 \rho}{l-d}\right)
$$

and the above equation becomes

$$
\ddot{\rho}+\frac{3 m_{2} g}{\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right)(l-d)} \rho=0 .
$$

Hence $\rho$ oscillates about $O$, i.e. $r$ oscillates about the value $l-d$, with angular frequency

$$
\omega=\sqrt{\frac{3 m_{2} g}{\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right)(l-d)}},
$$

or period

$$
T=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right)(l-d)}{3 m_{2} g}}
$$

2024.Problem Statement:
Two rods $A B$ and $B C$, each of length $a$ and mass $m$, are frictionlessly joined at $B$ and lie on a frictionless horizontal table. Initially the two rods (i.e. point $A, B, C)$ are collinear. An impulse $\bar{P}$ is applied at point $A$ in a direction perpendicular to the line $A B C$. Find the motion of the rods immediately after the impulse is applied.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-522.jpg?height=293&width=336&top_left_y=1289&top_left_x=592)

Fig. 2.20.
2024.Solution:
As the two rods $A B, B C$ are freely joined at $B$, take coordinates as shown in Fig. $2.20$ and let the coordinates of $B$ be $(x, y)$. Then the center of mass of $B C$ has coordinates 

$$
\left(x+\frac{1}{2} a \sin \theta_{1}, y+\frac{1}{2} a \cos \theta_{1}\right)
$$

and velocity

$$
\left(\dot{x}+\frac{1}{2} a \dot{\theta}_{1} \cos \theta_{1}, \dot{y}-\frac{1}{2} a \dot{\theta}_{1} \sin \theta_{1}\right)
$$

and that of $A B$ has coordinates

$$
\left(x+\frac{1}{2} a \sin \theta_{2}, y+\frac{1}{2} a \cos \theta_{2}\right)
$$

and velocity

$$
\left(\dot{x}+\frac{1}{2} a \dot{\theta}_{2} \cos \theta_{2}, \dot{y}-\frac{1}{2} a \dot{\theta}_{2} \sin \theta_{2}\right) \text {. }
$$

Each rod has a moment of inertia about its center of mass of $m a^{2} / 12$. Hence the total kinetic energy is

$$
\begin{aligned}
T=& \frac{1}{2} m\left[\dot{x}^{2}+\dot{y}^{2}+\frac{1}{4} a^{2} \dot{\theta}_{1}^{2}+a \dot{\theta}_{1}\left(\dot{x} \cos \theta_{1}-\dot{y} \sin \theta_{1}\right)\right]+\frac{1}{24} m a^{2} \dot{\theta}_{1}^{2} \\
&+\frac{1}{2} m\left[\dot{x}^{2}+\dot{y}^{2}+\frac{1}{4} a^{2} \dot{\theta}_{1}^{2}+a \dot{\theta}_{2}\left(\dot{x} \cos \theta_{2}-\dot{y} \sin \theta_{2}\right)\right]+\frac{1}{24} m a^{2} \dot{\theta}_{2}^{2} \\
=& \frac{1}{2} m\left[2\left(\dot{x}^{2}+\dot{y}^{2}\right)+a \dot{x}\left(\dot{\theta}_{1} \cos \theta_{1}+\dot{\theta}_{2} \cos \theta_{2}\right)-a \dot{y}\left(\dot{\theta}_{1} \sin \theta_{1}+\dot{\theta}_{2} \sin \theta_{2}\right)\right] \\
&+\frac{1}{6} m a^{2}\left(\dot{\theta}_{1}^{2}+\dot{\theta}_{2}^{2}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

The impulse $\bar{P}$ is applied at $A$ in a direction perpendicular to the line $A B C$. Thus the virtual moment of the impulse is $\bar{P} \delta\left(y+a \cos \theta_{2}\right)$ and the generalized components of the impulse are

$$
Q_{x}=0, \quad Q_{y}=\bar{P}, \quad Q_{\theta_{1}}=0, \quad Q_{\theta_{2}}=-a \bar{P} \sin \theta_{2} .
$$

Lagrange's equations for impulsive motion are

$$
\left(\frac{\partial T}{\partial \dot{q}_{j}}\right)_{f}-\left(\frac{\partial T}{\partial \dot{q}_{j}}\right)_{i}=Q_{j}
$$

where $i, f$ refer to the initial and final states of the system relative to the application of impulse. Note that at $t=0$ when the impulse is applied, $\theta_{1}=-\pi / 2, \theta_{2}=\pi / 2$. Furthermore, for the initial state, $\dot{\theta}_{1}=\dot{\theta}_{2}=\dot{x}=\dot{y}=$ 0 . As 

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\frac{\partial T}{\partial \dot{x}}=2 m \dot{x}+\frac{1}{2} m a\left(\dot{\theta}_{1} \cos \theta_{1}+\dot{\theta}_{2} \cos \theta_{2}\right) \\
&\frac{\partial T}{\partial \dot{y}}=2 m \dot{y}-\frac{1}{2} m a\left(\dot{\theta}_{1} \sin \theta_{1}+\dot{\theta}_{2} \sin \theta_{2}\right) \\
&\frac{\partial T}{\partial \dot{\theta}_{1}}=\frac{1}{2} m a \dot{x} \cos \theta_{1}-\frac{1}{2} m a \dot{y} \sin \theta_{1}+\frac{1}{3} m a^{2} \dot{\theta}_{1}, \\
&\frac{\partial T}{\partial \dot{\theta}_{2}}=\frac{1}{2} m a \dot{x} \cos \theta_{2}-\frac{1}{2} m a \dot{y} \sin \theta_{2}+\frac{1}{3} m a^{2} \dot{\theta}_{2},
\end{aligned}
$$

Lagrange's equations give

$$
\begin{aligned}
2 m \dot{x} &=0, \\
2 m \dot{y}+\frac{1}{2} m a\left(\dot{\theta}_{1}-\dot{\theta}_{2}\right) &=\bar{P}, \\
\frac{1}{2} m a \dot{y}+\frac{1}{3} m a^{2} \dot{\theta}_{1} &=0, \\
-\frac{1}{2} m a \dot{y}+\frac{1}{3} m a^{2} \dot{\theta}_{2} &=-a \bar{P} .
\end{aligned}
$$

The solution is

$$
\dot{x}=0, \quad \dot{y}=-\frac{\bar{P}}{m}, \quad \dot{\theta}_{1}=\frac{3 \bar{P}}{2 m a}, \quad \dot{\theta}_{2}=-\frac{9 \bar{P}}{2 m a} .
$$

Hence immediately after the application of impulse, the center of mass of $B C$ has velocity

$$
\left(\dot{x}, \dot{y}+\frac{1}{2} a \dot{\theta}_{1}\right)=\left(0,-\frac{\bar{P}}{4 m}\right) \text {, }
$$

and that of $A B$ has velocity

$$
\left(\dot{x}, \dot{y}-\frac{1}{2} a \dot{\theta}_{2}\right)=\left(0, \frac{5 \bar{P}}{4 m}\right) \text {. }
$$

2025.a.Problem Statement:
Consider a particle of mass $m$ moving in a plane under a central force

(assume $k>0$ )

$$
F(r)=-\frac{k}{r^{2}}+\frac{k^{\prime}}{r^{3}}
$$

What is the Lagrangian for this system in terms of the polar coordinates $r, \theta$ and their velocities?
2025.a.Solution:
As

$$
\begin{aligned}
&F(r)=-\frac{k}{r^{2}}+\frac{k^{\prime}}{r^{3}}, \\
&V(r)=-\int_{\infty}^{r} F(r) d r=-\frac{k}{r}+\frac{k^{\prime}}{2 r^{2}} .
\end{aligned}
$$

The Lagrangian is then

$$
L=T-V=\frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{r}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}\right)+\frac{k}{r}-\frac{k^{\prime}}{2 r^{2}} .
$$

2025.c.Problem Statement:
Consider a particle of mass $m$ moving in a plane under a central force

(assume $k>0$ )

$$
F(r)=-\frac{k}{r^{2}}+\frac{k^{\prime}}{r^{3}}
$$

Assume that $l^{2}>-m k^{\prime}$. Find the equation for the orbit, i.e. $r$ as a function of $\theta$.
2025.c.Solution:
As

$$
\begin{aligned}
&F(r)=-\frac{k}{r^{2}}+\frac{k^{\prime}}{r^{3}}, \\
&V(r)=-\int_{\infty}^{r} F(r) d r=-\frac{k}{r}+\frac{k^{\prime}}{2 r^{2}} .
\end{aligned}
$$

The Lagrangian is then

$$
L=T-V=\frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{r}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}\right)+\frac{k}{r}-\frac{k^{\prime}}{2 r^{2}} .
$$Lagrange's equations give the equations of motion

$$
\begin{aligned}
m\left(\ddot{r}-r \dot{\theta}^{2}\right)+\frac{k}{r^{2}}-\frac{k^{\prime}}{r^{3}} &=0, \\
m(r \ddot{\theta}+2 \dot{r} \dot{\theta}) &=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

The second equation has first integral $m r^{2} \dot{\theta}=$ constant. This quantity is the angular momentum of the mass about the origin $l=r \cdot m r \dot{\theta}$.

Let $u=r^{-1}$. As $r=u^{-1}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\dot{r} &=-u^{-2} \frac{d u}{d \theta} \dot{\theta}=-u^{-2} \frac{d u}{d \theta} \frac{l}{m r^{2}}=-\frac{l}{m} \frac{d u}{d \theta}, \\
\ddot{r} &=-\frac{l}{m} \frac{d^{2} u}{d \theta^{2}} \dot{\theta}=-\frac{l^{2}}{m^{2}} u^{2} \frac{d^{2} u}{d \theta^{2}}, \\
m r \dot{\theta}^{2} &=\frac{l^{2}}{m r^{3}}=\frac{l^{2} u^{3}}{m},
\end{aligned}
$$

Eq.
(1) becomes

$$
\frac{d^{2} u}{d \theta^{2}}+\left(1+\frac{m k^{\prime}}{l^{2}}\right) u-\frac{m k}{l^{2}}=0 .
$$

A special solution is

$$
u=\frac{m k}{l^{2}}\left(\frac{l^{2}}{l^{2}+m k^{\prime}}\right)=\frac{m k}{l^{2}+m k^{\prime}},
$$

As $l^{2}>-m k^{\prime}$, i.e. $\frac{m k^{\prime}}{l^{2}}>-1$,

$$
1+\frac{m k^{\prime}}{l^{2}}>0
$$

and the general solution is

$$
u=A \cos \left(\sqrt{1+\frac{m k^{\prime}}{l^{2}}} \theta+\alpha\right)+\frac{m k}{l^{2}+m k^{\prime}},
$$

where $A, \alpha$ are constants. By a suitable choice of coordinates, $\alpha$ can be put to zero. Hence the equation of the trajectory can be written as

$$
r=\left[A \cos \left(\sqrt{1+\frac{m k^{\prime}}{l^{2}}} \theta\right)+\frac{m k}{l^{2}+m k^{\prime}}\right]^{-1}
$$

2026.Problem Statement: A point particle of mass $m$ is constrained to move frictionlessly on the inside surface of a circular wire hoop of radius $r$, uniform density and mass $M$. The hoop is in the $x y$-plane, can roll on a fixed line (the $x$-axis), but does not slide, nor can it lose contact with the $x$-axis. The point particle is acted on by gravity exerting a force along the negative $y$-axis. At $t=0$ suppose the hoop is at rest. At this time the particle is at the top of the hoop and is given a velocity $v_{0}$ along the $x$-axis. What is the velocity $v_{f}$, with respect to the fixed axis, when the particle comes to the bottom of the hoop? Simplify your answer in the limits $m / M \rightarrow 0$ and $M / m \rightarrow 0$.
2026.Solution:
Use a fixed coordinate frame as shown in Fig. $2.21$ and let the coordinates of the center of the hoop be $(x, y)$. Then the mass $m$ has coordinates

$$
(x+r \sin \theta, r+r \cos \theta)
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-527.jpg?height=310&width=386&top_left_y=213&top_left_x=542)

Fig. 2.21.

and velocity

$$
(\dot{x}+r \dot{\theta} \cos \theta,-r \dot{\theta} \sin \theta) \text {. }
$$

As the hoop has moment of inertia $M r^{2}$, the system has kinetic energy

$$
T=\frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{x}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+2 r \dot{x} \dot{\theta} \cos \theta\right)+\frac{1}{2} M \dot{x}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} M r^{2}\left(\frac{\dot{x}}{r}\right)^{2}
$$

and potential energy

$$
V=m g(r+r \cos \theta) .
$$

Hence the Lagrangian is

$$
L=T-V=M \dot{x}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{x}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+2 r \dot{x} \dot{\theta} \cos \theta\right)-m g r(1+\cos \theta) .
$$

As $\partial L / \partial x=0$, Lagrange's equation gives

$$
(2 M+m) \dot{x}+m r \dot{\theta} \cos \theta=\text { constant . }
$$

At $t=0, m$ is at the top of the hoop, $\dot{x}=0, \theta=0, r \dot{\theta}=v_{0}$, giving the value of the constant as $m v_{0}$. When $m$ is at the bottom of the hoop, $\theta=\pi$, the velocity of the mass is

$$
v_{f}=\dot{x}+r \dot{\theta} \cos \pi=\dot{x}-r \dot{\theta},
$$

and Eq.
(1) becomes

$$
2 M \dot{x}+m v_{f}=m v_{0} .
$$

The total energy is conserved so that between these two points we have

$$
M \dot{x}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m v_{f}^{2}=\frac{1}{2} m v_{0}^{2}+2 m g r .
$$

Eliminating $\dot{x}$ between the last two equations gives

$$
(2 M+m) v_{f}^{2}-2 m v_{0} v_{f}-\left[(2 M-m) v_{0}^{2}+8 M g r\right]=0 .
$$

The solutions are

$$
v_{f}=\frac{m v_{0} \pm 2 \sqrt{M^{2} v_{0}^{2}+2(2 M+m) M g r}}{2 M+m} .
$$

In the limit $m / M \rightarrow 0, v_{f} \rightarrow \pm \sqrt{v_{0}^{2}+4 g r}$. The negative sign is to be chosen as for $M \gg m, \dot{x}$ is small and $v_{f} \simeq-r \dot{\theta}$. In the limit $M / m \rightarrow 0$, $v_{f} \rightarrow v_{0}$.

2027.a.Problem Statement:
A particle slides on the inside of a smooth vertical paraboloid of revolution $r^{2}=a z$. Show that the constraint force has a magnitude $=$ constant $\cdot\left(1+\frac{4 r^{2}}{a^{2}}\right)^{-\frac{3}{2}}$. What is its direction?

(1) Set up the Lagrangian function in a spherical coordinate system which is rotating with angular velocity $\omega$ about the $z$-axis.

(2) Show that your Lagrangian has the same form as in a fixed coordinate system with the addition of a velocity-dependent potential $U$ (which gives the centrifugal and Coriolis forces).

(3) Calculate from $U$ the components of the centrifugal and Coriolis forces in the radial $(r)$ and azimuthal $(\phi)$ directions.
2027.a.Solution:
Use cylindrical coordinates $(r, \varphi, z)$ as shown in Fig. 2.22. In Cartesian coordinates the particle, mass $m$, has coordinates

$$
(r \cos \varphi, r \sin \varphi, z),
$$

velocity

$$
(\dot{r} \cos \varphi-r \dot{\varphi} \sin \varphi, \dot{r} \sin \varphi+r \dot{\varphi} \cos \varphi, \dot{z}) \text {, }
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-529.jpg?height=363&width=367&top_left_y=233&top_left_x=629)

Fig. 2.22.

and hence Lagrangian

$$
L=T-V=\frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{r}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\varphi}^{2}+\dot{z}^{2}\right)-m g z .
$$

The constraint equation is

$$
f(r, \varphi, z)=-r^{2}+a z=0
$$

or

$$
-2 r d r+a d z=0 .
$$

Lagrange's equations

$$
\frac{d}{d t} \frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}-\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}}=Q_{i},
$$

where $Q_{i}$ are the generalized forces of constraint, then give, making use of Lagrange's undetermined multiplier $\lambda$,

$$
\begin{gathered}
m \ddot{r}-m r \dot{\varphi}^{2}=-2 r \lambda, \\
m \ddot{z}+m g=a \lambda, \\
m r^{2} \dot{\varphi}=\text { constant }=J, \quad \text { say } .
\end{gathered}
$$

The equation of constraint $z=\frac{r^{2}}{a}$ gives

$$
\dot{z}=\frac{2 r \dot{r}}{a}, \quad \ddot{z}=\frac{2 r \ddot{r}}{a}+\frac{2 \dot{r}^{2}}{a} .
$$

Using Eqs.
(3) and (4), we rewrite the total energy

$$
E=\frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{r}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\varphi}^{2}+\dot{z}^{2}\right)+m g z
$$

which is conserved, as

$$
\dot{r}^{2}=\left(\frac{2 E}{m}-\frac{J^{2}}{m^{2} r^{2}}-\frac{2 g r^{2}}{a}\right)\left(1+\frac{4 r^{2}}{a^{2}}\right)^{-1},
$$

and Eq.
(2) as

$$
\frac{m}{a}\left(2 r \ddot{r}+2 \dot{r}^{2}\right)+m g=a \lambda .
$$

Making use of Eqs.
(1) and (3), this becomes

$$
a \lambda\left(1+\frac{4 r^{2}}{a^{2}}\right)=\frac{2 m \dot{r}^{2}}{a}+m g+\frac{2 J^{2}}{m a r^{2}} .
$$

Expression (5) then reduces it to

$$
\lambda=\left(\frac{4 E}{a^{2}}+\frac{8 J^{2}}{m a^{4}}+\frac{m g}{a}\right)\left(1+\frac{4 r^{2}}{a^{2}}\right)^{-2}=\text { constant } \cdot\left(1+\frac{4 r^{2}}{a^{2}}\right)^{-2} .
$$

The force of constraint is thus

$$
\mathbf{f}=-2 r \lambda \mathbf{e}_{r}+a \lambda \mathbf{e}_{z},
$$

of magnitude

$$
\begin{aligned}
f &=a \lambda \sqrt{1+\frac{4 r^{2}}{a^{2}}} \\
&=\text { constant } \cdot\left(1+\frac{4 r^{2}}{a^{2}}\right)^{-\frac{3}{2}} .
\end{aligned}
$$

This force is in the $r z$-plane and is perpendicular to the inside surface of the paraboloid.
(It makes an angle arctan $(-a / 2 r)$ with the $r$-axis while the slope of the parabola is $2 r / a$ ).

(It makes an angle arctan $(-a / 2 r)$ with the $r$-axis while the slope of the parabola is $2 r / a$ ).As shown in Fig. 2.23, in spherical coordinates $(r, \theta, \varphi)$ an infinitesimal displacement of the particle can be resolved as

$$
\delta \mathbf{r}=(\delta r, r \delta \theta, r \delta \varphi \sin \theta),
$$

and its velocity as

$$
\dot{\mathbf{r}}=(\dot{r}, r \dot{\theta}, r \dot{\varphi} \sin \theta) \text {. }
$$

(1) Suppose the coordinate frame rotates with angular velocity $\omega$ about the $z$-axis. Then the velocity of the particle with respect to a fixed frame IS

$$
\mathbf{v}^{\prime}=\dot{\mathbf{r}}+\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{r},
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-531.jpg?height=409&width=483&top_left_y=240&top_left_x=529)

Fig. 2.23.

so the kinetic energy of the particle is

$$
T=\frac{1}{2} m\left[\dot{\mathbf{r}}^{2}+2 \dot{\mathbf{r}} \cdot \boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{r}+(\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{r})^{2}\right] .
$$

Referring to the rotating frame and using spherical coordinates we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{r} &=(r, 0,0), \\
\boldsymbol{\omega} &=(\omega \cos \theta,-\omega \sin \theta, 0), \\
\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{r} &=(0,0, \omega r \sin \theta), \\
2 \dot{\mathbf{r}} \cdot \boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{r} &=2 \omega r^{2} \dot{\varphi} \sin ^{2} \theta, \\
(\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{r})^{2} &=\omega^{2} r^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta, \\
\dot{\mathbf{r}}^{2} &=\dot{r}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\varphi}^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
L &=T-V \\
&=\frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{r}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\varphi}^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta+2 \omega r^{2} \dot{\varphi} \sin ^{2} \theta+\omega^{2} r^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta\right)-V(r) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Note that this is the Lagrangian of the particle with respect to a fixed frame, which is to be used in Lagrange's equations, using coordinates referring to the rotating frame.

(2) The Lagrangian can be written as

$$
L=\frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{r}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\varphi}^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta\right)-U-V
$$

with 

$$
U=-\frac{1}{2} m\left(2 \omega r^{2} \dot{\varphi} \sin ^{2} \theta+\omega^{2} r^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta\right) .
$$

Thus $L$ has the form of the Lagrangian the particle would have if the coordinate frame referred to were fixed and the particle were under a potential $U+V$, i.e. with an additional velocity-dependent potential $U$.

(3) Write the Lagrangian as

$$
L=T^{\prime}-U-V=L^{\prime}-U,
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
T^{\prime} &=\frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{r}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\varphi}^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta\right) \\
L^{\prime} &=T^{\prime}-V
\end{aligned}
$$

are the kinetic and Lagrangian the particle would have if the coordinate frame referred to were fixed. Lagrange's equations

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}}=0
$$

can be written as

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L^{\prime}}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}\right)-\frac{\partial L^{\prime}}{\partial q_{i}}=\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial U}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}\right)-\frac{\partial U}{\partial q_{i}} \equiv Q_{i}^{\prime} .
$$

$Q_{i}^{\prime}$ are the generalized forces that have to be introduced because of the fact that the frame referred to is rotating. Differentiating $U$ we find

$$
\begin{aligned}
Q_{r}^{\prime} &=2 m \omega r \dot{\varphi} \sin ^{2} \theta+m \omega^{2} r \sin ^{2} \theta, \\
Q_{\theta}^{\prime} &=2 m \omega r^{2} \dot{\varphi} \sin \theta \cos \theta+m \omega^{2} r^{2} \sin \theta \cos \theta, \\
Q_{\varphi}^{\prime} &=-2 m \omega r \dot{r} \sin ^{2} \theta-2 m \omega r^{2} \dot{\theta} \sin \theta \cos \theta .
\end{aligned}
$$

The generalized components $Q_{j}^{\prime}$ of a force $\mathbf{F}^{\prime}$ are defined by

$$
\mathbf{F}^{\prime} \cdot \delta \mathbf{r}=\sum_{j} Q_{j}^{\prime} \delta q_{j},
$$

i.e.

$$
F_{r} \delta r+F_{\theta} r \delta \theta+F_{\varphi} r \sin \theta \delta \varphi=Q_{r} \delta r+Q_{\theta} \delta \theta+Q_{\varphi} \delta \varphi .
$$

Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
&F_{r}=Q_{r}^{\prime}=2 m \omega r \dot{\varphi} \sin ^{2} \theta+m \omega^{2} r \sin ^{2} \theta, \\
&F_{\theta}=\frac{Q_{\theta}^{\prime}}{r}=2 m \omega r \dot{\varphi} \sin \theta \cos \theta+m \omega^{2} r \sin \theta \cos \theta, \\
&F_{\varphi}=\frac{Q_{\varphi}^{\prime}}{r \sin \theta}=-2 m \omega \dot{r} \sin \theta-2 m \omega r \dot{\theta} \cos \theta
\end{aligned}
$$

are the components of the centrifugal and Coriolis forces in the directions of $\mathbf{e}_{r}, \mathbf{e}_{\theta}, \mathbf{e}_{\varphi}$. Note that the velocity-dependent terms are due to the Coriolis force while the remaining terms are due the centrifugal force.

2028.b.Problem Statement:
A mass $M$ is constrained to slide without friction on the track $A B$ as shown in Fig. 2.24. A mass $m$ is connected to $M$ by a massless inextensible string.
(Make small angle approximation.)

Find the normal coordinates (and describe them).

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-533.jpg?height=448&width=390&top_left_y=1379&top_left_x=491)

Fig. 2.24.
2028.b.Solution:
Use coordinates as shown in Fig. 2.24. $M$ and $m$ have coordinates

$$
(x, 0), \quad(x+b \sin \theta,-b \cos \theta)
$$

respectively. The Lagrangian of the system is then

$$
L=T-V=\frac{1}{2} M \dot{x}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{x}^{2}+b^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+2 b \dot{x} \dot{\theta} \cos \theta\right)+m g b \cos \theta
$$

For small oscillations, $\theta$ and $\dot{\theta}$ are small quantities and we have the approximate Lagrangian

$$
L=\frac{1}{2} M \dot{x}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{x}^{2}+b^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+2 b \dot{x} \dot{\theta}\right)+m g b\left(1-\frac{1}{2} \theta^{2}\right) \text {. }
$$

Lagrange's equations

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}}=0
$$

then give $(m+M) \dot{x}+m b \dot{\theta}=C$, a constant, $\ddot{x}+b \ddot{\theta}+g \theta=0$.

In the above, the first equation can be written as

$$
(m+M) \dot{\eta}=C
$$

by setting

$$
\eta=x+\frac{m b \theta}{m+M} .
$$

As $(m+M) \ddot{x}+m b \ddot{\theta}=0$, the second equation can be written as

$$
\frac{M b \ddot{\theta}}{m+M}+g \theta=0 .
$$

The two new equations of motion are now independent of each other. Hence $\eta$ and $\theta$ are the normal coordinates of the system. The center of mass of the system occurs at a distance $\frac{m b}{m+M}$ from $M$ along the string. Hence $\eta$ is the $x$-coordinate of the center of mass. Equation (1) shows that the horizontal motion of the center of mass is uniform. The other normal coordinate, $\theta$, is the angle the string makes with the vertical.

2029.b.Problem Statement:
A simple pendulum is attached to a support which is driven horizontally with time as shown in Fig. $2.25$.

Find the equation of motion for $\theta$.
2029.b.Solution:
The mass $m$ has coordinates

$$
\left(y_{s}+l \sin \theta,-l \cos \theta\right)
$$

and velocity

$$
\left(\dot{y}_{s}+l \dot{\theta} \cos \theta, l \dot{\theta} \sin \theta\right) .
$$

Hence the Lagrangian is

$$
L=T-V=\frac{m}{2}\left(\dot{y}_{s}^{2}+l^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+2 l \dot{y}_{s} \dot{\theta} \cos \theta\right)+m g l \cos \theta .
$$

Lagrange's equation

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\theta}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial \theta}=0
$$

gives

$$
l \ddot{\theta}+\ddot{y}_{s} \cos \theta+g \sin \theta=0 .
$$

2029.c.Problem Statement:
A simple pendulum is attached to a support which is driven horizontally with time as shown in Fig. $2.25$.

For small angular displacements and a sinusoidal motion of the support

$$
y=y_{0} \cos (\omega t) .
$$

Find the steady-state solution to the equation of motion.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-535.jpg?height=345&width=320&top_left_y=1430&top_left_x=571)

Fig. 2.25.
2029.c.Solution:
The mass $m$ has coordinates

$$
\left(y_{s}+l \sin \theta,-l \cos \theta\right)
$$

and velocity

$$
\left(\dot{y}_{s}+l \dot{\theta} \cos \theta, l \dot{\theta} \sin \theta\right) .
$$

Hence the Lagrangian is

$$
L=T-V=\frac{m}{2}\left(\dot{y}_{s}^{2}+l^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+2 l \dot{y}_{s} \dot{\theta} \cos \theta\right)+m g l \cos \theta .
$$

Lagrange's equation

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\theta}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial \theta}=0
$$

gives

$$
l \ddot{\theta}+\ddot{y}_{s} \cos \theta+g \sin \theta=0 .
$$For $y_{s}=y_{0} \cos (\omega t)$ and small $\theta$, the above reduces to

$$
\ddot{\theta}+\omega_{0}^{2} \theta=\frac{y_{0}}{l} \omega^{2} \cos (\omega t)
$$

with $\omega_{0}=\sqrt{\frac{9}{l}}$. A particular solution is obtained by putting $\theta=A \cos (\omega t)$. Substitution gives

$$
A=\frac{y_{0} \omega^{2}}{l\left(\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}\right)} .
$$

The general solution is then

$$
\theta=\frac{y_{0} \omega^{2} \cos (\omega t)}{l\left(\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}\right)}+A \cos \left(\omega_{0} t\right)+B \sin \left(\omega_{0} t\right) .
$$

Resonance will take place if $\omega_{0} \approx \omega$. As long as $\omega \neq \omega_{0}$, the motion of the system is steady.

2030.a.Problem Statement:
A solid homogeneous cylinder of radius $r$ and mass $m$ rolls without slipping on the inside of a stationary larger cylinder of radius $R$ as shown in Fig. 2.26.

If the small cylinder starts at rest from an angle $\theta_{0}$ from the vertical, what is the total downward force it exerts on the outer cylinder as it passes through the lowest point?

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-537.jpg?height=396&width=375&top_left_y=639&top_left_x=592)

Fig. 2.26.
2030.a.Solution:
Take coordinates as shown in Fig. 2.26. The center of mass of the rolling cylinder has coordinates

$$
((R-r) \sin \theta,-(R-r) \cos \theta)
$$

and velocity

$$
((R-r) \dot{\theta} \cos \theta,(R-r) \dot{\theta} \sin \theta) \text {. }
$$

The cylinder has moment of inertia $\frac{1}{2} m r^{2}$ and the condition of rolling without slipping means

$$
(R-r) \theta=r \varphi .
$$

Initially $\dot{\theta}=0$ at $\theta=\theta_{0}$. Suppose the cylinder has velocity $v$ when it passes through the lowest point $\theta=0$. Conservation of the total energy $T+V$ gives

$$
\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}+\frac{1}{4} m r^{2} \dot{\phi}^{2}-m g(R-r)=-m g(R-r) \cos \theta_{0},
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \text { or, with } r \dot{\varphi}=(R-r) \dot{\theta}, v=(R-r) \dot{\theta} \text {, } \\
& m v^{2}=\frac{4}{3}(R-r)\left(1-\cos \theta_{0}\right) m g .
\end{aligned}
$$

The force exerted by the cylinder on the outer cylinder as it passes through the lowest point is vertically downward and has magnitude

$$
\begin{aligned}
m g+m(R-r) \dot{\theta}^{2} &=m g+\frac{m v^{2}}{(R-r)} \\
&=m g+\frac{4}{3}\left(1-\cos \theta_{0}\right) m g \\
&=\frac{1}{3} m g\left(7-4 \cos \theta_{0}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

and velocity

$$
\begin{aligned}
L=T-V &=\frac{1}{2} m(R-r)^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+\frac{1}{4} m r^{2} \dot{\varphi}^{2}+m g(R-r) \cos \theta \\
&=\frac{3}{4} m(R-r)^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+m g(R-r) \cos \theta .
\end{aligned}

$$

2031.b.Problem Statement:
A bead of mass $m$ is constrained to move on a hoop of radius $b$. The hoop rotates with constant angular velocity $\omega$ around a vertical axis which coincides with a diameter of the hoop.

Find the critical angular velocity $\Omega$ below which the bottom of the hoop provides a stable equilibrium position for the bead.
2031.b.Solution:
Use a rotating frame attached to the hoop as shown in Fig. 2.27. The mass $m$ has coordinates $(b \sin \theta, b \cos \theta)$ and velocity $(b \dot{\theta} \cos \theta,-b \dot{\theta} \sin \theta)$ referring to the rotating frame. In addition to the potential $m g b \cos \theta$ due to gravity, a potential due to a fictitious centrifugal force $m x \omega^{2}$ has to be introduced. As

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-539.jpg?height=323&width=286&top_left_y=994&top_left_x=594)

Fig. 2.27.

$$
m x \omega^{2}=-\frac{\partial U}{\partial x},
$$

we can take

$$
U=-\frac{1}{2} m \omega^{2} x^{2}=-\frac{1}{2} m \omega^{2} b^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta .
$$

Hence

$$
L=T-U-V=\frac{1}{2} m b^{2}\left(\dot{\theta}^{2}+\omega^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta\right)-m g b \cos \theta .
$$

Lagrange's equation

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\theta}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial \theta}=0
$$

then gives

$$
b \ddot{\theta}-b \omega^{2} \sin \theta \cos \theta-g \sin \theta=0 \text {. }
$$

At the bottom of the hoop, $\theta=\pi$. Let $\theta=\pi+\alpha$, where $\alpha$ is a small quantity. As

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\sin \theta=\sin (\pi+\alpha)=-\sin \alpha \approx-\alpha, \\
&\cos \theta=\cos (\pi+\alpha)=-\cos \alpha \approx-1,
\end{aligned}
$$

the equation of motion becomes

$$
\ddot{\alpha}+\left(\frac{g}{b}-\omega^{2}\right) \alpha=0 .
$$

For $\alpha$ to oscillate about the equilibrium position, i.e. for the equilibrium to be stable, we require

$$
\frac{g}{b}-\omega^{2}>0, \quad \text { i.e. } \omega<\sqrt{\frac{g}{b}} .
$$

Hence for stable equilibrium, $\omega$ must be smaller than a critical angular frequency $\Omega=\sqrt{\frac{g}{b}}$.

2031.c.Problem Statement:
A bead of mass $m$ is constrained to move on a hoop of radius $b$. The hoop rotates with constant angular velocity $\omega$ around a vertical axis which coincides with a diameter of the hoop.

Find the stable equilibrium position for $\omega>\Omega$.
2031.c.Solution:
Use a rotating frame attached to the hoop as shown in Fig. 2.27. The mass $m$ has coordinates $(b \sin \theta, b \cos \theta)$ and velocity $(b \dot{\theta} \cos \theta,-b \dot{\theta} \sin \theta)$ referring to the rotating frame. In addition to the potential $m g b \cos \theta$ due to gravity, a potential due to a fictitious centrifugal force $m x \omega^{2}$ has to be introduced. As

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-539.jpg?height=323&width=286&top_left_y=994&top_left_x=594)

Fig. 2.27.

$$
m x \omega^{2}=-\frac{\partial U}{\partial x},
$$

we can take

$$
U=-\frac{1}{2} m \omega^{2} x^{2}=-\frac{1}{2} m \omega^{2} b^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta .
$$

Hence

$$
L=T-U-V=\frac{1}{2} m b^{2}\left(\dot{\theta}^{2}+\omega^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta\right)-m g b \cos \theta .
$$

Lagrange's equation

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\theta}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial \theta}=0
$$

then gives

$$
b \ddot{\theta}-b \omega^{2} \sin \theta \cos \theta-g \sin \theta=0 \text {. }
$$

At the bottom of the hoop, $\theta=\pi$. Let $\theta=\pi+\alpha$, where $\alpha$ is a small quantity. As

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\sin \theta=\sin (\pi+\alpha)=-\sin \alpha \approx-\alpha, \\
&\cos \theta=\cos (\pi+\alpha)=-\cos \alpha \approx-1,
\end{aligned}
$$

the equation of motion becomes

$$
\ddot{\alpha}+\left(\frac{g}{b}-\omega^{2}\right) \alpha=0 .
$$

For $\alpha$ to oscillate about the equilibrium position, i.e. for the equilibrium to be stable, we require

$$
\frac{g}{b}-\omega^{2}>0, \quad \text { i.e. } \omega<\sqrt{\frac{g}{b}} .
$$

Hence for stable equilibrium, $\omega$ must be smaller than a critical angular frequency $\Omega=\sqrt{\frac{g}{b}}$.At equilibrium, $\ddot{\theta}=0$ and the equation of motion becomes

$$
b \omega^{2} \sin \theta \cos \theta+g \sin \theta=0 .
$$

Having considered the case $\theta=0$ in (b), we can take $\sin \theta \neq 0$ and so the above gives

$$
\cos \theta_{0}=-\frac{g}{b \omega^{2}}
$$

for the other equilibrium position.

To test the stability of this equilibrium, let $\beta=\theta-\theta_{0}$, where $\beta$ is a small quantity. As

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\sin \theta=\sin \left(\theta_{0}+\beta\right) \approx \sin \theta_{0}+\beta \cos \theta_{0}, \\
&\cos \theta=\cos \left(\theta_{0}+\beta\right) \approx \cos \theta_{0}-\beta \sin \theta_{0},
\end{aligned}
$$

the equation of motion becomes

$$
b \ddot{\beta}-b \omega^{2} \sin \theta_{0} \cos \theta_{0}-b \omega^{2}\left(\cos ^{2} \theta_{0}-\sin ^{2} \theta_{0}\right) \beta-g \sin \theta_{0}-g \beta \cos \theta_{0}=0,
$$

i.e.

$$
\ddot{\beta}-\omega^{2}\left(2 \cos ^{2} \theta_{0}-1\right) \beta-\frac{g}{b} \beta \cos \theta_{0}=0,
$$

or, using the value of $\cos \theta_{0}$,

$$
\ddot{\beta}+\left(1-\frac{g^{2}}{b^{2} \omega^{2}}\right) \beta=0 .
$$

Hence the equilibrium is stable since as $\omega>\Omega, 1-\frac{g^{2}}{b^{2} \omega^{2}}>0$.

2032.b.Problem Statement:
Consider the longitudinal motion of the system of masses and springs illustrated in Fig. 2.28, with $M>m$.

If the left-hand mass receives an impulse $P_{0}$ at $t=0$, find the motion of the left-hand mass as a function of time.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-541.jpg?height=95&width=417&top_left_y=1231&top_left_x=523)

Fig. 2.28.
2032.b.Solution:
Let $x_{1}, x_{2}, x_{3}$ be the displacements of the three masses, counting from the left, from their equilibrium positions. The Lagrangian of the system is

$$
L=T-V=\frac{1}{2} M \dot{x}_{1}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m \dot{x}_{2}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} M \dot{x}_{3}^{2}-\frac{1}{2} k\left(x_{2}-x_{1}\right)^{2}-\frac{1}{2} k\left(x_{3}-x_{2}\right)^{2} .
$$

Lagrange's equations

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}}=0
$$

then give

$$
\begin{aligned}
&M \ddot{x}_{1}+k\left(x_{1}-x_{2}\right)=0, \\
&m \ddot{x}_{2}+k\left(x_{2}-x_{1}\right)+k\left(x_{2}-x_{3}\right)=0, \\
&M \ddot{x}_{3}+k\left(x_{3}-x_{2}\right)=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

Try a solution of the type

$$
x_{i}=x_{i 0} e^{i \omega t} .
$$

Substitution gives

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(k-\omega^{2} M\right) x_{10}-k x_{20} &=0 \\
-k x_{10}+\left(2 k-\omega^{2} m\right) x_{20}-k x_{30} &=0 \\
-k x_{20}+\left(k-\omega^{2} M\right) x_{30} &=0
\end{aligned}
$$

For a solution where not all amplitudes vanish, we require

$$
\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
k-\omega^{2} M & -k & 0 \\
-k & 2 k-\omega^{2} m & -k \\
0 & -k & k-\omega^{2} M
\end{array}\right|=0
$$

which has solutions

$$
\omega=0, \quad \pm \sqrt{\frac{k}{M}}, \quad \pm \sqrt{\frac{k}{m}\left(1+\frac{2 M}{m}\right)} .
$$

Hence the system has three normal-mode (angular) frequencies

$$
\omega_{1}=0, \quad \omega_{2}=\sqrt{\frac{k}{M}}, \quad \omega_{3}=\sqrt{\frac{k}{m}\left(1+\frac{2 M}{m}\right)} .
$$

For $\omega=\omega_{1}$, Eqs.
(2) give

$$
x_{10}=x_{20}=x_{30}, \quad \text { or } \quad x_{1}=x_{2}=x_{3} \text {. }
$$

Equations (1) then give

$$
x_{1}=x_{2}=x_{3}=a t+b,
$$

where $a, b$ are constants, showing that in this mode the three masses undergo translation as a rigid body without oscillation.

For $\omega=\omega_{2}$, Eqs.
(2) give

$$
x_{2}=0, \quad x_{3}=-x_{1},
$$

and Eqs.
(1) give

$$
\ddot{x}_{1}+\omega_{2}^{2} x_{1}=0, \quad \ddot{x}_{3}+\omega_{2}^{2} x_{3}=0 .
$$

The solutions are then

$$
\begin{aligned}
&x_{1}=A \sin \left(\omega_{2} t\right)+B \cos \left(\omega_{2} t\right) \\
&x_{2}=0 \\
&x_{3}=-x_{1} .
\end{aligned}
$$

In this mode the middle mass stays stationary while the two end masses oscillate harmonically exactly out of phase with each other.

For $\omega=\omega_{3}$, we have, similarly,

$$
\begin{aligned}
&x_{1}=C \sin \left(\omega_{3} t\right)+D \cos \left(\omega_{3} t\right), \\
&x_{2}=-\frac{2 M x_{1}}{m}, \\
&x_{3}=x_{1} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Here the two outer masses oscillate with the same amplitude and phase, while the inner one oscillates out of phase and with a different amplitude.

The general longitudinal motion of the system is some linear conibination of the normal-modes:

$$
\begin{aligned}
&x_{1}=a t+b+A \sin \left(\omega_{2} t\right)+B \cos \left(\omega_{2} t\right)+C \sin \left(\omega_{3} t\right)+D \cos \left(\omega_{3} t\right), \\
&x_{2}=a t+b-\frac{2 M}{m}\left[C \sin \left(\omega_{3} t\right)+D \cos \left(\omega_{3} t\right)\right], \\
&x_{3}=a t+b-A \sin \left(\omega_{2} t\right)-B \cos \left(\omega_{2} t\right)+C \sin \left(\omega_{3} t\right)+D \cos \left(\omega_{3} t\right),
\end{aligned}
$$

The initial conditions that at $t=0$,

$$
x_{1}=x_{2}=x_{3}=0, \quad \dot{x}_{1}=\frac{P_{0}}{m}, \quad \dot{x}_{2}=\dot{x}_{3}=0
$$

then give 

$$
\begin{aligned}
a &=\frac{P_{0}}{m+2 M}, \\
A &=\frac{P_{0}}{2 M \omega_{2}}, \\
C &=\frac{P_{0} m}{2 M(m+2 M) \omega_{3}}, \\
b &=B=D=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the motion of the left-hand mass is given by

$$
x_{1}=P_{0}\left[\frac{t}{m+2 M}+\frac{\sin \left(\omega_{2} t\right)}{2 M \omega_{2}}+\frac{m \sin \left(\omega_{3} t\right)}{2 M(m+2 M) \omega_{3}}\right] \text {. }
$$
2032.b.Final Answer: $$P_{0}\left[\frac{t}{m+2 M}+\frac{\sin \left(\omega_{2} t\right)}{2 M \omega_{2}}+\frac{m \sin \left(\omega_{3} t\right)}{2 M(m+2 M) \omega_{3}}\right]$$

2033.b.Problem Statement:
Two pendulums of equal length $l$ and equal mass $m$ are coupled by a massless spring of constant $k$ as shown in Fig. 2.29. The unstretched length of the spring is equal to the distance between the supports.

Find the normal coordinates and frequencies of small vibrations about equilibrium.
2033.b.Solution:
Assume the masses are constrained to move in a vertical plane. Let the distance between the two supports be $d$, which is also the unstretched length of the spring, and use Cartesian coordinates as shown in Fig. 2.29. The masses have coordinates

$$
\left(l \sin \theta_{1},-l \cos \theta_{1}\right), \quad\left(d+l \sin \theta_{2},-l \cos \theta_{2}\right)
$$

and velocities

$$
\left(l \dot{\theta}_{1} \cos \theta_{1}, l \dot{\theta}_{1} \sin \theta_{1}\right), \quad\left(l \dot{\theta}_{2} \cos \theta_{2}, l \dot{\theta}_{2} \sin \theta_{2}\right),
$$

respectively. The length of the spring is the distance between the two masses:

$$
\sqrt{\left(d+l \sin \theta_{2}-l \sin \theta_{1}\right)^{2}+\left(l \cos \theta_{2}-l \cos \theta_{1}\right)^{2}} .
$$

Hence the Lagrangian of the system is

$$

L=& T-V=\frac{1}{2} m l^{2}\left(\dot{\theta}_{1}^{2}+\dot{\theta}_{2}^{2}\right)+m g l\left(\cos \theta_{1}+\cos \theta_{2}\right) \\
&-\frac{1}{2} k\left(\sqrt{d^{2}+2 d l\left(\sin \theta_{2}-\sin \theta_{1}\right)+2 l^{2}-2 l^{2} \cos \left(\theta_{2}-\theta_{1}\right)}-d\right)^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

534

Problems \& Solutions on Mechanics

As

$$
\begin{aligned}

& =m g l \sin \theta_{1}-k\left(\sqrt{d^{2}+2 d l\left(\sin \theta_{2}-\sin \theta_{1}\right)+2 l^{2}-2 l^{2} \cos \left(\theta_{2}-\theta_{1}\right)}-d\right) \\
& \times \frac{d l \cos \theta_{1}+l^{2} \sin \left(\theta_{2}-\theta_{1}\right)}{\sqrt{d^{2}+2 d l\left(\sin \theta_{2}-\sin \theta_{1}\right)+2 l^{2}-2 l^{2} \cos \left(\theta_{2}-\theta_{1}\right)}} \\
& \approx m g l \theta_{1}-k l\left[\sqrt{d^{2}+2 d l\left(\theta_{2}-\theta_{1}\right)}-d\right] \times \frac{d+l\left(\theta_{2}-\theta_{1}\right)}{\sqrt{d^{2}+2 d l\left(\theta_{2}-\theta_{1}\right)}} \\
& \approx m g l \theta_{1}-k l\left(1-\frac{1}{\sqrt{1+\frac{2 l\left(\theta_{2}-\theta_{1}\right)}{d}}}\right)\left[d+l\left(\theta_{2}-\theta_{1}\right)\right] \\
& \approx m g l \theta_{1}-k l\left[\frac{l\left(\theta_{2}-\theta_{1}\right)}{d}\right]\left[d+l\left(\theta_{2}-\theta_{1}\right)\right] \\
& \approx m g l \theta_{1}-k l^{2}\left(\theta_{2}-\theta_{1}\right),
\end{aligned}
$$

neglecting second and higher order terms in $\theta_{1}, \theta_{2}$ which are small quantities. Similarly,

$$
-\frac{\partial L}{\partial \theta_{2}}=m g l \theta_{2}+k l^{2}\left(\theta_{2}-\theta_{1}\right) .
$$

Thus the equations of motion for small oscillations are

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\ddot{\theta}_{1}+\frac{g \theta_{1}}{l}-\frac{k\left(\theta_{2}-\theta_{1}\right)}{m}=0, \\
&\ddot{\theta}_{2}+\frac{g \theta_{2}}{l}+\frac{k\left(\theta_{2}-\theta_{1}\right)}{m}=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

Let

$$
\eta=\frac{1}{2}\left(\theta_{1}+\theta_{2}\right), \quad \xi=\frac{1}{2}\left(\theta_{1}-\theta_{2}\right)
$$

and the above give

$$
\begin{array}{r}
\ddot{\eta}+\frac{g \eta}{l}=0, \\
\ddot{\xi}+\left(\frac{g}{l}+\frac{2 k}{m}\right) \xi=0 .
\end{array}
$$

These show that $\eta$ and $\xi$ are the normal coordinates with the corresponding normal (angular) frequencies

$$
\omega_{1}=\sqrt{\frac{g}{l}}, \quad \omega_{2}=\sqrt{\frac{g}{l}+\frac{2 k}{m}} .
$$
