2036.a.Problem Statement:
Find the Lagrangian equations of motion for the coplanar double oscillator shown in Fig. $2.32$ in the vibration limit, assuming massless strings or connecting rods. From them find the normal frequencies of the system.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-552.jpg?height=384&width=199&top_left_y=215&top_left_x=675)

Fig. 2.33.
2036.a.Solution:
The coordinates of $m_{1}, m_{2}$ are

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\left(l_{1} \sin \theta_{1},-l_{1} \cos \theta_{1}\right) \\
&\left(l_{1} \sin \theta_{1}+l_{2} \sin \theta_{2},-l_{1} \cos \theta_{1}-l_{2} \cos \theta_{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

and their velocities are

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\left(l_{1} \dot{\theta}_{1} \cos \theta_{1}, l_{1} \dot{\theta}_{1} \sin \theta_{1}\right) \\
&\left(l_{1} \dot{\theta}_{1} \cos \theta_{1}+l_{2} \dot{\theta}_{2} \cos \theta_{2}, l_{1} \dot{\theta}_{1} \sin \theta_{1}+l_{2} \dot{\theta}_{2} \sin \theta_{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

respectively. The Lagrangian of the system is then

$$
\begin{aligned}
L=& T-V=\frac{1}{2} m_{1}\left[l_{1}^{2} \dot{\theta}_{1}^{2}+l_{2}^{2} \dot{\theta}_{2}^{2}+2 l_{1} l_{2} \dot{\theta}_{1} \dot{\theta}_{2} \cos \left(\theta_{1}-\theta_{2}\right)\right] \\
&+m_{1} g l_{1} \cos \theta_{1}+m_{2} g\left(l_{1} \cos \theta_{1}+l_{2} \cos \theta_{2}\right) \\
\approx & \frac{1}{2}\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right) l_{1}^{2} \dot{\theta}_{1}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m_{2}\left(l_{2}^{2} \dot{\theta}_{2}^{2}+2 l_{1} l_{2} \dot{\theta}_{1} \dot{\theta}_{2}\right) \\
&+\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right) g l_{1}\left(1-\frac{\theta_{1}^{2}}{2}\right)+m_{2} g l_{2}\left(1-\frac{\theta_{2}^{2}}{2}\right),
\end{aligned}
$$

neglecting terms higher than second order in the small quantities $\theta_{1}, \theta_{2}$ in the small vibration limit. Lagrange's equations

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}}=0
$$

then give 

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\ddot{\theta}_{1}+\left(\frac{m_{2}}{m_{1}+m_{2}}\right) \frac{l_{2}}{l_{1}} \ddot{\theta}_{2}+\frac{g}{l_{1}} \theta_{1}=0, \\
&\ddot{\theta}_{1}+\frac{l_{2}}{l_{1}} \ddot{\theta}_{2}+\frac{g}{l_{1}} \theta_{2}=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

Let $\theta_{1}=\theta_{10} e^{i \omega t}, \theta_{2}=\theta_{20} e^{i \omega t}$ and obtain the secular equation

$$
\left|\begin{array}{cc}
\frac{g}{l_{1}}-\omega^{2} & -\frac{m_{2} l_{2} \omega^{2}}{\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right) l_{1}} \\
-\omega^{2} & \frac{g-l_{2} \omega^{2}}{l_{1}}
\end{array}\right|=0,
$$

or

$$
\left(\frac{m_{1}}{m_{1}+m_{2}}\right) l_{1} l_{2} \omega^{4}-g\left(l_{1}+l_{2}\right) \omega^{2}+g^{2}=0 .
$$

The normal frequencies $\omega_{1}, \omega_{2}$ are given by the solutions of this equation:

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\left.\begin{array}{c}
\omega_{1}^{2} \\
\omega_{2}^{2}
\end{array}\right\}=\frac{g}{2 m_{1} l_{1} l_{2}} \\
&\times\left[\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right)\left(l_{2}+l_{2}\right) \pm \sqrt{\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right)^{2}\left(l_{1}+l_{2}\right)^{2}-4\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right) m_{1} l_{1} l_{2}}\right] .
\end{aligned}
$$
2036.a.Final Answer: $$\frac{g}{2 m_{1} l_{1} l_{2}} \times\left[\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right)\left(l_{2}+l_{2}\right) \pm \sqrt{\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right)^{2}\left(l_{1}+l_{2}\right)^{2}-4\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right) m_{1} l_{1} l_{2}}\right]$$

2037.Problem Statement: A particle in an isotropic three-dimensional harmonic oscillator potential has a natural angular frequency $\omega_{0}$. Find its vibration frequencies if it is charged and is simultaneously acted on by uniform magnetic and electric fields. Discuss your result in the weak and strong field limits.
2037.Solution:
Assume that the uniform magnetic and electric fields, $B$ and $E$, are mutually perpendicular and take their directions as along the $z$ - and $x$-axes respectively. Then as

$$
B \mathbf{k}=\nabla \times \mathbf{A}, \quad E \mathbf{i}=-\nabla \Phi,
$$

we can take the vector and scalar potentials as

$$
\mathbf{A}=\frac{1}{2}(-B y \mathbf{i}+B x \mathbf{j}), \quad \Phi=-E x .
$$

As the particle is an isotropic harmonic oscillator of natural augular frequency $\omega_{0}$ and has charge $e$, say, its potential energy is

$$
V=\frac{1}{2} m \omega_{0}^{2} r^{2}+e \Phi-e \dot{\mathbf{r}} \cdot \mathbf{A},
$$

where $\mathbf{r}=(x, y, z)$ is the displacement of the particle from the origin, in $\mathrm{SI}$ units. Hence the Lagrangian is

$$
\begin{aligned}
L=T-V=& \frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{x}^{2}+\dot{y}^{2}+\dot{z}^{2}\right)-\frac{1}{2} m \omega_{0}^{2}\left(x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}\right) \\
&+e E x+\frac{1}{2} e B(-\dot{x} y+x \dot{y}) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Lagrange's equations

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}}=0 .
$$

then give

$$
\begin{aligned}
\ddot{x}+\omega_{0}^{2} x-\frac{e B \dot{y}}{m}-\frac{e E}{m} &=0, \\
\ddot{y}+\omega_{0}^{2} y+\frac{e B \dot{x}}{m} &=0, \\
\ddot{z}+\omega_{0}^{2} z &=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

The last equation shows that the vibration in the $z$-direction takes place with the natural angular frequency $\omega_{0}$. Letting $x=x^{\prime}+\frac{e E}{m \omega_{0}^{2}}$, the first two equations become

$$
\begin{gathered}
\ddot{x}^{\prime}+\omega_{0}^{2} x^{\prime}-\frac{e B \dot{y}}{m}=0, \\
\ddot{y}+\omega_{0}^{2} y+\frac{e B \dot{x}^{\prime}}{m}=0 .
\end{gathered}
$$

Try a solution of the type

$$
x^{\prime}=A^{\prime} e^{i \omega t}, \quad y=B^{\prime} e^{i \omega t}
$$

and we obtain the matrix equation

$$
\left(\begin{array}{cc}
\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2} & -\frac{i e B \omega}{m} \\
\frac{i e B \omega}{m} & \omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
A^{\prime} \\
B^{\prime}
\end{array}\right)=0 .
$$

The secular equation

$$
\left|\begin{array}{cc}
\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2} & -\frac{i e B \omega}{m} \\
\frac{i e B \omega}{m} & \omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}
\end{array}\right|=\left(\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}\right)^{2}-\left(\frac{e B \omega}{m}\right)^{2}=0
$$

then gives

which has two positive roots

$$
\omega^{2} \pm \frac{e B \omega}{m}-\omega_{0}^{2}=0
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\omega_{+}=\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{e B}{m}+\sqrt{\left(\frac{e B}{m}\right)^{2}+4 \omega_{0}^{2}}\right), \\
&\omega_{-}=\frac{1}{2}\left(-\frac{e B}{m}+\sqrt{\left(\frac{e B}{m}\right)^{2}+4 \omega_{0}^{2}}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the three normal-mode angular frequencies are $\omega_{0}, \omega_{+}$and $\omega_{-}$. Note that the last two modes of oscillations are caused by the magnetic field alone, whereas the electric field only causes a displacement $\frac{e E}{m \omega_{0}^{2}}$ along its direction.

For weak fields, $\frac{e B}{m} \ll \omega_{0}$, we have

$$
\omega_{+}=\omega_{0}+\frac{e B}{2 m}, \quad \omega_{-}=\omega_{0}-\frac{e B}{2 m} .
$$

For strong fields, $\frac{e B}{m} \gg \omega_{0}$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\omega_{+} & \approx \frac{1}{2}\left[\frac{e B}{m}+\frac{e B}{m}\left(1+\frac{2 m^{2} \omega_{0}^{2}}{e^{2} B^{2}}\right)\right] \\
&=\frac{e B}{m}+\frac{m \omega_{0}^{2}}{e B}, \\
\omega_{-} & \approx \frac{1}{2}\left[-\frac{e B}{m}+\frac{e B}{m}\left(1+\frac{2 m^{2} \omega_{0}^{2}}{e^{2} B^{2}}\right)\right] \\
&=\frac{m \omega_{0}^{2}}{e B} .
\end{aligned}
$$

2039.Problem Statement: A rectangular plate of mass $M$, length $a$ and width $b$ is supported at each of its corners by $a$ spring with spring constant $k$ as shown in Fig. 2.36. The springs are confined so that they can move only in the vertical direction. For small amplitudes, find the normal-modes of vibration and their frequencies. Describe each of the modes.
2039.Solution:
Use Cartesian coordinates with origin at the center of mass $C$ of the plate when the plate is in equilibrium, the $z$-axis vertically upwards, the $x$ - 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-560.jpg?height=275&width=421&top_left_y=247&top_left_x=280)

Fig. 2.36.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-560.jpg?height=318&width=422&top_left_y=219&top_left_x=861)

Fig. 2.37.

and $y$-axes along the axes of symmetry in the plane of the plate, and let the angles of rotation about the $x$ - and $y$-axes be $\varphi, \theta$ respectively, as shown in Fig. 2.37. If $z$ is the vertical coordinate of $C$, the vertical coordinates of the four corners are

$$
\begin{aligned}
&z_{A}=z-\frac{1}{2} a \varphi+\frac{1}{2} b \theta, \\
&z_{B}=z-\frac{1}{2} a \varphi-\frac{1}{2} b \theta, \\
&z_{D}=z+\frac{1}{2} a \varphi-\frac{1}{2} b \theta, \\
&z_{E}=z+\frac{1}{2} a \varphi+\frac{1}{2} b \theta,
\end{aligned}
$$

for small angle oscillations.

As the coordinates are relative to the equilibrium positions, the Lagrangian is

$$
\begin{aligned}
L &=T-V \\
&=\frac{1}{2} M \dot{z}^{2}+\frac{1}{24} M a^{2} \dot{\varphi}^{2}+\frac{1}{24} M b^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}-\frac{1}{2} k\left(z_{A}^{2}+z_{B}^{2}+z_{D}^{2}+z_{E}^{2}\right)-M g z \\
&=\frac{1}{2} M \dot{z}^{2}+\frac{1}{24} M a^{2} \dot{\varphi}^{2}+\frac{1}{24} M b^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}-\frac{1}{2} k\left(4 z^{2}+a^{2} \varphi^{2}+b^{2} \theta^{2}\right)-M g z .
\end{aligned}
$$

Lagrange's equations

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}}=0
$$

then give 

$$
\begin{aligned}
M \ddot{z}+4 k z+M g &=0, \\
\frac{1}{12} M \ddot{\varphi}+k \varphi &=0, \\
\frac{1}{12} M \ddot{\theta}+k \theta &=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

By putting $z=z^{\prime}-\frac{M g}{4 k}$, the first equation can be written as

$$
M \ddot{z}^{\prime}+4 k z^{\prime}=0 .
$$

The equations show that the normol-mode angular frequencies are

$$
\omega_{1}=2 \sqrt{\frac{k}{M}}, \quad \omega_{2}=\omega_{3}=2 \sqrt{\frac{3 k}{M}} .
$$

If we define

$$
\xi_{1}=\sqrt{M} z^{\prime}, \quad \xi_{2}=\sqrt{\frac{M}{12}} a \varphi, \quad \xi_{3}=\sqrt{\frac{M}{12}} b \theta,
$$

we can, neglecting a constant term in the potential energy, write

$$
\begin{aligned}
T &=\frac{1}{2}\left(\dot{\xi}_{1}^{2}+\dot{\xi}_{2}^{2}+\dot{\xi}_{3}^{2}\right), \\
V &=\frac{1}{2}\left(\omega_{1}^{2} \xi_{1}^{2}+\omega_{2}^{2} \xi_{2}^{2}+\omega_{3}^{2} \xi_{3}^{2}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

These are both in quadratic form, slowing that $\xi_{1}, \xi_{2}, \xi_{3}$ are the normalmode coordinates.

Denoting the amplitudes of $z^{\prime}, \varphi, \theta$ by $z_{0}^{\prime}, \varphi_{0}, \theta_{0}$ respectively, we obtain from the equations of motion

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(4 k-M \omega^{2}\right) z_{0} &=0, \\
\left(k-\frac{1}{12} M \omega^{2}\right) \varphi_{0} &=0, \\
\left(k-\frac{1}{12} M \omega^{2}\right) \theta_{0} &=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

It can be seen that if $\omega=\omega_{1}$ then $z_{0} \neq 0, \varphi_{0}=\theta_{0}=0$. If $\omega=\omega_{2}$ or $\omega_{3}$, then $z_{0}=0$, and one or both of $\varphi_{0}, \theta_{0}$ are not zero.

2041.a.Problem Statement:
A block of mass $m$ is attached to a wedge of mass $M$ by a spring with spring constant $k$. The inclined frictionless surface of the wedge makes an angle $\alpha$ to the horizontal. The wedge is free to slide on a horizontal frictionless surface, as shown in Fig. 2.39.

Given the relaxed length of the spring alone is $d$, find the value $s_{0}$ when both the block and the wedge are at rest.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-564.jpg?height=190&width=468&top_left_y=582&top_left_x=542)

Fig. 2.39.
2041.a.Solution:
When the block is in equilibrium, the sum of forces parallel to the inclined surface is zero:

$$
m g \sin \alpha-k\left(s_{0}-d\right)=0,
$$

yielding

$$
s_{0}=\frac{m g \sin \alpha}{k}+d .
$$

2041.b.Problem Statement:
A block of mass $m$ is attached to a wedge of mass $M$ by a spring with spring constant $k$. The inclined frictionless surface of the wedge makes an angle $\alpha$ to the horizontal. The wedge is free to slide on a horizontal frictionless surface, as shown in Fig. 2.39.

Find the Lagrangian for the system as a function of the $x$ coordinate of the wedge and the length of the spring $s$. Write the equations of motion.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-564.jpg?height=190&width=468&top_left_y=582&top_left_x=542)

Fig. 2.39.
2041.b.Solution:
When the block is in equilibrium, the sum of forces parallel to the inclined surface is zero:

$$
m g \sin \alpha-k\left(s_{0}-d\right)=0,
$$

yielding

$$
s_{0}=\frac{m g \sin \alpha}{k}+d .
$$Let the height of the wedge be $h$. Use coordinates as shown in Fig. $2.39$ and let the horizontal coordinate of the left side of the wedge be $x$. Then the mass $m$ will have coordinates

$$
(x+s \cos \alpha, h-s \sin \alpha) \text {. }
$$

The Lagrangian of the system is then

$$
\begin{aligned}
L=& T-V \\
=& \frac{1}{2} M \dot{x}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m\left[(\dot{x}+\dot{s} \cos \alpha)^{2}+(\dot{s} \sin \alpha)^{2}\right] \\
&-\frac{1}{2} k(s-d)^{2}-m g(h-s \sin \alpha) \\
=& \frac{1}{2}(m+M) \dot{x}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m \dot{s}^{2}+m \dot{x} \dot{s} \cos \alpha-\frac{1}{2} k(s-d)^{2}-m g(h-s \sin \alpha) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Lagrange's equations then give the equations of motion

$$
\begin{aligned}
&(m+M) \ddot{x}+m \ddot{s} \cos \alpha=0, \\
&m \ddot{x} \cos \alpha+m \ddot{s}+k s-(k d+m g \sin \alpha)=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

(x+s \cos \alpha, h-s \sin \alpha) \text {. }
$$

The Lagrangian of the system is then

$$
\begin{aligned}
L=& T-V \\
=& \frac{1}{2} M \dot{x}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m\left[(\dot{x}+\dot{s} \cos \alpha)^{2}+(\dot{s} \sin \alpha)^{2}\right] \\
&-\frac{1}{2} k(s-d)^{2}-m g(h-s \sin \alpha) \\
=& \frac{1}{2}(m+M) \dot{x}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m \dot{s}^{2}+m \dot{x} \dot{s} \cos \alpha-\frac{1}{2} k(s-d)^{2}-m g(h-s \sin \alpha) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Lagrange's equations then give the equations of motion

$$
\begin{aligned}
&(m+M) \ddot{x}+m \ddot{s} \cos \alpha=0, \\
&m \ddot{x} \cos \alpha+m \ddot{s}+k s-(k d+m g \sin \alpha)=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$Setting

$$
s=s^{\prime}+\frac{k d+m g \sin \alpha}{k},
$$

we can write the above equations as

$$
\begin{aligned}
(m+M) \ddot{x}+m \ddot{s}^{\prime} \cos \alpha &=0, \\
m \ddot{x} \cos \alpha+m \ddot{s}^{\prime}+k s^{\prime} &=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

Consider a solution of the form

$$
x=A e^{i \omega t}, \quad s^{\prime}=B e^{i \omega t},
$$

the above give the secular equation

$$
\left|\begin{array}{cc}
-(m+M) \omega^{2} & -m \omega^{2} \cos \alpha \\
-m \omega^{2} \cos \alpha & k-m \omega^{2}
\end{array}\right|=0
$$

yielding

$$
\omega_{1}=0, \quad \omega_{2}=\sqrt{\frac{k(m+M)}{m\left(M+m \sin ^{2} \alpha\right)}} .
$$

As the motion related to $\omega_{1}$ is not oscillatory but as a whole translational along the $x$-axis, there is only one natural frequency of vibration, $\omega_{2}$.

2043.Problem Statement:
Two unequal masses $M$ and $m(M>m)$ hang from a support by strings of equal lengths $l$. The masses are coupled by a spring of spring constant $K$ and of unstretched length equal to the distance between the support points as shown in Fig. 2.41. Find the normal-mode frequencies for the small oscillations along the line between the two masses. Give the relation between the motion of $M$ and that of $m$ in each mode. Write down the most general solution.

Now specialize for the case where at $t=0, m$ is at rest at its equilibrium position, and $M$ is released from rest with an initial positive displacement. If the total energy of the system is $E_{0}$ and the spring is very weak, find the 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-569.jpg?height=279&width=351&top_left_y=214&top_left_x=576)

Fig. 2.41.

maximum energy acquired by $m$ during the subsequent motion for the case $\frac{M}{m}=2$. (Where did you use the assumption that the spring is weak?)
2043.Solution:
Use coordinates as shown in Fig. $2.41$ with origin $O$ at the equilibrium position of the mass $m$ and the $x$ - and $y$-axes along the horizontal and vertical directions respectively and let the distance between the two supports be $L$. The masses $m$ and $M$ then have coordinates

$$
\left(l \sin \theta_{1}, l\left(1-\cos \theta_{1}\right)\right), \quad\left(L+l \sin \theta_{2}, l\left(1-\cos \theta_{2}\right)\right)
$$

and velocities

$$
\left(l \dot{\theta}_{1} \cos \theta_{1}, l \dot{\theta}_{1} \sin \theta_{1}\right), \quad\left(l \dot{\theta}_{2} \cos \theta_{2}, l \dot{\theta}_{2} \sin \theta_{2}\right)
$$

respectively. The Lagrangian of the system is

$$
\begin{aligned}
L=& T-V \\
=& \frac{1}{2} m l^{2} \dot{\theta}_{1}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} M l^{2} \dot{\theta}_{2}^{2}-\frac{1}{2} K l^{2}\left(\sin \theta_{2}-\sin \theta_{1}\right)^{2} \\
&-m g l\left(1-\cos \theta_{1}\right)-M g l\left(1-\cos \theta_{2}\right) \\
\approx & \frac{1}{2} m l^{2} \dot{\theta}_{1}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} M l^{2} \dot{\theta}_{2}^{2}-\frac{1}{2} K l^{2}\left(\theta_{2}-\theta_{1}\right)^{2}-\frac{1}{2} g l\left(m \theta_{1}^{2}+M \theta_{2}^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

for small oscillations in the horizontal direction.

Lagrange's equations

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}}=0
$$

then give

$$
\begin{gathered}
m l \ddot{\theta}_{1}+(m g+K l) \theta_{1}-K l \theta_{2}=0 \\
M l \ddot{\theta}_{2}+(M g+K l) \theta_{2}-K l \theta_{1}=0 .
\end{gathered}
$$

Try a solution of the type $\theta_{1}=A e^{i \omega t}, \theta_{2}=B e^{i \omega t}$ and write the above as

$$
\left(\begin{array}{cc}
m g+K l-m l \omega^{2} & -K l \\
-K l & M g+K l-M l \omega^{2}
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
A \\
B
\end{array}\right)=0 .
$$

The secular equation is then

$$
\left|\begin{array}{cc}
m g+K l-m l \omega^{2} & -K l \\
-K l & M g+K l-M l \omega^{2}
\end{array}\right|=0
$$

yielding the normal-mode angular frequencies

$$
\omega_{1}=\sqrt{\frac{g}{l}}, \quad \omega_{2}=\sqrt{\frac{m M g+K l(m+M)}{m M l}} .
$$

As

$$
\frac{A}{B}=\frac{M g+K l-M l \omega^{2}}{K l},
$$

we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{A}{B} &=1 \quad \text { for } \quad \omega=\omega_{1}, \\
\frac{A^{\prime}}{B^{\prime}} &=-\frac{M}{m} \quad \text { for } \quad \omega=\omega_{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence, for $\omega=\omega_{1}$,

$$
\theta_{1}=A \cos \left(\omega_{1} t+\varphi_{1}\right), \quad \theta_{2}=A \cos \left(\omega_{1} t+\varphi_{1}\right),
$$

for $\omega=\omega_{2}$,

$$
\theta_{1}=A^{\prime} \cos \left(\omega_{2} t+\varphi_{2}\right), \quad \theta_{2}=-\frac{m}{M} A^{\prime} \cos \left(\omega_{2} t+\varphi_{2}\right)
$$

and the most general solution is

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\theta_{1}=A \cos \left(\omega_{1} t+\varphi_{1}\right)+A^{\prime} \cos \left(\omega_{2} t+\varphi_{2}\right) \\
&\theta_{2}=A \cos \left(\omega_{1} t+\varphi_{1}\right)-\frac{m}{M} A^{\prime} \cos \left(\omega_{2} t+\varphi_{2}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Initially at $t=0, \dot{\theta}_{1}=\dot{\theta}_{2}=0$, giving $\dot{\varphi}_{1}=\dot{\varphi}_{2}=0$, and $\theta_{1}=0, \theta_{2}=\theta_{0}$, giving

$$
A=\frac{M}{m+M} \theta_{0}, \quad A^{\prime}=-A .
$$

If the initial total energy is $E_{0}$, then as

$$
E_{0}=\frac{1}{2} K l^{2} \theta_{0}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} M g l \theta_{0}^{2},
$$

we have, as $\theta_{0}$ is positive,

$$
\theta_{0}=\sqrt{\frac{2 E_{0}}{(K l+M g) l}} .
$$

If in addition, $M=2 m$, the general solution reduces to

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\theta_{1}=\frac{2}{3} \theta_{0}\left[\cos \left(\omega_{1} t\right)-\cos \left(\omega_{2} t\right)\right], \\
&\theta_{2}=\frac{2}{3} \theta_{0}\left[\cos \left(\omega_{1} t\right)+\frac{1}{2} \cos \left(\omega_{2} t\right)\right],
\end{aligned}
$$

with

$$
\omega_{1}=\sqrt{\frac{g}{l}}, \quad \omega_{2}=\sqrt{\frac{2 m g+3 K l}{2 m l}}, \quad \theta_{0}=\sqrt{\frac{2 E_{0}}{(2 m g+K l) l}} .
$$

The energy of $m$ is

$$
E_{1}=\frac{1}{2} m l^{2} \dot{\theta}_{1}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m g l \theta_{1}^{2} .
$$

If the spring is very weak, we can take $K l \ll m g$ so that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\omega_{2} &=\sqrt{\frac{g}{l}\left(1+\frac{3 K l}{2 m g}\right)} \approx \sqrt{\frac{g}{l}}\left(1+\frac{3 K l}{4 m g}\right)=\omega_{1}(1+\delta), \\
\theta_{0} &=\sqrt{\frac{E_{0}}{m g l}}\left(1-\frac{\delta}{3}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
\delta=\frac{3 K l}{4 m g} \ll 1 .
$$

We then have

$$
\begin{aligned}
E_{1}=& \frac{2}{9} m g l \theta_{0}^{2}\left[1+(1+\delta)^{2} \sin ^{2}\left(\omega_{2} t\right)+\cos ^{2}\left(\omega_{2} t\right)\right.\\
&\left.\quad-2(1+\delta) \sin \left(\omega_{1} t\right) \sin \left(\omega_{2} t\right)-2 \cos \left(\omega_{1} t\right) \cos \left(\omega_{2} t\right)\right] \\
\approx & \frac{4}{9} E_{0}\left[1-\cos \left(\omega_{1} \delta t\right)\right],
\end{aligned}
$$

neglecting $\delta$ as compared with unity. Hence the maximum energy of $m$ is $\frac{8}{9} E_{0}$
2043.Final Answer: $$\frac{2}{9} m g l \theta_{0}^{2}\left[1+(1+\delta)^{2} \sin ^{2}\left(\omega_{2} t\right)+\cos ^{2}\left(\omega_{2} t\right)\right.\left.\quad-2(1+\delta) \sin \left(\omega_{1} t\right) \sin \left(\omega_{2} t\right)-2 \cos \left(\omega_{1} t\right) \cos \left(\omega_{2} t\right)\right] \approx  \frac{4}{9} E_{0}\left[1-\cos \left(\omega_{1} \delta t\right)\right]$$

2044.Problem Statement:
Two small spheres of mass $M$ are suspended between two rigid supports as shown in Fig. 2.42. We assume that both particles can move in the plane of the figure, sideways and up and down. The three springs are equal, of spring constant $K$. The springs are under tension: in its unstretched condition each spring would be of length $\frac{a}{2}$. The springs are assumed massless and perfectly elastic. Assuming small oscillations about the equilibrium configuration shown above, find the frequencies for the four normal-modes of the system.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-572.jpg?height=120&width=360&top_left_y=1355&top_left_x=291)

Fig. 2.42.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-572.jpg?height=219&width=479&top_left_y=1283&top_left_x=857)

Fig. 2.43.
2044.Solution:
Since the motion is confined to the plane of the diagram of Fig. 2.42, the sideway motion is to be interpreted as longitudinal along the springs.

Let $\left(x_{1}, y_{1}\right)$ and $\left(x_{2}, y_{2}\right)$ be the horizontal and vertical displacements of the spheres, numbered from the left, from their respective positions of equilibrium. Using coordinates as shown in Fig. $2.43, m_{1}, m_{2}$ have coordinates $\left(a+x_{1}, y_{1}\right),\left(2 a+x_{2}, y_{2}\right)$ respectively. Talking the equilibrium configuration (Fig. 2.42) as the state of zero potential, we have for the system the potential energy

$$
\begin{aligned}
V=& \frac{1}{2} K\left[\sqrt{\left(a+x_{1}\right)^{2}+y_{1}^{2}}-\frac{a}{2}\right]^{2}-\frac{1}{2} K\left(\frac{a}{2}\right)^{2} \\
&+\frac{1}{2} K\left[\sqrt{\left(a+x_{2}-x_{1}\right)^{2}+\left(y_{2}-y_{1}\right)^{2}}-\frac{a}{2}\right]^{2} \\
&-\frac{1}{2} K\left(\frac{a}{2}\right)^{2}+\frac{1}{2} K\left[\sqrt{\left(a-x_{2}\right)^{2}+y_{2}^{2}}-\frac{a}{2}\right]^{2} \\
&-\frac{1}{2} K\left(\frac{a}{2}\right)^{2}+M g\left(y_{1}+y_{2}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Consider

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\frac{1}{2} K\left[\sqrt{\left(a+x_{1}\right)^{2}+y_{1}^{2}}-\frac{a}{2}\right]^{2}-\frac{1}{2} K\left(\frac{a}{2}\right)^{2} \\
&=\frac{1}{2} K\left[a^{2}+x_{1}^{2}+2 a x_{1}+y_{1}^{2}+\frac{a^{2}}{4}-a \sqrt{a^{2}+x_{1}^{2}+2 a x_{1}+y_{1}^{2}}\right]-\frac{1}{8} K a^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

As the term involving the square-root sign can be written as

$$
\begin{aligned}
&a^{2}\left(1+\frac{x_{1}^{2}+2 a x_{1}+y_{1}^{2}}{a^{2}}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}} \\
&\approx a^{2}\left[1+\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{x_{1}^{2}+2 a x_{1}+y_{1}^{2}}{a^{2}}\right)+\frac{1}{2 !}\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)\left(-\frac{1}{2}\right) \frac{4 x_{1}^{2}}{a^{2}}\right] \\
&=a^{2}+\frac{1}{2}\left(x_{1}^{2}+2 a x_{1}+y_{1}^{2}\right)-\frac{1}{2} x_{1}^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

retaining only terms of orders up to the second in the small quantities $x_{1}, y_{1}$, the above becomes

$$
\frac{1}{2} K\left(x_{1}^{2}+a x_{1}+\frac{1}{2} y_{1}^{2}\right) .
$$

The same approximation is taken over the other terms. Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
V \approx & \frac{1}{2} K\left[x_{1}^{2}+a x_{1}+\frac{y_{1}^{2}}{2}+\left(x_{2}-x_{1}\right)^{2}+a\left(x_{2}-x_{1}\right)\right.\\
&\left.+\frac{1}{2}\left(y_{2}-y_{1}\right)^{2}+x_{2}^{2}-a x_{2}+\frac{1}{2} y_{2}^{2}\right]+M g\left(y_{1}+y_{2}\right) \\
=& \frac{1}{2} K\left(2 x_{1}^{2}+2 x_{2}^{2}+y_{1}^{2}+y_{2}^{2}-2 x_{1} x_{2}-y_{1} y_{2}\right)+M g\left(y_{1}+y_{2}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

The Lagrangian is then

$$
\begin{aligned}
L=& T-V \\
=& \frac{1}{2} M\left(\dot{x}_{1}^{2}+\dot{y}_{1}^{2}+\dot{x}_{2}^{2}+\dot{y}_{2}^{2}\right) \\
&-\frac{1}{2} K\left(2 x_{1}^{2}+2 x_{2}^{2}+y_{1}^{2}+y_{2}^{2}-2 x_{1} x_{2}-y_{1} y_{2}\right)-M g\left(y_{1}+y_{2}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Lagrange's equations

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}}=0
$$

give

$$
\begin{aligned}
M \ddot{x}_{1}+2 K x_{1}-K x_{2} &=0, \\
M \ddot{x}_{2}+2 K x_{2}-K x_{1} &=0, \\
M \ddot{y}_{1}+K y_{1}-\frac{1}{2} K y_{2}+M g &=0, \\
M \ddot{y}_{2}+K y_{2}-\frac{1}{2} K y_{1}+M g &=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

It is seen that the equations naturally separate into two groups, those in $x_{1}, x_{2}$ and those in $y_{1}, y_{2}$. Let

$$
x_{i}=A_{i} e^{i \omega t}
$$

Then the first two equations give the secular equation

$$
\left|\begin{array}{cc}
2 K-M \omega^{2} & -K \\
-K & 2 K-M \omega^{2}
\end{array}\right|=\left(3 K-M \omega^{2}\right)\left(K-M \omega^{2}\right)=0
$$

yielding two normal-mode angular frequencies

$$
\omega_{1}=\sqrt{\frac{K}{M}}, \quad \omega_{2}=\sqrt{\frac{3 K}{M}}
$$

for longitudinal oscillations.

For the second group of two equations, let

$$
y_{1}^{\prime}=y_{1}+\frac{2 M g}{K}, \quad y_{2}^{\prime}=y_{2}+\frac{2 M g}{K} .
$$

They can then be written as

$$
\begin{aligned}
&M \ddot{y}_{1}^{\prime}+K y_{1}^{\prime}-\frac{1}{2} K y_{2}^{\prime}=0, \\
&M \ddot{y}_{2}^{\prime}+K y_{2}^{\prime}-\frac{1}{2} K y_{1}^{\prime}=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

Trying a solution of the type

$$
y_{i}^{\prime}=B_{i} e^{i \omega t},
$$

we obtain the secular equation

$$
\left|\begin{array}{cc}
K-M \omega^{2} & -\frac{K}{2} \\
-\frac{K}{2} & K-M \omega^{2}
\end{array}\right|=\left(\frac{3}{2} K-M \omega^{2}\right)\left(\frac{1}{2} K-M \omega^{2}\right)=0,
$$

which yields the normal-mode angular frequencies

$$
\omega_{3}=\sqrt{\frac{K}{2 M}}, \quad \omega_{4}=\sqrt{\frac{3 K}{2 M}}
$$

for vertical oscillations.

2046.Problem Statement:
Three equal point masses $m$ move on a circle of radius $b$ under forces derivable from the potential energy

$$
V(\alpha, \beta, \gamma)=V_{0}\left(e^{-\alpha}+e^{-\beta}+e^{-\gamma}\right) \text {. }
$$

where $\alpha, \beta, \gamma$ are their angular separations in radians, as shown in Fig. 2.46. When $\alpha=\beta=\gamma=\frac{2 \pi}{3}$, the system is in equilibrium. Find the normal-mode frequencies for small departure from equilibrium.

(Note that $\alpha, \beta, \gamma$ are not independent since $\alpha+\beta+\gamma=2 \pi$.) $(U C$, Berkeley $)$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-578.jpg?height=331&width=347&top_left_y=539&top_left_x=295)

Fig. 2.46.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-578.jpg?height=335&width=372&top_left_y=549&top_left_x=919)

Fig. $2.47$
2046.Solution:
Let $\theta_{1}, \theta_{2}, \theta_{3}$ be the angular displacements of the three masses from their equilibrium positions as shown in Fig. 2.47. We have

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\alpha=\frac{2 \pi}{3}+\theta_{2}-\theta_{1}, \\
&\beta=\frac{2 \pi}{3}+\theta_{3}-\theta_{2}, \\
&\gamma=\frac{2 \pi}{3}+\theta_{1}-\theta_{3} .
\end{aligned}
$$

As

$$
e^{-x} \approx 1-\frac{x}{1 !}+\frac{x^{2}}{2 !}-\cdots,
$$

we can write the potential energy as 

$$
\begin{aligned}
V=& V_{0} e^{-\frac{2 \pi}{3}}\left[e^{-\left(\theta_{2}-\theta_{2}\right)}+e^{-\left(\theta_{3}-\theta_{2}\right)}+e^{-\left(\theta_{1}-\theta_{3}\right)}\right] \\
\approx & V_{0} e^{-\frac{2 \pi}{3}}\left[3-\left(\theta_{2}-\theta_{1}\right)-\left(\theta_{3}-\theta_{2}\right)-\left(\theta_{1}-\theta_{3}\right)\right.\\
&\left.\quad+\frac{1}{2}\left(\theta_{2}-\theta_{1}\right)^{2}+\frac{1}{2}\left(\theta_{3}-\theta_{2}\right)^{2}+\frac{1}{2}\left(\theta_{1}-\theta_{3}\right)^{2}\right] \\
=& A\left(3+\theta_{1}^{2}+\theta_{2}^{2}+\theta_{3}^{2}-\theta_{1} \theta_{2}-\theta_{2} \theta_{3}-\theta_{3} \theta_{1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

with $A=V_{0} \exp \left(-\frac{2 \pi}{3}\right)$, retaining terms of orders up to the second in the small quantities $\theta_{1}, \theta_{2}, \theta_{3}$.

As the velocities are $b \dot{\theta}_{1}, b \dot{\theta}_{2}, b \dot{\theta}_{3}$, the kinetic energy is

$$
T=\frac{1}{2} B\left(\dot{\theta}_{1}^{2}+\dot{\theta}_{2}^{2}+\dot{\theta}_{3}^{2}\right)
$$

with $B=m b^{2}$.

The Lagrangian is therefore

$$
\begin{aligned}
L &=T-V \\
&=B\left(\dot{\theta}_{1}^{2}+\dot{\theta}_{2}^{2}+\dot{\theta}_{3}^{2}\right)-A\left(3+\theta_{1}^{2}+\theta_{2}^{2}+\theta_{3}^{2}-\theta_{1} \theta_{2}-\theta_{2} \theta_{3}-\theta_{3} \theta_{1}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Lagrange's equations

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}}=0
$$

then give

$$
\begin{aligned}
&B \ddot{\theta}_{1}+A\left(2 \theta_{1}-\theta_{2}-\theta_{3}\right)=0, \\
&B \ddot{\theta}_{2}+A\left(2 \theta_{2}-\theta_{3}-\theta_{1}\right)=0, \\
&B \ddot{\theta}_{3}+A\left(2 \theta_{3}-\theta_{1}-\theta_{2}\right)=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

Trying a solution of the type $\theta_{i}=C_{i} e^{i \omega t}$, we find the secular equation

$$
\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
2 A-B \omega^{2} & -A & -A \\
-A & 2 A-B \omega^{2} & -A \\
-A & -A & 2 A-B \omega^{2}
\end{array}\right|=0
$$

or, after some arithmetic manipulations,

$$
\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
0 & -2 A & A-B \omega^{2} \\
0 & 2 A-B \omega^{2} & -A \\
-3 A+B \omega^{2} & -A & 2 A-B \omega^{2}
\end{array}\right|=B \omega^{2}\left(-3 A+B \omega^{2}\right)^{2}=0 .
$$

Hence the normal-mode angular frequencies are

$$
\omega_{1}=0, \quad \omega_{2}=\omega_{3}=\sqrt{\frac{3 A}{B}}=\sqrt{\frac{3 V_{0} \exp \left(\frac{-2 \pi}{3}\right)}{m b^{2}}} .
$$

Note that $\omega_{1}$ does not give rise to oscillations, for in this case the equations of motion give $\theta_{1}=\theta_{2}=\theta_{3}$ and the system as a whole rotates with a constant angular velocity. The other two normal-modes are degenerate and there is only one normal-mode frequency

$$
\frac{1}{b} \sqrt{\frac{3 V_{0}}{m}} \exp \left(-\frac{\pi}{3}\right) .
$$

2047.b.Problem Statement:
Three point particles, two of mass $m$ and one of mass $M$, are constrained to lie on a horizontal circle of radius $r$. They are mutually connected by springs, each of constant $K$, that follow the arc of the circle and that are of equal length when the system is at rest as shown in Fig. 2.48. Assuming motion that stretches the springs only by a small amount from the equilibrium length $(2 \pi r / 3)$,

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-580.jpg?height=336&width=353&top_left_y=1187&top_left_x=604)

Fig. 2.48.

find a precise set of normal coordinates, one corresponding to each mode;
2047.b.Solution:
As the system is not acted upon by external torque, its angular momentum is conserved. This means that there is a normal-mode in which the system rotates as a whole. Consequently there are only two vibrational degrees of freedom. Let $\theta_{1}, \theta_{2}, \theta_{3}$ be respectively the angular displacements of $m, M, m$ from their equilibrium positions and let their amplitudes be $c_{1}, c_{2}, c_{3}$. When considering the vibration of the masses relative to their equilibrium positions, we can take the total angular momentum of the system to be zero. Then the two vibrational normal-modes correspond to

$$
c_{2}=0, \quad c_{1}=-c_{3} \quad \text { and } \quad c_{1}=c_{3}=-\frac{M c_{2}}{2 m} .
$$

Let the natural length of each spring be $a$ and denote the equilibrium length by $b$, i.e.

$$
b=\frac{2 \pi r}{3} \text {. }
$$

The Lagrangian of the system is

$$
\begin{aligned}
L &=T-V \\
&=\frac{1}{2} m r^{2}\left(\dot{\theta}_{1}^{2}+\dot{\theta}_{3}^{2}\right)+\frac{1}{2} M r^{2} \dot{\theta}_{2}^{2} \\
&-\frac{1}{2} K\left[\left(b+r \theta_{2}-r \theta_{1}-a\right)^{2}+\left(b+r \theta_{3}-r \theta_{2}-a\right)^{2}+\left(b+r \theta_{1}-r \theta_{3}-a\right)^{2}\right] .
\end{aligned}
$$

Lagrange's equations

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}}=0
$$

then give the differential equations of motion

$$
\begin{aligned}
&m \ddot{\theta}_{1}+K\left(2 \theta_{1}-\theta_{2}-\theta_{3}\right)=0, \\
&M \ddot{\theta}_{2}+K\left(2 \theta_{2}-\theta_{3}-\theta_{1}\right)=0, \\
&m \ddot{\theta}_{3}+K\left(2 \theta_{3}-\theta_{1}-\theta_{2}\right)=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

The above sum up to

$$
m \ddot{\theta}_{1}+M \ddot{\theta}_{2}+m \ddot{\theta}_{3}=0,
$$

and the first and third equations give

$$
m\left(\ddot{\theta}_{1}-\ddot{\theta}_{3}\right)+3 K\left(\theta_{1}-\theta_{3}\right)=0 .
$$

These can be written as

$$
\begin{gathered}
m \ddot{\xi}=0, \\
m \ddot{\eta}+3 K \eta=0
\end{gathered}
$$

if we set

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\xi=\theta_{1}+\frac{M \theta_{2}}{m}+\theta_{3}, \\
&\eta=\theta_{1}-\theta_{3} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence $\xi$ and $\eta$ are normal-mode coordinates of the system.

Equation (1) shows that $\omega_{1}=0$. Thus corresponding to this mode in which the system rotates as a whole and there is no oscillation.

Equation (2) shows that

$$
\omega_{2}=\sqrt{\frac{3 K}{m}} .
$$

To find the third normal coordinate, we choose the coordinate transformation

$$
q_{1}=\theta_{1}, \quad q_{2}=\theta_{2} \sqrt{\frac{M}{m}}, \quad q_{3}=\theta_{3}
$$

to make the kinetic energy a sum of squares:

$$
T=\frac{1}{2} m r^{2}\left(\dot{q}_{1}^{2}+\dot{q}_{2}^{2}+\dot{q}_{3}^{2}\right) .
$$

$q_{1}, q_{2}, q_{3}$ are just like Cartesian coordinates. The transformation between the three normal coordinates and the three "Cartesian" coordinates $q_{1}, q_{2}$, $q_{3}$ must be linear. We already have

$$
\xi=q_{1}+q_{2} \sqrt{\frac{M}{m}}+q_{3}, \quad \eta=q_{1}-q_{3} .
$$

Assume the third normal coordinate to be

$$
\zeta=A q_{1}+B q_{2}+C q_{3} .
$$

It should be orthogonal to the $\xi_{-}, \eta$-axes. Resolving along the $q_{i}$-axes we have

$$
\boldsymbol{\xi}=\left(1, \sqrt{\frac{M}{m}}, 1\right), \quad \boldsymbol{\eta}=(1,0,-1), \quad \boldsymbol{\zeta}=(A, B, C)
$$

Orthogonality means that

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\boldsymbol{\zeta} \cdot \boldsymbol{\xi}=A+B \sqrt{\frac{M}{m}}+C=0 \\
&\boldsymbol{\zeta} \cdot \boldsymbol{\eta}=A-C=0
\end{aligned}
$$

which yield $A=C, B=-2 A \sqrt{\frac{m}{M}}$. Since a normal coordinate remains so after multiplying it with a nonzero constant, we can set $A=1$, then

$$
\zeta=q_{1}-2 q_{2} \sqrt{\frac{m}{M}}+q_{3}=\theta_{1}-2 \theta_{2}+\theta_{3} .
$$

The equations of motion then give

$$
\ddot{\zeta}+\left(\frac{(2 m+M) K}{m M}\right) \zeta=0,
$$

yielding

$$
\omega_{3}=\sqrt{\frac{(2 m+M) K}{m M}} .
$$

2047.c.Problem Statement:
Three point particles, two of mass $m$ and one of mass $M$, are constrained to lie on a horizontal circle of radius $r$. They are mutually connected by springs, each of constant $K$, that follow the arc of the circle and that are of equal length when the system is at rest as shown in Fig. 2.48. Assuming motion that stretches the springs only by a small amount from the equilibrium length $(2 \pi r / 3)$,

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-580.jpg?height=336&width=353&top_left_y=1187&top_left_x=604)

Fig. 2.48.

find the frequency of each mode.
2047.c.Solution:
As the system is not acted upon by external torque, its angular momentum is conserved. This means that there is a normal-mode in which the system rotates as a whole. Consequently there are only two vibrational degrees of freedom. Let $\theta_{1}, \theta_{2}, \theta_{3}$ be respectively the angular displacements of $m, M, m$ from their equilibrium positions and let their amplitudes be $c_{1}, c_{2}, c_{3}$. When considering the vibration of the masses relative to their equilibrium positions, we can take the total angular momentum of the system to be zero. Then the two vibrational normal-modes correspond to

$$
c_{2}=0, \quad c_{1}=-c_{3} \quad \text { and } \quad c_{1}=c_{3}=-\frac{M c_{2}}{2 m} .
$$

Let the natural length of each spring be $a$ and denote the equilibrium length by $b$, i.e.

$$
b=\frac{2 \pi r}{3} \text {. }
$$

The Lagrangian of the system is

$$
\begin{aligned}
L &=T-V \\
&=\frac{1}{2} m r^{2}\left(\dot{\theta}_{1}^{2}+\dot{\theta}_{3}^{2}\right)+\frac{1}{2} M r^{2} \dot{\theta}_{2}^{2} \\
&-\frac{1}{2} K\left[\left(b+r \theta_{2}-r \theta_{1}-a\right)^{2}+\left(b+r \theta_{3}-r \theta_{2}-a\right)^{2}+\left(b+r \theta_{1}-r \theta_{3}-a\right)^{2}\right] .
\end{aligned}
$$

Lagrange's equations

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}}=0
$$

then give the differential equations of motion

$$
\begin{aligned}
&m \ddot{\theta}_{1}+K\left(2 \theta_{1}-\theta_{2}-\theta_{3}\right)=0, \\
&M \ddot{\theta}_{2}+K\left(2 \theta_{2}-\theta_{3}-\theta_{1}\right)=0, \\
&m \ddot{\theta}_{3}+K\left(2 \theta_{3}-\theta_{1}-\theta_{2}\right)=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

The above sum up to

$$
m \ddot{\theta}_{1}+M \ddot{\theta}_{2}+m \ddot{\theta}_{3}=0,
$$

and the first and third equations give

$$
m\left(\ddot{\theta}_{1}-\ddot{\theta}_{3}\right)+3 K\left(\theta_{1}-\theta_{3}\right)=0 .
$$

These can be written as

$$
\begin{gathered}
m \ddot{\xi}=0, \\
m \ddot{\eta}+3 K \eta=0
\end{gathered}
$$

if we set

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\xi=\theta_{1}+\frac{M \theta_{2}}{m}+\theta_{3}, \\
&\eta=\theta_{1}-\theta_{3} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence $\xi$ and $\eta$ are normal-mode coordinates of the system.

Equation (1) shows that $\omega_{1}=0$. Thus corresponding to this mode in which the system rotates as a whole and there is no oscillation.

Equation (2) shows that

$$
\omega_{2}=\sqrt{\frac{3 K}{m}} .
$$

To find the third normal coordinate, we choose the coordinate transformation

$$
q_{1}=\theta_{1}, \quad q_{2}=\theta_{2} \sqrt{\frac{M}{m}}, \quad q_{3}=\theta_{3}
$$

to make the kinetic energy a sum of squares:

$$
T=\frac{1}{2} m r^{2}\left(\dot{q}_{1}^{2}+\dot{q}_{2}^{2}+\dot{q}_{3}^{2}\right) .
$$

$q_{1}, q_{2}, q_{3}$ are just like Cartesian coordinates. The transformation between the three normal coordinates and the three "Cartesian" coordinates $q_{1}, q_{2}$, $q_{3}$ must be linear. We already have

$$
\xi=q_{1}+q_{2} \sqrt{\frac{M}{m}}+q_{3}, \quad \eta=q_{1}-q_{3} .
$$

Assume the third normal coordinate to be

$$
\zeta=A q_{1}+B q_{2}+C q_{3} .
$$

It should be orthogonal to the $\xi_{-}, \eta$-axes. Resolving along the $q_{i}$-axes we have

$$
\boldsymbol{\xi}=\left(1, \sqrt{\frac{M}{m}}, 1\right), \quad \boldsymbol{\eta}=(1,0,-1), \quad \boldsymbol{\zeta}=(A, B, C)
$$

Orthogonality means that

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\boldsymbol{\zeta} \cdot \boldsymbol{\xi}=A+B \sqrt{\frac{M}{m}}+C=0 \\
&\boldsymbol{\zeta} \cdot \boldsymbol{\eta}=A-C=0
\end{aligned}
$$

which yield $A=C, B=-2 A \sqrt{\frac{m}{M}}$. Since a normal coordinate remains so after multiplying it with a nonzero constant, we can set $A=1$, then

$$
\zeta=q_{1}-2 q_{2} \sqrt{\frac{m}{M}}+q_{3}=\theta_{1}-2 \theta_{2}+\theta_{3} .
$$

The equations of motion then give

$$
\ddot{\zeta}+\left(\frac{(2 m+M) K}{m M}\right) \zeta=0,
$$

yielding

$$
\omega_{3}=\sqrt{\frac{(2 m+M) K}{m M}} .
$$$\omega_{1}, \omega_{2}, \omega_{3}$ are the normal-mode angular frequencies corresponding to the three normal coordinates $\xi, \eta, \zeta$ respectively.

2048.d.Problem Statement:
A ring of mass $M$ and radius $R$ is supported from a pivot located at one point of the ring, about which it is free to rotate in its own vertical plane. A bead of mass $m$ slides without friction about the ring (Fig. 2.49).

Find the frequencies of the normal-modes of small oscillations for general $m$ and $M$.
2048.d.Solution:
Use coordinates as shown in Fig. 2.49. The mass $m$ and the center of mass of the ring have coordinates 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-584.jpg?height=318&width=320&top_left_y=238&top_left_x=588)

Fig. $2.49$.

$$
(R \sin \theta+R \sin \varphi, R \cos \theta+R \cos \varphi), \quad(R \sin \theta, R \cos \theta)
$$

and velocities

$$
(R \dot{\theta} \cos \theta+R \dot{\varphi} \cos \varphi,-R \dot{\theta} \sin \theta-R \dot{\varphi} \sin \varphi), \quad(R \dot{\theta} \cos \theta,-R \dot{\theta} \sin \theta)
$$

respectively. The ring has moment of inertial $2 M R^{2}$ about the pivot. The Lagrangian of the system is then

$$
\begin{aligned}
L=& T-V \\
=& M R^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m R^{2}\left[\dot{\theta}^{2}+\dot{\varphi}^{2}+2 \dot{\theta} \dot{\varphi} \cos (\theta-\varphi)\right] \\
&+(M+m) g R \cos \theta+m g R \cos \varphi,
\end{aligned}
$$

taking the pivot as the reference level of potential energy.

Lagrange's equations

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}}=0
$$

give the equations of motion

$$
\begin{aligned}
&(2 M+m) R \ddot{\theta}+m R \ddot{\varphi} \cos (\theta-\varphi) \\
&\quad+m R \dot{\varphi}^{2} \sin (\theta-\varphi)+(m+M) g \sin \theta=0, \\
&R \ddot{\varphi}+R \ddot{\theta} \cos (\theta-\varphi)-R \dot{\theta}^{2} \sin (\theta-\varphi)+g \sin \varphi=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$
to

For small oscillations, $\theta, \varphi, \dot{\theta}, \dot{\varphi}$ are small and the above reduce

$$
\begin{gathered}
(2 M+m) R \ddot{\theta}+m R \ddot{\varphi}+(M+m) g \theta=0, \\
R \ddot{\varphi}+R \ddot{\theta}+g \varphi=0 .
\end{gathered}
$$

Try a solution of the type $\theta=A e^{i \omega t}, \varphi=B e^{i \omega t}$ and write these equations as a matrix equation

$$
\left(\begin{array}{cc}
(M+m) g-(2 M+m) R \omega^{2} & -m R \omega^{2} \\
-R \omega^{2} & g-R \omega^{2}
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
A \\
B
\end{array}\right)=0 .
$$

The secular equation

$$
\begin{gathered}
\left|\begin{array}{cc}
(m+M) g-(2 M+m) R \omega^{2} & -m R \omega^{2} \\
-R \omega^{2} & g-R \omega^{2}
\end{array}\right| \\
=\left(2 R \omega^{2}-g\right)\left[M R \omega^{2}-(m+M) g\right]=0
\end{gathered}
$$

has positive roots

$$
\omega_{1}=\sqrt{\frac{g}{2 R}}, \quad \omega_{2}=\sqrt{\frac{(m+M) g}{M R}},
$$

which are the normal-mode angular frequencies of the system. The ratio of the amplitudes is

$$
\frac{A}{B}=\frac{g-R \omega^{2}}{R \omega^{2}}= \begin{cases}1 & \text { for } \omega=\omega_{1}, \\ -\frac{m}{M+m} & \text { for } \omega=\omega_{2} .\end{cases}
$$

If $m \gg M$

$$
\omega_{1}=\sqrt{\frac{g}{2 R}}, \quad \frac{A}{B}=1,
$$

i.e. $\theta$ and $\varphi$ have the same amplitude and phase;

$$
\omega_{2}=\sqrt{\frac{m g}{M R}}, \quad \frac{A}{B}=-1,
$$

i.e. $\theta$ and $\varphi$ have the same amplitude but opposite phases.

If $m \ll M$,

$$
\omega_{1}=\sqrt{\frac{g}{2 R}}, \quad \frac{A}{B}=1,
$$

i.e. $\theta$ and $\varphi$ have the same amplitude and phase as in the above;

$$
\omega_{2}=\sqrt{\frac{g}{R}}, \quad \frac{A}{B}=-\frac{m}{M},
$$

i.e. $\theta$ has a much smaller amplitude than $\varphi$ and the two oscillations are opposite in phase.

2051.b.Problem Statement:
A simple pendulum consisting of a mass $m$ and weightless string of length $l$ is mounted on a support of mass $M$ which is attached to a horizontal spring with force constant $k$ as shown in Fig. 2.51.

Find the frequencies for small oscillations.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-589.jpg?height=215&width=300&top_left_y=1607&top_left_x=544)

Fig. 2.51.
2051.b.Solution:
Use coordinates with origin at the position of $m$ when the system is in equilibrium, and the $x$ - and $y$-axes along the horizontal and vertical directions respectively as shown in Fig. 2.51. Then $M$ and $m$ have coordinates and velocities

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
(x, l), & (x+l \sin \theta, l-l \cos \theta) \\
(\dot{x}, 0), & (\dot{x}+l \dot{\theta} \cos \theta, l \dot{\theta} \sin \theta)
\end{array}
$$

respectively. The Lagrangian of the system is

$$
\begin{aligned}
L &=T-V \\
&=\frac{1}{2} M \dot{x}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{x}^{2}+l^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+2 l \dot{x} \dot{\theta} \cos \theta\right)-M g l-m g l(1-\cos \theta)-\frac{1}{2} k x^{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Lagrange's equations

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}}=0
$$

then give

$$
\begin{aligned}
(M+m) \ddot{x}-m l \dot{\theta}^{2} \sin \theta+m l \ddot{\theta} \cos \theta+k x &=0, \\
\ddot{\theta}+\ddot{x} \cos \theta+g \sin \theta &=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

For small oscillations, $x, \theta, \dot{x}, \dot{\theta}$ are small quantities. Neglecting terms of orders higher than two, the equations of motion become

$$
\begin{aligned}
(M+m) \ddot{x}+m l \ddot{\theta}+k x &=0, \\
\ddot{\theta}+\ddot{x}+g \theta &=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

Set

$$
x=A \exp (i \omega t), \quad \theta=B \exp (i \omega t) .
$$

These equations become

$$
\left(\begin{array}{cc}
k-(M+m) \omega^{2} & -m l \omega^{2} \\
-\omega^{2} & g-l \omega^{2}
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
A \\
B
\end{array}\right)=0 .
$$

The secular equation

$$
\left|\begin{array}{cc}
k-(M+m) \omega^{2} & -m l \omega^{2} \\
-\omega^{2} & g-l \omega^{2}
\end{array}\right|=M l \omega^{2}-[g(M+m)+k l] \omega^{2}+g k=0
$$

has two positive roots

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\omega_{1}=\left[\frac{g(M+m)+k l+\sqrt{[g(M+m)+k l]^{2}-4 M l g k}}{2 M l}\right]^{\frac{1}{2}}, \\
&\omega_{2}=\left[\frac{g(M+m)+k l-\sqrt{[g(M+m)+k l]^{2}-4 M l g k}}{2 M l}\right]^{\frac{1}{2}},
\end{aligned}
$$

which are the normal-mode angular frequencies of the system.
2051.b.Final Answer: $$\left[\frac{g(M+m)+k l-\sqrt{[g(M+m)+k l]^{2}-4 M l g k}}{2 M l}\right]^{\frac{1}{2}}$$

2052.a.Problem Statement:
Two masses, $2 m$ and $m$, are suspended from a fixed frame by elastic springs as shown in Fig. 2.52. The elastic constant (force/unit length) of each spring is $k$. Consider only vertical motion.

Calculate the frequencies of the normal-modes of oscillations of this system.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-591.jpg?height=250&width=209&top_left_y=1296&top_left_x=639)

Fig. 2.52.
2052.a.Solution:
Let the natural lengths of the upper and lower springs be $l_{1}, l_{2}$, and denote the positions of the upper and lower masses by $y_{1}, y_{2}$ as shown in Fig. 2.52, respectively. The Lagrangian is then 

$$
\begin{aligned}
L &=T-V \\
&=m \dot{y}_{1}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m \dot{y}_{2}^{2}+2 m g y_{1}+m g y_{2}-\frac{1}{2} k\left(y_{1}-l_{1}\right)^{2}-\frac{1}{2} k\left(y_{2}-y_{1}-l_{2}\right)^{2} \\
&=\frac{1}{2} m\left(2 \dot{y}_{1}^{2}+\dot{y}_{2}^{2}\right)+m g\left(2 y_{1}+y_{2}\right)-\frac{1}{2} k\left[\left(y_{1}-l_{1}\right)^{2}+\left(y_{2}-y_{1}-l_{2}\right)^{2}\right] .
\end{aligned}
$$

Lagrange's equations

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}}=0
$$

give

$$
\begin{aligned}
2 m \ddot{y}_{1}+2 k y_{1}-k y_{2} &=2 m g+k l_{1}-k l_{2} \\
m \ddot{y}_{2}+k y_{2}-k y_{1} &=m g+k l_{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Let $y_{1}=y_{1}^{\prime}+\eta_{1}, y_{2}=y_{2}^{\prime}+\eta_{2}$.

The above can be written as

$$
\begin{aligned}
2 m \ddot{y}_{1}^{\prime}+2 k y_{1}^{\prime}-k y_{2}^{\prime} &=0, \\
m \ddot{y}_{2}^{\prime}+k y_{2}^{\prime}-k y_{1}^{\prime} &=0,
\end{aligned}
$$

if we set

$$
\eta_{1}=\frac{3 m g+k l_{1}}{k}, \quad \eta_{2}=\frac{4 m g+k l_{1}+k l_{2}}{k} .
$$

Note that $y_{1}=\eta_{1}, y_{2}=\eta_{2}$ are the equilibrium positions of the masses $2 m$ and $m$ respectively, as can be seen from the force equations

$$
\begin{aligned}
3 m g &=k\left(y_{1}-l_{1}\right) \\
m g &=k\left(y_{2}-y_{1}-l_{2}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

With a solution of the type

$$
y_{1}^{\prime}=A e^{i \omega t}, \quad y_{2}^{\prime}=B e^{i \omega t},
$$

we have

$$
\left(\begin{array}{cc}
2 k-2 m \omega^{2} & -k \\
-k & k-m \omega^{2}
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
A \\
B
\end{array}\right)=0
$$

The secular equation

$$
\left|\begin{array}{cc}
2 k-2 m \omega^{2} & -k \\
-k & k-m \omega^{2}
\end{array}\right|=0
$$

has two positive roots

$$
\omega_{\pm}=\sqrt{\frac{k}{m}\left(1 \pm \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right)},
$$

which are the angular frequencies of the normal-modes of oscillation. As

$$
\frac{B}{A}=\frac{2 k-2 m \omega^{2}}{k}=\mp \sqrt{2},
$$

the corresponding normal-modes are $\left(\begin{array}{c}1 \\ -\sqrt{2}\end{array}\right)$ and $\left(\begin{array}{c}1 \\ \sqrt{2}\end{array}\right)$.

2052.b.Problem Statement:
Two masses, $2 m$ and $m$, are suspended from a fixed frame by elastic springs as shown in Fig. 2.52. The elastic constant (force/unit length) of each spring is $k$. Consider only vertical motion.

The upper mass $2 m$ is slowly displaced downwards from the equilibrium position by a distance $l$ and then let go, so that the system performs free oscillations. Calculate the subsequent motion of the lower mass $m$.
