Fig. 2.52.
2052.b.Solution:
Let the natural lengths of the upper and lower springs be $l_{1}, l_{2}$, and denote the positions of the upper and lower masses by $y_{1}, y_{2}$ as shown in Fig. 2.52, respectively. The Lagrangian is then 

$$
\begin{aligned}
L &=T-V \\
&=m \dot{y}_{1}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m \dot{y}_{2}^{2}+2 m g y_{1}+m g y_{2}-\frac{1}{2} k\left(y_{1}-l_{1}\right)^{2}-\frac{1}{2} k\left(y_{2}-y_{1}-l_{2}\right)^{2} \\
&=\frac{1}{2} m\left(2 \dot{y}_{1}^{2}+\dot{y}_{2}^{2}\right)+m g\left(2 y_{1}+y_{2}\right)-\frac{1}{2} k\left[\left(y_{1}-l_{1}\right)^{2}+\left(y_{2}-y_{1}-l_{2}\right)^{2}\right] .
\end{aligned}
$$

Lagrange's equations

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}}=0
$$

give

$$
\begin{aligned}
2 m \ddot{y}_{1}+2 k y_{1}-k y_{2} &=2 m g+k l_{1}-k l_{2} \\
m \ddot{y}_{2}+k y_{2}-k y_{1} &=m g+k l_{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Let $y_{1}=y_{1}^{\prime}+\eta_{1}, y_{2}=y_{2}^{\prime}+\eta_{2}$.

The above can be written as

$$
\begin{aligned}
2 m \ddot{y}_{1}^{\prime}+2 k y_{1}^{\prime}-k y_{2}^{\prime} &=0, \\
m \ddot{y}_{2}^{\prime}+k y_{2}^{\prime}-k y_{1}^{\prime} &=0,
\end{aligned}
$$

if we set

$$
\eta_{1}=\frac{3 m g+k l_{1}}{k}, \quad \eta_{2}=\frac{4 m g+k l_{1}+k l_{2}}{k} .
$$

Note that $y_{1}=\eta_{1}, y_{2}=\eta_{2}$ are the equilibrium positions of the masses $2 m$ and $m$ respectively, as can be seen from the force equations

$$
\begin{aligned}
3 m g &=k\left(y_{1}-l_{1}\right) \\
m g &=k\left(y_{2}-y_{1}-l_{2}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

With a solution of the type

$$
y_{1}^{\prime}=A e^{i \omega t}, \quad y_{2}^{\prime}=B e^{i \omega t},
$$

we have

$$
\left(\begin{array}{cc}
2 k-2 m \omega^{2} & -k \\
-k & k-m \omega^{2}
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{l}
A \\
B
\end{array}\right)=0
$$

The secular equation

$$
\left|\begin{array}{cc}
2 k-2 m \omega^{2} & -k \\
-k & k-m \omega^{2}
\end{array}\right|=0
$$

has two positive roots

$$
\omega_{\pm}=\sqrt{\frac{k}{m}\left(1 \pm \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right)},
$$

which are the angular frequencies of the normal-modes of oscillation. As

$$
\frac{B}{A}=\frac{2 k-2 m \omega^{2}}{k}=\mp \sqrt{2},
$$

the corresponding normal-modes are $\left(\begin{array}{c}1 \\ -\sqrt{2}\end{array}\right)$ and $\left(\begin{array}{c}1 \\ \sqrt{2}\end{array}\right)$.The general motion of the system is given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
&y_{1}^{\prime}=A \cos \left(\omega_{+} t+\varphi_{1}\right)+A^{\prime} \cos \left(\omega_{-} t+\varphi_{2}\right) \\
&y_{2}^{\prime}=-\sqrt{2} A \cos \left(\omega_{+} t+\varphi_{1}\right)+\sqrt{2} A^{\prime} \cos \left(\omega_{-} t+\varphi_{2}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

The initial condition is that at $t=0$,

$$
y_{1}^{\prime}=y_{2}^{\prime}=l, \quad \dot{y}_{1}^{\prime}=\dot{y}_{2}^{\prime}=0 .
$$

This gives

$$
\begin{gathered}
\varphi_{1}=\varphi_{2}=0, \\
A=\frac{l}{2}\left(1-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right), \quad A^{\prime}=\frac{l}{2}\left(1+\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right) .
\end{gathered}
$$

Hence the motion of the mass $2 m$ is described by

$$
\begin{aligned}
y_{2}=(&\left.\frac{1}{2}-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right) l \cos \left[\sqrt{\frac{k}{m}\left(1+\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right)} t\right] \\
&+\left(\frac{1}{2}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right) l \cos \left[\sqrt{\frac{k}{m}\left(1-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right)} t\right]+l_{1}+l_{2}+\frac{4 m g}{k} .
\end{aligned}
$$
2052.b.Final Answer: $$(\left.\frac{1}{2}-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right) l \cos \left[\sqrt{\frac{k}{m}\left(1+\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right)} t\right] +\left(\frac{1}{2}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right) l \cos \left[\sqrt{\frac{k}{m}\left(1-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right)} t\right]+l_{1}+l_{2}+\frac{4 m g}{k}$$

2057.Problem Statement:
A negligibly thin piece of metal of mass $m$ in the shape of a square hangs from two identical springs at two corners as shown in Fig. 2.58. The springs can move only in the vertical plane. Calculate the frequencies of vibration of the normal-modes of small amplitude oscillations.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-605.jpg?height=258&width=268&top_left_y=1548&top_left_x=275)

Fig. 2.58.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-605.jpg?height=273&width=266&top_left_y=1555&top_left_x=906)

Fig. 2.59.
2057.Solution:
Let $x$ be the vertical displacement of the center of mass of the square from its equilibrium position and $\theta$ the angle of rotation of the square in the vertical plane containing the springs as shown in Fig. 2.59. The square has moment of inertial $\frac{1}{6} m s^{2}, s$ being the length of each side of the square. For small $\theta$, the extensions of the springs are $x+\frac{1}{2} s \theta$ and $x-\frac{1}{2} s \theta$. Hence the kinetic and potential energies are

$$
\begin{aligned}
&T=\frac{1}{2} m \dot{x}^{2}+\frac{1}{12} m s^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2} \\
&V=-m g x+\frac{1}{2} k\left[\left(x+\frac{1}{2} s \theta\right)^{2}+\left(x-\frac{1}{2} s \theta\right)^{2}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

where $k$ is the spring constant, taking the potential reference level at the equilibrium position, and the Lagrangian is

$$
L=T-V=\frac{1}{2} m \dot{x}^{2}+\frac{1}{12} m s^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+m g x-k\left(x^{2}+\frac{1}{4} s^{2} \theta^{2}\right) .
$$

Lagrange's equations

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}}=0
$$

give

$$
\begin{aligned}
&m \ddot{x}+2 k x-m g=0, \\
&\frac{1}{6} m s^{2} \ddot{\theta}+\frac{1}{2} k s^{2} \theta=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

Let $x^{\prime}=x-\frac{m g}{2 k}$ and we can write the first equation as

$$
m \ddot{x}^{\prime}+2 k x^{\prime}=0 .
$$

Thus $x^{\prime}$ and $\theta$ are the normal coordinates of the system with the corresponding normal angular frequencies

$$
\omega_{1}=\sqrt{\frac{2 k}{m}}, \quad \omega_{2}=\sqrt{\frac{3 k}{m}} .
$$

2058.Problem Statement:
A small sphere, mass $m$ and radius $r$, hangs like a pendulum between two plates of a capacitor, as shown in Fig. 2.60, from an insulating rod of length $l$. The plates are grounded and the potential of the sphere is $V$.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-607.jpg?height=429&width=540&top_left_y=506&top_left_x=407)

Fig, $2.60$.

The position of the sphere is displaced by an amount $\Delta x$. Calculate the frequency of small oscillations and specify for what conditions of the voltage $V$ such oscillations occur. Make reasonable approximations to simplify the calculation.
2058.Solution:
We assume that the mass of the insulating rod and the radius of the sphere are very small and can be neglected. The charge on the sphere is

$$
q=4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r V
$$

$\varepsilon_{0}$ being the permittivity of free space. According to the method of images, the forces between the sphere and the plates of the capacitor are the same as those between the charges on the sphere and its images symmetrically located at positions as shown in Fig. 2.60. Take $x$-axis along the horizontal with origin at the equilibrium position. The kinetic and potential energies of the system are respectively 

$$
\begin{aligned}
T &=\frac{1}{2} m \dot{x}^{2} \\
V &=-\frac{q^{2}}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}}\left[\frac{1}{b+2 x}+\frac{1}{b-2 x}\right]+m g l(1-\cos \theta) \\
&=-\frac{q^{2}}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}} \frac{2 b}{b^{2}-4 x^{2}}+m g l(1-\cos \theta)
\end{aligned}
$$

For small $x, x \approx l \theta$,

$$
\frac{1}{b^{2}-4 x^{2}} \approx \frac{1}{b^{2}}\left(1+\frac{4 l^{2} \theta^{2}}{b^{2}}\right),
$$

and the Lagrangian is

$$
L=T-V=\frac{1}{2} m l^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+\frac{q^{2}}{2 \pi \varepsilon_{0} b}\left(1+\frac{4 l^{2} \theta^{2}}{b^{2}}\right)-\frac{1}{2} m g l \theta^{2} .
$$

Lagrange's equation

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\theta}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial \theta}=0
$$

gives

$$
m l^{2} \ddot{\theta}-\frac{4 q^{2}}{\pi \varepsilon_{0}} \frac{l^{2} \theta}{b^{3}}+m g l \theta=0 .
$$

Hence the angular frequency of small oscillations is

$$
\omega=\sqrt{\frac{g}{l}-\frac{4 q^{2}}{\pi \varepsilon_{0}} \frac{1}{m b^{3}}}=\sqrt{\frac{g}{l}-\frac{64 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r^{2} V^{2}}{m b^{3}}} .
$$

The condition for such oscillations to take place is that $\omega$ be real, i.e.

$$
V<\sqrt{\frac{g m b^{3}}{64 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r^{2} l}}
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-609.jpg?height=483&width=1010&top_left_y=217&top_left_x=197)

Fig. $2.61$

Note that the above solution is only approximate since the images themselves will produce more images, some of which are shown in Fig. 2.61, which also have to be taken into account. Thus the potential due to electrostatic interactions is

$$
\begin{aligned}
U &=-\frac{q^{2}}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}} \sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\left[\frac{1}{(2 n-1) b-2 x}+\frac{1}{(2 n-1) b+2 x}-\frac{2}{2 n b}\right] \\
& \approx-\frac{q^{2}}{2 \pi \varepsilon_{0}} \sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\left\{\frac{1}{(2 n-1) b}\left[1+\frac{4 x^{2}}{(2 n-1)^{2} b^{2}}\right]-\frac{1}{2 n b}\right\} \\
&=-\frac{q^{2}}{2 \pi \varepsilon_{0} b} \sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\left[\left(\frac{1}{2 n-1}-\frac{1}{2 n}\right)+\frac{4 x^{2}}{(2 n-1)^{3} b^{2}}\right] \\
&=-\frac{q^{2}}{2 \pi \varepsilon_{0} b}\left(\alpha+\frac{4 l^{2} \theta^{2} \beta}{b^{2}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

with

$$
\alpha=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{2 n(2 n-1)}, \quad \beta=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{(2 n-1)^{3}} .
$$

This would give

$$
\omega=\sqrt{\frac{g}{l}-\frac{64 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r^{2} V^{2} \beta}{m b^{3}}}
$$

and the condition for oscillations 

$$
V<\sqrt{\frac{g m b^{3}}{64 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r^{2} l \beta}} .
$$

The $\beta$ series converges rapidly. With maximum $n=3, \beta=1.05$ and the third decimal remains unchanged when more terms are added. As $\beta^{-\frac{1}{2}}=0.98$, the two-image calculation gives a good approximation.

2059.a.Problem Statement:
A smooth uniform circular hoop of mass $M$ and radius $a$ swings in a vertical plane about a point $O$ at which it is freely hinged to a fixed support. A bead $B$ of mass $m$ slides without friction on the hoop. Denote the inclination $O C$ (where $C$ is the center of the hoop) to the downward vertical by $\varphi$.

Find the equations of motion for $\theta$ and $\varphi$.
2059.a.Solution:
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-610.jpg?height=338&width=301&top_left_y=1127&top_left_x=661)

Fig. $2.62$

The moment of inertia of the hoop about $O$ is

$$
I=M a^{2}+M a^{2}=2 M a^{2} .
$$

Use coordinates as shown in Fig. 2.62. The coordinates and velocity of the bead are respectively

$(a \sin \theta+a \sin \varphi,-a \cos \theta-a \cos \varphi),(a \dot{\theta} \cos \theta+a \dot{\varphi} \cos \varphi, a \dot{\theta} \sin \theta+a \dot{\varphi} \sin \varphi)$. The Lagrangian of the system is

$$
\begin{aligned}
L=T-V=& M a^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m a^{2}\left[\dot{\theta}^{2}+\dot{\varphi}^{2}+2 \dot{\theta} \dot{\varphi} \cos (\theta-\varphi)\right] \\
&+M g a \cos \theta+m g a(\cos \theta+\cos \varphi) \\
=& \frac{1}{2}(2 M+m) a^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m a^{2} \dot{\varphi}^{2}+m a^{2} \dot{\theta} \dot{\varphi} \cos (\theta-\varphi) \\
&+(M+m) g a \cos \theta+m g a \cos \varphi
\end{aligned}
$$

Lagrange's equations give

$$
\begin{aligned}
&(2 M+m) a \ddot{\theta}+m a \ddot{\varphi} \cos (\theta-\varphi)+m a \dot{\varphi}^{2} \sin (\theta-\varphi)+(M+m) g \sin \theta=0, \\
&a \ddot{\theta} \cos (\theta-\varphi)+a \ddot{\varphi}-a \dot{\theta}^{2} \sin (\theta-\varphi)+g \sin \varphi=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

2059.b.Problem Statement:
A smooth uniform circular hoop of mass $M$ and radius $a$ swings in a vertical plane about a point $O$ at which it is freely hinged to a fixed support. A bead $B$ of mass $m$ slides without friction on the hoop. Denote the inclination $O C$ (where $C$ is the center of the hoop) to the downward vertical by $\varphi$.

Find the characteristic frequencies and normal-modes for small oscillations about the position of stable equilibrium.
2059.b.Solution:
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-610.jpg?height=338&width=301&top_left_y=1127&top_left_x=661)

Fig. $2.62$

The moment of inertia of the hoop about $O$ is

$$
I=M a^{2}+M a^{2}=2 M a^{2} .
$$

Use coordinates as shown in Fig. 2.62. The coordinates and velocity of the bead are respectively

$(a \sin \theta+a \sin \varphi,-a \cos \theta-a \cos \varphi),(a \dot{\theta} \cos \theta+a \dot{\varphi} \cos \varphi, a \dot{\theta} \sin \theta+a \dot{\varphi} \sin \varphi)$. The Lagrangian of the system is

$$
\begin{aligned}
L=T-V=& M a^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m a^{2}\left[\dot{\theta}^{2}+\dot{\varphi}^{2}+2 \dot{\theta} \dot{\varphi} \cos (\theta-\varphi)\right] \\
&+M g a \cos \theta+m g a(\cos \theta+\cos \varphi) \\
=& \frac{1}{2}(2 M+m) a^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m a^{2} \dot{\varphi}^{2}+m a^{2} \dot{\theta} \dot{\varphi} \cos (\theta-\varphi) \\
&+(M+m) g a \cos \theta+m g a \cos \varphi
\end{aligned}
$$

Lagrange's equations give

$$
\begin{aligned}
&(2 M+m) a \ddot{\theta}+m a \ddot{\varphi} \cos (\theta-\varphi)+m a \dot{\varphi}^{2} \sin (\theta-\varphi)+(M+m) g \sin \theta=0, \\
&a \ddot{\theta} \cos (\theta-\varphi)+a \ddot{\varphi}-a \dot{\theta}^{2} \sin (\theta-\varphi)+g \sin \varphi=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$For small oscillations, retaining terms up to second order in the small quantities $\theta, \varphi, \dot{\theta}, \dot{\varphi}$, we have from the above

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\ddot{\theta}+\left(\frac{M+m}{2 M+m}\right) \frac{g \theta}{a}+\frac{m}{2 M+m} \ddot{\varphi}=0, \\
&\ddot{\theta}+\frac{g}{a} \varphi+\ddot{\varphi}=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

For a solution of the type $\theta=A \exp (i \omega t), \varphi=B \exp (i \omega t)$, the above become

$$
\begin{aligned}
{\left[\left(\frac{M+m}{2 M+m}\right) \frac{g}{a}-\omega^{2}\right] A-\frac{m \omega^{2}}{2 M+m} B } &=0 \\
-\omega^{2} A+\left(\frac{g}{a}-\omega^{2}\right) B &=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

For nonzero solutions the determinant of the coefficients must vanish. Thus

$$
\left[M \omega^{2}-\frac{(M+m) g}{a}\right]\left(2 \omega^{2}-\frac{g}{a}\right)=0
$$

whose two positive roots

$$
\omega_{1}=\sqrt{\frac{g}{2 a}}, \quad \omega_{2}=\sqrt{\left(\frac{M+m}{M}\right) \frac{g}{a}}
$$

are the characteristic angular frequencies of the system for small oscillations. As $\frac{A}{B}=\frac{g}{a \omega^{2}}-1$, we have for $\omega=\omega_{1}, \frac{A}{B}=1$ and the normal-mode $\left(\begin{array}{l}1 \\ 1\end{array}\right)$, for $\omega=\omega_{2}, \frac{A}{B}=-\frac{m}{M+m}$ and the normal-mode $\left(\begin{array}{c}1 \\ -\frac{M+m}{m}\end{array}\right)$.

2060.Problem Statement:
A small body of mass $m$ and charge $q$ is constrained to move without friction on the interior of a cone of opening angle $2 \alpha$. A charge $-q$ is fixed at the apex of the cone as shown in Fig. 2.63. There is no gravity. Find the frequency of small oscillations about equilibrium trajectories of the moving body in terms of $\dot{\varphi}_{0}$, the equilibrium angular velocity of the body around the inside of the cone. Assume $v \ll c$ so that radiation is negligible.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-612.jpg?height=487&width=297&top_left_y=779&top_left_x=659)

Fig. $2.63$
2060.Solution:
Use coordinates as shown in Fig. 2.63. In the Cartesian system, $m$ has coordinates $(r \cos \varphi, r \sin \varphi, z)$, or, as $z=r \cot \alpha,(r \cos \varphi, r \sin \varphi, r \cot \alpha)$, and velocity

$(\dot{r} \cos \varphi-r \dot{\varphi} \sin \varphi, r \sin \varphi+r \dot{\varphi} \cos \varphi, \dot{r} \cot \alpha)$.

The Lagrangian is then

$$
\begin{aligned}
L=T-V &=\frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{r}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\varphi}^{2}+\dot{r}^{2} \cot ^{2} \alpha\right)+\frac{q^{2}}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}} \cdot \frac{\sin \alpha}{r} \\
&=\frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{r}^{2} \csc ^{2} \alpha+r^{2} \dot{\varphi}^{2}\right)+\frac{q^{2} \sin \alpha}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Analytical Mechanics

601

Lagrange's equations

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}}=0
$$

give

$$
\begin{gathered}
m \ddot{r} \csc ^{2} \alpha-m r \dot{\varphi}^{2}+\frac{q^{2} \sin \alpha}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r^{2}}=0 \\
m r^{2} \dot{\varphi}=J \text { (constant) }
\end{gathered}
$$

or, combining the above,

$$
m \ddot{r} \csc ^{2} \alpha-\frac{J^{2}}{m r^{3}}+\frac{q^{2} \sin \alpha}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r^{2}}=0
$$

For the equilibrium trajectory,

$$
\ddot{r}=0, \quad r=r_{0}, \quad \dot{\varphi}=\dot{\varphi}_{0},
$$

the above becomes

$$
\frac{J^{2}}{m r_{0}^{3}}=\frac{q^{2} \sin \alpha}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r_{0}^{2}}
$$

For small oscillations about equilibrium, let $r=r_{0}+\xi$, where $\xi \ll r_{0}$. Then

$$
\frac{1}{r^{2}} \approx \frac{1}{r_{0}^{2}}\left(1-\frac{2 \xi}{r_{0}}\right), \quad \frac{1}{r^{3}}=\frac{1}{r_{0}^{3}}\left(1-\frac{3 \xi}{r_{0}}\right)
$$

and Eq.
(1) becomes

$$
m \ddot{\xi}+\frac{q^{2} \sin ^{3} \alpha}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r_{0}^{3}} \xi=0 .
$$

Hence the angular frequency for small oscillations is

$$
\omega=\sqrt{\frac{q^{2} \sin ^{3} \alpha}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} m r_{0}^{3}}}=\dot{\varphi}_{0} \sin \alpha,
$$

as

$$
\dot{\varphi}_{0}=\sqrt{\frac{J^{2}}{m^{2} r_{0}^{4}}}=\sqrt{\frac{q^{2} \sin \alpha}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} m r_{0}^{3}}} .
$$

2061.a.Problem Statement:
A flywheel of moment of inertia I rotates about its center in a horizontal plane. A mass $m$ can slide freely along one of the spokes and is attached to the center of the wheel by a spring of natural length $l$ and force constant $k$ as shown in Fig. 2.64.

Find an expression for the energy of this system in terms of $r, \dot{r}$, and the angular momentum $J$.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-614.jpg?height=304&width=312&top_left_y=867&top_left_x=629)

Fig. 2.64.

2061.b.Problem Statement:
A flywheel of moment of inertia I rotates about its center in a horizontal plane. A mass $m$ can slide freely along one of the spokes and is attached to the center of the wheel by a spring of natural length $l$ and force constant $k$ as shown in Fig. 2.64.

Suppose the flywheel initially has a constant angular velocity $\Omega_{0}$ and the spring has a steady extension $r=r_{0}$. Use the result of part (a) to determine the relation between $\Omega_{0}$ and $r_{0}$ and the frequency of small oscillations about this initial configuration.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-614.jpg?height=304&width=312&top_left_y=867&top_left_x=629)

Fig. 2.64.
2061.b.Solution:
Let $r$ be the distance of $m$ from the center and $\dot{\theta}$ the angular velocity of the flywheel at time $t$. The system has angular momentum

$$
J=I \dot{\theta}+m r^{2} \dot{\theta}
$$

and energy

$$
\begin{aligned}
T+V &=\frac{1}{2} I \dot{\theta}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{r}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}\right)+\frac{1}{2} k(r-l)^{2} \\
&=\frac{J^{2}}{2\left(I+m r^{2}\right)}+\frac{1}{2} m \dot{r}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} k(r-l)^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$The Lagrangian of the system is

$$
L=T-V=\frac{1}{2} I \dot{\theta}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m \dot{r}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m r^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}-\frac{1}{2} k(r-l)^{2} .
$$

Lagrange's equations

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}}=0
$$

give

$$
\begin{aligned}
&m \ddot{r}-m r \dot{\theta}^{2}+k(r-l)=0, \\
&\left(I+m r^{2}\right) \dot{\theta}=\text { constant }=J,
\end{aligned}
$$

or, combining the two,

$$
m \ddot{r}-\frac{m r J^{2}}{\left(I+m r^{2}\right)^{2}}+k(r-l)=0 .
$$

Initially, $\ddot{r}=0, r=r_{0}, \dot{\theta}=\Omega_{0}, J=\left(I+m r_{0}^{2}\right) \Omega_{0}$. For small oscillations about this equilibrium configuration, let $r=r_{0}+\rho$, where $\rho \ll r_{0}$. As

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{m r J^{2}}{\left(I+m r^{2}\right)^{2}} & \approx \frac{m\left(r_{0}+\rho\right) J^{2}}{\left(I+m r_{0}^{2}+2 m r_{0} \rho\right)^{2}} \\
& \approx \frac{m r_{0} J^{2}}{\left(I+m r_{0}^{2}\right)^{2}}\left(1+\frac{\rho}{r_{0}}-\frac{4 m r_{0} \rho}{I+m r_{0}^{2}}\right) \\
& \approx \frac{m r_{0} J^{2}}{\left(I+m r_{0}^{2}\right)^{2}}\left[1-\left(\frac{3 m r_{0}^{2}-I}{I+m r_{0}^{2}}\right) \frac{\rho}{r_{0}}\right] \\
& \approx \frac{m r_{0} J^{2}}{\left(I+m r_{0}^{2}\right)^{2}}-\left(\frac{3 m r_{0}^{2}-I}{I+m r_{0}^{2}}\right) m \Omega_{0}^{2} \rho, \\
\frac{m r_{0} J^{2}}{\left(I+m r_{0}^{2}\right)^{2}} &=m r_{0} \Omega_{0}^{2}=k\left(r_{0}-l\right),
\end{aligned}
$$

Eq.
(2) becomes

$$
\ddot{\rho}+\left[\frac{k}{m}+\left(\frac{3 m r_{0}^{2}-I}{I+m r_{0}^{2}}\right) \Omega_{0}^{2}\right] \rho=0 .
$$

Therefore, provided that $I$ is such that

$$
\left(\frac{I-3 m r_{0}^{2}}{I+m r_{0}^{2}}\right) \Omega_{0}^{2}<\frac{k}{m},
$$

the system will oscillate about the initial configuration with angular frequency

$$
\omega=\sqrt{\frac{k}{m}+\left(\frac{3 m r_{0}^{2}-I}{I+m r_{0}^{2}}\right) \Omega_{0}^{2}}
$$

after a small perturbation. Note that Eq.
(1) implies

$$
r_{0}=\frac{k l}{k-m \Omega_{0}^{2}},
$$

i.e. $r_{0}$ itself is related to $\Omega_{0}$.

2062.Problem Statement:
Three point-like masses (two of them equal) and the massless springs (constant $K$ ) connecting them are constrained to move in a frictionless tube of radius $R$. This system is in gravitational field (g) as shown in Fig. 2.65. The springs are of zero length at equilibrium and the masses may move through one another. Using Lagrangian methods, find the normal-modes of small vibration about the position of equilibrium of this system and describe each of the modes.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-616.jpg?height=206&width=308&top_left_y=1355&top_left_x=323)

Fig. 2.65.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-616.jpg?height=312&width=369&top_left_y=1265&top_left_x=935)

Fig. 2.66.

2065.Problem Statement: A particle of mass $M$ moves along the $x$-axis under the influence of the potential energy $V(x)=-K x \exp (-a x)$, where $K$ and $a$ are positive constants. Find the equilibrium position and the period of small oscillations about this equilibrium position. Consider also the cases where $K$ and/or $a$ are negative.
2065.Solution:
Expand the potential near a point $x_{0}$ :

$$
V(x)=V\left(x_{0}\right)+\left(\frac{\partial V}{\partial x}\right)_{x_{0}}\left(x-x_{0}\right)+\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{\partial^{2} V}{\partial x^{2}}\right)_{x_{0}}\left(x-x_{0}\right)^{2}+\ldots .
$$

For $x_{0}$ to be an equilibrium position,

$$
\left(\frac{\partial V}{\partial x}\right)_{x_{0}}=K\left(a x_{0}-1\right) e^{-a x_{0}}=0
$$

giving

$$
x_{0}=\frac{1}{a} .
$$

As

$$
\left(\frac{\partial^{2} V}{\partial x^{2}}\right)_{V_{0}}=a K\left(2-a x_{0}\right) e^{-a x_{0}}=\frac{a k}{e}>0
$$

the equilibrium is stable.

Let

$$
\xi=x-x_{0}=x-\frac{1}{a}
$$

and take $x_{0}$ as the reference level of potential energy. Then the potential at $\xi$ is

$$
V(\xi)=\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{\partial^{2} V}{\partial x^{2}}\right)_{x_{0}} \xi^{2}=\frac{a K}{2 e} \xi^{2} .
$$

The Lagrangian is then

$$
L=T-V=\frac{1}{2} M \dot{\xi}^{2}-\frac{a K}{2 e} \xi^{2} .
$$

Lagrange's equation

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\xi}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial \xi}=0
$$

yields

$$
M \ddot{\xi}+\frac{a K}{e} \xi=0 .
$$

This shows that the angular frequency of small oscillations about the equilibrium position is

$$
\omega=\sqrt{\frac{a K}{M e}},
$$

and the period is

$$
T=\frac{2 \pi}{\omega}=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{M e}{a K}} .
$$

If both $a$ and $K$ are negative, then $a K$ is positive and the above results still hold.

If only one of $a, K$ is negative then

$$
\left(\frac{\partial^{2} V}{\partial x^{2}}\right)_{x_{0}}<0,
$$

which means that the potential at equilibrium is a maximum and the equilibrium is unstable. Hence no oscillation occurs. This can also be seen from the equation of motion, which would give an imaginary $\omega$.

2066.a.Problem Statement:
A particle of mass $m$ moves under gravity on a smooth surface the equation of which is $z=x^{2}+y^{2}-x y$, the $z$-axis being vertical, pointing upwards.

Find the equations of motion of the particle.
2066.a.Solution:
As

$$
\begin{aligned}
&z=x^{2}+y^{2}-x y \\
&\dot{z}=2 x \dot{x}+2 y \dot{y}-\dot{x} y-x \dot{y}=\dot{x}(2 x-y)+\dot{y}(2 y-x) .
\end{aligned}
$$

The Lagrangian is

$$
\begin{aligned}
L=& T-V \\
=& \frac{1}{2} m\left[\dot{x}^{2}+\dot{y}^{2}+\dot{x}^{2}(2 x-y)^{2}+\dot{y}^{2}(2 y-x)^{2}+2 \dot{x} \dot{y}(2 x-y)(2 y-x)\right] \\
&-m g\left(x^{2}+y^{2}-x y\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Lagrange's equations

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}}=0
$$

give

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\frac{d}{d t}\left[\dot{x}+\dot{x}(2 x-y)^{2}+\dot{y}(2 x-y)(2 y-x)\right] \\
&=2 \dot{x}^{2}(2 x-y)-\dot{y}^{2}(2 y-x)+2 \dot{x} \dot{y}(2 y-x)-\dot{x} \dot{y}(2 x-y)-2 g x+g y, \\
&\frac{d}{d t}\left[\dot{y}+\dot{y}(2 y-x)^{2}+\dot{x}(2 x-y)(2 y-x)\right] \\
&=2 \dot{y}^{2}(2 y-x)-\dot{x}^{2}(2 x-y)+2 \dot{x} \dot{y}(2 x-y)-\dot{x} \dot{y}(2 y-x)-2 g y+g x .
\end{aligned}
$$
2066.a.Final Answer: $$2 \dot{y}^{2}(2 y-x)-\dot{x}^{2}(2 x-y)+2 \dot{x} \dot{y}(2 x-y)-\dot{x} \dot{y}(2 y-x)-2 g y+g x$$

2066.b.Problem Statement:
A particle of mass $m$ moves under gravity on a smooth surface the equation of which is $z=x^{2}+y^{2}-x y$, the $z$-axis being vertical, pointing upwards.

Find the frequencies of the normal-modes for small oscillations about the position of stable equilibrium.
2066.b.Solution:
As

$$
\begin{aligned}
&z=x^{2}+y^{2}-x y \\
&\dot{z}=2 x \dot{x}+2 y \dot{y}-\dot{x} y-x \dot{y}=\dot{x}(2 x-y)+\dot{y}(2 y-x) .
\end{aligned}
$$

The Lagrangian is

$$
\begin{aligned}
L=& T-V \\
=& \frac{1}{2} m\left[\dot{x}^{2}+\dot{y}^{2}+\dot{x}^{2}(2 x-y)^{2}+\dot{y}^{2}(2 y-x)^{2}+2 \dot{x} \dot{y}(2 x-y)(2 y-x)\right] \\
&-m g\left(x^{2}+y^{2}-x y\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Lagrange's equations

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}}=0
$$

give

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\frac{d}{d t}\left[\dot{x}+\dot{x}(2 x-y)^{2}+\dot{y}(2 x-y)(2 y-x)\right] \\
&=2 \dot{x}^{2}(2 x-y)-\dot{y}^{2}(2 y-x)+2 \dot{x} \dot{y}(2 y-x)-\dot{x} \dot{y}(2 x-y)-2 g x+g y, \\
&\frac{d}{d t}\left[\dot{y}+\dot{y}(2 y-x)^{2}+\dot{x}(2 x-y)(2 y-x)\right] \\
&=2 \dot{y}^{2}(2 y-x)-\dot{x}^{2}(2 x-y)+2 \dot{x} \dot{y}(2 x-y)-\dot{x} \dot{y}(2 y-x)-2 g y+g x .
\end{aligned}
$$As

$$
\frac{\partial V}{\partial x}=m g(2 x-y), \quad \frac{\partial V}{\partial y}=m g(2 y-x),
$$

equilibrium occurs at the origin $(0,0)$. For small oscillations about the origin, $x, y, \dot{x}, \dot{y}$ are small quantities and the equations of motion reduce to

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\ddot{x}+2 g x-g y=0, \\
&\ddot{y}+2 g y-g x=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

Considering a solution of the type

$$
x=x_{0} e^{i \omega t}, \quad y=y_{0} e^{i \omega t},
$$

we find the secular equation

$$
\left|\begin{array}{cc}
2 g-\omega^{2} & -g \\
-g & 2 g-\omega^{2}
\end{array}\right|=\left(g-\omega^{2}\right)\left(3 g-\omega^{2}\right)=0 .
$$

Its position roots

$$
\omega_{1}=\sqrt{g}, \quad \omega_{2}=\sqrt{3 g}
$$

are the angular frequencies of the normal-modes of the system. Note that as $\omega_{1}, \omega_{2}$ are real the equilibrium is stable.

2067.Problem Statement: A rigid structure consists of three massless rods joined at a point attached to two point masses (each of mass $m$ ) as shown in Fig. 2.69, with $A B=B C=L, B D=l$, the angle $A B D=D B C=\theta$. The rigid system is supported at the point $D$ and rocks back and forth with a small amplitude of oscillation. What is the oscillation frequency? What is the limit on $l$ for stable oscillations?
2067.Solution:
The structure oscillates in a vertical plane. Take it as the $x y$-plane as shown in Fig. $2.70$ with the origin at the point of support $D$ and the $y$-axis vertically upwards. We have

$$
\overline{A D}=\overline{C D}=b=\sqrt{L^{2}+l^{2}-2 L l \cos \theta},
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-629.jpg?height=418&width=289&top_left_y=219&top_left_x=608)

Fig. 2.69.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-629.jpg?height=459&width=339&top_left_y=781&top_left_x=579)

Fig. 2.70.

and the angles between $\overline{A D}$ and $\overline{C D}$ with the vertical are $\alpha+\varphi, \alpha-\varphi$ respectively, where $\alpha=\theta+\psi, \psi$ being given by

$$
\frac{b}{\sin \theta}=\frac{l}{\sin \psi} .
$$

The masses $m_{1}, m_{2}$ have coordinates

$$
(-b \sin (\alpha+\varphi),-b \cos (\alpha+\varphi)),(b \sin (\alpha-\varphi),-b \cos (\alpha-\varphi))
$$

and velocities

$$
(-b \dot{\varphi} \cos (\alpha+\varphi), b \dot{\varphi} \sin (\alpha+\varphi)),(-b \dot{\varphi} \cos (\alpha-\varphi),-b \dot{\varphi} \sin (\alpha-\varphi))
$$

respectively. Thus the Lagrangian is 

$$
L=T-V=m b^{2} \dot{\varphi}^{2}+m g b[\cos (\alpha+\varphi)+\cos (\alpha-\varphi)] .
$$

Lagrange's equation

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\varphi}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial \varphi}=0
$$

then gives

$$
2 m b^{2} \ddot{\varphi}+m g b[\sin (\alpha+\varphi)-\sin (\alpha-\varphi)]=0 .
$$

For small oscillations, $\varphi \ll \alpha$ and

$$
\sin (\alpha \pm \varphi) \approx \sin \alpha \pm \varphi \cos \alpha,
$$

so the equation of motion reduces to

$$
b \ddot{\varphi}+\varphi g \cos \alpha=0,
$$

giving the angular frequency as

$$
\omega=\sqrt{\frac{g \cos \alpha}{b}} .
$$

As

$$
\begin{aligned}
\cos \alpha &=\cos (\theta+\psi)=\cos \theta \cos \psi-\sin \theta \sin \psi \\
&=\frac{1}{b}\left(\sqrt{b^{2}-l^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta} \cos \theta-l \sin ^{2} \theta\right) \\
&=\frac{1}{b}(L \cos \theta-l)
\end{aligned}
$$

we have

$$
\omega=\sqrt{\frac{g(L \cos \theta-l)}{L^{2}+l^{2}-2 L l \cos \theta}} .
$$

Since

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{\partial^{2} V}{\partial \varphi^{2}} &=m g b[\cos (\alpha+\varphi)+\cos (\alpha-\varphi)] \\
&=2 m g b \cos \alpha
\end{aligned}
$$

at the equilibrium position $\varphi=0$, oscillations are stable if $\cos \alpha>0$. This requires that

$$
L \cos \theta-l>0,
$$

or

$$
l<L \cos \theta .
$$

2070.a.Problem Statement:
A motor turns a vertical shaft to which is attached a simple pendulum of length $l$ and mass $m$ as shown in Fig. 2.72. The pendulum is constrained to move in a plane. This plane is rotated at constant angular speed $\omega$ by the motor.

Find the equations of motion of the mass $m$.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-635.jpg?height=480&width=189&top_left_y=1135&top_left_x=659)

Fig. 2.72.
2070.a.Solution:
Use rotating coordinates as shown in Fig. $2.72$ with the $x$ - and $z$-axes in the plane of oscillation of the pendulum. In this frame the mass $m$ has coordinates 

$$
(l \sin \theta, 0,-l \cos \theta)
$$

and velocity

$$
(l \dot{\theta} \cos \theta, 0, l \dot{\theta} \sin \theta) .
$$

In the fixed frame $m$ has an additional velocity

$$
\begin{aligned}
\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{r} &=(0,0, \omega) \times(l \sin \theta, 0,-l \cos \theta) \\
&=(0, \omega l \sin \theta, 0) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the Lagrangian of the system is

$$
L=T-V=\frac{1}{2} m l^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m l^{2} \omega^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta+m g l \cos \theta .
$$

Lagrange's equation

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\theta}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial \theta}=0
$$

then gives

$$
\ddot{\theta}+\left(\frac{g}{l}-\omega^{2} \cos \theta\right) \sin \theta=0 .
$$

2070.c.Problem Statement:
A motor turns a vertical shaft to which is attached a simple pendulum of length $l$ and mass $m$ as shown in Fig. 2.72. The pendulum is constrained to move in a plane. This plane is rotated at constant angular speed $\omega$ by the motor.

Find the angular frequencies of any oscillatory motions.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-635.jpg?height=480&width=189&top_left_y=1135&top_left_x=659)

Fig. 2.72.
2070.c.Solution:
Use rotating coordinates as shown in Fig. $2.72$ with the $x$ - and $z$-axes in the plane of oscillation of the pendulum. In this frame the mass $m$ has coordinates 

$$
(l \sin \theta, 0,-l \cos \theta)
$$

and velocity

$$
(l \dot{\theta} \cos \theta, 0, l \dot{\theta} \sin \theta) .
$$

In the fixed frame $m$ has an additional velocity

$$
\begin{aligned}
\boldsymbol{\omega} \times \mathbf{r} &=(0,0, \omega) \times(l \sin \theta, 0,-l \cos \theta) \\
&=(0, \omega l \sin \theta, 0) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the Lagrangian of the system is

$$
L=T-V=\frac{1}{2} m l^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m l^{2} \omega^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta+m g l \cos \theta .
$$

Lagrange's equation

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\theta}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial \theta}=0
$$

then gives

$$
\ddot{\theta}+\left(\frac{g}{l}-\omega^{2} \cos \theta\right) \sin \theta=0 .
$$For equilibrium, $\ddot{\theta}=0$. The equation of motion gives the equilibrium positions as

$$
\theta_{1}=0, \quad \theta_{2}=\arccos \left(\frac{g}{l \omega^{2}}\right) .
$$

For oscillation near $\theta_{1}=0$, in the small angle approximation the equation of motion reduces to

$$
\ddot{\theta}+\left(\frac{g}{l}-\omega^{2}\right) \theta=0 .
$$

If $\omega<\sqrt{\frac{9}{l}}$, the equilibrium is stable. $\theta$ is harmonic and can be represented by

$$
\theta(t)=A_{1} \cos \left(\Omega_{1} t+\varphi_{1}\right),
$$

where $A_{1}, \varphi_{1}$ are constants to be determined from the initial conditions, and $\Omega_{1}=\sqrt{\frac{9}{l}-\omega^{2}}$ is the angular frequency of small angle oscillations. If $\omega>\sqrt{\frac{g}{l}}$, the equilibrium is unstable.

For oscillations near $\theta_{2}$, let $\theta=\theta_{2}+\alpha$, where $\alpha \ll \theta_{2}$. The equation of motion is then, in the first approximation,

$$
\ddot{\alpha}+\left(\frac{g}{l}-\omega^{2} \cos \theta_{2}+\omega^{2} \alpha \sin \theta_{2}\right)\left(\sin \theta_{2}+\alpha \cos \theta_{2}\right)=0,
$$

or

$$
\ddot{\alpha}+\alpha \omega^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta_{2}=0
$$

The solution is

$$
\alpha(t)=A_{2} \cos \left(\Omega_{2} t+\varphi_{2}\right)
$$

where $\Omega_{2}=\omega \sin \theta_{2}=\frac{1}{l \omega} \sqrt{l^{2} \omega^{4}-g^{2}}$ is the angular frequency of small oscillations about $\theta_{2}, A_{2}, \varphi_{2}$ are constants to be determined from the initial conditions. Hence

$$
\theta(t)=A_{2} \cos \left(\Omega_{2} t+\varphi_{2}\right)+\theta_{2} .
$$

For small angle oscillations about $\theta_{1}$, the angular frequency is $\Omega_{1}=$ $\sqrt{\frac{g}{l}-\omega^{2}}$; and about $\theta_{2}, \Omega_{2}=\frac{1}{l \omega} \sqrt{l^{2} \omega^{4}-g^{2}}$.

2072.a.Problem Statement:
Consider a particle of mass $m$ which is constrained to move on the surface of a sphere of radius $R$. There are no externol forces of any kind on the particle.

What is the number of generalized coordinates necessary to describe the problem?
2072.a.Solution: As the particle is constrained to move on the surface of a sphere, there are two degrees of freedom and hence two generalized coordinates are needed.

2072.c.Problem Statement:
Consider a particle of mass $m$ which is constrained to move on the surface of a sphere of radius $R$. There are no externol forces of any kind on the particle.

What is the Hamiltonian of the system? Is it conserved? sphere.
2072.c.Solution:
As the particle is constrained to move on the surface of a sphere, there are two degrees of freedom and hence two generalized coordinates are needed.Choose $(\theta, \varphi)$ of spherical coordinates as the generalized coordinates. As there are no external forces, $V=0$. The Lagrangian of the system is

$$
L=T=\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}=\frac{1}{2} m R^{2}\left(\dot{\theta}^{2}+\dot{\varphi}^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta\right) .
$$

As $p_{i}=\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}$, we have

$$
p_{\theta}=m R^{2} \dot{\theta}, \quad p_{\varphi}=m R^{2} \dot{\varphi} \sin ^{2} \theta,
$$

and

$$
H=p_{\theta} \dot{\theta}+p_{\varphi} \dot{\varphi}-L=\frac{1}{2 m R^{2}}\left(p_{\theta}^{2}+\frac{p_{\varphi}^{2}}{\sin ^{2} \theta}\right) .
$$

Since the Hamiltonian $H$ is not an explicit function of time, it is a constant of the motion, or, in other words, conserved.

2073.a.Problem Statement:
A light, uniform U-shaped tube is partially filled with mercury (total mass $M$, mass per unit length $\rho$ ) as shown in Fig. 2.73. The tube is mounted so that it can rotate about one of the vertical legs. Neglect friction, the mass and moment of inertia of the glass tube, and the moment of inertia of the mercury column on the axis of rotation.

Calculate the potential energy of the mercury column and describe its possible motion when the tube is not spinning.

1) Give the Lagrangian for the system.

2) Give the equation of motion.

3) What quantities are conserved in the motion? Give expressions for these quantities. 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-642.jpg?height=368&width=469&top_left_y=221&top_left_x=575)

Fig. $2.73$.

4) Describe the motion qualitatively as completely as you can.
(Wisconsin)
2073.a.Solution:
Let $z$ be the distance of the top of the mercury column from its equilibrium position. Suppose an external force $F$ acting on the descending top causes it to descend slowly a distance $d z$. Then $F=2 \rho z g$ and its work done is

$$
d W=F d z=2 z \rho g d z .
$$

This work is stored as potential energy $d V$. Hence the potential energy of the mercury column is $V=\rho g z^{2}$. If the tube is not spinning, the mercury column will oscillate about the equilibrium position and the Lagrangian of the system is

$$
L=\frac{1}{2} \rho s \dot{z}^{2}-\rho g z^{2}
$$

where $s=l+2 h$. Lagrange's equation gives

$$
\ddot{z}+\frac{2 g}{s} z=0 .
$$

Hence the mercury column will oscillate with an angular frequency

$$
\omega=\sqrt{\frac{2 g}{s}}=\sqrt{\frac{2 g}{l+2 h}} .
$$

2074.a.Problem Statement:
A particle under the action of gravity slides on the inside of a smooth paraboloid of revolution whose axis is vertical. Using the distance from the axis, $r$, and the azimuthal angle $\varphi$ as generalized coordinates, find

The Lagrangian of the system.
2074.a.Solution:
Suppose the paraboloid of revolution is generated by a parabola which in cylindrical coordinates $(r, \varphi, z)$ is represented by

$$
z=A r^{2},
$$

where $A$ is a positive constant.

The Lagrangian of the system is

$$
\begin{aligned}
L=T-V &=\frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{r}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\varphi}^{2}+\dot{z}^{2}\right)-m g z \\
&=\frac{1}{2} m\left(1+4 A^{2} r^{2}\right) \dot{r}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m r^{2} \dot{\varphi}^{2}-A m g r^{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$
2074.a.Final Answer: $$\frac{1}{2} m\left(1+4 A^{2} r^{2}\right) \dot{r}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m r^{2} \dot{\varphi}^{2}-A m g r^{2}$$

2074.b.Problem Statement:
A particle under the action of gravity slides on the inside of a smooth paraboloid of revolution whose axis is vertical. Using the distance from the axis, $r$, and the azimuthal angle $\varphi$ as generalized coordinates, find

The generalized momenta and the corresponding Hamiltonian.
2074.b.Solution:
Suppose the paraboloid of revolution is generated by a parabola which in cylindrical coordinates $(r, \varphi, z)$ is represented by

$$
z=A r^{2},
$$

where $A$ is a positive constant.

The Lagrangian of the system is

$$
\begin{aligned}
L=T-V &=\frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{r}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\varphi}^{2}+\dot{z}^{2}\right)-m g z \\
&=\frac{1}{2} m\left(1+4 A^{2} r^{2}\right) \dot{r}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m r^{2} \dot{\varphi}^{2}-A m g r^{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$The generalized momenta are

$$
\begin{aligned}
p_{r} &=\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{r}}=m\left(1+4 A^{2} r^{2}\right) \dot{r} \\
p_{\varphi} &=\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\varphi}}=m r^{2} \dot{\varphi}
\end{aligned}
$$

and the Hamiltonian is

$$
\begin{aligned}
H &=p_{r} \dot{r}+p_{\varphi} \dot{\varphi}-L \\
&=\frac{1}{2} m\left(1+4 A^{2} r^{2}\right) \dot{r}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m r^{2} \dot{\varphi}^{2}+A m g r^{2} \\
&=\frac{p_{r}^{2}}{2 m\left(1+4 A^{2} r^{2}\right)}+\frac{p_{\varphi}^{2}}{2 m r^{2}}+A m g r^{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$

2074.c.Problem Statement:
A particle under the action of gravity slides on the inside of a smooth paraboloid of revolution whose axis is vertical. Using the distance from the axis, $r$, and the azimuthal angle $\varphi$ as generalized coordinates, find

The equation of motion for the coordinate $r$ as a function of time.
2074.c.Solution:
Suppose the paraboloid of revolution is generated by a parabola which in cylindrical coordinates $(r, \varphi, z)$ is represented by

$$
z=A r^{2},
$$

where $A$ is a positive constant.

The Lagrangian of the system is

$$
\begin{aligned}
L=T-V &=\frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{r}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\varphi}^{2}+\dot{z}^{2}\right)-m g z \\
&=\frac{1}{2} m\left(1+4 A^{2} r^{2}\right) \dot{r}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m r^{2} \dot{\varphi}^{2}-A m g r^{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$The generalized momenta are

$$
\begin{aligned}
p_{r} &=\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{r}}=m\left(1+4 A^{2} r^{2}\right) \dot{r} \\
p_{\varphi} &=\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\varphi}}=m r^{2} \dot{\varphi}
\end{aligned}
$$

and the Hamiltonian is

$$
\begin{aligned}
H &=p_{r} \dot{r}+p_{\varphi} \dot{\varphi}-L \\
&=\frac{1}{2} m\left(1+4 A^{2} r^{2}\right) \dot{r}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m r^{2} \dot{\varphi}^{2}+A m g r^{2} \\
&=\frac{p_{r}^{2}}{2 m\left(1+4 A^{2} r^{2}\right)}+\frac{p_{\varphi}^{2}}{2 m r^{2}}+A m g r^{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$Lagrange's equations

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}}=0
$$

give

$$
\begin{aligned}
&m\left(1+4 A^{2} r^{2}\right) \ddot{r}+4 m A^{2} r \dot{r}^{2}-m r \dot{\varphi}^{2}+2 A m g r=0, \\
&m r^{2} \dot{\varphi}=\text { constant } .
\end{aligned}
$$

Letting the constant be $m h$ and eliminating $\dot{\varphi}$ from the first equation, we obtain the equation for $r$ :

$$
\left(1+4 A^{2} r^{2}\right) r^{3} \ddot{r}+4 A^{2} r^{4} \dot{r}^{2}+2 A g r^{4}=h^{2} .
$$

2074.d.Problem Statement:
A particle under the action of gravity slides on the inside of a smooth paraboloid of revolution whose axis is vertical. Using the distance from the axis, $r$, and the azimuthal angle $\varphi$ as generalized coordinates, find

If $\frac{d \varphi}{d t}=0$, show that the particle can execute small oscillations about the lowest point of the paraboloid, and find the frequency of these oscillations.
2074.d.Solution:
Suppose the paraboloid of revolution is generated by a parabola which in cylindrical coordinates $(r, \varphi, z)$ is represented by

$$
z=A r^{2},
$$

where $A$ is a positive constant.

The Lagrangian of the system is

$$
\begin{aligned}
L=T-V &=\frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{r}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\varphi}^{2}+\dot{z}^{2}\right)-m g z \\
&=\frac{1}{2} m\left(1+4 A^{2} r^{2}\right) \dot{r}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m r^{2} \dot{\varphi}^{2}-A m g r^{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$The generalized momenta are

$$
\begin{aligned}
p_{r} &=\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{r}}=m\left(1+4 A^{2} r^{2}\right) \dot{r} \\
p_{\varphi} &=\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\varphi}}=m r^{2} \dot{\varphi}
\end{aligned}
$$

and the Hamiltonian is

$$
\begin{aligned}
H &=p_{r} \dot{r}+p_{\varphi} \dot{\varphi}-L \\
&=\frac{1}{2} m\left(1+4 A^{2} r^{2}\right) \dot{r}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m r^{2} \dot{\varphi}^{2}+A m g r^{2} \\
&=\frac{p_{r}^{2}}{2 m\left(1+4 A^{2} r^{2}\right)}+\frac{p_{\varphi}^{2}}{2 m r^{2}}+A m g r^{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$Lagrange's equations

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}}=0
$$

give

$$
\begin{aligned}
&m\left(1+4 A^{2} r^{2}\right) \ddot{r}+4 m A^{2} r \dot{r}^{2}-m r \dot{\varphi}^{2}+2 A m g r=0, \\
&m r^{2} \dot{\varphi}=\text { constant } .
\end{aligned}
$$

Letting the constant be $m h$ and eliminating $\dot{\varphi}$ from the first equation, we obtain the equation for $r$ :

$$
\left(1+4 A^{2} r^{2}\right) r^{3} \ddot{r}+4 A^{2} r^{4} \dot{r}^{2}+2 A g r^{4}=h^{2} .
$$If $\dot{\varphi}=0$, the first equation of (c) becomes

$$
\left(1+4 A^{2} r^{2}\right) \ddot{r}+4 A^{2} r \dot{r}^{2}+2 A g r=0 .
$$

The lowest point of the paraboloid is given by $r=0$. For small oscillations in its vicinity, $r, \dot{r}, \ddot{r}$ are small quantities. Then to first approximation the above becomes

$$
\ddot{r}+2 A g r=0 .
$$

As the coefficient of $r$ is positive, the particle executes simple harmonic motion about $r=0$ with angular frequency

$$
\omega=\sqrt{2 A g} .
$$

2075.c.Problem Statement:
A nonrelativistic electron of mass $m$, charge $-e$ in a cylindrical magneton moves between a wire of radius $a$ at a negative electric potential $-\phi_{0}$ and a concentric cylindrical conductor of radius $R$ at zero potential. There is a uniform constant magnetic field $B$ parallel to the axis. Use cylindrical coordinates $r, \theta, z$. The electric and magnetic vector potentials can be written as

$$
\phi=-\phi_{0} \frac{\ln (r / R)}{\ln (a / R)}, \quad \mathbf{A}=\frac{1}{2} B r \mathbf{e}_{\theta}
$$

( $\mathbf{e}_{\theta}$ is a unit vector in the direction of increasing $\theta$ ).

Assuming that an electron leaves the inner wire with zero initial velocity, there is a value of the magnetic field $B_{c}$ such that for $B \leq B_{c}$ the electron can reach the outer cylinder, and for $B>B_{c}$ the electron cannot reach the outer cylinder. Find $B_{c}$ and make a sketch of the electron's trajectory for this case.

You may assume that $R \gg a$.
2075.c.Solution:
In SI units, the Lagrangian is

$$
L=T-V=\frac{1}{2} m \dot{\mathbf{r}}^{2}+e \phi-e \dot{\mathbf{r}} \cdot \mathbf{A} .
$$

As

$$
\dot{\mathbf{r}}=(\dot{r}, r \dot{\theta}, \dot{z}), \quad \mathbf{A}=\left(0, \frac{1}{2} B r, 0\right),
$$

the above becomes

$$
L=\frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{r}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+\dot{z}^{2}\right)+e \phi-\frac{1}{2} e B r^{2} \dot{\theta} .
$$

The generalized momenta are

$$
p_{r}=\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{r}}=m \dot{r}, \quad p_{\theta}=\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\theta}}=m r^{2} \dot{\theta}-\frac{1}{2} e B r^{2}, \quad p_{z}=\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{z}}=m \dot{z},
$$

and the Hamiltonian is 

$$
\begin{aligned}
H &=p_{r} \dot{r}+p_{\theta} \dot{\theta}+p_{z} \dot{z}-L \\
&=\frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{r}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+\dot{z}^{2}\right)-e \phi \\
&=\frac{p_{r}^{2}}{2 m}+\frac{1}{2 m r^{2}}\left(p_{\theta}+\frac{1}{2} e B r^{2}\right)^{2}+\frac{p_{z}^{2}}{2 m}-e \phi \\
&=\frac{1}{2 m}\left[p_{r}^{2}+\left(\frac{p_{\theta}}{r}+\frac{1}{2} e B r\right)^{2}+p_{z}^{2}\right]-e \phi .
\end{aligned}
$$

As $H$ is not an explicit function of time, it is a constant of the motion. Also, as

$$
\dot{p}_{i}=-\frac{\partial H}{\partial q_{i}},
$$

if $H$ does not contain $q_{i}$ explicitly, $p_{i}$ is a constant of the motion. Hence $p_{\theta}, p_{z}$ are constants of the motion. Explicitly,

$$
\begin{aligned}
&H=\frac{1}{2 m}\left[p_{r}^{2}+\left(\frac{p_{\theta}}{r}+\frac{1}{2} e B r\right)^{2}+p_{z}^{2}\right]-e \phi=E \\
&p_{\theta}=m r^{2} \dot{\theta}-\frac{1}{2} e B r^{2}=C_{1}, \\
&p_{z}=m \dot{z}=C_{2},
\end{aligned}
$$

where $E, C_{1}, C_{2}$ are constants.

The initial conditions $r=a, \dot{r}=\dot{\theta}=\dot{z}=0$ at $t=0$ give

$$
E=-e \phi=e \phi_{0}, \quad C_{1}=-\frac{1}{2} e B a^{2}, \quad C_{2}=0 .
$$

$p_{z}=C_{2}=0$ means that there is no motion along the $z$-direction. $H=E$ gives

$$
\frac{1}{2 m}\left[p_{r}^{2}+\left(\frac{1}{2} e B\right)^{2}\left(r-\frac{a^{2}}{r}\right)^{2}\right]+e \phi_{0}\left[\frac{\ln \left(\frac{r}{R}\right)}{\ln \left(\frac{a}{R}\right)}\right]=e \phi_{0} .
$$

Suppose a value $B_{c}$ of the magnetic field will just make the electron reach the outer cylinder. As then $p_{r}=0$ at $r=R$, the above gives

$$
\frac{1}{2 m}\left(\frac{1}{2} e B_{c}\right)^{2}\left(R-\frac{a^{2}}{R}\right)^{2}=e \phi_{0} \text {. }
$$

If we assume that $a \ll R$, this reduces to

$$
B_{\mathrm{c}}=\frac{2}{R} \sqrt{\frac{2 m \phi_{0}}{e}} .
$$

At $r=R, p_{r}$ is given by

$$
\frac{1}{2 m}\left[p_{r}^{2}+\left(\frac{1}{2} e B R\right)^{2}\right]=e \phi_{0}
$$

or

$$
p_{r}^{2}=2 m e \phi_{0}-\left(\frac{1}{2} e B R\right)^{2}=\left(B_{c}^{2}-B^{2}\right)\left(\frac{1}{2} e R\right)^{2} .
$$

$p_{r}$ is real at $r=R$ if $B \leq B_{c}$. Hence under this condition the electron can reach the outer cylinder. If $B>B_{c}, p_{r}$ is imaginary at $r=R$ and the electron cannot reach the outer cylinder. For the latter case the trajectory of the electron is as sketched in Fig. 2.74.

2076.a.Problem Statement:
Consider the Lagrangian

$$
L=\frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{x}^{2}-\omega^{2} x^{2}\right) e^{\gamma t}
$$

for the motion of a particle of mass $m$ in one dimension $(x)$. The constants $m, \gamma$ and $\omega$ are real and positive.

Find the equation of motion.
2076.a.Solution:
Lagrange's equation

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{x}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial x}=0
$$

gives the equation of motion

$$
\ddot{x}+\omega^{2} x=-\gamma \dot{x} .
$$

2076.c.Problem Statement:
Consider the Lagrangian

$$
L=\frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{x}^{2}-\omega^{2} x^{2}\right) e^{\gamma t}
$$

for the motion of a particle of mass $m$ in one dimension $(x)$. The constants $m, \gamma$ and $\omega$ are real and positive.

Find the canonical momentum, and from this construct the Hamiltonian function.
2076.c.Solution:
Lagrange's equation

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{x}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial x}=0
$$

gives the equation of motion

$$
\ddot{x}+\omega^{2} x=-\gamma \dot{x} .
$$The particle moves as a damped harmonic oscillator. It is subject to an restoring force $-m \omega^{2} x$ and a damping force $-m \gamma \dot{x}$ proportional to its speed.

The canonical momentum is

$$
p=\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{x}}=m e^{\gamma t} \dot{x}
$$

and the Hamiltonian is

$$
\begin{aligned}
H &=p \dot{x}-L \\
&=m e^{\gamma t} \dot{x}^{2}-\frac{1}{2} m e^{\gamma t} \dot{x}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m e^{\gamma t} \omega^{2} x^{2} \\
&=\frac{p^{2} e^{-\gamma t}}{2 m}+\frac{1}{2} m \omega^{2} x^{2} e^{\gamma t} .
\end{aligned}
$$
2076.c.Final Answer: $$\frac{p^{2} e^{-\gamma t}}{2 m}+\frac{1}{2} m \omega^{2} x^{2} e^{\gamma t}$$

2076.e.Problem Statement:
Consider the Lagrangian

$$
L=\frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{x}^{2}-\omega^{2} x^{2}\right) e^{\gamma t}
$$

for the motion of a particle of mass $m$ in one dimension $(x)$. The constants $m, \gamma$ and $\omega$ are real and positive.

For the initial conditions $x(0)=0$ and $\dot{x}(0)=v_{0}$, what is $x(t)$ asymptotically as $t \rightarrow \infty$ ?
2076.e.Solution:
Lagrange's equation

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{x}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial x}=0
$$

gives the equation of motion

$$
\ddot{x}+\omega^{2} x=-\gamma \dot{x} .
$$The particle moves as a damped harmonic oscillator. It is subject to an restoring force $-m \omega^{2} x$ and a damping force $-m \gamma \dot{x}$ proportional to its speed.

The canonical momentum is

$$
p=\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{x}}=m e^{\gamma t} \dot{x}
$$

and the Hamiltonian is

$$
\begin{aligned}
H &=p \dot{x}-L \\
&=m e^{\gamma t} \dot{x}^{2}-\frac{1}{2} m e^{\gamma t} \dot{x}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m e^{\gamma t} \omega^{2} x^{2} \\
&=\frac{p^{2} e^{-\gamma t}}{2 m}+\frac{1}{2} m \omega^{2} x^{2} e^{\gamma t} .
\end{aligned}
$$Since $H$ depends explicitly on time, it is not a constant of motion. It follows that energy is not conserved also. Physically, in the course of the motion, the damping force continually does negative work, causing dissipation of energy.

Try a solution of the type $x \sim e^{i \Omega t}$. Substitution in the equation of motion gives

$$
\Omega^{2}-i \gamma \Omega-\omega^{2}=0,
$$

which has solutions

$$
\Omega=\frac{i}{2}\left(\gamma \pm \sqrt{\gamma^{2}-4 \omega^{2}}\right) .
$$

Hence

$$
x=A \exp \left[-\frac{1}{2}\left(\gamma+\sqrt{\gamma^{2}-4 \omega^{2}}\right) t\right]+B \exp \left[-\frac{1}{2}\left(\gamma-\sqrt{\gamma^{2}-4 \omega^{2}}\right) t\right] .
$$

The initial conditions $x=0, \dot{x}=v_{0}$ at $t=0$ give

$$
B=-A, \quad A=-\frac{v_{0}}{\sqrt{\gamma^{2}-4 \omega^{2}}} .
$$

If $\gamma<2 \omega$, let $\frac{1}{2} \sqrt{\gamma^{2}-4 \omega^{2}}=i \omega_{1}$. Then

$$
x=-\frac{v_{0}}{2 i \omega_{1}} e^{-\frac{\gamma t}{2}}\left(e^{-i \omega_{1} t}-e^{i \omega_{1} t}\right)=\frac{v_{0}}{\omega_{1}} e^{-\frac{\gamma t}{2}} \sin \left(\omega_{1} t\right)
$$

so that $x \rightarrow 0$ as $t \rightarrow \infty$.

If $\gamma>2 \omega$, both $\gamma \pm \sqrt{\gamma^{2}-4 \omega^{2}}$ are real and positive so that there will be no oscillation and $x$ will decrease monotonically to zero as $t \rightarrow \infty$.

2077.a.Problem Statement:
A particle is confined inside a box and can move only along the $x$-axis. The ends of the box move toward the center with a speed small compared with the particle's speed (Fig. 2.75).

If the momentum of the particle is $p_{0}$ when the walls of the box are at a distance $x_{0}$ apart, find the momentum of the particle at any later time. Collisions with the walls are perfectly elastic. Assume that at all times the speed of the particle is much less than the speed of light.
2077.a.Solution:
Consider a collision of the particle with one of the walls. As the collision is perfectly elastic, the relative speeds before and after the collision are equal. If the particle is incident with speed $v$ and reflected back with speed $v^{\prime}$ and the wall has speed $V$ towards the particle, we have 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-652.jpg?height=213&width=436&top_left_y=224&top_left_x=571)

Fig. $2.75$.

$$
v+V=v^{\prime}-V
$$

i.e.

$$
v^{\prime}=v+2 V .
$$

Thus after each collision, the magnitude of the particle momentum gains an amount $2 m V, m$ being the mass of the particle. When the walls are at a distance $x$ apart, as $V$ is much smaller than the speed of the particle, the interval between two consecutive collisions is

$$
T=\frac{x}{\left(\frac{p}{m}\right)}=\frac{x m}{p},
$$

$p$ being the particle momentum. The change of momentum in time $d t$ is

$$
d p=2 m V \frac{d t}{T}=\frac{2 V p d t}{x} .
$$

As the walls move toward each other with speed $V$,

$$
x=x_{0}-2 V t,
$$

measuring time from the moment $x=x_{0}$. Then

$$
d p=-\frac{p d x}{x} .
$$

As $p=p_{0}$ when $x=x_{0}$, its integration gives

$$
p=\frac{p_{0} x_{0}}{x}=\frac{p_{0} x_{0}}{x_{0}-2 V t} .
$$

2078.c.Problem Statement:
The Poisson bracket is defined by

$$
[a, b]=\sum_{k}\left(\frac{\partial a}{\partial q_{k}} \frac{\partial b}{\partial p_{k}}-\frac{\partial a}{\partial p_{k}} \frac{\partial b}{\partial q_{k}}\right) .
$$

Find two independent constants of the motion and verify using part
2078.c.Solution:
Using Hamilton's canonical equations

$$
\dot{q}_{k}=\frac{\partial H}{\partial p_{k}}, \quad \dot{p}_{k}=-\frac{\partial H}{\partial q_{k}},
$$

we find

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{d a}{d t} &=\sum_{k} \frac{\partial a}{\partial q_{k}} \dot{q}_{k}+\sum_{k} \frac{\partial a}{\partial p_{k}} \dot{p}_{k}+\frac{\partial a}{\partial t} \\
&=\sum_{k} \frac{\partial a}{\partial q_{k}} \frac{\partial H}{\partial p_{k}}-\sum_{k} \frac{\partial a}{\partial p_{k}} \frac{\partial H}{\partial q_{k}}+\frac{\partial a}{\partial t} \\
&=[a, H]+\frac{\partial a}{\partial t} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Introducing the new variables

$$
\eta=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(x+y), \quad \xi=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(x-y),
$$

we have 

$$
x=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(\eta+\xi), \quad y=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(\eta-\xi) .
$$

Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
T &=\frac{1}{4} m\left[(\dot{\eta}+\dot{\xi})^{2}+(\dot{\eta}-\dot{\xi})^{2}\right] \\
&=\frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{\eta}^{2}+\dot{\xi}^{2}\right), \\
V &=\frac{1}{4} K\left[(\eta+\xi)^{2}+(\eta-\xi)^{2}\right]+\frac{1}{2} C\left(\eta^{2}-\xi^{2}\right) \\
&=\frac{1}{2} K\left(\eta^{2}+\xi^{2}\right)+\frac{1}{2} C\left(\eta^{2}-\xi^{2}\right) \\
&=\frac{1}{2}(K+C) \eta^{2}+\frac{1}{2}(K-C) \xi^{2}, \\
L &=L_{1}+L_{2},
\end{aligned}
$$

with

$$
\begin{aligned}
&L_{1}=\frac{1}{2} m \dot{\eta}^{2}-\frac{1}{2}(K+C) \eta^{2}, \\
&L_{2}=\frac{1}{2} m \dot{\xi}^{2}-\frac{1}{2}(K-C) \xi^{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Note that the form of $L_{1}$ and $L_{2}$ indicates that $\eta$ and $\xi$ are normal coordinates. Hence the system is equivalent to two harmonic oscillators with angular frequencies

$$
\omega_{1}=\sqrt{\frac{K+C}{m}}, \quad \omega_{2}=\sqrt{\frac{K-C}{m}}
$$

respectively. As the frequencies are different the system acts as a nonisotropic harmonic oscillator.

As the canonical momenta are by definition

$$
\begin{aligned}
p_{\eta} &=\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\eta}}=m \dot{\eta}, \quad p_{\xi}=\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\xi}}=m \dot{\xi}, \\
H &=p_{\eta} \dot{\eta}+p_{\xi} \dot{\xi}-L \\
&=\frac{1}{2 m} p_{\eta}^{2}+\frac{1}{2 m} p_{\xi}^{2}+\frac{1}{2}(K+C) \eta^{2}+\frac{1}{2}(K-C) \xi^{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$

This can also be written as

$$
H=H_{1}+H_{2}
$$

with $H_{1}, H_{2}$ corresponding to $L_{1}, L_{2}$ respectively, i.e.

$$
H_{1}=\frac{p_{\eta}^{2}}{2 m}+\frac{1}{2}(K+C) \eta^{2}, \quad H_{2}=\frac{p_{\xi}^{2}}{2 m}+\frac{1}{2}(K-C) \xi^{2} .
$$

As $H_{1}, H_{2}$ do not contain $t$ explicitly, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{d H_{1}}{d t} &=\left[H_{1}, H\right]=\left[H_{1}, H_{1}+H_{2}\right]=\left[H_{1}, H_{1}\right]+\left[H_{1}, H_{2}\right]=\left[H_{1}, H_{2}\right] \\
&=\frac{\partial H_{1}}{\partial \eta} \frac{\partial H_{2}}{\partial p_{\eta}}+\frac{\partial H_{1}}{\partial \xi} \frac{\partial H_{2}}{\partial p_{\xi}}-\frac{\partial H_{1}}{\partial p_{\eta}} \frac{\partial H_{2}}{\partial \eta}-\frac{\partial H_{1}}{\partial p_{\xi}} \frac{\partial H_{2}}{\partial \xi}=0
\end{aligned}
$$

and, similarly,

$$
\frac{d H_{2}}{d t}=0 .
$$

Hence $\mathrm{H}_{1}, \mathrm{H}_{2}$ are two independent constants of the motion.

2078.d.Problem Statement:
The Poisson bracket is defined by

$$
[a, b]=\sum_{k}\left(\frac{\partial a}{\partial q_{k}} \frac{\partial b}{\partial p_{k}}-\frac{\partial a}{\partial p_{k}} \frac{\partial b}{\partial q_{k}}\right) .
$$

If $C=0$ find a third constant of the motion.
2078.d.Solution:
Using Hamilton's canonical equations

$$
\dot{q}_{k}=\frac{\partial H}{\partial p_{k}}, \quad \dot{p}_{k}=-\frac{\partial H}{\partial q_{k}},
$$

we find

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{d a}{d t} &=\sum_{k} \frac{\partial a}{\partial q_{k}} \dot{q}_{k}+\sum_{k} \frac{\partial a}{\partial p_{k}} \dot{p}_{k}+\frac{\partial a}{\partial t} \\
&=\sum_{k} \frac{\partial a}{\partial q_{k}} \frac{\partial H}{\partial p_{k}}-\sum_{k} \frac{\partial a}{\partial p_{k}} \frac{\partial H}{\partial q_{k}}+\frac{\partial a}{\partial t} \\
&=[a, H]+\frac{\partial a}{\partial t} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Introducing the new variables

$$
\eta=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(x+y), \quad \xi=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(x-y),
$$

we have 

$$
x=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(\eta+\xi), \quad y=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(\eta-\xi) .
$$

Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
T &=\frac{1}{4} m\left[(\dot{\eta}+\dot{\xi})^{2}+(\dot{\eta}-\dot{\xi})^{2}\right] \\
&=\frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{\eta}^{2}+\dot{\xi}^{2}\right), \\
V &=\frac{1}{4} K\left[(\eta+\xi)^{2}+(\eta-\xi)^{2}\right]+\frac{1}{2} C\left(\eta^{2}-\xi^{2}\right) \\
&=\frac{1}{2} K\left(\eta^{2}+\xi^{2}\right)+\frac{1}{2} C\left(\eta^{2}-\xi^{2}\right) \\
&=\frac{1}{2}(K+C) \eta^{2}+\frac{1}{2}(K-C) \xi^{2}, \\
L &=L_{1}+L_{2},
\end{aligned}
$$

with

$$
\begin{aligned}
&L_{1}=\frac{1}{2} m \dot{\eta}^{2}-\frac{1}{2}(K+C) \eta^{2}, \\
&L_{2}=\frac{1}{2} m \dot{\xi}^{2}-\frac{1}{2}(K-C) \xi^{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Note that the form of $L_{1}$ and $L_{2}$ indicates that $\eta$ and $\xi$ are normal coordinates. Hence the system is equivalent to two harmonic oscillators with angular frequencies

$$
\omega_{1}=\sqrt{\frac{K+C}{m}}, \quad \omega_{2}=\sqrt{\frac{K-C}{m}}
$$

respectively. As the frequencies are different the system acts as a nonisotropic harmonic oscillator.

As the canonical momenta are by definition

$$
\begin{aligned}
p_{\eta} &=\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\eta}}=m \dot{\eta}, \quad p_{\xi}=\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\xi}}=m \dot{\xi}, \\
H &=p_{\eta} \dot{\eta}+p_{\xi} \dot{\xi}-L \\
&=\frac{1}{2 m} p_{\eta}^{2}+\frac{1}{2 m} p_{\xi}^{2}+\frac{1}{2}(K+C) \eta^{2}+\frac{1}{2}(K-C) \xi^{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$

This can also be written as

$$
H=H_{1}+H_{2}
$$

with $H_{1}, H_{2}$ corresponding to $L_{1}, L_{2}$ respectively, i.e.

$$
H_{1}=\frac{p_{\eta}^{2}}{2 m}+\frac{1}{2}(K+C) \eta^{2}, \quad H_{2}=\frac{p_{\xi}^{2}}{2 m}+\frac{1}{2}(K-C) \xi^{2} .
$$

As $H_{1}, H_{2}$ do not contain $t$ explicitly, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{d H_{1}}{d t} &=\left[H_{1}, H\right]=\left[H_{1}, H_{1}+H_{2}\right]=\left[H_{1}, H_{1}\right]+\left[H_{1}, H_{2}\right]=\left[H_{1}, H_{2}\right] \\
&=\frac{\partial H_{1}}{\partial \eta} \frac{\partial H_{2}}{\partial p_{\eta}}+\frac{\partial H_{1}}{\partial \xi} \frac{\partial H_{2}}{\partial p_{\xi}}-\frac{\partial H_{1}}{\partial p_{\eta}} \frac{\partial H_{2}}{\partial \eta}-\frac{\partial H_{1}}{\partial p_{\xi}} \frac{\partial H_{2}}{\partial \xi}=0
\end{aligned}
$$

and, similarly,

$$
\frac{d H_{2}}{d t}=0 .
$$

Hence $\mathrm{H}_{1}, \mathrm{H}_{2}$ are two independent constants of the motion.If $C=0, \omega_{1}=\omega_{2}$ and the oscillator becomes an isotropic one. The Hamiltonian is

$$
H=\frac{1}{2 m} p_{\eta}^{2}+\frac{1}{2 m} p_{\xi}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} K \eta^{2}+\frac{1}{2} K \xi^{2} .
$$

Let $J=m\left(\eta p_{\xi}-\xi p_{\eta}\right)$. Then as

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{d J}{d t} &=[J, H] \\
&=\frac{\partial J}{\partial \eta} \frac{\partial H}{\partial p_{\eta}}-\frac{\partial J}{\partial p_{\eta}} \frac{\partial H}{\partial \eta}+\frac{\partial J}{\partial \xi} \frac{\partial H}{\partial p_{\xi}}-\frac{\partial J}{\partial p_{\xi}} \frac{\partial H}{\partial \xi} \\
&=p_{\xi} p_{\eta}+m K \xi \eta-p_{\eta} p_{\xi}-m K \eta \xi=0,
\end{aligned}
$$

$J$ is also a constant of the motion.

2081.b.Problem Statement:
A particle of mass $m$ moves in one dimension $q$ in a potential energy field $V(q)$ and is retarded by a damping force $-2 m \gamma \dot{q}$ proportional to its velocity.

For the generating function

$$
F_{2}(q, P, t)=\exp (\gamma t) q P
$$

find the transformed Hamiltonian $K(Q, P, t)$. For an oscillator potential

$$
V(q)=\frac{1}{2} m \omega^{2} q^{2}
$$

show that the transformed Hamiltonian yields a constant of the motion

$$
K=\frac{P^{2}}{2 m}+\frac{1}{2} m \omega^{2} Q+\gamma Q P .
$$
2081.b.Solution:
Lagrange's equation

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial q}=0
$$

gives

$$
m \ddot{q}=-\frac{\partial V}{\partial q}-2 m \gamma \dot{q} .
$$

The particle is seen to be subject to a potential force $-\frac{\partial V}{\partial q}$ and a damping force $-2 m \gamma \dot{q}$ proportional to its speed. Hence the given Lagrangian is appropriate. The Hamiltonian is given by

$$
H=p \dot{q}-L
$$

with

$$
p=\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}}=m \dot{q} e^{2 \gamma t}
$$

Thus

$$
H=\left(\frac{1}{2} m \dot{q}^{2}+V\right) e^{2 \gamma t}=\frac{p^{2} e^{-2 \gamma t}}{2 m}+V(q) e^{2 \gamma t}
$$

For the generating function $F_{2}(q, P, t)$ we have

$$
p=\frac{\partial F_{2}}{\partial q}, \quad Q=\frac{\partial F_{2}}{\partial P}, \quad K=H+\frac{\partial F_{2}}{\partial t} .
$$

As $F_{2}=q P e^{\gamma t}$,

$$
\begin{gathered}
p=P e^{\gamma t}, \quad Q=q e^{\gamma t}, \\
K=\frac{p^{2} e^{-2 \gamma t}}{2 m}+V(q) e^{2 \gamma t}+\gamma q P e^{\gamma t}
\end{gathered}
$$

For an oscillator of potential

$$
V=\frac{1}{2} m \omega^{2} q^{2}=\frac{1}{2} m \omega^{2} Q^{2} e^{-2 \gamma t},
$$

the transformed Hamiltonian is

$$
K=\frac{P^{2}}{2 m}+\frac{1}{2} m \omega^{2} Q^{2}+\gamma Q P .
$$

As it does not depend on time explicitly, $K$ is a constant of the motion.

2082.a.Problem Statement:
Suppose that a system with time-independent Hamiltonian $H_{0}(q, p)$ has imposed on it an external oscillating field, so that the Hamiltonian becomes $H=H_{0}(q, p)-\varepsilon q \sin \omega t$, where $\varepsilon$ and $\omega$ are given constants.

What is the physical interpretation of $\varepsilon \sin \omega t$ ?
2082.a.Solution: A possible interpretation is shown in the following example. A particle of charge $e$ moves in an electric field uniform in space but oscillating in time, namely an electrical field whose strength is represented by $(\varepsilon / e) \sin \omega t$. Then $\varepsilon \sin \omega t$ is the force exerted on the particle by the electric field.

2082.c.Problem Statement:
Suppose that a system with time-independent Hamiltonian $H_{0}(q, p)$ has imposed on it an external oscillating field, so that the Hamiltonian becomes $H=H_{0}(q, p)-\varepsilon q \sin \omega t$, where $\varepsilon$ and $\omega$ are given constants.

Find a canonical transformation which restores the canonical form of the equations of motion. What is the "new" Hamiltonian?
2082.c.Solution:
A possible interpretation is shown in the following example. A particle of charge $e$ moves in an electric field uniform in space but oscillating in time, namely an electrical field whose strength is represented by $(\varepsilon / e) \sin \omega t$. Then $\varepsilon \sin \omega t$ is the force exerted on the particle by the electric field.Hamilton's canonical equations of motion are now

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\dot{q}=\frac{\partial H}{\partial p}=\frac{\partial H_{0}}{\partial p}, \\
&\dot{p}=-\frac{\partial H}{\partial q}=-\frac{\partial H_{0}}{\partial q}+\varepsilon \sin (\omega t) .
\end{aligned}
$$

We have

$$
H(q, p, t)=H_{0}(q, p)-\varepsilon q \sin (\omega t)
$$

and wish to find a new Hamiltonian

$$
K(Q, P)=H_{0}(q, p)
$$

by a canonical transformation. Let the generating function be $F_{2}(q, P, t)$. As

$$
\frac{\partial F_{2}}{\partial t}=K-H=\varepsilon q \sin (\omega t),
$$

we take

$$
F_{2}=q P-\frac{\varepsilon q}{\omega} \cos (\omega t) .
$$

The transformation equations are

$$
p=\frac{\partial F_{2}}{\partial q}=P-\frac{\varepsilon}{\omega} \cos (\omega t)
$$

or

$$
P=p+\frac{\varepsilon}{\omega} \cos (\omega t)
$$

and

$$
Q=\frac{\partial F_{2}}{\partial P}=q
$$

Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
K(Q, P) &=H+\frac{\partial F_{2}}{\partial t} \\
&=H_{0}(q, p)-\varepsilon q \sin (\omega t)+\varepsilon q \sin (\omega t) \\
&=H_{0}\left(Q, P-\frac{\varepsilon}{\omega} \cos (\omega t)\right) \\
\frac{\partial K}{\partial P} &=\frac{\partial H_{0}}{\partial p} \frac{\partial p}{\partial P}=\frac{\partial H_{0}}{\partial p}=\dot{q}=\dot{Q}, \\
-\frac{\partial K}{\partial Q} &=-\frac{\partial H_{0}}{\partial q} \frac{\partial q}{\partial Q}=-\frac{\partial H_{0}}{\partial q}=\dot{p}-\varepsilon \sin (\omega t)=\dot{P}
\end{aligned}
$$

use having been of the results in (b). Hence the transformation restores the canonical form of the equations of motion with the Hamiltonian $H_{0}$.

2083.a.Problem Statement: Solve the Hamilton-Jacobi equation for the generating function $S(q, \alpha, t)$ in the case of a single particle moving under the Hamiltonian $H=\frac{1}{2} p^{2}$. Find the canonical transformation $q=q(\beta, \alpha)$, and $p=p(\beta, \alpha)$, where $\beta$ and $\alpha$ are the transformed coordinate and momentum respectively. Interpret your result.
2083.a.Solution:
The Hamilton-Jacobi equation

$$
\frac{\partial S}{\partial t}+H(q, p, t)=0
$$

with $p=\frac{\partial S}{\partial q}$ becomes, for this case,

$$
\frac{\partial S}{\partial t}+\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{\partial S}{\partial q}\right)^{2}=0 .
$$

As $H$ does not depend on $q, t$ explicitly, we can take the two terms on the left-hand side as equal to $-\gamma, \gamma$ respectively, where $\gamma$ is at most a function of $p$. Then

$$
S=\sqrt{2 \gamma} q-\gamma t .
$$

Setting $\alpha=\sqrt{2 \gamma}$, we have the generating function

$$
S=\alpha q-\frac{1}{2} \alpha^{2} t
$$

The constant $\alpha$ can be taken to be the new momentum $P$. The transformation equations are thus

$$
\begin{aligned}
p &=\frac{\partial S}{\partial q}=\alpha \\
Q &=\frac{\partial S}{\partial P}=\frac{\partial S}{\partial \alpha}=q-\alpha t=\beta, \quad \text { say } .
\end{aligned}
$$

As $g=\beta+\alpha t$, the particle moves with uniform velocity $\beta$ in the $q, p$ system.

\frac{F}{A}=n \varphi,

where $F$ is the shearing force, $n$ the shear modulus of the material of the block, $\varphi$ the shear angle, and $A$ the cross sectional area of the block parallel to $F$, gives the resulting displacement as

2084.c.Problem Statement: Find the expression for the speed of the transverse elastic wave.
2084.c.Solution:
Hooke's law for shearing 

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-667.jpg?height=340&width=514&top_left_y=232&top_left_x=496)

Fig. 2.77.

$$
\frac{F}{A}=n \varphi,
$$

where $F$ is the shearing force, $n$ the shear modulus of the material of the block, $\varphi$ the shear angle, and $A$ the cross sectional area of the block parallel to $F$, gives the resulting displacement as

$$
u=l \varphi=\frac{l F}{A n},
$$

as $\varphi$ is a small angle.The potential energy of a unit volume of the block due to shear strain is

$$
\frac{1}{l A} \int_{0}^{u} F d u^{\prime}=\frac{1}{l A} \int_{0}^{\varphi} A n \varphi^{\prime} l d \varphi^{\prime}=\frac{1}{2} n \varphi^{2}=\frac{1}{2} n\left(\frac{\partial u}{\partial x}\right)^{2}
$$

The kinetic energy of the block during shearing is

$$
\int_{0}^{l} \frac{1}{2} \rho A\left(\frac{\partial u}{\partial t}\right)^{2} d x
$$

$\rho$ being the density of the block. Within the elastic limits, energy is considered and Hamilton's principle

$$
\delta \int_{t_{1}}^{t_{2}} L d t=0
$$

applies. Thus

$$
\delta \int_{t_{1}}^{t_{2}}(T-V) d t=\delta \int_{t_{1}}^{t_{2}} \int_{0}^{l}\left[\frac{n}{2}\left(\frac{\partial u}{\partial x}\right)^{2}-\frac{\rho}{2}\left(\frac{\partial u}{\partial t}\right)^{2}\right] A d x d t=0 .
$$

As, integrating by parts, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{0}^{l} \delta\left(\frac{\partial u}{\partial x}\right)^{2} d x &=2 \int_{0}^{l}\left(\frac{\partial u}{\partial x}\right) \frac{\partial}{\partial x}(\delta u) d x \\
&=\left.2\left(\frac{\partial u}{\partial x}\right) \delta u\right|_{0} ^{l}-2 \int_{0}^{l} \frac{\partial^{2} u}{\partial x^{2}} \delta u d x, \\
\int_{0}^{l} \delta\left(\frac{\partial u}{\partial t}\right)^{2} d t &=\left.2\left(\frac{\partial u}{\partial t}\right) \delta u\right|_{t_{1}} ^{t_{2}}-2 \int_{0}^{l}\left(\frac{\partial^{2} u}{\partial t^{2}}\right) \delta u d t,
\end{aligned}
$$

and as $\delta u=0$ at $y=0, l$ and $t=t_{1}, t_{2}$, the above becomes

$$
-\int_{t_{1}}^{t_{2}} \int_{0}^{l}\left(n \frac{\partial^{2} u}{\partial x^{2}}-\rho \frac{\partial^{2} u}{\partial t^{2}}\right) \delta u A d x d t=0
$$

giving

$$
\frac{\partial^{2} u}{\partial x^{2}}-\frac{\rho}{n} \frac{\partial^{2} u}{\partial t^{2}}=0
$$

as the equation of motion for the displacement $u$.

The equation shows that $u$, which is in the $y$-direction, propagates along the $x$-direction as a transverse wave with speed

$$
v=\sqrt{\frac{n}{\rho}} \text {. }
$$

3003.a.Problem Statement:
A light source at rest at position $x=0$ in reference frame $S$ emits two pulses (called $P_{1}$ and $P_{2}$ ) of light, $P_{1}$ at $t=0$ and $P_{2}$ at $t=\tau$. A frame $S^{\prime}$ moves with velocity $v \hat{\mathbf{x}}$ with respect to $S$. An observer in frame $S^{\prime}$ receives the initial pulse $P_{1}$ at time $t^{\prime}=0$ at $x^{\prime}=0$.

Calculate the time $\tau^{\prime}$ between the reception of the pulses at $x^{\prime}=0$ as a function of $\tau$ and $\beta=\frac{v}{c}$.
3003.a.Solution:
![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-673.jpg?height=232&width=632&top_left_y=700&top_left_x=512)

Fig. 3.1.

The inertial frames $S, S^{\prime}$ are as shown in Fig. 3.1. Assume that the origins $O$ and $O^{\prime}$ coincide at $t=t^{\prime}=0$ so that the emission of $P_{1}$ and its arrival at the observer both occur at $x=0, t=0, x^{\prime}=0, t^{\prime}=0$ as given. The emission of $P_{2}$ is at $x=0, t=\tau$ in $S$ and

$$
\begin{aligned}
x^{\prime} &=\gamma(x-\beta c t)=-\gamma \beta c \tau, \\
t^{\prime} &=\gamma\left(t-\frac{\beta x}{c}\right)=\gamma \tau
\end{aligned}
$$

in $S$. The signal take a time

$$
\Delta t^{\prime}=\frac{\left|x^{\prime}\right|}{\mathrm{c}}=\gamma \beta \tau
$$

to arrive at the observer. Hence the observer records the time of arrival as

$$
t^{\prime}+\Delta t^{\prime}=\gamma(1+\beta) \tau,
$$

or

$$
\tau^{\prime}=\tau \sqrt{\frac{1+\beta}{1-\beta}}
$$

3010.a.Problem Statement:
A monochromatic transverse wave with frequency $
u$ propagates in a direction which makes an angle of $60^{\circ}$ with the $x$-axis in the reference frame $K$ of its source. The source moves in the $x$-direction at speed $v= rac{4}{5} c$ towards an observer at rest in the $K^{\prime}$ frame (where his $x^{\prime}$-axis is parallel to the $x$-axis). The observer measures the frequency of the wave.

Determine the measured frequency $
u^{\prime}$ in terms of the proper frequency $
u$ of the wave.
3010.a.Solution:
The frame $K$ of the light source moves with velocity $\beta$ c relative to $K^{\prime}$, the observer's frame. The (inverse) transformation of the components of the wave 4 -vector is given by

$$
k_{x}^{\prime} \mathrm{c}=\gamma\left(k_{x} \mathrm{c}+\beta \omega\right), \quad k_{y}^{\prime} \mathrm{c}=k_{y} \mathrm{c}, \quad k_{z}^{\prime} \mathrm{c}=k_{z} \mathrm{c}, \quad \omega^{\prime}=\gamma\left(\omega+\beta k_{x} \mathrm{c}\right)
$$

where $\gamma=\left(1-\beta^{2}\right)^{-\frac{1}{2}}$. The angular frequency of the wave in $K$ is $\omega=2 \pi \nu$. If the angle between the light and the $x$-axis is $\theta$, then

$$
k_{x}=k \cos \theta, \quad k_{y}=k \sin \theta, \quad k_{z}=0, \quad \omega=k \mathrm{c} .
$$

Thus

$$
\omega^{\prime}=\gamma(\omega+\beta \omega \cos \theta)=\gamma(1+\beta \cos \theta) \omega,
$$

or

$$
\nu^{\prime}=\frac{(1+\beta \cos \theta) \nu}{\sqrt{1-\beta^{2}}} .
$$

The above can also be written as

$$
k^{\prime}=\gamma(1+\beta \cos \theta) k
$$

As

$$
k_{x}^{\prime}=\gamma\left(k_{x}+\frac{\beta \omega}{\mathrm{c}}\right)=\gamma k(\cos \theta+\beta),
$$

the angle $\mathbf{k}^{\prime}$ makes with the $x^{\prime}$-axis is given by

$$
\cos \theta^{\prime}=\frac{k_{x}^{\prime}}{k^{\prime}}=\frac{\cos \theta+\beta}{1+\beta \cos \theta} .
$$

With $\beta=0.8, \theta=60^{\circ}$, we have

$$
\nu^{\prime}=\left(\frac{1+0.8 \cos 60^{\circ}}{\sqrt{1-0.8^{2}}}\right) \nu=\frac{1.4}{0.6} \nu=\frac{7}{3} \nu,
$$

3015.a.Problem Statement:
A mirror is moving through vacuum with relativistic speed $v$ in the $x$ direction. A beam of light with frequency $\omega_{i}$ is normally incident (from $x=+\infty$ ) on the mirror, as shown in Fig. 3.9.

What is the frequency of the reflected light expressed in terms of $\omega_{i}$, $\mathrm{c}$ and $v ?$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-695.jpg?height=271&width=404&top_left_y=1264&top_left_x=593)

Fig. 3.9.
3015.a.Solution:
Let $\Sigma, \Sigma^{\prime}$ be the rest frames of the light source and observer, and of the mirror respectively. The transformation for angular frequency is given by

$$
\omega^{\prime}=\gamma\left(\omega-\beta c k_{x}\right), \quad \omega=\gamma\left(\omega^{\prime}+\beta c k_{x}^{\prime}\right),
$$

where $\beta=\frac{v}{c}, \gamma=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\beta^{2}}}$. For the incident light, $\omega=\omega_{i}, k_{x}=-\frac{\omega_{i}}{c}$, the mirror perceives

$$
\omega_{i}^{\prime}=\gamma\left(\omega_{i}+\beta \omega_{i}\right)=\gamma(1+\beta) \omega_{i} .
$$

On reflection, $\omega_{r}^{\prime}=\omega_{i}^{\prime}$. The observer in $\Sigma$ will perceive

$$
\omega_{r}=\gamma\left(\omega_{r}^{\prime}+\beta c k_{x}^{\prime}\right)
$$

with $k_{x}^{\prime}=\omega_{r}^{\prime} / \mathrm{c}$, or

$$
\begin{aligned}
\omega_{r} &=\gamma(1+\beta) \omega_{r}^{\prime}=\gamma^{2}(1+\beta)^{2} \omega_{i} \\
&=\left(\frac{1+\beta}{1-\beta}\right) \omega_{i}=\left(\frac{c+v}{c-v}\right) \dot{\omega}_{i}
\end{aligned}
$$

as the angular frequency of the reflected light.

\omega_{r}=\gamma\left(\omega_{r}^{\prime}+\beta c k_{x}^{\prime}\right)
