Fig. 3.21.
3030.b.Solution:
For convenience use units such that $c=1(m, E, p$ are all in $\mathrm{MeV})$. Consider the Lorentz-invariant and conserved quantity $E^{2}-p^{2}$. In laboratory frame, before the decay

$$
E^{2}-p^{2}=E_{\pi}^{2}-p_{\pi}^{2}=m_{\pi}^{2} .
$$

In the rest frame of the pion, after the decay

$$
\begin{aligned}
E^{\prime 2}-p^{\prime 2} &=\left(E_{\mu}^{\prime}+E_{\nu}^{\prime}\right)^{2}-\left(\mathbf{p}_{\mu}^{\prime}+\mathbf{p}_{\nu}^{\prime}\right)^{2} \\
&=\left(E_{\mu}^{\prime}+E_{\nu}^{\prime}\right)^{2}=p_{\mu}^{\prime 2}+m_{\mu}^{2}+p_{\nu}^{\prime 2}+2 p_{\nu}^{\prime} \sqrt{p_{\mu}^{\prime 2}+m_{\mu}^{2}} \\
&=2 p_{\nu}^{\prime 2}+m_{\mu}^{2}+2 p_{\nu}^{\prime} \sqrt{p_{\nu}^{\prime 2}+m_{\mu}^{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

as $\mathbf{p}_{\mu}^{\prime}=-\mathbf{p}_{\nu}^{\prime}$, and $E_{\nu}^{\prime}=p_{\nu}^{\prime}$ assuming the neutrino to have zero rest mass. Equating the above two expressions gives

$$
E_{\nu}^{\prime}=p_{\nu}^{\prime}=\frac{m_{\pi}^{2}-m_{\mu}^{2}}{2 m_{\pi}}=29.9 \mathrm{MeV} .
$$In the laboratory frame (Fig. 3.21), momentum conservation gives

$$
p_{\pi}=p_{\nu} \cos \theta+p_{\mu} \cos \alpha, \quad p_{\nu} \sin \theta=p_{\mu} \sin \alpha,
$$

or

$$
p_{\mu}^{2}=p_{\pi}^{2}+p_{\nu}^{2}-2 p_{\pi} p_{\nu} \cos \theta,
$$

and energy conservation gives

$$
E_{\pi}=E_{\nu}+E_{\mu} .
$$

As $p_{\nu}=E_{\nu}, p_{\mu}^{2}=E_{\mu}^{2}-m_{\mu}^{2}$, the last two equations give

$$
p_{\nu}=\frac{m_{\pi}^{2}-m_{\mu}^{2}}{2\left(E_{\pi}-p_{\pi} \cos \theta\right)} .
$$

As $E_{\pi} \gg m_{\pi}$, we have

$$
p_{\pi}=E_{\pi} \sqrt{1-\frac{m_{\pi}^{2}}{E_{\pi}^{2}}} \approx E_{\pi}\left[1-\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{m_{\pi}}{E_{\pi}}\right)^{2}\right]
$$

and hence

$$
E_{\nu}=p_{\nu} \approx \frac{\left(m_{\pi}^{2}-m_{\mu}^{2}\right) E_{\pi}}{2 E_{\pi}^{2}(1-\cos \theta)+m_{\pi}^{2} \cos \theta} .
$$

For neutrinos emitted in the forward direction, $\theta=0$ and

$$
E_{\nu} \approx\left[1-\left(\frac{m_{\mu}}{m_{\pi}}\right)^{2}\right] E_{\pi}=85.4 \mathrm{GeV} \text {. }
$$

3030.c.Problem Statement:
High-energy neutrino beams at Fermi laboratory are made by first forming a monoenergetic $\pi^{+}$(or $K^{+}$) beam and then allowing the pions to decay by $\pi^{+} \rightarrow \mu^{+}+\nu$. Recall that the mass of the pion is $140 \mathrm{MeV} / \mathrm{c}^{2}$ and the mass of the muon is $106 \mathrm{MeV} / \mathrm{c}^{2}$.

Find the angle $\theta$ at which the neutrino's energy has fallen to half of its maximum energy.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-722.jpg?height=149&width=285&top_left_y=766&top_left_x=628)

Fig. 3.21.
3030.c.Solution:
For convenience use units such that $c=1(m, E, p$ are all in $\mathrm{MeV})$. Consider the Lorentz-invariant and conserved quantity $E^{2}-p^{2}$. In laboratory frame, before the decay

$$
E^{2}-p^{2}=E_{\pi}^{2}-p_{\pi}^{2}=m_{\pi}^{2} .
$$

In the rest frame of the pion, after the decay

$$
\begin{aligned}
E^{\prime 2}-p^{\prime 2} &=\left(E_{\mu}^{\prime}+E_{\nu}^{\prime}\right)^{2}-\left(\mathbf{p}_{\mu}^{\prime}+\mathbf{p}_{\nu}^{\prime}\right)^{2} \\
&=\left(E_{\mu}^{\prime}+E_{\nu}^{\prime}\right)^{2}=p_{\mu}^{\prime 2}+m_{\mu}^{2}+p_{\nu}^{\prime 2}+2 p_{\nu}^{\prime} \sqrt{p_{\mu}^{\prime 2}+m_{\mu}^{2}} \\
&=2 p_{\nu}^{\prime 2}+m_{\mu}^{2}+2 p_{\nu}^{\prime} \sqrt{p_{\nu}^{\prime 2}+m_{\mu}^{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

as $\mathbf{p}_{\mu}^{\prime}=-\mathbf{p}_{\nu}^{\prime}$, and $E_{\nu}^{\prime}=p_{\nu}^{\prime}$ assuming the neutrino to have zero rest mass. Equating the above two expressions gives

$$
E_{\nu}^{\prime}=p_{\nu}^{\prime}=\frac{m_{\pi}^{2}-m_{\mu}^{2}}{2 m_{\pi}}=29.9 \mathrm{MeV} .
$$In the laboratory frame (Fig. 3.21), momentum conservation gives

$$
p_{\pi}=p_{\nu} \cos \theta+p_{\mu} \cos \alpha, \quad p_{\nu} \sin \theta=p_{\mu} \sin \alpha,
$$

or

$$
p_{\mu}^{2}=p_{\pi}^{2}+p_{\nu}^{2}-2 p_{\pi} p_{\nu} \cos \theta,
$$

and energy conservation gives

$$
E_{\pi}=E_{\nu}+E_{\mu} .
$$

As $p_{\nu}=E_{\nu}, p_{\mu}^{2}=E_{\mu}^{2}-m_{\mu}^{2}$, the last two equations give

$$
p_{\nu}=\frac{m_{\pi}^{2}-m_{\mu}^{2}}{2\left(E_{\pi}-p_{\pi} \cos \theta\right)} .
$$

As $E_{\pi} \gg m_{\pi}$, we have

$$
p_{\pi}=E_{\pi} \sqrt{1-\frac{m_{\pi}^{2}}{E_{\pi}^{2}}} \approx E_{\pi}\left[1-\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{m_{\pi}}{E_{\pi}}\right)^{2}\right]
$$

and hence

$$
E_{\nu}=p_{\nu} \approx \frac{\left(m_{\pi}^{2}-m_{\mu}^{2}\right) E_{\pi}}{2 E_{\pi}^{2}(1-\cos \theta)+m_{\pi}^{2} \cos \theta} .
$$

For neutrinos emitted in the forward direction, $\theta=0$ and

$$
E_{\nu} \approx\left[1-\left(\frac{m_{\mu}}{m_{\pi}}\right)^{2}\right] E_{\pi}=85.4 \mathrm{GeV} \text {. }
$$As

$$
E_{\nu} \approx \frac{\left(m_{\pi}^{2}-m_{\mu}^{2}\right) E_{\pi}}{2 E_{\pi}^{2}-\left(2 E_{\pi}^{2}-m_{\pi}^{2}\right) \cos \theta},
$$

$E_{\nu}$ is maximum for neutrinos emitted at $\theta=0$. For $E_{\nu}$ at half the maximum value, i.e.

$$
\left(\frac{m_{\pi}^{2}-m_{\mu}^{2}}{m_{\pi}^{2}}\right) \frac{E_{\pi}}{2}=\frac{\left(m_{\pi}^{2}-E_{\mu}^{2}\right) E_{\pi}}{2 E_{\pi}^{2}-\left(2 E_{\pi}^{2}-m_{\pi}^{2}\right) \cos \theta},
$$

we have

$$
\cos \theta=\frac{2\left(E_{\pi}^{2}-m_{\pi}^{2}\right)}{2 E_{\pi}^{2}-m_{\pi}^{2}} \approx 1-\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{m_{\pi}}{E_{\pi}}\right)^{2} \approx 1-\frac{\theta^{2}}{2}
$$

as $\theta$ is obviously small. Hence

$$
\theta=\frac{m_{\pi}}{E_{\pi}}=0.0007 \mathrm{rad}=2.4^{\prime} .
$$

3031.a.Problem Statement: A particle of mass $m_{1}=1 \mathrm{~g}$ traveling at $0.9$ times the speed of light collides head-on with a stationary particle of mass $m_{2}=10 \mathrm{~g}$ and is embedded in it. What is the rest mass and velocity of the resulting composite particle?
3031.a.Solution:
Let the composite have mass $m$ and velocity $\beta c$. Conservation of energy and of momentum give

$$
m \gamma c^{2}=\left(m_{1} \gamma_{1}+m_{2}\right) c^{2}, \quad m \gamma \beta c=m_{1} \gamma_{1} \beta_{1} c .
$$

where $\gamma=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\beta^{2}}}$, etc. Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
\beta &=\frac{m_{1} \gamma_{1} \beta_{1}}{m_{1} \gamma_{1}+m_{2}}=\frac{m_{1} \beta_{1}}{m_{1}+m_{2} \sqrt{1-\beta_{1}^{2}}}=\frac{0.9}{1+10 \sqrt{1-0.9^{2}}}=0.168, \\
m^{2} &=(m \gamma)^{2}-(m \gamma \beta)^{2}=\left(m_{1} \gamma_{1}+m_{2}\right)^{2}-\left(m_{1} \gamma_{1} \beta_{1}\right)^{2} \\
&=m_{1}^{2}+m_{2}^{2}+2 \gamma_{1} m_{1} m_{2},
\end{aligned}
$$

as $(\gamma \beta)^{2}=\gamma^{2}-1$, etc., or

$$
m=\sqrt{m_{1}^{2}+m_{2}^{2}+\frac{2 m_{1} m_{2}}{\sqrt{1-\beta_{1}^{2}}}}=\sqrt{1+100+\frac{20}{\sqrt{1-0.9^{2}}}}=12.1 \mathrm{~g} .
$$

Thus the composite has rest mass $12.1 \mathrm{~g}$ and velocity $0.168 \mathrm{c}$.

3033.a.Problem Statement:
Of particular interest in particle physics at present are weak interactions at high energies. These can be investigated by studying high-energy neutrino interactions. One can produce neutrino beams by letting $\pi$ and $K$ mesons decay in flight. Suppose a $200 \mathrm{GeV} / \mathrm{c} \pi$ meson beam is used to produce neutrinos via the decay $\pi \rightarrow \mu+\nu$. The lifetime of a $\pi$ meson is $\tau_{\pi^{\pm}}=2.60 \times 10^{-8} \mathrm{~s}$ in its rest frame, and its rest energy is $139.6 \mathrm{MeV}$. The rest energy of the muon is $105.7 \mathrm{MeV}$, and the neutrino is massless.

Calculate the mean distance traveled by the pions before they decay.
3033.a.Solution:
Let $m$ be the rest mass of a pion. As $m \gamma \beta c^{2}=200 \mathrm{GeV}$, we have

$$
\gamma \beta=\sqrt{\gamma^{2}-1}=\frac{200}{0.1396}=1432.7
$$

and can take

$$
\beta \approx 1, \quad \gamma=1433 .
$$

On account of time dilation, the laboratory lifetime of a pion is $\tau=\gamma \tau_{\pi}=$ $1433 \times 2.6 \times 10^{-8}=3.726 \times 10^{-5} \mathrm{~s}$. So the mean distance traveled by the pions before they decay is

$$
\tau c=3.726 \times 10^{-5} \times 3 \times 10^{8}=1.12 \times 10^{4} \mathrm{~m}=11.2 \mathrm{~km} \text {. }
$$

3033.b.Problem Statement:
Of particular interest in particle physics at present are weak interactions at high energies. These can be investigated by studying high-energy neutrino interactions. One can produce neutrino beams by letting $\pi$ and $K$ mesons decay in flight. Suppose a $200 \mathrm{GeV} / \mathrm{c} \pi$ meson beam is used to produce neutrinos via the decay $\pi \rightarrow \mu+\nu$. The lifetime of a $\pi$ meson is $\tau_{\pi^{\pm}}=2.60 \times 10^{-8} \mathrm{~s}$ in its rest frame, and its rest energy is $139.6 \mathrm{MeV}$. The rest energy of the muon is $105.7 \mathrm{MeV}$, and the neutrino is massless.

Calculate the maximum angle of the muons (relative to the pion direction) in the laboratory.
3033.b.Solution:
Let $m$ be the rest mass of a pion. As $m \gamma \beta c^{2}=200 \mathrm{GeV}$, we have

$$
\gamma \beta=\sqrt{\gamma^{2}-1}=\frac{200}{0.1396}=1432.7
$$

and can take

$$
\beta \approx 1, \quad \gamma=1433 .
$$

On account of time dilation, the laboratory lifetime of a pion is $\tau=\gamma \tau_{\pi}=$ $1433 \times 2.6 \times 10^{-8}=3.726 \times 10^{-5} \mathrm{~s}$. So the mean distance traveled by the pions before they decay is

$$
\tau c=3.726 \times 10^{-5} \times 3 \times 10^{8}=1.12 \times 10^{4} \mathrm{~m}=11.2 \mathrm{~km} \text {. }
$$The total energy of the system in the rest frame $\Sigma^{\prime}$ of the pion is its rest energy $m_{\pi} c^{2}$. Conservation of energy requires that for $\pi \rightarrow \mu+\nu$,

$$
m_{\pi} c^{2}=E_{\mu}^{\prime}+E_{\nu}^{\prime},
$$

the prime being used to denote quantities in the $\Sigma^{\prime}$ frame. As the total momentum is zero in $\Sigma^{\prime}, \mathbf{p}_{\mu}^{\prime}=-\mathbf{p}_{\nu}^{\prime}$ and $E_{\nu}^{\prime}=p_{\nu}^{\prime} c=p_{\mu}^{\prime} c$, assuming the neutrino to have zero rest mass. Thus

$$
\left(m_{\pi} c^{2}-E_{\mu}^{\prime}\right)^{2}=p_{\nu}^{\prime 2} c^{2}=p_{\mu}^{\prime 2} c^{2}=E_{\mu}^{\prime 2}-m_{\mu}^{2} c^{4}
$$

giving

$$
E_{\mu}^{\prime}=\frac{\left(m_{\pi}^{2}+m_{\mu}^{2}\right) c^{2}}{2 m_{\pi}}=109.8 \mathrm{MeV} .
$$

Take the $x^{\prime}$-axis along the direction of motion of the pion. Transformation equations for the muon momentum are

$$
\begin{aligned}
&p_{\mu} \cos \theta=\gamma\left(p_{\mu}^{\prime} \cos \theta^{\prime}+\frac{\beta E_{\mu}^{\prime}}{c}\right) \\
&p_{\mu} \sin \theta=p_{\mu}^{\prime} \sin \theta^{\prime}
\end{aligned}
$$

giving

$$
\tan \theta=\frac{p_{\mu}^{\prime} \sin \theta^{\prime}}{\gamma\left(p_{\mu}^{\prime} \cos \theta^{\prime}+\frac{\beta E_{\mu}^{\prime}}{c}\right)} .
$$

For $\theta$ to be maximum, we require

$$
\frac{d \tan \theta}{d \theta^{\prime}}=0,
$$

which gives

$$
\cos \theta^{\prime}=-\frac{p_{\mu}^{\prime} c}{\beta E_{\mu}^{\prime}} \approx-\frac{p_{\mu}^{\prime} c}{E_{\mu}^{\prime}}=-\frac{\sqrt{E_{\mu}^{\prime 2}-m_{\mu}^{2} c^{4}}}{E_{\mu}^{\prime}}=-0.271
$$

or $\theta^{\prime}=105.7^{\circ}$. This in turn gives

$$
\theta=0.0112^{\circ}=0.675^{\prime} \text {. }
$$

Note that this is the maximum angle of emission in the laboratory since the minimum angle is 0 , corresponding to $\theta^{\prime}=0$.

3033.c.Problem Statement:
Of particular interest in particle physics at present are weak interactions at high energies. These can be investigated by studying high-energy neutrino interactions. One can produce neutrino beams by letting $\pi$ and $K$ mesons decay in flight. Suppose a $200 \mathrm{GeV} / \mathrm{c} \pi$ meson beam is used to produce neutrinos via the decay $\pi \rightarrow \mu+\nu$. The lifetime of a $\pi$ meson is $\tau_{\pi^{\pm}}=2.60 \times 10^{-8} \mathrm{~s}$ in its rest frame, and its rest energy is $139.6 \mathrm{MeV}$. The rest energy of the muon is $105.7 \mathrm{MeV}$, and the neutrino is massless.

Calculate the minimum and maximum momenta the neutrinos can have.
3033.c.Solution:
Let $m$ be the rest mass of a pion. As $m \gamma \beta c^{2}=200 \mathrm{GeV}$, we have

$$
\gamma \beta=\sqrt{\gamma^{2}-1}=\frac{200}{0.1396}=1432.7
$$

and can take

$$
\beta \approx 1, \quad \gamma=1433 .
$$

On account of time dilation, the laboratory lifetime of a pion is $\tau=\gamma \tau_{\pi}=$ $1433 \times 2.6 \times 10^{-8}=3.726 \times 10^{-5} \mathrm{~s}$. So the mean distance traveled by the pions before they decay is

$$
\tau c=3.726 \times 10^{-5} \times 3 \times 10^{8}=1.12 \times 10^{4} \mathrm{~m}=11.2 \mathrm{~km} \text {. }
$$The total energy of the system in the rest frame $\Sigma^{\prime}$ of the pion is its rest energy $m_{\pi} c^{2}$. Conservation of energy requires that for $\pi \rightarrow \mu+\nu$,

$$
m_{\pi} c^{2}=E_{\mu}^{\prime}+E_{\nu}^{\prime},
$$

the prime being used to denote quantities in the $\Sigma^{\prime}$ frame. As the total momentum is zero in $\Sigma^{\prime}, \mathbf{p}_{\mu}^{\prime}=-\mathbf{p}_{\nu}^{\prime}$ and $E_{\nu}^{\prime}=p_{\nu}^{\prime} c=p_{\mu}^{\prime} c$, assuming the neutrino to have zero rest mass. Thus

$$
\left(m_{\pi} c^{2}-E_{\mu}^{\prime}\right)^{2}=p_{\nu}^{\prime 2} c^{2}=p_{\mu}^{\prime 2} c^{2}=E_{\mu}^{\prime 2}-m_{\mu}^{2} c^{4}
$$

giving

$$
E_{\mu}^{\prime}=\frac{\left(m_{\pi}^{2}+m_{\mu}^{2}\right) c^{2}}{2 m_{\pi}}=109.8 \mathrm{MeV} .
$$

Take the $x^{\prime}$-axis along the direction of motion of the pion. Transformation equations for the muon momentum are

$$
\begin{aligned}
&p_{\mu} \cos \theta=\gamma\left(p_{\mu}^{\prime} \cos \theta^{\prime}+\frac{\beta E_{\mu}^{\prime}}{c}\right) \\
&p_{\mu} \sin \theta=p_{\mu}^{\prime} \sin \theta^{\prime}
\end{aligned}
$$

giving

$$
\tan \theta=\frac{p_{\mu}^{\prime} \sin \theta^{\prime}}{\gamma\left(p_{\mu}^{\prime} \cos \theta^{\prime}+\frac{\beta E_{\mu}^{\prime}}{c}\right)} .
$$

For $\theta$ to be maximum, we require

$$
\frac{d \tan \theta}{d \theta^{\prime}}=0,
$$

which gives

$$
\cos \theta^{\prime}=-\frac{p_{\mu}^{\prime} c}{\beta E_{\mu}^{\prime}} \approx-\frac{p_{\mu}^{\prime} c}{E_{\mu}^{\prime}}=-\frac{\sqrt{E_{\mu}^{\prime 2}-m_{\mu}^{2} c^{4}}}{E_{\mu}^{\prime}}=-0.271
$$

or $\theta^{\prime}=105.7^{\circ}$. This in turn gives

$$
\theta=0.0112^{\circ}=0.675^{\prime} \text {. }
$$

Note that this is the maximum angle of emission in the laboratory since the minimum angle is 0 , corresponding to $\theta^{\prime}=0$.The neutrino has energy

$$
E_{\nu}^{\prime}=m_{\pi} c^{2}-E_{\mu}^{\prime}=139.6-109.8=29.8 \mathrm{MeV}
$$

and momentum $p_{\nu}^{\prime}=29.8 \mathrm{MeV} / \mathrm{c}$ in $\Sigma^{\prime} . E_{\nu}^{\prime}$ can be transformed to the $\Sigma$ frame by

$$
E_{\nu}=\gamma\left(E_{\nu}^{\prime}+\beta p_{\nu}^{\prime} c \cos \theta^{\prime}\right) .
$$

As $E_{\nu}=p_{\nu} c, E_{\nu}^{\prime}=p_{\nu}^{\prime} c$, the above can be written as

$$
p_{\nu}=\gamma\left(1+\beta \cos \theta^{\prime}\right) p_{\nu}^{\prime} .
$$

Hence neutrinos emitted in the forward direction of the pion rest frame, i.e. $\theta^{\prime}=0$, will have the largest momentum in the laboratory of

$$
\left(p_{\nu}\right)_{\max }=\gamma(1+\beta) p_{\nu}^{\prime} \approx \frac{2 \gamma E_{\nu}^{\prime}}{c}=8.54 \times 10^{4} \mathrm{MeV} / c
$$

while neutrinos emitted backward in $\Sigma^{\prime}$ will have the smallest momentum in the laboratory of

$$
\left(p_{\nu}\right)_{\min }=\gamma(1-\beta) p_{\nu}^{\prime}=\left(\gamma-\sqrt{\gamma^{2}-1}\right) p_{\nu}^{\prime} \approx \frac{1}{2 \gamma} \frac{E_{\nu}^{\prime}}{\mathrm{c}}=1.04 \times 10^{-2} \mathrm{MeV} / c
$$

3034.Problem Statement: A $K$ meson of rest energy $494 \mathrm{MeV}$ decays into a $\mu$ meson of rest energy $106 \mathrm{MeV}$ and a neutrino of zero rest energy. Find the kinetic energies of the $\mu$ meson and neutrino into which the $K$ meson decays while at rest.
3034.Solution:
Conservation of energy gives

$$
m_{K} c^{2}=E_{\mu}+E_{\nu}=\sqrt{p_{\mu}^{2} c^{2}+m_{\mu}^{2} c^{4}}+p_{\nu} c=\sqrt{p_{\mu}^{2} c^{2}+m_{\mu}^{2} c^{4}}+p_{\mu} c
$$

as $\mathbf{p}_{\mu}=-\mathbf{p}_{\nu}$, or $p_{\mu}=p_{\nu}$, for momentum conservation. Hence

$$
p_{\mu}=\left(\frac{m_{K}^{2}-m_{\mu}^{2}}{2 m_{K}}\right) c .
$$

Thus

$$
\begin{aligned}
E_{\nu} &=p_{\nu} c=p_{\mu} c=\left(\frac{m_{K}^{2}-m_{\mu}^{2}}{2 m_{K}}\right) c^{2} \\
&=235.6 \mathrm{MeV}, \\
E_{\mu} &=\sqrt{p_{\mu}^{2} c^{2}+m_{\mu}^{2} c^{4}}=\left(\frac{m_{K}^{2}+m_{\mu}^{2}}{2 m_{K}}\right) c^{2} \\
&=258.4 \mathrm{MeV} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore the kinetic energy of the neutrino is $235.6 \mathrm{MeV}$, and that of the muon is $258.4-106=152.4 \mathrm{MeV}$.

3036.a.Problem Statement:
The following question is a question on Newtonian gravity.

Calculate the radius and density of a solar-mass $\operatorname{star}\left(M=2 \times 10^{33} \mathrm{~g}\right)$ from which light could not escape.
3036.a.Solution:
By the equivalence of mass and energy, a photon of energy $E=m c^{2}$ has an equivalent mass $m$. The potential of a particle of mass $m$ at the surface of a star of mass $M$ and radius $R$ is

$$
V=-\frac{G M m}{R},
$$

where $G$ is the constant of gravitation. Hence for the photon to escape the star, we require $E+V \geq 0$, or $E \geq-V$. Conversely the photon will be confined to the star if $E \leq-V$, i.e.

$$
m c^{2} \leq \frac{G M m}{R},
$$

or

$$
R \leq \frac{G M}{c^{2}}=\frac{6.67 \times 10^{-8} \times 2 \times 10^{33}}{\left(3 \times 10^{10}\right)^{2}}=1.48 \times 10^{5} \mathrm{~cm}=1.48 \mathrm{~km}
$$

The density $\rho$ of the sun must then be

$$
\begin{aligned}
\rho & \geq M\left(\frac{4}{3} \pi R^{3}\right)^{-1}=\left(\frac{3}{4 \pi}\right) \times \frac{2 \times 10^{33}}{\left(1.48 \times 10^{5}\right)^{3}} \\
&=1.47 \times 10^{-1} \times \frac{10^{33}}{10^{15}}=1.47 \times 10^{17} \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{cm}^{3} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Note that this result is consistent with the gravitational red shift. A photon of frequency $\nu$ emitted by the star will have a frequency $\nu^{\prime}$ at a large distance from it, where

$$
\nu^{\prime}=\nu\left(1-\frac{G M}{R c^{2}}\right)
$$

For the photon to escape the gravitational field of the star we require that $\nu^{\prime} \geq 0$, or

$$
R \geq \frac{G M}{c^{2}} .
$$

3038.Problem Statement: A hypothetical flashlight emits a well-collimated beam and is capable of converting a significant fraction of its rest mass into light. If the flashlight starts at rest with mass $m_{0}$, and is then turned on and allowed to move freely along a straight line, find its rest mass $m$ when it reaches a velocity $v$ relative to its original rest frame. Do not assume $c \gg v$.
3038.Solution:
Let the total energy of all the photons emitted before the light reaches the velocity $v=\beta c$ be $E$. Then the total momentum of the photons is $\frac{E}{c}$ and is opposite in direction to $v$. Let the rest mass of the flashlight be $m$ when its velocity is $v$. Conservation of energy gives

$$
m \gamma c^{2}+E=m_{0} c^{2},
$$

and conservation of momentum gives

$$
m \gamma \beta c-\frac{E}{c}=0,
$$

with $\gamma=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\beta^{2}}}$. Eliminating $E$ from the above gives

$$
m \gamma(1+\beta)=m_{0},
$$

or

$$
m=\frac{m_{0}}{\gamma(1+\beta)}=m_{0} \sqrt{\frac{1-\beta}{1+\beta}}=m_{0} \sqrt{\frac{c-v}{c+v}} .
$$

3039.a.Problem Statement:
A particle of charge $q$, mass $m$ moves in a circular orbit of radius $R$ in the $x y$-plane in a uniform magnetic field $\mathbf{B}=B \hat{\mathbf{z}}$.

Find $B$ in terms of $q, R, m$, and the angular frequency $\omega$.
3039.a.Solution:
The equation of motion of the particle in the laboratory is

$$
\frac{d \mathbf{p}}{d t}=q \mathbf{u} \times \mathbf{B} .
$$

As $\mathbf{p}$ and $\mathbf{u}$ are parallel,

$$
\mathbf{p} \cdot \frac{d \mathbf{p}}{d t}=\frac{1}{2} \frac{d p^{2}}{d t}=q \mathbf{p} \cdot \mathbf{u} \times \mathbf{B}=0 .
$$

Hence $p^{2}$ and thus the magnitude of $\mathbf{p}$ and $\mathbf{u}$ are constant. It follows that

$$
\gamma_{u}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\left(\frac{u}{c}\right)^{2}}}
$$

is also a constant. Then, as $\mathbf{p}=m \gamma_{u} \mathbf{u}$, the equation of motion can be written as

$$
\frac{d \mathbf{u}}{d t}=\mathbf{u} \times \boldsymbol{\omega}
$$

with $\boldsymbol{\omega}=q \mathbf{B} / m \gamma_{u}$. As

$$
\mathbf{u}=(\dot{x}, \dot{y}, 0), \quad \boldsymbol{\omega}=(0,0, \omega),
$$

it becomes

$$
\ddot{x}=\dot{y} \omega, \quad \ddot{y}=-\dot{x} \omega, \quad \ddot{z}=0 .
$$

Since the motion is confined to the $x y$-plane, the $z$ equation need not be considered. The other two equations combine to give

$$
\ddot{\xi}+i \omega \dot{\xi}=0
$$

by putting $x+i y=\xi$. It has general solution

$$
\xi=\rho e^{-i(\omega t+\varphi)}+\xi_{0},
$$

where $\rho, \varphi$ are real constants and $\xi_{0}$ is a complex constant. This solution is equivalent to

$$
x-x_{0}=R \cos (\omega t+\varphi), \quad y-y_{0}=-R \sin (\omega t+\varphi),
$$

showing that the motion is circular with a radius $R$ given by

$$
u=\sqrt{\dot{x}^{2}+\dot{y}^{2}}=R \omega,
$$

$\omega$ being the angular velocity of revolution. Hence

$$
B=\frac{m \gamma_{u} \omega}{q}=\frac{m \omega}{q} \frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\left(\frac{u}{c}\right)^{2}}}=\frac{m \omega}{q} \frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\left(\frac{R \omega}{c}\right)^{2}}} .
$$

3039.b.Problem Statement:
A particle of charge $q$, mass $m$ moves in a circular orbit of radius $R$ in the $x y$-plane in a uniform magnetic field $\mathbf{B}=B \hat{\mathbf{z}}$.

The speed of the particle is constant (since the $\mathbf{B}$ field does no work on it). An observer moving with uniform velocity $\beta \hat{\mathbf{x}}$ does not, however, see the particle's speed as constant. What is $u_{0}^{\prime}$ ( the zero component of the particle's 4-velocity) as measured by this observer?
3039.b.Solution:
The equation of motion of the particle in the laboratory is

$$
\frac{d \mathbf{p}}{d t}=q \mathbf{u} \times \mathbf{B} .
$$

As $\mathbf{p}$ and $\mathbf{u}$ are parallel,

$$
\mathbf{p} \cdot \frac{d \mathbf{p}}{d t}=\frac{1}{2} \frac{d p^{2}}{d t}=q \mathbf{p} \cdot \mathbf{u} \times \mathbf{B}=0 .
$$

Hence $p^{2}$ and thus the magnitude of $\mathbf{p}$ and $\mathbf{u}$ are constant. It follows that

$$
\gamma_{u}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\left(\frac{u}{c}\right)^{2}}}
$$

is also a constant. Then, as $\mathbf{p}=m \gamma_{u} \mathbf{u}$, the equation of motion can be written as

$$
\frac{d \mathbf{u}}{d t}=\mathbf{u} \times \boldsymbol{\omega}
$$

with $\boldsymbol{\omega}=q \mathbf{B} / m \gamma_{u}$. As

$$
\mathbf{u}=(\dot{x}, \dot{y}, 0), \quad \boldsymbol{\omega}=(0,0, \omega),
$$

it becomes

$$
\ddot{x}=\dot{y} \omega, \quad \ddot{y}=-\dot{x} \omega, \quad \ddot{z}=0 .
$$

Since the motion is confined to the $x y$-plane, the $z$ equation need not be considered. The other two equations combine to give

$$
\ddot{\xi}+i \omega \dot{\xi}=0
$$

by putting $x+i y=\xi$. It has general solution

$$
\xi=\rho e^{-i(\omega t+\varphi)}+\xi_{0},
$$

where $\rho, \varphi$ are real constants and $\xi_{0}$ is a complex constant. This solution is equivalent to

$$
x-x_{0}=R \cos (\omega t+\varphi), \quad y-y_{0}=-R \sin (\omega t+\varphi),
$$

showing that the motion is circular with a radius $R$ given by

$$
u=\sqrt{\dot{x}^{2}+\dot{y}^{2}}=R \omega,
$$

$\omega$ being the angular velocity of revolution. Hence

$$
B=\frac{m \gamma_{u} \omega}{q}=\frac{m \omega}{q} \frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\left(\frac{u}{c}\right)^{2}}}=\frac{m \omega}{q} \frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\left(\frac{R \omega}{c}\right)^{2}}} .
$$Let $S, S^{\prime}$ be respectively the laboratory frame and the rest frame of the moving observer. The zeroth component of the velocity four-vector, defined as $u^{\alpha}=\left(\gamma_{u} c, \gamma_{u} \mathbf{u}\right)$, transforms according to

$$
\gamma_{u}^{\prime} c=\gamma\left(\gamma_{u} c-\beta \gamma_{u} u_{1}\right),
$$

where $\gamma=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\beta^{2}}}$. Thus

$$
\begin{aligned}
u_{0}^{\prime} \equiv \gamma_{u}^{\prime} c &=\gamma \gamma_{u}(c-\beta \dot{x}) \\
&=\gamma \gamma_{u}[c+\beta \omega R \sin (\omega t+\varphi)] \\
&=\gamma \gamma_{u}\left[c+\beta u \sin \left(\omega \gamma_{u} \tau+\varphi\right)\right],
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\tau$ is the proper time of the particle. Thus $u_{0}^{\prime}$ is not constant in $S^{\prime}$.

3039.c.Problem Statement:
A particle of charge $q$, mass $m$ moves in a circular orbit of radius $R$ in the $x y$-plane in a uniform magnetic field $\mathbf{B}=B \hat{\mathbf{z}}$.

Calculate $\frac{d u_{0}^{\prime}}{d \tau}$ and, thus, $\frac{d p_{0}^{\prime}}{d \tau}$. How can the energy of the particle change?
3039.c.Solution:
The equation of motion of the particle in the laboratory is

$$
\frac{d \mathbf{p}}{d t}=q \mathbf{u} \times \mathbf{B} .
$$

As $\mathbf{p}$ and $\mathbf{u}$ are parallel,

$$
\mathbf{p} \cdot \frac{d \mathbf{p}}{d t}=\frac{1}{2} \frac{d p^{2}}{d t}=q \mathbf{p} \cdot \mathbf{u} \times \mathbf{B}=0 .
$$

Hence $p^{2}$ and thus the magnitude of $\mathbf{p}$ and $\mathbf{u}$ are constant. It follows that

$$
\gamma_{u}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\left(\frac{u}{c}\right)^{2}}}
$$

is also a constant. Then, as $\mathbf{p}=m \gamma_{u} \mathbf{u}$, the equation of motion can be written as

$$
\frac{d \mathbf{u}}{d t}=\mathbf{u} \times \boldsymbol{\omega}
$$

with $\boldsymbol{\omega}=q \mathbf{B} / m \gamma_{u}$. As

$$
\mathbf{u}=(\dot{x}, \dot{y}, 0), \quad \boldsymbol{\omega}=(0,0, \omega),
$$

it becomes

$$
\ddot{x}=\dot{y} \omega, \quad \ddot{y}=-\dot{x} \omega, \quad \ddot{z}=0 .
$$

Since the motion is confined to the $x y$-plane, the $z$ equation need not be considered. The other two equations combine to give

$$
\ddot{\xi}+i \omega \dot{\xi}=0
$$

by putting $x+i y=\xi$. It has general solution

$$
\xi=\rho e^{-i(\omega t+\varphi)}+\xi_{0},
$$

where $\rho, \varphi$ are real constants and $\xi_{0}$ is a complex constant. This solution is equivalent to

$$
x-x_{0}=R \cos (\omega t+\varphi), \quad y-y_{0}=-R \sin (\omega t+\varphi),
$$

showing that the motion is circular with a radius $R$ given by

$$
u=\sqrt{\dot{x}^{2}+\dot{y}^{2}}=R \omega,
$$

$\omega$ being the angular velocity of revolution. Hence

$$
B=\frac{m \gamma_{u} \omega}{q}=\frac{m \omega}{q} \frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\left(\frac{u}{c}\right)^{2}}}=\frac{m \omega}{q} \frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\left(\frac{R \omega}{c}\right)^{2}}} .
$$Let $S, S^{\prime}$ be respectively the laboratory frame and the rest frame of the moving observer. The zeroth component of the velocity four-vector, defined as $u^{\alpha}=\left(\gamma_{u} c, \gamma_{u} \mathbf{u}\right)$, transforms according to

$$
\gamma_{u}^{\prime} c=\gamma\left(\gamma_{u} c-\beta \gamma_{u} u_{1}\right),
$$

where $\gamma=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\beta^{2}}}$. Thus

$$
\begin{aligned}
u_{0}^{\prime} \equiv \gamma_{u}^{\prime} c &=\gamma \gamma_{u}(c-\beta \dot{x}) \\
&=\gamma \gamma_{u}[c+\beta \omega R \sin (\omega t+\varphi)] \\
&=\gamma \gamma_{u}\left[c+\beta u \sin \left(\omega \gamma_{u} \tau+\varphi\right)\right],
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\tau$ is the proper time of the particle. Thus $u_{0}^{\prime}$ is not constant in $S^{\prime}$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{d u_{0}^{\prime}}{d \tau} &=\gamma \gamma_{u}^{2} \beta \omega u \cos \left(\omega \gamma_{u} \tau+\varphi\right) \\
&=R\left(\frac{q B}{m}\right)^{2} \frac{\beta}{\sqrt{1-\beta^{2}}} \cos \left(\frac{q B \tau}{m}+\varphi\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

If the four-momentum is defined as $p^{\alpha}=\left(m u_{0}, \mathbf{p}\right)$, then, as $m$ is a constant,

$$
\frac{d p_{0}^{\prime}}{d \tau}=m \frac{d u_{0}^{\prime}}{d \tau}=\frac{R q^{2} B^{2}}{m} \frac{\beta}{\sqrt{1-\beta^{2}}} \cos \left(\frac{q B \tau}{m}+\varphi\right),
$$

which signifies a change of energy

$$
\frac{d E}{d \tau}=c \frac{d p_{0}^{\prime}}{d \tau} .
$$

Note that in the $S^{\prime}$ frame, the electromagnetic field is given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
E_{\|}^{\prime} &=E_{\|}=0 \\
E_{\perp}^{\prime} &=\gamma\left(\mathbf{E}_{\perp}+\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{B}_{\perp}\right) \\
&=\gamma \mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{B}_{\perp} \\
&=\gamma \beta \hat{\mathbf{x}} \times B \hat{\mathbf{z}}=-\gamma \beta B \hat{\mathbf{y}},
\end{aligned}
$$

so that there is also an electric field in the $S^{\prime}$ frame which does work on the particle.

3041.a.Problem Statement:
A photon of momentum $p$ impinges on a particle at rest of mass $m$.

What is the total relativistic energy of photon plus particle in the center of mass frame of reference?
3041.a.Solution:
Consider the quantity $E^{2}-P^{2} c^{2}$ of the system which is invariant under Lorentz transformation:

$$
\left(p c+m c^{2}\right)^{2}-p^{2} c^{2}=E^{\prime 2},
$$

where $E^{\prime}$ is total energy of the system in the center of mass frame, which is by definition the inertial frame in which the total momentum vanishes. Hence 

$$
E^{\prime}=\sqrt{2 p m c^{3}+m^{2} c^{4}} .
$$

3041.b.Problem Statement:
A photon of momentum $p$ impinges on a particle at rest of mass $m$.

What is the magnitude of the particle's momentum in the center of mass frame?
3041.b.Solution:
Consider the quantity $E^{2}-P^{2} c^{2}$ of the system which is invariant under Lorentz transformation:

$$
\left(p c+m c^{2}\right)^{2}-p^{2} c^{2}=E^{\prime 2},
$$

where $E^{\prime}$ is total energy of the system in the center of mass frame, which is by definition the inertial frame in which the total momentum vanishes. Hence 

$$
E^{\prime}=\sqrt{2 p m c^{3}+m^{2} c^{4}} .
$$In the center of mass frame, the total momentum $P^{\prime}=0$ and $p$ the momentum of the particle is equal and opposite to that of the photon $p^{\prime}$. Momentum transformation

$$
P^{\prime}=0=\gamma\left(P-\frac{\beta E}{c}\right)
$$

gives

$$
\beta=\frac{P c}{E}=\frac{p c}{p c+m c^{2}}, \quad \gamma=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\beta^{2}}}
$$

for the center of mass frame. The particle momentum in the center of mass frame is then, using the transformation equation again,

$$
p^{\prime}=\gamma(0-\beta m c)=-\gamma \beta m c=\frac{-p m c}{\sqrt{2 p m c+m^{2} c^{2}}} .
$$
3041.b.Final Answer: $$\frac{-p m c}{\sqrt{2 p m c+m^{2} c^{2}}}$$

3041.c.Problem Statement:
A photon of momentum $p$ impinges on a particle at rest of mass $m$.

If elastic backward scattering of the photon occurs, what is the momentum of the final photon in the laboratory frame?
3041.c.Solution:
Consider the quantity $E^{2}-P^{2} c^{2}$ of the system which is invariant under Lorentz transformation:

$$
\left(p c+m c^{2}\right)^{2}-p^{2} c^{2}=E^{\prime 2},
$$

where $E^{\prime}$ is total energy of the system in the center of mass frame, which is by definition the inertial frame in which the total momentum vanishes. Hence 

$$
E^{\prime}=\sqrt{2 p m c^{3}+m^{2} c^{4}} .
$$In the center of mass frame, the total momentum $P^{\prime}=0$ and $p$ the momentum of the particle is equal and opposite to that of the photon $p^{\prime}$. Momentum transformation

$$
P^{\prime}=0=\gamma\left(P-\frac{\beta E}{c}\right)
$$

gives

$$
\beta=\frac{P c}{E}=\frac{p c}{p c+m c^{2}}, \quad \gamma=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\beta^{2}}}
$$

for the center of mass frame. The particle momentum in the center of mass frame is then, using the transformation equation again,

$$
p^{\prime}=\gamma(0-\beta m c)=-\gamma \beta m c=\frac{-p m c}{\sqrt{2 p m c+m^{2} c^{2}}} .
$$Let the final momenta of the photon and the particle be $-p_{1}$ and $p_{2}$ respectively. Conservation of energy and of momentum give

$$
\begin{aligned}
p c+m c^{2} &=p_{1} c+\sqrt{p_{2}^{2} c^{2}+m^{2} c^{4}} \\
p &=-p_{1}+p_{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

These combine to give

$$
\left(p-p_{1}\right)^{2}+2\left(p-p_{1}\right) m c=\left(p+p_{1}\right)^{2},
$$

or

$$
p_{1}=\frac{p m c}{2 p+m c} .
$$

3042.a.Problem Statement:
We consider the possibility that one of the recently discovered particles, the $\psi^{\prime}(3.7)$, can be produced when a photon collides with a proton in the reaction

$$
\gamma+p \rightarrow p+\psi^{\prime}
$$

In this problem we shall take the mass of $\psi^{\prime}$ to be $4 M_{p}$, where $M_{p}$ is the proton mass, which is a reasonable approximation. The target proton is initially at rest and the incident photon has energy $E$ in the laboratory system.

Determine the minimum energy $E$ that the photon must have for the above reaction to be possible. The answer can be given in units of $M_{p} c^{2}$ $(=938 \mathrm{MeV})$
3042.a.Solution:
At threshold, the final-state particles $p, \psi^{\prime}$ are stationary in the center of mass frame. Using the fact that the quantity $E^{2}-P^{2} c^{2}$ is invariant under Lorentz transformation and for an isolated system is conserved, we have, as a photon of energy $E$ has momentum $\frac{E}{c}$,

$$
\left(E_{0}+M_{p} c^{2}\right)^{2}-E_{0}^{2}=\left(M_{p} c^{2}+4 M_{p} c^{2}\right)^{2},
$$

giving

$$
E_{0}=12 M_{p} c^{2}
$$

as the threshold photon energy.

3042.b.Problem Statement:
We consider the possibility that one of the recently discovered particles, the $\psi^{\prime}(3.7)$, can be produced when a photon collides with a proton in the reaction

$$
\gamma+p \rightarrow p+\psi^{\prime}
$$

In this problem we shall take the mass of $\psi^{\prime}$ to be $4 M_{p}$, where $M_{p}$ is the proton mass, which is a reasonable approximation. The target proton is initially at rest and the incident photon has energy $E$ in the laboratory system.

Determine the velocity, i.e. $v / c$, for the $\psi^{\prime}$ particle when the photon energy $E$ is just above the threshold energy $E_{0}$.
3042.b.Solution:
At threshold, the final-state particles $p, \psi^{\prime}$ are stationary in the center of mass frame. Using the fact that the quantity $E^{2}-P^{2} c^{2}$ is invariant under Lorentz transformation and for an isolated system is conserved, we have, as a photon of energy $E$ has momentum $\frac{E}{c}$,

$$
\left(E_{0}+M_{p} c^{2}\right)^{2}-E_{0}^{2}=\left(M_{p} c^{2}+4 M_{p} c^{2}\right)^{2},
$$

giving

$$
E_{0}=12 M_{p} c^{2}
$$

as the threshold photon energy.Near threshold, the $\psi^{\prime}$ is produced at rest in the center of mass frame, so its velocity in the laboratory is the velocity of the center of mass, i.e. of the system:

$$
v=\frac{P c^{2}}{E}=\frac{E_{0} c}{E_{0}+M_{p} c^{2}}=\frac{12}{13} \mathrm{c} .
$$

3043.Problem Statement: An antiproton of energy $E_{0}$ interacts with a proton at rest to produce two equal mass particles, each with mass $m_{x}$. One of these produced particles is detected at an angle of $90^{\circ}$ to the incident beam as measured in the laboratory. Calculate the total energy $\left(E_{s}\right)$ of this particle and show that it is independent of $m_{x}$ as well as of $E_{0}$.
3043.Solution:
Antiproton and proton have the same mass $m$, say. The collision is depicted in Fig. 3.23. Momentum conservation gives

$$
p_{0}=p_{2} \cos \theta, \quad p_{1}=p_{2} \sin \theta,
$$

or

$$
p_{2}^{2}=p_{0}^{2}+p_{1}^{2} .
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-742.jpg?height=273&width=502&top_left_y=609&top_left_x=505)

Fig. $3.23$.

Energy conservation gives

$$
E_{0}+m c^{2}=E_{s}+\sqrt{p_{2}^{2} c^{2}+m_{x}^{2} c^{4}} .
$$

Combining the last two equations gives

$$
\left(E_{0}+m c^{2}\right)^{2}+E_{s}^{2}-2\left(E_{0}+m c^{2}\right) E_{s}=p_{0}^{2} c^{2}+p_{1}^{2} c^{2}+m_{x}^{2} c^{4}
$$

or

$$
2 m^{2} c^{4}+2 E_{0} m c^{2}=2\left(E_{0}+m c^{2}\right) E_{s},
$$

since $E_{0}^{2}=p_{0}^{2} c^{2}+m^{2} c^{4}, E_{s}^{2}=p_{1}^{2} c^{2}+m_{x}^{2} c^{4}$. Hence

$$
E_{s}=m c^{2} \text {. }
$$

It is seen that $E_{s}$ depends only on the proton mass but is independent of either $m_{x}$ or $E_{0}$.

3045.Problem Statement: A charged particle (with charge $e$ and rest mass $m$ ) moves in an electromagnetic field which is constant in space and time and whose components are $\mathbf{E}=(a, 0,0)$ and $\mathbf{B}=(0,0, b)$ in a Lorentz frame $S$. It is assumed that $|\mathbf{E}| \neq|\mathbf{B}|$. State the differential equations for the particle's four-vector velocity (as function of the proper time). Show that the solutions may be expressed as superpositions of exponentials, and determine the exponents. Under what conditions (on $\mathbf{E}$ and $\mathbf{B}$ ) are all components of the four-velocity bounded along every trajectory?
3045.Solution:
The motion of the particle is described by the 4 -vector equation

$$
\frac{d p^{\alpha}}{d s}=F^{\alpha},
$$

where $d s=c d \tau, \tau$ being the proper time of the particle,

$$
\begin{aligned}
p^{\alpha} &=m c^{2} u^{\alpha}=m c^{2}\left(\frac{\gamma}{c} \mathbf{u}, \gamma\right) \\
F^{\alpha} &=\left(\gamma \mathbf{F}, \frac{\gamma}{c} \mathbf{u} \cdot \mathbf{F}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

with $\gamma=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\frac{u^{2}}{c^{2}}}}$ and $\mathbf{u}$ being the velocity of the particle.

The force acting on the particle is the Lorentz force

$$
\mathbf{F}=e(\mathbf{E}+\mathbf{u} \times \mathbf{B}) .
$$

With $\mathbf{u}=\left(u_{x}, u_{y}, u_{z}\right), \mathbf{E}=(a, 0,0), \mathbf{B}=(0, \mathbf{0}, b)$, and $\mathbf{u} \cdot \mathbf{F}=e \mathbf{u} \cdot \mathbf{E}=e a u_{x}$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
F^{\alpha} &=e \gamma\left(a+b u_{y},-b u_{x}, 0, \frac{a u_{x}}{c}\right) \\
&=e\left(a u_{4}+c b u_{2},-c b u_{1}, 0, a u_{1}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the equations of motion are 

$$
\begin{aligned}
&m \frac{d u_{1}}{d \tau}=\frac{e}{c}\left(c b u_{2}+a u_{4}\right) \\
&m \frac{d u_{2}}{d \tau}=-e b u_{1} \\
&m \frac{d u_{3}}{d \tau}=0 \\
&m \frac{d u_{4}}{d \tau}=\frac{e a u_{1}}{c}
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus $u_{3}$ is a constant and need not be considered further. To solve the other equations, try

$$
u_{j}=A_{j} e^{\lambda \tau}, \quad j=1,2,4 .
$$

The equations now become

$$
\begin{aligned}
m \lambda A_{1}-e b A_{2}-\frac{e}{c} a A_{4} &=0, \\
e b A_{1}+m \lambda A_{2} &=0, \\
-\frac{e}{c} a A_{1}+m \lambda A_{4} &=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

For a solution where not all $A^{\prime}$ s vanish, we require

$$
\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
m \lambda & -e b & -\frac{e a}{c} \\
e b & m \lambda & 0 \\
-\frac{e a}{c} & 0 & m \lambda
\end{array}\right|=0,
$$

i.e.

$$
m \lambda\left(m^{2} \lambda^{2}+e^{2} b^{2}-\frac{e^{2} a^{2}}{c^{2}}\right)=0
$$

The roots are

$$
\lambda_{1}=0, \quad \lambda_{2}=\frac{e}{m c} \sqrt{a^{2}-c^{2} b^{2}}, \quad \lambda_{3}=-\frac{e}{m c} \sqrt{a^{2}-c^{2} b^{2}} .
$$

The general solution for the equation of motion is a superposition of exponentials with these exponents. For all components of the 4-velocity to be bounded along every trajectory we require that the $\lambda$ 's are either zero or imaginary, i.e.

$$
a \leq c b, \quad \text { or } \quad|\mathbf{E}| \leq c|\mathbf{B}| .
$$

3047.b.Problem Statement:
It is well known that planets move in elliptical orbits around the sun and the derivation of the orbit equation is a standard exercise in classical mechanics. However, if the effects of special relativity only are taken into account, the orbit is a precessing ellipse of the form

$$
\frac{1}{r}=\frac{1}{r_{0}}\left\{1+\epsilon \cos \left[\alpha\left(\theta-\theta_{0}\right)\right]\right\},
$$

where $\alpha=1$ corresponds to the classical result of zero precession.

Given that the mean radius of the orbit of Mercury is $58 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{~km}$ and that its orbital period is 88 days, calculate the precession of Mercury's orbit in seconds of arc per century.
(This effect does not, of course, account for the total precession rate of Mercury.)

(Chicago
3047.b.Solution:
Consider a planet of mass $m$ and velocity $\mathbf{v}$. As it moves in an elliptical orbit, i.e. in a plane, use polar coordinates $(r, \theta)$ with the sun at the origin. The Lagrangian of the system is

$$
L=-\frac{m c^{2}}{\gamma}+\frac{G m M}{r},
$$

where $\gamma=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\beta^{2}}}$ with

$$
\beta^{2}=\frac{v^{2}}{c^{2}}=\frac{\dot{r}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}}{c^{2}},
$$

$M$ being the mass of the sun. As

$$
\frac{\partial}{\partial \dot{r}}\left(\frac{1}{\gamma}\right)=\frac{-\gamma \dot{r}}{c^{2}}, \quad \frac{\partial}{\partial \dot{\theta}}\left(\frac{1}{\gamma}\right)=\frac{-\gamma r^{2} \dot{\theta}}{c^{2}}, \quad \frac{\partial}{\partial r}\left(\frac{1}{\gamma}\right)=\frac{-\gamma r \dot{\theta}^{2}}{c^{2}},
$$

Lagrange's equations

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}\right)-\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}}=0
$$

give

$$
\begin{gathered}
\frac{d}{d t}(m \gamma \dot{r})-m \gamma r \dot{\theta}^{2}+\frac{G m M}{r^{2}}=0, \\
m \gamma r^{2} \dot{\theta}=b, \text { a constant } .
\end{gathered}
$$

Letting $u=\frac{1}{r}$, the last two equations combine to give

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{b}{\dot{\theta}} \frac{d u}{d t}\right)+b u \dot{\theta}-G m M u^{2}=0,
$$

or

$$
\frac{d^{2} u}{d \theta^{2}}+u=\frac{G m M u^{2}}{b \dot{\theta}},
$$

as

$$
\frac{d u}{d t}=\dot{\theta} \frac{d u}{d \theta} .
$$

The total energy of the planet is

$$
E=m \gamma c^{2}-\frac{G m M}{r} .
$$

Thus

$$
\frac{G m M u^{2}}{b \dot{\theta}}=\frac{G m M}{b^{2} c^{2}}(E+G m M \mu)
$$

and Eq.
(1) becomes

$$
\frac{d^{2} u}{d \theta^{2}}+\alpha^{2} u=\frac{G m M E}{b^{2} c^{2}},
$$

where

$$
\alpha^{2}=1-\left(\frac{G m M}{b c}\right)^{2} .
$$

A special solution of Eq.
(2) is

$$
u=\frac{G m M E}{b^{2} c^{2} \alpha^{2}},
$$

and its general solution is thus

$$
u=A \cos \left[\alpha\left(\theta-\theta_{0}\right)\right]+\frac{G m M E}{b^{2} c^{2} \alpha^{2}},
$$

where $A$ and $\theta_{0}$ are constants. The orbit is therefore given by

$$
\frac{1}{r}=\frac{1}{r_{0}}\left\{1+\epsilon \cos \left[\alpha\left(\theta-\theta_{0}\right)\right]\right\}
$$

with

$$
r_{0}=\frac{b^{2} c^{2} \alpha^{2}}{G m M E}=\frac{(b c)^{2}-(G m M)^{2}}{G m M E}, \quad \epsilon=A r_{0}, \quad \alpha=\sqrt{1-\left(\frac{G m M}{b c}\right)^{2}},
$$

$A, \theta_{0}$ being constants, and $b, E$ being the angular momentum about the sun and the total energy of the planet respectively.

Suppose $r$ is minimum at $\theta_{1}$ and it next returns to this minimum at $\theta_{2}$. Then $\alpha\left(\theta_{2}-\theta_{1}\right)=2 \pi$. Hence the perihelion advances an angle

$$
\Delta \theta=\frac{2 \pi}{\alpha}-2 \pi=2 \pi\left(\frac{1}{\alpha}-1\right)
$$

in one period of revolution. Note that there is no precession if $\alpha=1$. Since the amount of precession is small compared with $2 \pi, \alpha$ is close to unity and can be expressed as

$$
\alpha \approx 1-\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{G m M}{b c}\right)^{2}
$$

and we have

$$
\Delta \theta \approx \pi\left(\frac{G m M}{b c}\right)^{2}
$$

per period of revolution. From a consideration of the gravitational attraction we have

$$
\frac{G m M}{\bar{r}^{2}}=m \gamma \bar{r} \dot{\theta}^{2},
$$

where $\bar{r}$ is the mean radius of the orbit of Mercury. As

$$
\begin{gathered}
b=m \gamma \bar{r}^{2} \dot{\theta}, \\
\frac{G m M}{b c}=\frac{\vec{r} \dot{\theta}}{c}=\frac{2 \pi \bar{r}}{\tau c},
\end{gathered}
$$

where $\tau=88$ days is the period of one revolution. In a century there are

$$
\frac{100 \times 365}{88}=414.8
$$

revolutions, so that the total precession per century is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Theta &=414.8 \times 4 \pi^{3} \times\left(\frac{58 \times 10^{6}}{88 \times 24 \times 3600 \times 3 \times 10^{5}}\right)^{2} \\
&=3.326 \times 10^{-5} \mathrm{rad} \\
&=6.86 \text { seconds of arc. }
\end{aligned}
$$

This is about $\frac{1}{6}$ of the observed value, which can only be accounted for if general relativity is used for the calculation.

3049.Problem Statement: What is the velocity of a particle if its kinetic energy equals its rest energy?
3049.Solution:
The kinetic energy of a particle of rest mass $m_{0}$ is

$$
T=E-m_{0} c^{2}=m_{0} c^{2}(\gamma-1)
$$

where $\gamma=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\frac{v^{2}}{c^{2}}}}$. As this equals $m_{0} c^{2}, \gamma=2$. Hence

$$
\frac{v}{c}=\sqrt{1-\frac{1}{\gamma^{2}}}=\sqrt{\frac{3}{4}},
$$

or

$$
v=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} c .
$$

3050.a.Problem Statement:
A beam of electrons is scattered by a fixed scattering target as shown in Fig. 3.27. The electrons are elastically scattered. Each electron has an energy $E=\frac{5}{3} m_{0} c^{2}$ and the beam has a flux of $Q$ electrons per second.

What is the velocity of the incident electrons?

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2022_10_30_c9a328acda25199719adg-755.jpg?height=323&width=271&top_left_y=1511&top_left_x=577)

Fig. 3.27
3050.a.Solution: As $E=m_{0} \gamma c^{2}=\frac{5}{3} m_{0} c^{2}, \gamma=\frac{5}{3}$ and $\frac{v}{c}=\sqrt{1-\frac{1}{\gamma^{2}}}=\frac{4}{5}$. Hence the electron velocity is $0.8 c$.

3051.Problem Statement: The principle of equivalence asserts that gravitational and inertial masses are equal. Does a photon have nonzero gravitational mass? Explain. Suppose a photon is falling toward the earth and it falls a distance of $10 \mathrm{~m}$. Calculate the effect on the frequency of the photon. What experimental technique could be used to measure this frequency change?
3051.Solution:
The gravitational mass of a photon is not zero but is equal to the inertial mass

$$
m=\frac{E}{c^{2}}=\frac{h \nu}{c^{2}},
$$

in accordance with the principle of equivalence, even though its rest mass is zero. When the photon falls a distance $l$ in a gravitational field g, its energy increases and so does its frequency: 

$$
h \nu^{\prime} \approx h \nu+m g l=h \nu\left(1+\frac{g l}{c^{2}}\right) .
$$

Writing $\nu^{\prime}=\nu+\Delta \nu$, we have

$$
\frac{\Delta \nu}{\nu} \approx \frac{g l}{c^{2}}=\frac{9.8 \times 10}{\left(3 \times 10^{8}\right)^{2}}=1.1 \times 10^{-15} .
$$

Thus falling through a distance of $10 \mathrm{~m}$ in the gravitational field of the earth, the frequency of a photon will increase (blue shift) by a factor $1+1.1 \times 10^{-15}$. The slight increase in frequency can be detected experimentally using the Mössbauer effect.

3052.a.Problem Statement:
Consider a very high energy scattering experiment involving two particles with the same rest mass $m_{0}$, one initially at rest and the other incident with momentum $p$ and total energy $E$.

Find the velocity of the center of mass $\beta^{*}=\frac{v^{*}}{c}$.
3052.a.Solution:
The system of two particles has total energy $E+m_{0} c^{2}$ and total momentum $p$ in the laboratory system. The velocity of the center of mass, which is the velocity of the system as a whole, in units of $c$, is then

$$
\beta^{*}=\frac{p c}{E+m_{0} c^{2}} .
$$

3052.b.Problem Statement:
Consider a very high energy scattering experiment involving two particles with the same rest mass $m_{0}$, one initially at rest and the other incident with momentum $p$ and total energy $E$.

In the extreme relativistic limit $p c \gg m_{0} c^{2}$, find the total energy $E^{*}$ of the system in the center of mass frame (i.e. the frame in which the total 3-momentum is zero).
3052.b.Solution:
The system of two particles has total energy $E+m_{0} c^{2}$ and total momentum $p$ in the laboratory system. The velocity of the center of mass, which is the velocity of the system as a whole, in units of $c$, is then

$$
\beta^{*}=\frac{p c}{E+m_{0} c^{2}} .
$$The quantities $E^{2}-p^{2} c^{2}$ of a system is invariant under Lorentz transformation. In the laboratory frame it is

$$
\left(E+m_{0} c^{2}\right)^{2}-p^{2} c^{2}=2 E m_{0} c^{2}+2 m_{0}^{2} c^{4}
$$

as $E^{2}-p^{2} c^{2}=m_{0}^{2} c^{4}$. In the center of mass frame it is $(2 \bar{E})^{2}$, where $\bar{E}$ is the total energy of each particle. Hence 

$$
\begin{aligned}
E^{*} &=2 \bar{E}=\sqrt{2 E m_{0} c^{2}+2 m_{0}^{2} c^{4}} \\
& \approx \sqrt{2 E m_{0} c^{2}} \approx \sqrt{2 p m_{0} c^{3}}
\end{aligned}
$$

in the extreme relativistic limit for which $p c \gg m_{0} c^{2}$, since in this case

$$
E=\sqrt{p^{2} c^{2}+m_{0}^{2} c^{4}} \approx p c \gg m_{0} c^{2} .
$$

3053.Problem Statement: A particle of rest mass $m$ and initial velocity $v_{0}$ along the $x$-axis is subject after $t=0$ to a constant force $F$ acting in the $y$-direction. Find its velocity at any time $t$, and show that $|\mathbf{v}| \rightarrow c$ as $t \rightarrow \infty$.
3053.Solution:
The equation of motion

$$
\mathbf{F}=\frac{d}{d t}(m \gamma \mathbf{v})
$$

where $\gamma=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\frac{v^{2}}{c^{2}}}}$, can be written as

$$
0=\frac{d}{d t}(m \gamma \dot{x}), \quad F=\frac{d}{d t}(m \gamma \dot{y})
$$

with $\mathbf{v}=(\dot{x}, \dot{y}), \mathbf{F}=(0, F)$. As $F$ is constant for $t>0$ and initially $\dot{x}=v_{0}$, $\dot{y}=0, F=0$, the above integrate to give

$$
m \gamma \dot{x}=m \gamma_{0} v_{0}, \quad m \gamma \dot{y}=F t,
$$

where $\gamma_{0}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\frac{v^{2}}{c^{2}}}}$. Hence

$$
\beta^{2} c^{2}=\dot{x}^{2}+\dot{y}^{2}=\frac{1}{m^{2} \gamma^{2}}\left(m^{2} \gamma_{0}^{2} v_{0}^{2}+F^{2} t^{2}\right),
$$

or

$$
\gamma^{2} \beta^{2}=\frac{\beta^{2}}{1-\beta^{2}}=\frac{m^{2} \gamma_{0}^{2} v_{0}^{2}+F^{2} t^{2}}{m^{2} c^{2}}
$$

giving

$$
\beta^{2}=\frac{m^{2} \gamma_{0}^{2} v_{0}^{2}+F^{2} t^{2}}{m^{2} \gamma_{0}^{2} v_{0}^{2}+m^{2} c^{2}+F^{2} t^{2}} .
$$

As $\gamma_{0}^{2} \frac{v_{0}^{2}}{c^{2}}=\gamma_{0}^{2}-1$, we have

$$
v=\beta \mathrm{c}=\sqrt{\frac{m^{2} \gamma_{0}^{2} v_{0}^{2}+F^{2} t^{2}}{m^{2} \gamma_{0}^{2} c^{2}+F^{2} t^{2}}} \mathbf{c} .
$$

The velocity components are

$$
\dot{x}=\frac{\gamma_{0} v_{0}}{\gamma}, \quad \dot{y}=\frac{F t}{m \gamma},
$$

where

$$
\gamma=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\beta^{2}}}=\sqrt{\frac{m^{2} \gamma_{0}^{2} c^{2}+F^{2} t^{2}}{m^{2} c^{2}}} .
$$

For $t \rightarrow \infty$, as $m \gamma_{0} v_{0}, m \gamma_{0}$ c remain constant we have

$$
v \rightarrow\left(\frac{F t}{F t}\right) \mathrm{c}=\mathrm{c} .
$$

3054.a.Problem Statement:
An electron of energy $E \gg m c^{2}$ and a photon of energy $W$ collide.

What is $W^{\prime}$, the energy of the photon in the electron (e) frame of reference?
3054.a.Solution:
Suppose the photon makes angles $\theta, \theta^{\prime}$ with the initial direction of motion of the electron, which is taken to be the direction of the $x$-axis, in the $L$ - and $e$-frames respectively. As $(\mathbf{p c}, E)$ forms a 4-vector, the photon energy transforms according to 

$$
W^{\prime}=\gamma\left(W-\frac{\beta W}{\mathrm{c}} \cdot c \cos \theta\right)=\gamma(1-\beta \cos \theta) W,
$$

where $\gamma=\frac{E}{m c^{2}}, \beta=\frac{p c}{E}$ with $p=\frac{1}{c} \sqrt{E^{2}-m^{2} c^{4}}$ being the momentum of the electron in the $L$-frame. As $E \gg m c^{2}$,

$$
p c \approx E\left(1-\frac{m^{2} c^{4}}{2 E^{2}}\right) .
$$

Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
W^{\prime} & \approx \frac{E}{m \mathrm{c}^{2}}\left[1-\left(1-\frac{m^{2} c^{4}}{2 E^{2}}\right) \cos \theta\right] W \\
&=\left[\frac{E}{m c^{2}}(1-\cos \theta)+\frac{m c^{2}}{2 E} \cos \theta\right] W .
\end{aligned}
$$
